headline: More Offices, More Searches and More Pieces of the Puzzle
abstract: Overview of Oct 26 events in war to combat terrorism (M)

headline: Léopold Senghor Dies at 95; Senegal's Poet of Négritude
abstract: Leopold Sedar Senghor, poet, professor, philosopher and statesman who became Senegal's first president, dies at age 95; photo (M)

headline: Corner Office to Kitchen Table; Households Pull Double Duty: Are a Few More Outlets Too Much to Ask?
abstract: Roundup of household gadgets, mostly eletronic, that would make good holiday gifts; photos (M)

headline: In an uneasy climate, the group approach is so popular, even rivals unite in campaigns.
abstract: 'United we stand' is serving as strategy for advertisers to attract attention of consumers in aftermath of terrorist attacks; growing number of television commercials, print advertisements, posters and other pitches are begin presented under sponsorship of trade groups, industry associations and umbrella organizations; commercial with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov George E Pataki urges travelers to 'come see New York united in its finest hour'; photo (M)

headline: The Health Care Spark
abstract: John Glasel letter comments on Nov 11 article on health-care industry

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: More Political Violence
abstract: Zimbabwe authorities accuse political opposition in killing of supporter of Pres Robert Mugabe (S)

headline: The Awkward Middle Child Of Computers Resurfaces
abstract: NEC offers subnotebook computer that functions like laptop but syncs with desktop; photo (S)

headline: Accident Suspected in Black Sea Crash
abstract: Pentagon strongly believes that long-range antiaircraft missile fired during Ukrainian training exercise struck Siberian Airlines jet before it exploded and crashed into Black Sea; salvage vessels ferry wreckage to Russian port of Sochi; photos; map; US experts say intercepted telemetry data shows single missile 'wildly off course' before explosion, almost certainly SA-5 that can hit targets up to 155 miles away; Ukrainian officials back away from denials, while Russians demand US back up assertion; videotape of crash site taken by rescue worker appears to show metallic tip of long cylinder floating amid debris; regular weekly charter flight from Tel Aviv had been subjected to standard rigorous security checks (M)

headline: In a Desolate House, Vestiges of a Violent 1999 Hijacking
abstract: Americans find trove of evidence in abandoned house in Kabul, Afghanistan, including vestiges of 1999 Indian Airlines hijacking, recruiting literature and terrorist training manuals, all belonging to Harkat ul-Mujahedeen, Kashmiri Islamic extremist group that has been on State Department list of terrorist organizations since 1997; group was accused in hijacking but denied involvement; other documents linking group to Al Qaeda are retrieved; photo of airplane tickets from hijacked flight (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Coke Subsidiary To Diversify
abstract: Indian subsidiary of Coca-Cola Company is planning expansion into country's ready-to-drink coffee and tea market (S)

headline: Gillette, Defying Economy, Introduces a $9 Razor Set
abstract: Gillette, world's leading maker of razors, unveils new Mach3 Turbo blades and razors; successor to best-selling and most expensive Mach3 will be 17 percent more expensive, at cost of $9 for razor and two blades; photo (M)

headline: German Utilities Scramble, but Regret Enron's Exit
abstract: Collapse of Enron has immediate effect on small German gas utility called Stadtwerke Peine: about one-third of its natural gas deliveries stop flowing at 5 pm; fortunately for Peine, which started buying gas from Enron only year ago, it is able to negotiate new deal with another supplier about 15 minutes before old contract expires (M)

headline: Ulster's Protestant Leader In Party Showdown Today
abstract: Showdown meeting of Ulster Unionists on December 1 underscores persistence of dangerous divisions in province's Protestant majority at time when end of stalemate over disarmament of militias seemed to have cleared way for progress toward peace; party members have been summoned to Belfast by hard-liners opposed to leadership of David Trimble; purpose is to restrict his ability to keep party engaged in government with Catholic rivals Sinn Fein of Irish Republican Army, while IRA guerrillas keep any arms (M)

headline: Salfit Journal; In the West Bank, Even Olive Trees Cause Quarrels
abstract: Olive trees, symbol of peace worldwide celebrated in Koran and Bible, are also sources of conflict in Salfit on West Bank, where they are emblems of nationalism for Palestinians but menace for some Israelis; settlers who built communities on West Bank see groves both as sources of danger, but also as areas for potential expansion; for some, destroying trees can be means of striking at Palestinians; Palestinians see settlements standing where their fathers' trees once did; map; photo (M)

headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
abstract: James Grant, 55  Founder and editor, Grant's Interest Rate Observer    BOOK -- "Religion and Public Doctrine in Modern England, Volume 3" by Maurice Cowling (2001)  WHY -- "The book traces the sources of the epochal change by which England has chosen virtually to put aside Christianity. And it is, in fact, a page turner."

headline: South African Court Orders Medicine for H.I.V.-Infected Mothers
abstract: southo

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Punishment From God?
abstract: Sheik Omar bin Mohammed al-Sabeel, preacher at Grand Mosque in Mecca, attributes recent aridness and drought in Saudi Arabia to Saudis' 'excessive sins, taboos and crimes'; suggests worshipers repent as they begin fasting for holy month of Ramadan (S)

headline: U.S. Lawyers Ready to Help Son of Sheik Linked to Plot
abstract: Lawyers who represented Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, blind Egyptian cleric convicted in 1995 terrorist plot to blow up New York City landmarks, say they are ready to represent his son Ahmed, who is believed to have been captured by Northern Alliance forces in Afghanistan; team includes Ramsey Clark, Lynne F Stewart and Abdeen M Jabara (M)

headline: In Pakistan, A Shaky Ally
abstract: News analysis of Pakistan's new role as strange and shaky US ally in war against terrorism; nation is rediscovered crony from America's cold war days that has been forced back into friendship at 'gunpoint' to fight terrorism; Bush administration is siding with military government that has itself armed Islamic militants and sent them to fight Indian authorities in disputed territory of Kashmir; map; photo (M)

headline: Ads Down, Yahoo Expects a Hard Quarter
abstract: Yahoo says it barely met its forecasts for revenue and profit in third quarter and sharply cuts its sales forecast for fourth quarter; company lost $24.1 million, in contrast with profit of $47.7 million year earlier; sales fell to $166.1 million, from $295.6 million year ago; photo (M)

headline: Past Economic Cures Are Now Fuel for a Crisis
abstract: News analysis of Argentina's crisis and resignation of Domingo F Cavallo, who came into office nine months ago to try to rescue reeling economy; photo; Pres Fernando de la Rua leaves office hours later; heavily indebted country is now utterly without coherent economic and monetary strategy, and no political consensus exists as to what should be done or who should lead (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Electronics Losses
abstract: Hitachi reports loss of 110.5 billion yen ($906 million) for half year ended Sept 30; Matsushita Electric Industrial, another Japanese electronics manufacturer, reports loss of 69.5 billion yen ($570 million) for same period (S)

headline: Manager's Exit Is Another Blow to ABB
abstract: Swiss-Swedish industrial group ABB Ltd loses second top manager in three weeks and third in year with resignation of chief financial officer Renato Fassbind, who will become chief executive of Diethelm Keller Holding, Swiss international trading house; names Peter Voser successor; photo (M)

headline: Key Tronic Verdict May Put It in Default
abstract: key tronic verdict may put it in def

headline: Russia's New Rich Invest in Domestic Stocks
abstract: HISTORIANS of the New Russia may one day find it odd that the emerging class of young Russian professionals left its mark on Moscow's discos, shopping centers and luxury car dealerships long before it did on the country's stock exchanges.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche Net Income Rises
abstract: Porsche A.G. said that its net income rose 29 percent in the fiscal year ended July 31 as sales of its 911 Turbo and Boxster sports cars increased. Net income rose to 270.5 million euros ($239 million) in the year from 210 million euros a year earlier. Sales rose 22 percent to 4.44 billion euros ($3.92 billion). Porsche is increasing profit and sales, as are its competitors, Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. and DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s Mercedes-Benz unit, even amid economic slowdowns in their biggest markets, the United States and Germany. The company's pretax profit margin was 12 percent in fiscal 2001, about the same as the year earlier. Porsche said it would pay a dividend of 2.54 euros a common share and 2.6 euros for each preferred share. Its shares closed up 0.8 percent at 393.30 euros.

headline: An agency giant is expected to warn of lower profits, and analysts darken their outlook.
abstract: Havas Advertising is expected to warn investors that profits will not meet expectations; two industry analysts, Laura Rich Fine and Michael J Russell Jr, make further reductions in their estimates of ad spending this year and next; CMR says national broadcast and cable television networks and local TV stations lost $313.2 million in revenue from Sept 11 through Sept 15; graph (M)

headline: Jury Deadlocks in Back Royalties Trial Against Genentech
abstract: The jury in a trial in which a leading cancer center is seeking more than $400 million from Genentech is deadlocked, according to a lawyer for the medical center.    The state court jury sent a note to the judge this afternoon saying it was split evenly, 6 to 6, and asking for advice, said Glenn L. Krinsky, general counsel of the City of Hope National Medical Center, which is suing Genentech. Judge Edward Y. Kakita said he would give the jury advice on Tuesday, Mr. Krinsky said.

headline: Joe Modise, 72, Fighter Against Apartheid
abstract: Joe Modise, a guerrilla fighter who led the armed struggle against apartheid and became South Africa's first black defense minister, died in his home near Pretoria on Monday night, government officials said Tuesday.     He was 72 and had cancer, said Snuki Zikalala, a family spokesman.

headline: Carmichael Lynch Ends Work for Ikea
abstract: Advertising: Carmichael Lynch En

headline: Sentiment on Japan's Economy Worsens
abstract: Bank of Japan's Tankan report shows Japanese business leaders are rapidly losing confidence in country's weakening economy, and they see no end to current recession in first quarter of 2002; report gives few hints that companies expect rebound soon; US dollar drops to 125.82 yen in Tokyo after report is released, down from 126.01 in New York trading; companies surveyed by bank say they expect to spend 7.8 percent less on factories, equipment and capital goods in remainder of fiscal year, which ends March 31, and they expect sales to slip 3 percent and profits 18.7 percent from year ago; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Cease-Fire, On Both Sides
abstract: Sri Lanka's new government, elected on pledge to revive stalled peace effort with ethnic Tamil rebels, matches monthlong cease-fire declared by rebels to begin Dec 24 (S)

headline: Global Slump Is Blurring Line At Bank Units for Junk Bonds
abstract: J P Morgan Chase to combine certain parts of its European corporate bond operations to better cope with increasing number of companies whose investment-grade debts have been reduced to junk status (M)

headline: Veterans of Soviets' Old War Warn of Betrayal and Brutality
abstract: One by one the men pulled out black-and-white photographs with edges worn soft from repeated handling.     One showed noncommissioned officers hugging after finishing training. Another was of a young man having a medal pinned on him. A third showed muscular troops, topless and lounging on grass during a lull in the fighting, looking as much like a high-school sports team as an infantry squad.

headline: U.S. Aiming to Cut Supplies to Lift the Taliban's Grip
abstract: Amid a third day of airstrikes against Taliban soldiers on the front line, Pentagon officials said for the first time that their goal was to choke off fuel, food and other supplies to the group.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Shipbuilding Merger
abstract: Japan's Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries and Sumitomo Heavy Industries say they will combine their tanker and warship divisions into 50-50 joint venture, to be called Marine United (S)

headline: Cable and Wireless in Deal to Acquire Exodus for $850 Million
abstract: Cable and Wireless said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire the assets of Exodus Communications, the leading U.S. web hosting group which in September filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DUN & BRADSTREET CORP.,  Murray Hill, N.J., a provider of business information, agreed to buy Harris InfoSource International Inc., Twinsburg, Ohio, a privately held database company. Terms were not disclosed.    BEST BUY CO.,  Eden Prairie, Minn., the United States' largest electronics retailer, agreed with GTC Telecom Corp., Costa Mesa, Calif., a long distance carrier, to market GTC's 5-cent-a-minute long-distance rate plan in more than 400 retail stores. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Silence, on a Day to Remember the Attacks, Says Much
abstract: Saudi Arabia, home of 15 of 19 terrorist hijackers, makes no public acknowledgement of three-month anniversary of Sept 11 attacks, even as governments around world mark day with public ceremonies; photo of Saudi envoy Prince Bandar bin Sultan (M)

headline: A BLOW TO PEACE
abstract: Israeli Tourism Minister Rehavam Zeevi, leader of far right, is shot and killed in stealthy, audacious attack at hotel in Jerusalem; Israeli government threatens to treat Palestinian Authority as terrorist organization and 'act accordingly' unless it immediately hands over gunmen blamed for assault; killing threatens new efforts for peace in Israel and, with them, Bush administration's hopes of building Arab support for international coalition against terrorism; Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine says 'special squad' hunted down Zeevi in revenge for Israel's killing of group's leader Abu Ali Mustafa on Aug 27; this is first slaying by Palestinians of elected Israeli politician; spokesman for Yasir Arafat expresses regret for slaying of Zeevi but rejects idea of turning over killers to Israel; holds that Palestinian Authority has responsibility for trying anyone arrested in its territory; Zeevi had just announced his resignation as minister of tourism, saying Prime Min Ariel Sharon's stand against Palestinian violence was weakening under American pressure (M)

headline: Nations Back Freer Trade, Hoping to Aid Global Growth
abstract: Trade ministers from more than 140 nations agree on agenda to topple tariffs and liberalize trade on everything from wheat to insurance policies; members of World Trade Orgn seek, in six days of nearly round-the-clock meetings in Doha, Qatar, to balance their national interests against urgent need to shore up world's battered economy; trade is growing at slowest rate since early 1980's and world economy is on brink of recession, putting intense pressure on negotiators to act together to stimulate growth; World Bank estimates that outline agreed on could help add $2.8 trillion to global economic activity by 2015; photos (M)

headline: Bush Calls World Economy Goal of Attacks on U.S.
abstract: Pres Bush, at Shanghai economic summit, says two American soldiers who killed in accident in Pakistan died in just cause, and tells leaders of 21 nations that terrorists who struck World Trade Center were trying to cause collapse of world markets and shatter confidence in world economic system; calls on businesses worldwide to join fight, while acknowledging that new security and border curbs may affect world commerce; photo; Bush will leave Shanghai early, after meeting with Russian Pres Putin; Bush emphasizes fight against terrorists who live on 'hunted margins of mankind'; other leaders focus on Asia's fast-declining economy (M)

headline: As 'Southern Alliance' Gels, Many Wonder if It Can Last
abstract: United States policy makers urge formation of southern alliance of Pashtun tribes in Taliban's political and ethnic stronghold in southern part of Afghanistan; while strategy appears to be taking hold, many Afghans worry that failure to build national government could plunge country back into anarchy of early 1990's when southern Afghanistan fell prey to warlordism among Pashtun tribal leaders; overall situation is described as murky, as there are tribes and subtribes and unknown, perhaps misunderstood, alliances; certainly, developments in south will lack clarity of military outcome in north (M)

headline: The Good, the Bad and the Totally Arbitrary
abstract: Readers share stories of their annual job performance reviews; drawings (M)

headline: From the Counter To the Computer
abstract: My First Job article by Robert Petrocelli, 35, co-founder of Heartlab, privately held company in his native Westerly, Rhode Island, that produces cardiac information management systems; his photos (S)

headline: Arab Soldiers in the Israeli Army Find They Are Always on Guard
abstract: Chaotic nightly clashes between Palestinians and Israelis at Termit army post in Gaza Strip have particular twist, which is that almost all of Israeli soldiers there are from battalion of Bedouins, Muslims who are Israeli citizens, and thus vulnerable to attack from all sides; photos; map; fighting takes place on moonscape of crushed or bullet-ridden homes shot through with Palestinian tunnels and littered with increasingly sophisticated Palestinian bombs; Bedouin soldiers tell of being suspected by Israelis and attacked by Arabs (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Dec 2 article about David and Lucille Packer Foundation, which misstated a board member's name

headline: Fast Ends in Kabul, But a Hunger Grows For a New, Better Life
abstract: Gunfire echoes through Kabul to celebrate end of Ramadan and start of Eid al-Fitr feast, but exuberant fusillades seem also to celebrate Afghans' hopes for peace and change; photos (M)

headline: Microsoft and Samsung Strike a Deal
abstract: Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, made an alliance with Samsung Electronics last week and outlined a sweeping view of the next stage of the digital revolution, one that involves high-speed access and household gadgets.    Noting the speed with which Korea has entered the Internet age, Mr. Gates observed that high-speed broadband connections were now used by 40 percent of Korean homes and offices, a level more than twice that of any other country.

headline: MYRIAD GENETICS TO BE MARKETED BY LABORATORY CORP.
abstract: Laboratory Corp of America will market Myriad Genetics' tests for breast cancer and other diseases including colon cancer, melanoma and hypertension (S)

headline: With Photo Software, Fiddle a Little or a Lot
abstract: Q.  My photo scanner came with a free bare-bones image-editing program, but I'm wondering if I'm missing anything by not having a professional-level program. What features do I gain with more expensive software?    A.  When you buy a scanner, the machine usually comes with a program that allows you to do a variety of simple tasks like cropping photos, removing red-eye, applying standard filters and saving digital images in various file formats.

headline: Pakistan Is 2 Worlds: One Urbane, One Enraged
abstract: Article discusses deep divide in Pakistan between Islamic militants and business and upper classes; Pakistan's upper classes are secure that attack by US on neighboring Afghanistan will not force dissolution of society and institute Taliban-like leadership; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Uzbek Dissident Released
abstract: Leader of Uzbekistan's democratic opposition, Muhammad Salikh, is released from Prague jail where he was being held on warrant from Uzbekistan's authoritarian ruler, Islam Karimov; Czech court will decide whether to extradite him to his homeland to serve 15-year term on terrorism charge; human rights groups say he faces certain death if sent home (S)

headline: China Jails 6 For Spreading Sect's Material
abstract: Six people affiliated with Qinghua University in Beijing are given prison sentences of 3 to 12 years for downloading material from banned Falun Gong spiritual movement from Internet and passing it along (M)

headline: ECOLAB TO BUY REST OF JOINT VENTURE FOR $445 MILLION
abstract: ecolab to buy rest of joint venture fo

headline: Shaping Young Islamic Hearts and Hatreds
abstract: Islamic seminaries in Pakistan that have become incubators for holy warriors fighting in Afghanistan teach student body of some 750,000 to million narrow curriculum of Islamic law and distrust or even hatred of United States; militant Muslims teach in many such seminaries, known as madrassas, that US war on terrorism is aimed at worldwide annihilation of Islam; schools engender devotion from students from poorest classes who have nowhere else to go; photos (M)

headline: Royal Path: Late Births Lose Stigma In Japan
abstract: Stigma once attached to having first child in one's 30's is fading in Japan, and this trend should get fresh impetus now that Crown Princess Masako has given birth to her first child just days before her 38th birthday; however, women who want to marry and have children after building careers for themselves still face myriad social obstacles; legislators have shelved bill that for first time would have allowed married women to keep their family names legally (M)

headline: Interwave May Supply Telstra Equipment
abstract: Interwave Communications is expected to announce signing ive-year contract to supply wireless network equipment to Telstra Corp, Australia's largest mobile communications company; contract is worth as much as $50 million for Interwave (S)

headline: The Signs Of a Buildup Are Becoming More Evident
abstract: Uzbek government official says American troops, supplies and equipment are being assembled at tightly guarded Khanabad air base in Uzbekistan, sign if American military's effort against Taliban; Khanabad air base will be used to stage limited missions into Afghanistan, under agreement reached by Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld and Pres Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan; both governments issue public statement that American forces will use Uzbek bases and airspace only for relief and rescue missions; photo (M)

headline: Know Thy Retailer: Help for Mail Phobia
abstract: Michelle Slatalla On-line Shopper column comments on how recent concerns about anthrax in the mails has created a type of aversion about receiving packages; drawing (M)

headline: A Would-Be Warlord Is Given Short Shrift by New Rulers
abstract: Afghan Northern Alliance soldiers force Sayed Jaffar, would-be governor of Baghlan province, to flee his home and take to mountains with his men; American-educated son of traditional ruling family tried and failed to take city of Pul-i-Khumri by force (M)

headline: Bayer Is a Bit Taken Aback By the Frenzy to Get Its Drug
abstract: Article examines rise of Cipro to status as antibiotic of choice for treating anthrax, surprising even Bayer AG, its manufacturer (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Spy Trial Begins
abstract: Valentin Danilov, Russian physicist, resumes trial on charges of spying for China, where he was under contract to perform research for Chinese company; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy Looks for Change in Sudan
abstract: Nobody ran, as they usually do, when an airplane swept in low over the Nuba Mountains in Sudan the other day. For a change, it was food aid and not government bombs showering down on the people of Nuba, one of the most remote and wretched areas of a vast country at war with itself for 18 years.    In the first sustained aid effort in a decade to reach these mountains, planes allowed in by Sudan's government ferried food to about 150,000 people caught here in determined rebellion against the rulers of the north, and the capital, Khartoum.

headline: Barrick Gold Joins Battle For a Rival
abstract: Barrick Gold of Toronto wades into takeover battle over Normandy Mining of Australia, with plans for closer cooperation with AngloGold of South Africa if AngloGold's bid for Normandy succeeds; AngloGold is vying with Newmont Mining for control of Normandy (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Chinese Bank Stake
abstract: HSBC Holdings says its Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp unit will buy 8 percent of Bank of Shanghai for 517.9 million yuan, or about $63 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: 500 Asylum-Seekers Try to Dash Through Channel Tunnel
abstract: More than 500 asylum seekers break through fences and storm into Channel Tunnel, making mad dash for Britain with French police in hot pursuit; tunnel is closed for 10 hours, and all refugees are captured; Eurotunnel and British officials complain that locating Red Cross camps so close to tunnel entrance encourages such incidents; French say Britain's generous policies toward asylum-seekers encourages illegal migration; map; photos (M)

headline: EBay Continues to Flourish Despite Faltering Economy
abstract: EBay posts sales and profits for third quarter that exceed analysts' expectations; company earned $18.8 million, up 24 percent from year-earlier period; sales were $194.4 million, up 71 percent; president-chief executive Meg Whitman comments; photo (M)

headline: An Unexpected Reversal Of War-Crimes Convictions
abstract: Surprise ruling of UN war crimes tribunal investigating atrocities in Bosnian war, quashing convictions of three Croatian fighters and reducing sentences of two others, could alter views of critics, who have often dismissed tribunal as rubber-stamp court intended to condemn Serbs and Croats and alleviate Western guilt; photo (M)

headline: U.S. and Pakistan Discuss Nuclear Security
abstract: American military and intelligence officials discuss with Pakistani government concerns over security of country's nuclear weapons stockpile and its two nuclear plants; discuss improving security and installing new safeguards amid fears that any attacks against terrorists in Afghanistan could boil over into Pakistan, where Afghan sympathizers in military could seize control of nuclear weapons; Pres Pervez Musharraf says nation's nuclear arsenal is safe and that there is no risk of weapons falling into wrong hands; formal limitations on how much assistance US can provide Pakistan because of latter's refusal to sign nonproliferation treaty discussed; US law imposing restrictions on sharing information about nuclear weapons with other countries noted (M)

headline: Locking Up The Plastic; Many Americans Cut Back On High-Interest Debt
abstract: Americans in recent months have cut back on their use of credit for first time in almost 10 years; new frugality comes after decade in which ever-growing levels of consumer debt helped drive longest economic boom in American history; consumers are becoming more conservative, lowering odds of huge bankruptcy problems if country falls into long recession; continued decline in personal debt could prolong downturn by crimping consumer spending, one of few strengths of American economy over last year; graphs; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: A Citizen Challenges the President
abstract: Private citizen challenges recent decision by France's highest court of appeal that Pres Jacques Chirac cannot be tried on corruption charges before end of his term; citizen seeks to have case put before European Court of Human Rights (S)

headline: Producing a TV Spot Cost 3% Less in 2000
abstract: Average cost of producing 30-second national television advertisement decreases 3 percent from 1999 to 2000, to $332,000 (S)

headline: Report Says Ulster Force Failed to Heed Tip Before Fatal Bombing
abstract: Investigation by Northern Ireland police watchdog reportedly uncovers evidence that police intelligence officers failed to pass along tip eleven days before bombing of Omagh in August 1998; 29 people were killed and more than 200 injured (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EXXON MOBIL CORP., Houston, the oil company, said it had agreed with state officials on a plan to extract about 75,000 barrels of hydrocarbon liquids a day from natural gas reserves in its Point Thomson gas and condensate field on Alaska's North Slope by 2006.    TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRIES, Petach Tikva, Israel, a generic drug manufacturer, said it would not buy the injectable-drug unit of FH Faulding & Co., a division of Mayne Nickless Ltd., Melbourne, Australia, a health care company, because of unspecified problems it had uncovered.

headline: World Bank Says Poor Nations Will Suffer Worst Economic Toll
abstract: World Bank predicts that Sept 11 terrorist attacks will have greatest economic impact on poor nations that do not have safety nets in place to absorb sharp economic downturn; says economic output across developing world could be reduced by slower growth in world trade, slump in tourism, lower commodity prices and falling foreign investment; says this would strain already weak social service and health care systems; estimates that 10 million people will fall below bank's extreme poverty line of $1 a day or less as direct result of slower economic growth (M)

headline: Retail Sales Increase 7.1%, Mostly From Car Incentives
abstract: US retail sales surge 7.1 percent in October after decline of 2.2 percent in September; graph (M)

headline: BAUSCH & LOMB GIVEN APPROVAL ON CONTACT LENS USE
abstract: Food and Drug Administration extends length of time users can wear Bausch & Lomb's PureVision soft contact lenses to as long as 30 days (S)

headline: Guatemalan Family Ties
abstract: Wendy Murdock, chief operating officer in retail and high net worth for Citigroup Asset Management, writes The Boss column, about her and her family's ties to family in Guatemala; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Figures Show Rate of Productivity Gained in Third Quarter
abstract: Labor Department statistics show productivity in third-quarter 2001 rose at fastest pace in more than year as companies relied on fewer workers to produce goods and services; productivity increased at faster-than-expected 2.7 percent annual rate from July through September, compared with 2.2 percent in previous three months; chart (M)

headline: Hewlett Profit, Off 89%, Stirs New Optimism For Merger
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co reports fiscal fourth-quarter earnings dropped 89 percent, to $97 million; revenue fell 18 percent, to $10.9 billion; executives and some analysts point to figures, which exceed Wall Street's lowered expectations, as positive sign for its planned merger with Compaq Computer Co; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Sri Lanka: 25 Rebels Killed In Sea Battle
abstract: Sri Lankan naval patrol engages rebel boats off coast, in area held by Tamil Tigers; map; 25 rebels reported killed (S)

headline: Your Job Is Safe. So Why That Frown?
abstract: David Leonhardt column on how recessions diminish happiness of people who do not lose their jobs and take pay cuts; cites study by three economists, Andrew J Oswald, Rafael Di Tella and Robert J MacCulloch, who focused on 'fear effect,' widespread worries about jobs, salaries, retirement accounts and family members that accompany recession; graph (M)

headline: Big Networks Clear the Decks For Coverage And Comment
abstract: US television networks and all-news cable channels give blanket coverage to release of tape showing Osama bin Laden rejoicing at destruction of World Trade Center (S)

headline: Blair to Meet With Arafat On Tensions In Mideast
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair to meet Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, London, in bid backed by United States to calm Mideast violence and help jump-star stalled peace talks with Israel; sees continuing unrest threatening moderate Arab support for antiterror coalition; Blair's office plans to ask television executives to delay or limit broadcast of statements taped by Osama bin Laden and his allies because they may contain coded messages to operatives outside Afghanistan; Britain is also urging reporters given tours by Taliban to put in context unconfirmed Taliban claims of civilian casualties in Afghanistan (M)

headline: A Phone Answers the Question 'How Are You?' With a Photo
abstract: Nokia's latest cellphone has large color screen and built-in digital camera; photo (S)

headline: Cendant Is Said to Be in Talks For U.S. Operations of Budget
abstract: Cendant Corp is said to be negotiating to acquire US operations of Budget Group, troubled car rental company; Budget is currently disposing of its remaining European businesses; Cendant owns Avis Rent a Car System (M)

headline: Across Afghanistan, Taliban Soldiers Keep Up the Fight
abstract: Large swaths of territory across Afghanistan still seem to be in Taliban's grip, even as US military proclaims Taliban a defeated force and Afghanistan in hands of friends; situation in parts of southern and western Afghanistan described; villages nationwide are seeing Taliban soldiers returning home with guns and grievances intact; in areas dominated by ethnic Pashtuns, who constitute bulk of Taliban, former foot soldiers of Mullah Muhammad Omar roam free; some Taliban commanders, allowed to switch sides and keep guns, are switching back and fresh fighting is result (M)

headline: Shares Close Up After the Fed's Move to Reduce Rates
abstract: Dow Jone industrial average increases 113.76 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 8,950.59; Nasdaq composite index gains 11.87 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,492.33; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 12.78 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,051.33; graph; chart (M)

headline: Dougie Millings, 88, the Tailor for the Beatles
abstract: Dougie Millings, tailor to stars whose crowning achievement was outfitting the Beatles, dies at age 88 (S)

headline: Afghan Rebels Seem a Reluctant Force So Far
abstract: Many Afghan rebel commanders in Northern Alliance say they are not ready to fight soon; note time is running out to launch autumn offensive; complain United States had not delivered pledged military supplies; are squabbling among selves; none of late Ahmad Shah Massoud's surviving lieutenants seems able to unify ethnically diverse collection of feuding warlords; inactivity at alliance's Ay Khanom training center noted; map; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Saudi Sees No bin Laden-Iraq Link
abstract: saudi sees no bin laden-iraq link**Prince Turki bin Faisal, former head of Saudi intelligence, says his government has seen no evidencethat Iraq provided support to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network and that Saudi Arabia would not support making Iraq military target of war on terrorism; says best way to topple Saddam Hussein would be coup from within; warning, in interview, aims to head off what many Arabs suspect might be next phase in US campaign; photo (M)

headline: Blair Tries to Lift Mideast Peace Talks From 'Low Point'
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair meets Prime Min Ariel Sharon in Jerusalem and Yasir Arafat in Gaza; presses both to stop fighting and start negotiating, warning that conflict has global stakes; photos; Arafat distances himself from terrorist leader Osama bin Laden's 'dangerous talk'; Sharon says Israel will withdraw from West Bank when Arafat cracks down on militants; Israeli helicopter attacks car said to carry Hamas suicide bombers; two killed, one captured; Blair, reeling off list of recent suicide attacks, says he understands security pressure on Sharon, but says response must follow international law (M)

headline: Palestinians Say Israeli Forces Killed a Top Leader of Hamas
abstract: Israeli forces tonight killed a top leader of the Palestinian extremist group Hamas who had eluded them for years, Hamas officials said.

headline: Cost Controls Help Raise Nike's Profit
abstract: Cost controls and increased sales of clothing and goods overseas boost Nike Inc's quarterly profit 8.3 percent, to $129.3 million, for period ended Nov 30 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Government Cuts Sales Tax
abstract: South Korean government cuts sales taxes on luxury goods by 2 percent to 10 percent, causing spike in sales of cars and electronics; move is intended to spur consumer spending, and boost economic growth (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Soybean prices fall on report of increasing production in face of expectations of lessened demand; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Homestore Profit To Miss Estimates
abstract: Homestore.com, largest home-sales site on Web, says third-quarter earnings will be lower than it has projected; graph (S)

headline: In Drive to Extradite Pilot, U.S. Tones Down Charges
abstract: United States, at extradition hearing, London, dramatically scales back charges against Algerian pilot Lotfi Raissi, held in connection with Sept 11 attack; abandons effort to link him to attacks as 'lead trainer' of suspected hijacker Hani Hanjour; instead charges he made false statements when he applied for pilot's license; Judge Timothy Workman denies Raissi bail, citing 'tenuous' link to attack; photo (M)

headline: U.S. and Spain Swap Notes
abstract: Spanish Interior Min Mariano Rajoy and Atty Gen John Ashcroft meet in Madrid to discuss cooperation against terrorism; photo (S)

headline: North Korea Calls Japan's Sinking of Mystery Boat 'Brutal Piracy'
abstract: North Korea denounces sinking by Japan of unidentified boat in high seas gun battle as 'brutal piracy' and denies that it was spy ship (M)

headline: EMI Shakes Up Management After Music Business Slides
abstract: In an admission that its attempts to rebuild its presence in the United States had fallen flat, the EMI Group said today that Ken Berry, its high-profile head of recorded music and highest-paid executive, had left the company.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate5.50   5.50   9.50       Discount rate   2.00   2.00   6.00       Federal funds   2.50   2.52   6.49       3-month T-bills   2.14   2.17   6.15       6-month T-bills   2.10   2.13   6.04       10-yr. T-infl.   3.08   3.08   3.82       10-yr. T-note   4.64   4.62   5.62       30-yr.
