headline: Layoffs Are Announced At Several Agencies
abstract: Several agencies laid off employees last week. The New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, dismissed 20 people, or 6 percent of its staff of 330.    Deutsch, part of the Partnership division of Interpublic, eliminated about 25 jobs, affecting about 3 percent of the staff of 900 at the agency's offices in Marina del Rey, Calif., and New York. The step, the first such move by the agency, was described as part of a restructuring that would include hiring additional staff members with other skills.

headline: Economy & Business; Wall St. Isn't Expecting Much Exuberance, Irrational or Otherwise
abstract: Wall Street companies end year with little expectation of exuberance, irrational or otherwise; layoffs and falling profits dominate industry's mindset; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA PHILIPPINES: THE PEOPLE V. MRS. MARCOS Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, was fingerprinted and released on bail after a court ordered her arrest on four counts of corruption involving transactions of more than $350 million in money she is accused of stealing during the 1970's. Mrs. Marcos has for several years been facing corruption charges, and $629 million in Swiss bank deposits have been frozen pending determination of the true owners.    Seth Mydans (NYT).

headline: Despite Sneezes, No Cold Yet in Brazil
abstract: Financial markets in Brazil and neighboring nations take Argentine economic turmoil in stride, suggesting damage may not spread (M)

headline: Most Schools Are Wired
abstract: New statistics indicate that 97 percent of America’s public schools are now connected to the Internet.

headline: Even in a gloomy business outlook, magazine executives see some long-term opportunities.
abstract: Magazine executives at American Magazine Conference say problems confronting industry bring with them opportunities to strengthen operations to prepare for inevitable cyclical upturn; American Association of Advertising Agencies suspends publication of its own magazine, Agency, because of weak economy (M)

headline: 9 Feared Dead as Helicopter Is Downed by Abkhazia Rebels
abstract: Five United Nations observers and four other people apparently died today after rebels shot down their Russian-made helicopter in Abkhazia.

headline: Private Sector; The Morning Run, for a Cause
abstract: Niall FitzGerald, Unilever co-chairman, will run in New York City Marathon and has raised $2 million from corporations that will be donated to children's charities if he finishes; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Flights Cut
abstract: Japan's All Nippon Airways will discontinue nine flights to US as company grapples with 35 percent declin in international traffic after terrorist attacks in US (S)

headline: The French Seem a Bit Friendlier
abstract: Gabrielle Parnes, American who lives in Paris, talks about living abroad in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks on US; photo (S)

headline: Private Sector; Bankruptcy Court Fault Lines Between the Good and the Bad
abstract: Malden Mills chief executive, Aaron M Feuerstein, is hailed for looking after his employees idled by devastating mill fire, while another company in Chapter 11, Polaroid, is reviled for scrapping health benefits for 6,000 retired employees even as it seeks to award executives $19 million in bonuses; photo (M)

headline: In Tougher Times, It's a Life of Affluence Minus Trimmings; Pinched, But Not Really Pinching Pennies
abstract: Residents of affluent communities like Colorado Springs, Colo, are not changing spending behavior overnight in face of signs of possible recession, but they are avoiding capricious spending; stock market drop seems to be key factor in more cautious spending; graph of household net worth, which has taken sharp hit lately; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rival Sues Tivo Over Patent
abstract: Pause Technology files patent infringement lawsuit against Tivo; patent at issue covers technology that enables viewers to pause live TV, fast forward programs and replay parts of programs while they are being recorded; so far, only Motorola has announced it will license Pause patent for its future line of personal video recorders; graph (S)

headline: For Britain, Euro Is Invasion It May Have to Invite
abstract: People in Battle, England, reflect general suspicion of euro among Britons; opinion surveys show consistently that two-thirds of Britons are opposed to adopting new currency, and Prime Min Tony Blair, who sees adoption of eur as key to country's leadership role in Europe, will have difficult time winning them over, even with his status enhanced by his new role on world stage; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Turkey: I.M.F. Pact Paves Way For Loan
abstract: Turkey and International Monetary Fund agree on three-year economic program, clearing way for new aid from lender to close $10 billion financing gap through end of next year (S)

headline: George Scharffenberger, 82, Former Chief of City Investing
abstract: George T Scharffenberger, former chief of City Investing Company, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline: Reporter's Notebook; No Jerry Lewis, but Saudi Telethon Reaches Goal
abstract: Reporter's Notebook on Saudi Arabia, where recent telethon raised more than $36 million for Afghan people; photos; Saudi government picks careful path between supporting US campaign against terrorism and expressing public's unease about civilian suffering; telethon mirrors government's way of throwing money at nasty problems, and leaving unpleasant details under rug; television Islamic-style, Americans at American International School and lack of jobs for young educated Saudis also discussed (M)

headline: Production of Smallpox Vaccine to Begin by December, U.S. Says
abstract: Health and Human Services Sec Tommy G Thompson says he expects production of smallpox vaccine to begin by late November or early December; goverment selects Acambis, small biotechnology company, to make 54 million doses (M)

headline: ENTERCOM TO BUY RADIO STATIONS FROM TRIBUNE CO.
abstract: Entercom Communications Corp will acquire three radio stations in Denver from Tribune Co for $180 million (S)

headline: Selling to the Disabled Can Mean More Than Ads
abstract: Carmen Jones, founder of Solutions Marketing Group, helps companies develop and carry out marketing strategies aimed at people with disabilities; says that in addition to including handicapped people in advertising, companies need to show consumers with disabilities that they are valued consumers, not an inconvenience; Bill and Cheryl Duke of W C Duke Associates train employees in service industries in etiquette of dealing with customers with disabilities; photo (M)

headline: Moody's Cuts Calpine's Credit Rating to Junk
abstract: Moody's Investors Service cuts credit rating of Calpine Corp to junk, causing its shares to fall to two-year low and its bonds to drop to 78 cents on dollar; also cuts ratings of Dynegy Holdings, unit of Dynegy Inc (M)

headline: Disdain for the Chat Room
abstract: Bud Lavery letter deplores instant messaging (Dec 13 article)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fewer Tire Replacements Expected
abstract: Bridgestone Corp says its Firestone subsidiary in US will probably replace fewer than 400,000 tires, about half of those covered under its latest recall, because most of affected tires are already off road; Bridgestone will spend about $30 million to replace tires (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Economy Tumbles
abstract: At least 25,000 jobs were lost in manufacturing sector, Jan-Apr, in sign of Zimbabwe's worsening economic plight; industry confederation warns more firms will likely close because of recently imposed price controls on basic goods (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST.

headline: The Microsoft Conundrum
abstract: Analysis of obstacles that loom on both sides of Microsoft Corp antitrust case despite push to settle case (M)

headline: G.M. Is Said To Be Near Picking Winner For DirecTV
abstract: General Motors Corp hopes to decide Oct 27 whether to sell DirecTV, its communications satellite business, to News Corp or EchoStar Communications Corp; EchoStar appears to have edge in negotiations; News Corp is trying to gain advantage by rallying support in Washington, arguing that EchoStar deal would raise serious antitrust concerns; Sen Ernest F Hollings, chairman of Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, and Repr Billy Tauzin, chairman of House Energy and Commerce Committee, express reservations about of merger that they say could eliminate competition; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Envoy Tries to Pave Holes in Road to Coalition
abstract: Focus on problems confronting Lakhdar Brahimi, UN envoy for Afghanistan, in efforts to patch together Afghan coalition government; says he has received assurances from some rival factions that they will comply with agreement to form new government and will carry out transfer of power on December 22; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   5.50   5.50   9.50        Discount rate   2.00   2.00   6.00        Federal funds   2.50   2.50   6.46        3-month T-bills   2.17   2.18   6.03        6-month T-bills   2.15   2.15   6.00        10-yr. T-infl.   3.16   3.14   3.96        10-yr. T-note   4.60   4.59   5.77        30-yr. T-bond   5.36   5.37   5.82        Telephone bd.   7.50   7.52   8.05        Municipal bds.   5.21   5.21   5.82          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Promised Land No Longer; Dot-Commers Who Once Flocked to San Francisco Are Turning Elsewhere
abstract: Some employees of defunct Internet companies, lured to San Francisco area by dot-com boom, are reluctantly seeking jobs in other fields; others are leaving Northern California altogether; graphs of area's unemployment rate; photos (M)

headline: EQUITY FIRM BUYS CONTROLLING STAKE IN CARVEL
abstract: Roark Capital Group buys majority control of Carvel Corp, ice cream distributor and franchiser, from Investcorp for $30 million (S)

headline: ALCOA PLANS TO LAY OFF 6,500 AND CLOSE PLANTS
abstract: Aluminum maker Alcoa plays to lay off about 6,500 workers at 40 sites in Americas and Europe, or 4.6 percent of its work force, and close plants to reduce costs (S)

headline: Argentine Economy: Postponing the Inevitable
abstract: Analysis of Argentina's economic woes; government's decision over weekend to limit cash withdrawals may have succeeded in preventing run on banks, but it also signals what may be economy's last gasp before default, colapse and adoption of dollar as currency; prospects facing Pres Fernando de la Rua discussed; photo of scene outside Buenos Aires bank (M)

headline: Nissan Workers Reject Bid To Join Union in Tennessee
abstract: Nissan Motor Co workers in Smyrna, Tenn, vote more than 2 to 1 to reject United Automobile Workers; union has never been able to organize in plant operated solely by foreign automaker; victory was much needed for UAW, whose membership has shrunk to less than 700,000 from 1.5 million over last two decades (M)

headline: Business Travel; Private charters, although languishing this year, are expected to fill a future air travel niche.
abstract: Joe Sharkey Business Travel column on prediction of Michael Dyment, Andersen consultant, that 10 years from now business travelers will be flying not on commercial aircraft, but on planes owned in whole or in part by their companies, or on charter flights, including some on fixed schedules (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: President Won't Meet Rebel Leader
abstract: President José Eduardo dos Santos, left, has ruled out direct talks with the rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, saying that previous negotiations with him were fruitless. Mr. Savimbi's rebel group, Unita, has called for peace talks in recent months and has mounted a series of attacks to prove it remains a force to be reckoned with. Angola celebrates 26 years of independence this month but the country has been racked by civil war, with few breaks for peace, since winning its independence from Portugal in 1975.     Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

headline: U.S. Planes From the Enterprise Are Using Their Bombs and Missiles Sparingly
abstract: Senior officers on carrier Enterprise say main reason for limited number of carrier air strikes is that number of identified targets in Afghanistan is also limited; say one attack did succeed in hitting some of few Russian-made fighter jets in Afghan arsenal, but that some F-14 and F-18 warplanes are returning to carrier after nighttime missions with their munitions still attached, indication that they were unable to seek out acceptable site to hit; photo (M)

headline: With Cellphones, Who Knows Where the Time Goes?
abstract: Some cellphones and service providers allow subscribers to keep track of their minutes used; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Steps Up Air Attack, While Defending Results of Campaign
abstract: American warplanes pound Taliban forces along front lines with troop-killing and armor-penetrating cluster bombs, while Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld and Gen Richard B Myers, chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, seek to counter criticism that airstrikes are falling short of America's goal; unmanned Predator reconnaissance drone is used to relay information about new targets to gunships; officials say air campaign has destroyed Taliban's arsenal of aircraft and air defenses and cut off their communications; Rumsfeld voices concern about likelihood of capturing or killing Osama bin Laden and about conflicting information given at press briefings; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Travelers Stay Home
abstract: Number of Japanese who go overseas in September plunges 21.5 percent from month year earlier; Sept 11 attacks in United States led thousands of Japanese to cancel their travel plans (S)

headline: Kashmir's Islamic Guerrillas See Little to Fear From U.S.
abstract: Leaders of Lashkar-e-Taiba, Pakistani group that has been challenging Indian rule in Kashmir and has been linked to Dec 13 attack on Indian Parliament, react with studied indifference when group is added to official US list of terrorist organizations and Pres Bush asks Pakistan's government to disband it and arrest its leaders; indifference reflects idea common among Islamic militants that God's will, and certainly not American power, is ultimate driving force of mankind's affairs; also echoes something of turbulent history of region and fatalism it has engendered in succeeding generations; map; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Waives Wireless Charges
abstract: AT&T Wireless tells customers it will waive airtime charges for wireless calls placed and received on day of terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon (S)

headline: Nokia Offers Note of Optimism on Earnings
abstract: Nokia revises upward its fourth-quarter earnings forecast, saying it now expects earnings at top of, or even above, its earlier estimated range of 18 to 20 euro cents a share (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Credit Rating Cut
abstract: Argentina's credit rating is cut by Moody's Investors Service for fourth time this year, taking it below that of any other country (S)

headline: Venezuelan Justices Approve the Extradition of a Colombian Rebel
abstract: Venezuela's Supreme Court approve extradition of Jose Maria Ballestas, Colombia rebel, to his homeland to face charges that he hijacked airliner in April 1999; case has been particular sore point between two countries (M)

headline: Militias From South Closing In On Taliban's Last Major Bastion
abstract: United States military officials say opposition forces in southern Afghanistan are on verge of laying siege to Kandahar, last major bastion of Taliban military power; American warplanes continue to bomb Taliban positions in and around Kandahar as opposition militias cut off main roads into city; Pakistani officials are negotiating with anti-Taliban leaders from tribes along Pakistan-Afghanistan border in halting effort to draw them into makeshift 'Southern Alliance' that would duplicate coordination among anti-Taliban forces in north; American officials say rebel commanders in south are aggressively negotiating with Taliban factions inside Kandahar, through intermediaries and over satellite phones, urging them to lay down their arms; say some Taliban troops have defected, but many others, including some Al Qaeda fighters, are vowing to make last stand in Kandahar; photos; map (M)

headline: Market Place; Dynegy's Rushed Gamble on Enron Carries Some Big Risks
abstract: Dynegy Inc has positioned itself to become most important player in volatile but potentially lucrative business of energy trading by agreeing to buy rival Enron Corp for more than $9 billion in stock; but hastily arranged deal carries big risks for Dynegy, especially since no one outside Enron appears to understand company's tangled finances fully; some analysts wonder why Dynegy decided to take on Enron's huge debt instead of simply trying to hire away Enron's best traders, some of whom were already leaving the company; in addition, Enron said in recent filing with Securities and Exchange Commission that it had used partnerships to overstate its earnings by total of $600 million over last fiver years (M)

headline: U.S. Clears Seagram Unit's Sale If Diageo Gives Up Malibu Rum
abstract: Diageo of Britain and Pernod Ricard of France receive approval from United States antitrust regulators for their joint acquisition of Seagram wine and spirits business; approval is granted on condition that Diageo sell its Malibu rum brand within six months (S)

headline: Sales Climb for Greeting Cards
abstract: Sales of greeting cards climb, as Americans try to express their feelings in wake of Sept 11 terrorism; Hallmark Cards ships six new cards addressing this tragedy (S)

headline: Dynegy to Acquire Fast-Sinking Rival Enron
abstract: With its finances in doubt, the Enron Corporation agreed today to be acquired by a rival, Dynegy Inc., for stock valued at more than $9 billion.

headline: Bluetooth Defies Obituaries
abstract: Manufacturers of cellphones and other electronic equipment continue to design products that use Bluetooth, fledgling technology that promises to simplify communications among cellphones, hand-held computers and other wireless devices by streaming information back and forth over short-range radio; some engineers though technology would die after wireless networking standard known as Wi-Fi arrived in coffee shops and airport lounges; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Rise on Hopes of an Interest-Rate Cut by the Fed
abstract: Stocks rose today in a broad rally led by technology issues, as investors followed a familiar pattern of being optimistic ahead of the Federal Reserve's regular meeting on interest rates.

headline: From Taiwan, a Fear of China Technology
abstract: When Morris Chang declared recently that the future of the world's chip industry lies not in Taiwan or the United States, but in China, political and business leaders sat up and took notice.

headline: Step Right Up! On Show in Iran, Sins of Uncle Sam
abstract: Iran marks 22d anniversary of takeover of US Embassy with special exhibit on grounds of compound, opened to public for first time; features include carnival game involving pounding on devilish face wearing US-flag hat; photos; conservatives use occasion to stoke fresh anti-American sentiment, even as those who once climbed walls mellow and officials take tentative steps toward cooperating with US (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Stocks Surge, Bonds Fall, And Some See A New Bull Run
abstract: Stocks surge on growing optimism that economy, which had been officially declared in recession just over week ago, will quickly rebound; shift to stocks pushes bond prices lower and their yields higher; Nasdaq composite index gains 83.74 points, or 4.27 percent, at 2,046.84; Dow Jones industrial average gains 220.45 points, or 2.23 percent, at 10,114.29; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 25.55 points, or 2.23 percent, at 1,170.35; yield on benchmark 10-year Treasury note rises to 4.89 percent from 4.66 percent, biggest one-day move in five years; 30-year bond rises to 5.35 percent from 5.20 percent; two-year note jumps to 3.07 percent from 2.73 percent; graphs; chart on key US interest rates (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Fewer Foreigners
abstract: Germany reports 7.29 million foreigners lived in country last year, down slightly from year before (S).

headline: Business Travel; Some female flight attendants are complaining of being 'fondled and groped' by security guards.
abstract: Association of Flight Attendants has complained to Transportation Sec Norman Y Mineta about illicit touching of female flight attendants by male airport security guards after Sept 11; union spokeswoman says some flight attendants will not speak out because they do not want to be accused of being against enhanced security (M)

headline: Week's Schedule Of Equity Offerings
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Apex Mortgage Capital, Los Angeles, four million shares. Jolson.

headline: Goldman Gets More Pieces Of Energy Pie
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group seems to be making tidy profit in rocky business of investing in power-generating companies; will get $355 million cancellation payment from Constellation Energy Group, which drops plan to split off its unregulated power-marketing business; windfall follows big gain for Goldman and investment partnerships it manages on sale of its stake in Orion Power Holdings to Reliant Resources (M)

headline: Elmo, Still Ticklish, Is Selling Better, Too
abstract: DIARY Elmo, Still Ticklish, Is Selling Better, Too.

headline: Taliban Will Rise Again, Aide to Leader Promises
abstract: Taliban leadership vows not to give up stronghold in southern Afghanistan or spiritual home of Kandahar, ruling out talks with Northern Alliance or other opposition groups on future national government; spokesman, Mullah Omar's private secretary Tayab Agha, warns of return to anarchy and warlordism; photo at news conference (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Product Selected By Charter
abstract: Technology Briefing: Microsoft Product Sel

headline: E-Commerce Report; Corporations seem poised to spend more in a handful of areas but have also become fixated on prompt payoffs.
abstract: Sept 11 terrorist attacks have spurred senior managers to focus technology spending on Internet security, technology recovery systems and telecommuting gear and shift away from more basic business-to-business e-commerce spending; many companies have dropped plans for new projects (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cantor Adds To Network For Its Data On Prices
abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald, dominant broker in US Treasury market, begins to distribute its price data through several sources, including Bloomberg terminals; for last 20 years data has been disseminateed exclusively through Telerate, which is being sold as part of bankruptcy reorganization (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Says Attacks Seek to Help Rebels Advance
abstract: US warplanes concentrate strikes in Afghanistan on 16th day of bombing on front-line Taliban positions; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says target are being hit to give direct support to anti-Taliban forces in north; says attacks on Taliban forces and Al Qaeda terrorists are intended to clear way for anti-Taliban Northern Alliance to advance; suggests attacks will continue, if necessary, through Ramadan, Muslim holy month of fasting; military officials say operations are being coordinated with rebels; photo (M)

headline: THIRD QUARTER
abstract: Graphs display average returns, by sector type, of mutual funds during third quarter (M)

headline: Nicaragua to Decide Fate of Ortega's New-Age Candidacy
abstract: Daniel Ortega, former Sandinista leader who lost Nicaraugan presidency in 1990 election, is tied in polls with Enrique Bolanos in new bid for presidency; is popular with young people who never knew hardships of life under his administration, whose policies he now repudiates as utopian; has built coalition that includes former political foes, including some jailed by his government; United States has been backing opposition in spirit; former Pres Jimmy Carter, who heads international delegation of electoral observers, scores US effort to influence election; photo (M)

headline: Riyadh Journal; An Ambassador's Journey From Rome to Mecca
abstract: Saudi press is taking delight in announcing that Torquato Cardilli, Italy's ambassador to Saudi Arabia, has converted to Islam; it is first time that any foreign ambassador to kingdom that is home to Islam's two holiest sites had taken such a momentous step; photo; map (M)

headline: Squeezed by a Renovation, the Modern Finds Space Online
abstract: Museum of Modern Art, with more than half of its midtown gallaries closed for renovation, turns to Internet and mounts its first Web-only exhibition, Artists of Brucke; photo (S)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Eric Beckson, executive vice president at Turnstile Publishing Company, Orlando, Fla., was named president and chief executive.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Leftist Wins Race for Governor
abstract: Lazaro Cardenas, candidate of left-wing Democratic Revolutionary Party, is elected governor of Michoacan state, Mexico, defeating Alfredo Anaya of Institutional Revolutionary Party; photo (S)

headline: Talks on Vaccine For Smallpox
abstract: Health Sec Tommy G Thompson says United States is negotiating with seven companies to make smallpox vaccine that could be used in case of terrorist attack, news conference; says he is moving quickly to get vaccine for all Americans; drug industry experts say almost none of new doses will be available until Feb or Mar (M)

headline: Pope Opens Bishop Synod; Role of Each Is the Focus
abstract: Pope John Paul II celebrates Mass in St Peter's Cathedral in Rome, opening meeting of bishops from around world who will spend month discussing their role in church, as well as that of Pope (M)

headline: A War on Two Fronts, and in the Anthrax Laboratories
abstract: Overview and summary of latest developments in war against terrorism

headline: Coca-Cola keeps some brands where they are while PepsiCo battles a former agency in court.
abstract: Coca-Cola Co freezes planned shifts in creative accounts of two of its brands, Powerade sports drinks and Dasani water, because of legal battle between PepsiCo and Foote Cone & Belding, which was to gain the Coca-Cola assignments but had worked on campaigns of competing PepsiCo products; Coca-Cola says Wieden & Kennedy and Berlin Cameron & Partners will continue on these accounts until legal issues are resolved (M)

headline: Searching the Web, Searching the Mind
abstract: Six of top ten queries made through Google's online search engine came from people fixated on Sept 11 terrorist attacks and war on terrorism (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ex-AremisSoft Executives Accused of Fraud by S.E.C.  The Securities and Exchange Commission accused two former executives of AremisSoft, a publicly traded software company, of defrauding investors of at least $200 million.    The S.E.C. said that Roys Poyiadjis and Lycourgos Kyprianou, the former co-chief executives of AremisSoft, used false financial statements to inflate the price of AremisSoft's stock, then sold millions of shares of AremisSoft to unwitting investors. [Page C6.]

headline: Waging a Deadly Stalemate on Afghanistan's Front Line
abstract: If Northern Alliance soldiers in Afghanistan backed by American bombing are to initiate frontal assault against Kabul, they must somehow breach front lines like militarily crucial one in Markaze Ferque Chil; for years seemingly impenetrable maze of mine-fields and fortifications has cemented stalemate preventing either side from advancing; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: False Alarm On Uranium Deal
abstract: Russia's Interior Ministry reports that seven people arrested outside Moscow who were reported to be offering to sell about two pounds of weapons-grade uranium were in fact peddling low-grade uranium pellets that would be useless to terrorists (S)

headline: Mohammed I. Kamel, 74; Quit in Cairo Over Camp David
abstract: Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel, former Egyptian foreign minister, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: Marks & Spencer Says Sales Show First Gain in 3 Years
abstract: British retailer Marks & Spencer reports its first quarterly sales increase in more than three years; sales rose 1.3 percent in period ended Sept 29 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consolidating To Build Ships
abstract: WA

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The dollar proves to be surprisingly resilient in the wake of the attacks.
abstract: US dollar, symbol of America's financial strength, has been surprisingly resilient in wake of terrorist attacks; while dollar has fallen 2.1 percent against euro, it has been rising against Canadian dollar, Mexican peso, Australian dollar and emerging-market currencies, including Brazilian real; graph; chart (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Mainstream Sites Serve as Portals to Hate
abstract: EARLIER this month, in a cramped airport lounge in San Jose, Calif., two seemingly unrelated parties sat down to talk about hate.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom To Repurchase Stake
abstract: Gazprom's board votes to buy back control of Purgas, subsidiary that slipped out of its control in 1999 in transaction that investors call dubious (S)

headline: OBITUARY : Gene Fenn, 90, Photographer
abstract: PARIS—  Gene Fenn, 90, a fashion photographer for Harper's Bazaar and other popular women's magazines, died Nov. 14 in Paris.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: French Cut Wireless License Prices
abstract: Shares of French mobile phone operators surge after government lowers price of acquiring third-generation licenses; instead of block payment of 4.95 billion euros ($4.5 billion) for each license, companies will now pay 619 million euros up front, and then fees based on subscriber rates once services are operational; revised terms apply to two licenses that have yet to be sold, as well as two bought last year by France Telecom and Vivendi Universal (S)

headline: Deutsche Bank Plans to Cut 2,100 Jobs
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG will cut 2,100 jobs at its corporate and investment-banking unit, part of 10 percent reduction in its work force this year (S)

headline: U.S. AND BRITAIN STRIKE AFGHANISTAN, AIMING AT BASES AND TERRORIST CAMPS; BUSH WARNS 'TALIBAN WILL PAY A PRICE'
abstract: US and Britain launch powerful barrage of cruise missiles and long-range bombers against Afghanistan on October 8 in campaign to destroy terrorist training camps of Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network and Taliban government that has protected it; Pres Bush announces start of military campaign in nationwide televised address; says 'carefully targeted' actions are designed to disrupt use of Afghanistan as terrorist base of operations and to attack military capability of bin Laden organization; says Taliban failed to meet demands to surrender bin Laden, stop supporting terrorism and release foreign aid workers they hold; reiterates warning to nations that sponsor or protect terrorists; address is followed by statement of support from British Prime Min Tony Blair; both leaders emphasize that military campaign is not war against Islam; bin Laden issues own threat in videotape broadcast worldwide; stakes claim to lead all Muslims in fight against America, which he casts as murderer, with Israel, of Iraqis and Palestinians; praises hijackers who staged September 11 attacks on US; vows America will not live in peace until peace reigns in Palestine; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says bin Laden is not specific target; says initial bombing is intended to create conditions for sustained anti-terrorist operations against his organization; says US is seeking to orchestrate overthrow of Taliban by providing military aid and developing relationships with groups that oppose regime and terrorists they support; reiterates that US is not at war with Islam, noting armed forces have been sent abroad five times in last decade to defend oppressed Muslim populations; administration officials indicate opening aerial campaign can go on for week and will be followed by ground operations by Special Forces units to garner information and hunt down leaders of Al Qaeda network; initial bombardment described; is carried out by 15 land-based bombers and 25 strike aircraft from aircraft carriers; weapons include precision guided bombs; American warships and British submarines fire 50 Tomahawk cruise missiles; witnesses say skies over capital of Kabul are lit up with flashes; say thunderous explosions are heard throughout night; report attacks around cities of Kandahar and Jalalabad, strongholds of radical Islamic regime; Pentagon sends C-17 cargo planes to drop relief supplies of food and medicine for hundreds of thousands of refugees believed fleeing Afghan cities during bombing campaign; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar drops as investors worry that Federal Reserve's 10 interest-rate cuts this year will not prevent recession; in New York, dollar settles at 120.90 yen, down from 121.06 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Chief of Swiss Electrical Giant Resigns, Citing Declining Profit
abstract: Percy Barnevik, chmn of ABB, Europe's biggest electrical engineering group, unexpectedly steps down, saying he is taking his share of responsibility for sagging profits and stock price at company he was instrumental in shaping; photo (S)

headline: Americans Rescue Soldier Who Fell Ill
abstract: United States personnel late Saturday night rescued an Army Special Operations soldier who had fallen ill while assisting front-line rebel troops.

headline: D. B. Blanchard, 58, Investment Adviser
abstract: David B Blanchard, chairman of Clifford Management Group, dies at 58 (S)

headline: Vehicle Sales Stayed Robust In November
abstract: Automobile sales remain surprisingly strong through November, easing and possibly shortening national economic recession; automakers begin to announce production increases to replenish inventories; interest-free financing offers from major US manufacturers fuel sales increases, but their long-term financial effects on industry remain unclear; photo (M)

headline: 1,400 Layoffs Are Planned At Waterford Wedgwood
abstract: Waterford Wedgwood, Irish luxury goods conglomerate, will cut 1,400 of its 10,000 jobs worldwide in response to slumping sales; says changes will add 43 million euros ($38 million) in company profits for charge of 60 million euros ($54 million); unveils new advertising campaign; more than 1,100 of company's layoffs will be at manufacturing operations in Britain, although 100 workers will lose their jobs at company's flagship crystal plant in Waterford, Ireland; will also close 40 of its British retail outlets, with loss of 400 jobs; chief executive Redmond O'Donoghue moves to group chief executive; Tony O'Reilly Jr is named chief executive of Wedgwood ceramics division (M)

headline: In Japan, Beef Business Sinks in a Sea of Skepticism
abstract: Japanese consumers abandon beef in response to single case of mad cow disease; beef sales have fallen 50 percent; beef barbecue restaurants are changing their menus and cutting prices; consumers lack faith in government in wake of disclosure that it suppressed European Commision warning that Japan was likely candidate for disease; map; photo (M)

headline: Look at bin Laden Is Unlikely to Change the Minds of Arabs Hostile to U.S.
abstract: The videotape of Osama bin Laden that was released today is unlikely to change the minds of those Arabs who already suspect the worst of the United States.    ''This is nonsense, total nonsense,'' declared Mohamed al-Amir, the father of Mohamed Atta, the presumed leader of the Sept. 11 terrorists. ''But this is to be expected from the Americans.''

headline: In Hindsight, C.I.A. Sees Flaws That Hindered Efforts on Terror
abstract: CIA Dir George Tenet moves to address what some say are significant flaws in nation's defenses against terrorism that were exploited by Sept 11 hijackers; strongly worded memo to senior officers demands end to turf battles and coordination of efforts throughout national security apparatus, warning that nation is at war and there is no time for 'meetings' to address problems that must be fixed immediately; memo does not address controversy over requiring high-level approval before recruitment of foreign spies with unsavory backgrounds, guideline that key congressional leaders want to abolish; there is little appetite in Washington for postmortem on failure to detect Sept 11 plot, with all agencies running flat out to investigate attacks, prevent further assaults and take offensive against Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda terrorists; officials looking back say there were series of intercepted communications and 'real heightened danger' toward end of June and July that Al Qaeda was plotting major operation, but no specific targets; analysts postulated attack around Fourth of July, most likely against American interests overseas, not within US, and, when that date passed, they believed attack had somehow been aborted; Sec Colin Powell says there was no 'fidelity' on summer warnings; failure to fully investigate Zaarias Moussaaoui, arrested after strange behavior at Minnesota flight school, also recounted; photos (L)

headline: State of Emergency in Gaza and the West Bank
abstract: The third Palestinian suicide bomber in just over 12 hours struck on a city bus in Haifa on Sunday, killing himself and 15 others.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Ruling Deferred In Overcharge Suit
abstract: Judge J Frederick Motz postpones his ruling on Microsoft's $1 billion plan for equipping needy schools with computers in order to settle claims that it overcharged consumers for its software products (S)

headline: Israeli's Slaying Ignites Clashes And New Fears
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian forces clash in two West Bank cities and their leaders dig in to seemingly irreconcilable positions over killing of Israel's senior right-wing politician, Tourism Min Rehavam Zeevi; top Palestinian official accuses Israelis of plotting to kill Yasir Arafat, while some leading Israeli politicians want Arafat banished from West Bank and Gaza Strip; Israeli government cuts off all contact with Palestinian governing authority; diplomats portray Arafat as furious over Zeevi's killing, which was claimed by Palestinian fringe group; Prime Min Ariel Sharon's ultimatum to Arafat--hand over those responsible or be treated as sponsor of terrorism--and Arafat's refusal put antagonists on course for collision that American and other diplomats want to avert; photo (M)

headline: Fusing Old and New
abstract: Analysis of new management team announced at AOL Time Warner focuses on desire by media companies to go wherever customers are; says what is evolving in media industry is complicated creature that has media companies searching for ways to fuse elements of old offline publishing and entertainment units and new online units into single--and profitable--hybrid; holds success of new team at AOL Time Warner may depend on its crossbreeding skills (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. Project Draws Big Names
abstract: IBM signs up more than 20 companies to help with project to develop computer networks that can largely manage themselves, recognizing faults and repairing them without human handlers (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for LYNN TURNER; Lessons for Auditors In Enron's Collapse
abstract: Lynn Turner, director of Center for Quality Financial Reporting at Colorado State University, answers Five Questions on what auditors and accounting profession should learn from collapse of Enron Corp and Arthur Andersen role in debacle; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Bangladesh: The Voting Begins
abstract: Bangladeshis vote in national parliamentary elects that pits Awami4

headline: Officials Recount Road to Deadlock Over Missile Talks
abstract: Six months of negotiations between United States and Russia over 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty failed because Bush administration is unwilling to discuss each missile test with Moscow in advance, and because Russia refuses any change that would allow unrestricted testing; senior Bush administration officials say critical moment came on Nov 3 in Moscow, when Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld told Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin that US would withdraw from treaty if Russia continued to object to American plans for extensive testing; say any hope of reaching accord was buried during Putin's Nov 13 visit with Pres Bush at White House, because neither president had any new proposals to break impasse and each recognized that there was no way to accommodate Pentagon's aggressive testing progam in treaty clearly designed to prevent just that; photos (M)

headline: Levin to Retire as Chief Executive of AOL Time Warner
abstract: AOL Time Warner said that its chief, Gerald Levin, will retire in May and would be succeeded by Richard Parsons, the company's co-chief operating officer.

headline: U.S. News & World Report Cuts Salaries to Avoid More Layoffs
abstract: US News & World Report editor Brian Duffy sets across-the-board salary cuts of up to 10 percent for most staff members, including self, to avoid further job cuts; says 13 people are being laid off; cites drop in advertising (M)

headline: Celebrities Join Bristol-Myers Campaign
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb has enlisted stars like Sylvester Stallone, Dana Carvey, Kirk Douglas and Angela Bassett to appear in magazine ads to help sell its cholesterol-lowering drug Pravachol; Bristol-Myers's partner in campaign is Entertainment Industry Foundation, charitable arm of movie and television industry; photo (M)

headline: Stock Exchange Fines Firm $1 Million
abstract: American Stock Exchange fines Spear, Leeds & Kellogg division of Goldman Sachs Group $1 million for failing to supervise Pasquale Schettino, executive accused of conducting fraudulent trades for Bullseye Securities, brokerage firm that cleared its trades through Spear; Schettino was fined 100,000 two years ago and was barred from exchange (S)

headline: DataBank; It Was Bears Over Bulls, by a Nose
abstract: Review of week's stock market activity; graphs (S)

headline: Reykjavik Journal; Whaling Ban, Not NATO, Heats Iceland's Temper
abstract: Focus on debate over resumption whaling in Iceland, which resigned from International Whaling Commission in 1991 and forfeited right to catch up to 400 whales annually for 'scientific research;' despite opposition by whale lovers, poll suggests 75 percent of population backs resumption of whaling; maps; photos (M)

headline: Deploying Stealthy B-2's, Military Promises Day-and-Night Bombing Campaign
abstract: US air strikes on Taliban government of Afghanistan begin what officials say will be week-long, round-the-clock bombing campaign, hitting airfields and missile command centers across country, including targets in Kandahar and Kabul, both political and spiritual centers; strikes did not specifically target Osama bin Laden because intelligence services are not certain of his location; photo of Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld with Gen Richard B Myers, Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Hewlett Heir Intensifies Opposition to Compaq Deal  Walter Hewlett, the most outspoken opponent of Hewlett-Packard's acquisition of Compaq Computer, stepped up the pressure with a letter urging the boards of both companies to abandon the proposed merger.    In his letter, Mr. Hewlett, a Hewlett-Packard board member, said that in recent meetings with large shareholders he found ''enormous unhappiness'' about the deal. [Page C4.]    Aetna to Eliminate 6,000 Jobs  Aetna, the troubled health insurance giant, said that it would eliminate 6,000 jobs, or about one-sixth of its work force. [C7.]

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Leaders of the Old Afghanistan Prepare for the New
abstract: Huge assemblage of pre-Taliban Afghan leaders meet, Peshawar, Pakistan, to map strategy for post-Taliban Afghanistan; meeting, hosted by Pir Syed Ahmad Gailani, Sufi religious leader, is rare display of unity among 700 tribal elders, Islamic scholars, fractious politicians and former guerrilla commanders, most of them exiles; speakers urge United States to stop air raids; some laud Osama bin Laden and hold he should remain Afghanistan's guest; photo (M)

headline: A Year Later, Free Serbia Struggles to Overcome Its Past
abstract: Serbs celebrate first anniversary of fall of Slobodan Milosevic; photo; country has rejoined international community, opening borders and drawing large numbers of foreigners, although it is still surviving on foreign aid, unable to pay its debts and attracting little foreign investment (M)

headline: Insurance Prices Soaring, A.I.G. Chief Says
abstract: American International Group chief executive, Maurice R Greenberg, says insurance prices are rising in aftermath of terrorist attacks in US; says prices for some kinds of commercial insurance are doubling, up from expected increases of 20 percent to 60 percent as industry emerges from long period of cutthroat pricing; increases his estimate of losses for AIG in attacks to $800 million, up from $500 million (M)

headline: 9 Killed in Swiss Alps Tunnel
abstract: A head-on collision between two trucks killed up to nine people today in the Gotthard Tunnel, the main north-south road link through the Swiss Alps.

headline: Big Steel: An Invalid That Can Roar In Washington
abstract: Richard W Stevenson analysis special treatment from government sought by big steel companies; companies seek protection from low-priced imports, federal money to help pay health and pension benefits and assurance that mergers of steel companies into giant competitor will not run into antitrust problems, and they want US to pressure other nations to scale back their steel-making capacities; analysts say that companies are overreaching and that even if industry succeeds in getting what it wants, plan would do little more than put off day when it succumbs to subsidized foreign rival and nimble new breed of domestic competitors that oppose concessions sought by Big Steel; Bush administration is opening to some parts of plan, but is wary of embracing others; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: AT&T Ends Excite Bid
abstract: AT&T Corp drops its $307 million offer to purchase ExciteAtHome after company, bankrupt Internet service, disconnects AT&T customers; other buyers are unlikely (S)

headline: San Francisco Relishes Freedom to be Fanciful
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO—  This city is so far off the fashion map, says Honey von Djernquist of Phobos & Deimos, that the reaction of the buyers at the New York trade shows is often: "Oh you cute little provincial thing, so nice of you to drop by; please go now."

headline: Biotech Drug For Angina Is Promising, Doctors Say
abstract: Doctors say CV Therapeutics' drug ranolazine could become first new type of treatment for chest pain of angina in more than two decades; results of clinical trials at American Heart Association meeting show drug reduces episodes of chest pain to three per week from four a week and increases time patients could exercise on treadmill (M)

headline: British Telecom Announces A Resignation And a Big Loss
abstract: British Telecommunications announces huge quarterly loss and its second top-level resignation in a week; Philip Hampton, chief financial officer, is stepping down; company reports net loss of $2.16 billion for quarter ended Sept 30; photo of Hampton with Sir Peter Bonfield, chief executive (M)

headline: Executive Retiring at ChevronTexaco
abstract: Chevron Texaco Corp says Richard Matzke will retire as vice chairman next year after 40 years with Chevron and will be succeeded by Peter Robertson (S)

headline: Talks Fail With Taliban Besieged In Kunduz
abstract: Talks to secure peaceful handover of besieged Taliban-held city of Kunduz collapse, setting stage for possible battle involving thousands of foreign Taliban troops believed to be trapped there; American bombers strike Taliban positions outside city, and Northern Alliance commanders decide to move into city; most alliance troops regard foreign Taliban troops as invaders who have wrecked their country, and they hold them in especially bitter contempt; photo (M)

headline: Debut Shares Of Prudential Rise Modestly On First Day
abstract: Shares of Prudential Insurance Co of America rise modest 6.5 percent on their first day of trading (M)

headline: U.S. to Block Assets It Says Help Finance Hamas Killers
abstract: Pres Bush, responding to weekend's suicide bombings in Israel, is to announce freezing of assets of leading Islamic foundation in United States and two other financial groups; administration officials say groups help finance militant Palestinian orgn Hamas; officials and counterterrorism experts say that freeze would apply to assets of Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development; other two financial groups are Al Aqsa International Bank, based in Palestinian-controlled region, and Beit El-Mal Holdings Co, investment group in West Bank and Gaza (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Funds To Sell Chip Maker's Stock
abstract: Two Taiwan government funds and other investors to sell up to 350 million shares in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co; stock falls 6.4 percent on news (S)0

headline: Banks' Rates Giving Savers Little to Cheer
abstract: Investors who have sought out most conservative investments, such as money market accounts and certificates of deposit, have also suffered this year as rates paid on these savings have dwindled; shrinking returns on deposits are especially hard on people who depend on interest income for living expenses; Bankrate.com says rate on average one-year certificate of deposit has fallen to 2.94 percent from 5.33 percent at start of year; decline in money market yields is less severe but also steep, falling from 2.11 percent to 1.55 percent; many consumers say banks have complicated task of finding best possible deals (M)

headline: Pay Claims Now, Quibble Later; Insurers Tend to the Disrupted Businesses in New York
abstract: Insurers are paying claims made by companies that were damaged or destroyed on Sept 11, or forced to close when they found themselves behind police barricades; monetary damages from attacks are expected to run to more than $40 billion, great majority of that suffered by business; insurance adjustors aim to get to customers fast, assess damage and administer infusions of cash; Geoffrey R Montreuil, claims adjustor for Hartford, unit of Hartford Financial Services Group, comments; graph; photos (M)

headline: Economic Data Are Suggesting Slower Recovery
abstract: Commerce Department reports companies' new orders for durable goods fell 8.5 percent in September, to $165.4 billion, their lowest level since 1996; National Association of Realtors says sales of existing homes dropped 11.7 percent in September; Labor Department reports jobless claims rose to 504,000 for the week, climbing above 500,000 for second time in recent weeks; graphs (M)

headline: Tuberculosis Group Tries to Spur Research for New Antibiotics
abstract: Global Alliance for TB Drug Development, new group, hopes to entice major drug companies into plunging into tuberculosis market; will release study that estimates that market will be worth $700 million a year by 2010; study may not provide much incentive, since big pharmaceutical companies prefer to concentrate research on drugs that will yield $1 billion in yearly sales; no new TB drug has been patented in 30 years, while companies spend fortunes in hunting for cures for baldness, obesity and impotence(M)

headline: Bush's Exhortation at the U.N., and Firing Up the Hollywood Canteen
abstract: Overview of day's events in US war on terrorism (M)

headline: Lehman Profit Drops 67%, Hammered by Sept. 11 Disruption
abstract: Three Wall Street firms report earnings that reflect importance of their physical location on Sept 11 when terrorists attacked in lower Manhattan; Lehman Brothers Holdings, with employees scattered by attacks, reports fourth-quarter net income fell 67 percent, largely because of displacement from its offices; Goldman Sachs Group net income fell 17 percent and Bear Stearns Companies' dropped 21 percent for same quarter; neither suffered degree of disruption that Lehman did (M)

headline: The News Media Make Ready For War
abstract: News media face big financial and logistical challenges in covering war against terrorists in Afghanistan; one of largest international media deployments ever, costing at least $25 million in first week or so, has fanned out to region; reporters are unsure how safely and independently they will be able to operate; map; photo (M)

headline: Citing Deteriorating Operations, Moody's Cuts AT&T's Credit Rating
abstract: Moody's Investors Service reduces credit rating of AT&T Corp to level that may make it more difficult for company to issue commercial paper (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Fashfile : Alber Elbaz Set to Sign With Lanvin
abstract: PARIS—  Alber Elbaz, a smart designer recently out of the limelight, has been wooed by Lanvin. According to Paris sources, the French house is about to close on a deal that will secure Elbaz for Lanvin, which was sold by its parent company L'Oreal in July.

headline: Article 2001100892453895679 -- No Title
abstract: Document is not available. A template could not be found for NYT_Article #1002444706275.

headline: Some (Modest) Proposals to Reform Airlines, With a Special Emphasis on Those Movies
abstract: Joe Queenan article enumerates reforms that airlines should be required to make in exchange for federal bailout, such as giving free drinks to everyone and improving in-flight reading material; cartoon (M)

headline: Argentina's Tottering Economy Is Steadied a Bit by Agreement
abstract: President Fernando de la Rúa's effort to avert a financial meltdown gained some ground Wednesday night when the governors of Argentina's three largest provinces signed an agreement that cuts public spending and introduces a large amount of scrip of questionable value into the economy.    The signing appeared to head off a virtual revolt by the governors of Buenos Aires, Córdoba and Santa Fe provinces, all leaders of the opposition Justicialist Party, who argued that the central government was trying to balance its budget on the backs of their local governments.

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Politics and a Texas Airline
abstract: The Boss column by Southwest Airlines president and chief operating officer Colleen C Barrett focuses on Barrett's fondness for state of Texas; photo (M)

headline: International Business; Small-Scale Financing Takes Hold in Africa
abstract: Niche firms find profit in financing small to mid-sized businesses in Africa; lenders combine first-world business advice with needed funding at multiple locations around continent; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Gore Campaign Manager To Be President of SBC  William M. Daley, the campaign manager for Al Gore's unsuccessful presidential bid, has decided to move down to what was once the enemy's territory, Texas, to become president of SBC Communications.    The appointment to the newly created position places Mr. Daley second in command behind Edward E. Whitacre Jr., SBC's chairman and chief executive. The move is set to be formally announced today. [Page C2.]

headline: New Library of Alexandria Opens (Few) Doors
abstract: Bibliotheca Alexandrina, modern incarnation of Library of Alexandria, stages temporary opening welcoming residents of once glamorous but now dilapidated port city in Egypt to use building for six weeks while administrators wrestle with long-delayed formal inauguration; director Ismail Serageldin says facility needs at least four additional months of construction work and continues to lack some basics expected of modern library, like Internet connections and computers (M)

headline: NationsRent Files For Bankruptcy
abstract: NationsRent Inc, which rents heavy construction equipment to contractors, seeks bankruptcy protection from creditors because of industry slowdown; James Kirk resigns as chairman (S)

headline: KODAK IS BUYING ENCAD, MAKER OF WIDE-FORMAT PRINTERS
abstract: Eastman Kodak said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Encad Inc., a maker of wide-format inkjet printers used for advertising displays and architectural plans, for about $25 million in stock and cash. Encad, based in San Diego, lost $13.8 million on sales of $93.6 million last year. The acquisition is expected to add to earnings beginning in 2003, Kodak said. Sales of wide-format printers amount to about $2.4 billion a year and are increasing at a 15 percent annual rate, said Yves Millette, general manager of Kodak's printer business.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Asking Aid, Colombians Cite Terror; U.S. Demurs
abstract: Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia invokes worldwide antiterrorism efforts in seeking further US support for government's war against rebel groups, including permission to use American helicopters for counterinsurgency as well as antinarcotics operations; however, American officials who work on Colombia policy, as well as a top Colombian official, say they do not expect US to become further engaged aganst rebels (M)

headline: Chávez Finds a Brash Rival in the Mayor of Caracas
abstract: Alfredo Peña seems to get pleasure from provoking Venezuela's volatile leader, President Hugo Chávez.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Trial For Communists
abstract: Five senior Communist-era officials in Czech Republic go on trial, charged with masterminding plan to force dissidents to flee country in late 1970's (S)2

headline: The Yen's Relentless Downhill Slide
abstract: Yen falls against dollar for 11th straight day as Japan systematically nudges currency lower; has lost nearly 7 percent of its value in Dec alone as Japan tries to fight its way out of recession by devaluing its currency; China and South Korea are urging Japan to halt yen's slide; graph of value of yen; photos (M)

headline: An Overhanging Bleakness
abstract: Lisa Belkin column says working life, like life outside work, is not going to return to some pre-Sept 11 normality and people should begin accommodating themselves to what is now normal, however uneasy, and take control of those things that can be controlled; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNETUSENET ARCHIVE IS POSTED ON WEB The big search engine Google restored decades of the Internet's own history to the World Wide Web by putting an archive of 700 million Usenet newsgroup messages dating back to 1981 online. The archive can be found at www.groups.google.com. Usenet predates Internet domain naming, and emerged alongside e-mail as a method to share messages among a wide community of computer users. Google acquired Usenet archives stretching back to 1995 from Deja.com in February 2001. But earlier postings were not warehoused in any central location.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST TURKEY: I.M.F. SIGNALS NEW LOAN The head of the International Monetary Fund said that he would recommend a new loan for Turkey to bridge a $10 billion financing gap, leaving the nation close to an unprecedented third I.M.F. rescue in a year. The managing director of the I.M.F., Horst Köhler, above, said after an informal board meeting Thursday that Turkey's performance under its existing $19 billion loan was

headline: Challenges Abound for New Chief at Beleaguered United Airlines
abstract: United Airlines' new chief executive, John W Creighton Jr, will presumably have to move quickly stanch losses estimated at $20 million a day; must also refashion management team that has lost credibility with employees and manage expectations of labor unions that helped topple his predecessor, James E Goodwin; Frederick C Dubinsky, chairman of Air Line Pilots Association unit at United, strongly endorses Creighton but is cool to idea of wage concessions; many analysts think that such concessions are critical to turning United around; photo (M)

headline: The Health Care Spark
abstract: David St Clair letter comments on Nov 11 article on health-care industry

headline: On Front Line of a Far Corner of War, Boys and Men Wait for the Americans
abstract: Northern Alliance seems to be making no special effort in Charotai, Afghanistan, for major offensive to gain ground, even as American planes pound Taliban; fighting in frontline area rarely reaches fever pitch, with life continuing much as it has since rebels stalled Taliban advance year ago; photo (M)

headline: Edward Radford, 79, Scholar Of the Risks From Radiation
abstract: Dr Edward P Radford, who energetically promoted a higher estimate of cancer risk from radiation exposure and whose position was eventually upheld, dies at age 79; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; A Los Angeles Laker in King Arthur's Dome
abstract: Philip F Anschutz, billionaire who has turned economic disaster to advantage before, will attempt to turn London's blighted Millennium Dome into successful sports and entertainment complex; photo (M)

headline: Input Devices Call On a Little Muscle
abstract: GestureWrist, wristwatch developed by Jun Rekimoto, director of Interaction Laboratory at Sony Computer Science Laboratories, uses tiny motion sensors to track arm movements so that user's hand gestures can essentially function as mouse clicks; hiding electronics in ordinary items like wristwatch is intended to make wearable computer equipment more widely accepted; photo (M)

headline: Filipino Troops Plan Rescue of Three Hostages
abstract: Philippine soldiers say they will come in shooting when moment arrives to rescue two American missionaries and Filipino nurse who have been held hostage in dense jungle for nearly seven months; three hostages--Martin and Gracia Burnham of Wichita, Kansas, and Deborah Yap--are last of dozens who have been seized for ransom over last two years by Abu Sayyaf, Muslim separatist group (M)

headline: Bin Laden Has Less Room to Hide, U.S. Says
abstract: American intelligence officials say Osama bin Laden is on move, forced by Taliban's military setbacks to find safe haven in rapidly shrinking area of southern Afghanistan; say terrorist leader and key lieutenants have not tried to leave country, despite sudden collapse of Taliban's front lines; say US still does not know bin Laden's precise location and has been unable to mount attack; do not believe his security forces have defected; say Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, is moving to new locations in southern Afghanistan, fearful of American efforts to kill him (M)

headline: ENRON CORP. FILES LARGEST U.S. CLAIM FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Enron Corp, which became one of world's dominant energy companies by reshaping way natural gas and electricity are bought and sold, files largest corporate bankruptcy in American history; files lawsuit blaming Dynegy, company that agreed to acquire it on November 9, for backing out after citing Enron's rapid deterioration and misrepresentations; is seeking $1 billion or more in loans and partnership with major bank to allow it to stay in business; is demanding at least $10 billion in damages from Dynegy and court order blocking company from seizing natural gas pipeline that is one of company's prized assets; Dynegy says actions are perfectly legal; plans to take control in return for its $1.5 billion investment in Enron; chairman Charles Watson calls lawsuit frivolous and allegations false; says Enron is trying to deflect public attention away from facts; Enron's rise as major energy company and its downfall discussed; filing with Federal Bankruptcy Court lists assets of $49.8 billion, and debts of $31.2 billion, which do not include many items not listed in financial statements; chart; photos (M)

headline: Afghans, Elated Yet Wary, Greet New Way of Life
abstract: Residents of several cities in Afghanistan greeted fighters last week from the opposition Northern Alliance, showering them with flowers and money in some places, and celebrated in a variety of ways.     The Taliban imposed a harsh variety of Islam that brought them condemnation around the globe. All men had to wear beards at least four inches long. No woman could work or go to school or leave the house alone, and women had to be completely covered if they ventured out of their houses at all. Television and music and many other forms of recreation were banned.

headline: Muted Response From Arab Governments
abstract: Article discusses Arab response to US-led attacks on Afghanistan; initial official responses are muted, but throughout region, Arabs and other Muslims watch Al Jazeera television for latest news (M)

headline: As Alliance Deals With a Warlord, Taliban Fighters Slip Away
abstract: Ghullan Muhammad, warlord of collection of villages in Maidan Shahr, Afghanistan, surrenders to, joins or makes deal with North Alliance; just which it is still is not clear after one day of frantic negotiations and marshaling of forces; hard-core Taliban fighters and unknown number of Islamic zealots slip away during negotiations; they could be headed for Taliban stronghold of Kandahar, or they could be disappearing into mountains, perhaps to fight another day as guerrillas; possibility that Taliban fighters will be allowed to fade into hills, with potential to re-emerge and destabilize Afghanistan, is worrying to Western diplomats trying to reconstruct country; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Nov 18 article on champagne sales

headline: U.S. Marines Probing Deeper Into Taliban-Controlled Areas
abstract: Having established firepower on the ground in southern Afghanistan, American marines are now probing deeper toward the swaths of territory still under control of the Taliban.

headline: Ford Settles Ignition Suits By Extending Warranties
abstract: Judge Michael E Ballachey approves proposal by Ford Motor Co to settle lawsuits in five states by reimbursing current and former owners who replaced flawed ignition systems on millions of cars and trucks; settlement is structured as warranty extension and not as recall; economist hired by plaintiffs estimates agreement could cost Ford as much as $2.7 billion, figure Ford says is overstated; lawsuits involve about 22 million vehicles, most of which were produced between 1983 and 1995 (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Agency Fears Attacks' Effect On Refugees
abstract: United Nations refugee agaency says it is worried that asylum seekers are being victimized and refugee protection standards are being eroded because of Sept 11 terrorist attacks in United States (S)

headline: WASHINGTON TRUST BANCORP BUYING FIRST FINANCIAL
abstract: Washington Trust Bancorp acquires First Financial Corp for about $39 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: London Journal; Recipe for Roasting the Sacred Cow, Tastelessly
abstract: Private Eye, satirical and highly irreverent British magazine, is again embroiled in furor, this time for poking fun at Pres Bush's handling of Sept 11 terrorist attack against World Trade Center; editor, Ian Hislop, remains unapologetic; says he is all for bad taste if it can be justified in making a point; photo (M)

headline: Mine Blast in China Kills 33 Workers
abstract: A pocket of gas exploded in a coal mine in central China this week, killing 33 miners.

headline: Cartoons in a Duet With Dvorak
abstract: Carnegie Hall web site offers

headline: AT&T Is Sticking to Timetable on Cable Unit
abstract: AT&T Corp chairman, C Michael Armstrong, reiterates that he hopes to decide on plan to either spin off or sell company's cable television unit by end of year; AT&T Broadband is number one cable television company in US (M)

headline: Crompton Moving Offices
abstract: Crompton Corp, specialty chemical maker, will relocate its headquarters to Middlebury, Conn, from Greenwich, to consolidate offices; most of 250 employees in Greenwich will be offered jobs in Middlebury (S)

headline: With Taliban Gone, Opium Farmers Return to Their Only Cash Crop
abstract: Afghan farmers prepare to resume cultivation of opium poppies, which were banned by Taliban, saying there is not enough profit in growing other crops to make living; UN Drug Control Program reports country's production of raw opium fell from world-record peak of more than million pounds in 1999 to estimated 40,600 pounds in 2001; Afghanistan is expected to regain status as world's leading source of heroin in year or two; photos; chart (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Africa: Somalia: Protest Over Shaky Currency
abstract: Thousands of Somalis stage violent demonstration in Magadishu demanding that business owners and money dealers accept 500-shilling notes, which are worth about two cents; with Somali shilling at all-time low--2,620 to dollar--many merchants turn away notes because they are worth so little (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Search Engine Expands
abstract: Internet search engine Google expands its index to include material in Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint documents and other business and academic file formats linked from Web pages (S)

headline: War Duty Beckons Anew for Bridge of Friendship, but Uzbeks Are at Ease
abstract: Uzbek residents and military commanders are little concerned about serious attack by Taliban, which has declared jihad, because Uzbekistan has clear military edge at its border with Afghanistan; Uzbek soldiers on patrol at border shun protective gear and make little effort to conceal selves; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Steel Venture
abstract: Germany's ThyssenKrupp and China's Baosteel Group will officially open $1.43 billion stainless steel manufacturing plant in Shanghai, representing one of the largest foreign investments yet in country; ThyssenKrupp holds 60 percent of the joint venture; photo (S)

headline: A Hong Kong Point Man Redefines Allegiance
abstract: FEW public officials here talk as  Mike Rowse does  a rat-a-tat-tat of jokes, stories and epithets delivered in a workaday accent worlds away from the pukka tones of a classic British colonial.    When Britain returned Hong Kong to China in 1997, about 100 British civil servants stayed behind, blending into this increasingly Chinese society with varying success. Mr. Rowse's populist style played well, and he has become one of the most senior British officials.

headline: MAKER OF JIM BEAM SELLS ITS WHISKEY BUSINESS IN BRITAIN
abstract: Fortune Brands sells its Scotch whiskey business in Britain unit's management for $290 million; whiskey unit's management has formed company, Kyndal International Ltd, to purchase business (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Scansoft Gets Lernout Assets
abstract: ScanSoft, maker of digital imaging software, completes its purchase of speech technology assets of Lernout & Hauspie, bankrupted after accounting irregularities came to light (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   5.00   5.00   9.50       Discount rate   1.50   1.50   6.00       Federal funds   2.06   1.88   6.50       3-month T-bills   1.92   1.92   6.16       6-month T-bills   1.99   1.98   6.04       10-yr. headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Falling Profits At Amadeus
abstract: Amadeus reports third-quarter net profits fell 33 percent; warns of possible fourth-quarter loss (S)

headline: Special Operations Gunship Being Used Against Taliban
abstract: Pentagon acknowledges dispatch of AC-130 gunship operated by special operations forces into skies over Afghanistan; use of lumbering AC-130 seen as indication of increasing American confidence that threat from Taliban air defense is greatly diminished; Pentagon officials say bombing campaign, originally expected to last week, has been spurred on longer by discovery of Taliban troops on move, and by identification of new targets from fresh intelligence (M)

headline: Blair, as Face of Coalition, Ends Tour of Arab World
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair, ending whirlwind tour meant to defend attacks on Afghanistan to jittery Arab leaders, calls on people of all faiths and political persuasions to join fight against international terrorism, Cairo; warns terrorists who attacked United States seek to pit Muslims against non-Muslims and Arab world against West; is also reaching out to Arab public; tour underscores difficulties of drawing Arab states into coalition that has taken military action against Muslim state; British officials seek to refute report Saudi Arabia rejected his bid to visit; photo of Blair with Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   5.00   5.00   9.50       Discount rate   1.50   1.50   6.00       Federal funds   2.13   2.09   6.62       3-month T-bills   1.73   1.75   6.02       6-month T-bills   1.73   1.74   5.89       10-yr. T-infl.   3.40   3.40   3.81       10-yr. T-note   4.76   4.77   5.51       30-yr. T-bond   5.29   5.24   5.64       Telephone bd.   7.50   7.50   7.90       Municipal bds.   5.30   5.30   5.72          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: An American Is Said to Be Killed During a Failed Prison Uprising
abstract: Taliban troops stage revolt at prison outside Mazar-i-Sharif, where hundreds are being held under control of National Alliance; hundreds reportedly die; US warplanes bombs prison to help quell uprising; American reported among dead; Pentagon spokesman says fighting began when number of non-Afghan Taliban fighters opened fire on National Alliance guards; describes uprising as suicide mission; says that there are no American military casualties, but that CIA official at prison may have been seriously wounded; uprising seems certain to deepen distrust National Alliance feels as it takes control of hundreds, and potentially thousands, of Taliban soldiers; photo (M)

headline: Insurer Sues to Limit Its Payout for World Trade Center
abstract: Swiss Re, biggest insurer of World Trade Center, files federal suit to limit its payments to half of what buildings' managers are asking; Larry A Silverstein, whose companies hold 99-year lease on property, seeks $7 billion on grounds that each of two hijacked airliners that crashed into towers was separate attack covered by $3.5 billion in insurance; his photo; Swiss Re sees single insurable incident (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trevi Extradition Postponed
abstract: Lawyers for Gloria Trevi, the Mexican pop singer who fled to Brazil after being charged with sexual abuse in her homeland, have obtained an injunction indefinitely postponing her extradition. Ms. Trevi is nearly six months pregnant and has been held in a jail in Brasília for more than a year; local news media are reporting that the singer has been repeatedly raped by the police officers supervising her detention.   Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: A Vote On Tougher Abortion Laws
abstract: Irish government announces plans to hold national referendum before spring 2002 on measures to make it more difficult for women to have abortions; 1992 Supreme Court decision outlawed abortion, except in cases in which carrying fetus to term threatens mother's life, or if she threatens to commit suicide; new proposal will create legislation to uphold ban and to remove suicide provision (S)

headline: An upturn in account spending that was expected in 2002 may not come until 2003, executives say.
abstract: Advertising industry executives at American Magazine Conference panel predicted expected upturn in advertising spending will begin later than expected, possibly not until 2003; latest figures show American ad spending fell 6.4 percent from 2000 first half, with decline continuing through third quarter (M)

headline: People
abstract: Jonathan Harries, executive vice president and worldwide creative director for global brands at Foote, Cone & Belding, is named chairman at Chicago office and worldwide creative director at agency; chairman's post is new; in creative post, Harries succeeds Geoff Thompson, who is retiring; David Corr and Lance Paull are named co-presidents and executive creative directors at New York office of Publicis in US (S)

headline: A 3rd Front: War's Spoils
abstract: Analysis of war in Afghanistan notes United States military, which created conditions for sudden fall of Kabul to Northern Alliance, has little control over alliance, which moved into city despite its repeated promises to wait; notes other US allies in war against terrorism in Afghanistan are also unpredictable; military success leaves US with no clear answers to questions about Afghanistan's future; alliance is now pledging to keep bulk of its forces outside city; has deployed 3,000 security troops across city to bring order, not occupy it (M)

headline: 12-Year-Olds Take Up Arms Against Taliban
abstract: Seemingly endless civil war in Afghanistan has ensnared hundreds of young soldiers; many, as young as 12 years of age, are part of campaign by Afghan opposition forces, with American support, against Osama bin Laden and Taliban governors sheltering him; photo (M)

headline: Food for Refugees, Raids on Caves and the Fate of Taliban Prisoners
abstract: Overview of developments, December 10, in US military campaign in Afghanistan against terrorism (M)

headline: Investing; Fund Strategies to Soothe Tax Pain
abstract: Dismal stock market performance means that most mutual fund investors will face only small tax bites this year, unlike last year, when many investors found they they had to pay record capital gains taxes on funds that had fallen in value; many advisers urge client to plan for years when investment returns, and tax bills, are likely to be higher and suggest a number of strategies; photo; graph (M)

headline: War on Terror Casts Chechen Conflict in a New Light
abstract: Terrorist attacks of Sept 11 alter perception of Russia's struggle with Chechen rebels, who have attracted outsiders and members of strict Wahhabi branch of Islam; until Sept 11, US and West shrugged off Russian assertions that conflict is part of battle against international terrorism; Pres Bush has since challenged Chechen rebels to sever all ties with Osama bin Laden and terrorism; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcasters Sue ReplayTV
