abstract: ABC, CBS and NBC file copyright infringement suit against ReplayTV Inc and its corporate parent Sonicblue Inc, manufacturers of digital device that allows users to record programs without advertisements and to transmit them to other people over Internet (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil declines on increasing evidence that slowing world economy is hurting energy demand; in New York, crude oil for November delivery falls 50 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $21.31 per barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Most Afghan Opium Grown In Rebel-Controlled Areas
abstract: United Nations study indicates that most opium grown in Afghanistan this year was in areas controlled by rebel group Northern Alliance; opium harvests in Taliban-controlled areas plummeted after ban by Taliban, however, both factions appear to be heavily involved in, and financed by, drug trade (M)

headline: Ancient Secret System Moves Money Globally
abstract: Hawala, informal and far-reaching banking network, although illegal in most countries, is thought to move billions of dollars unseen by regulators, with records destroyed once transfer is completed; Pakistani officials believe Osama bin Laden's terrorist network uses hawala to transfer money to agents outside Afghanistan, along with conventional means; even new scrutiny spurred by Sept 11 terrorist attacks is unlikely to uncover full details of how bin Laden's money moves through ancient system; photos (M)

headline: Boycott Threat Is Early Test for Afghan Leadership Pact
abstract: One day after plans for interim Afghan government are announced, Gen Abdul Rashid Dostum, whose forces dominate much of northern Afghanistan, vows to boycott new administration and says he will not go to Kabul until 'proper government' is in place; his representatives to negotiations in Germany came away with ministries of agriculture, mining and industry in interim government, but he had hoped for foreign ministry as reward for role his forces played in toppling Taliban (M)

headline: NUCOR TO BUY ASSETS OF TRICO STEEL FOR $120 MILLION
abstract: Nucor To Buy AsseA

headline: Safety Caps Are Considered For Cosmetics
abstract: Consumer Product Safety Commission is expected to require manufacturers to put child-resistant caps on array of household products that contain hydrocarbons, including cosmetics; first proposed regulating products in 1997, but cosmetics companies demanded more study, saying that change would be expensive and that risk of children's dying from cosmetics containing hydrocarbons was very remote; 16-month-old boy in California died in May after pouring baby oil into his mouth; that apparently convinced majority of three-member commission that regulation is necessary; Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association argues that only automotive and household chemicals should be forced to put safety caps on their products (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Bomber Killed By Own Device
abstract: Protestant teenager is killed in Northern Ireland when pipe bomb he is preparing to throw at police and Catholic crowd blows up in his hand in North Belfast neighborhood that has been scene of nightly rioting (S)

headline: A Tale of 2 Engines: How Hybrid Cars Tame Emissions
abstract: Explanation of how hybrid electric vehicles work; diagrams; photo (L)

headline: Knowing the Options In Writing a Will
abstract: letters: knowing the options in wr8

headline: Clan Leader Turned Statesman: Hamid Karzai
abstract: Man in the News biographical sketch of Hamid Karzai, who has been named to lead interim government in Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: Chip Maker to Combine Its Regional Accounts
abstract: addeno

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Songwriters Sue Music Services
abstract: Technology Briefing: Songwriters Sue Music S

headline: A Coalition Forms
abstract: A timeline chronicling the progress of the war thus far.

headline: Near Unity At the U.N. On Opposing Terrorism
abstract: Annual round of speeches at United Nations General Assembly draws to close with almost every nation joining to condemn terrorism; John Negroponte, chief US representative to UN, expresses satisfaction with his first General Assembly (M)

headline: Building Web Pages Without the Drudgery of HTML
abstract: Familiarity with HTML is no longer required to create Web page, and help is available from Internet providers and Web sites; photos (M)

headline: Interim Presidency Decided in Argentina but Doubts Linger
abstract: Argentine political leaders propose unusual three-step process to install new president to complete term of Fernando de la Rua, who resigned; party leaders chose Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, governor of small province, to be designated interim president and serve until successor can be elected in national vote now likely to be held on Mar 3; country is shaken by doubt and confusion as to who will eventually take power and how new government will deal with acute economic crisis that forced president to leave in middle of his term; photo (M)

headline: Consumers Ready To Spend for Holidays
abstract: Survey finds that majority of households across nation have no plans to curtail holiday spending this year despite bruised economy and terrorist attacks; finds that 57 percent of people questioned say they will spend about same amount as last year, 28 percent plan to spend less and 18 percent more; suggestions for consumers on not overspending (S)

headline: Argentina's Leader Comes Begging, Burdened by More Bad News
abstract: Argentine Pres Fernando de la Rua's critical negotiations with opposition governors to curtail spending fall apart just as he leaves for New York to seek emergency help (M)

headline: S.& P. Cuts Credit Rating Of Japan
abstract: Standard & Poor's reduced its rating of Japan's credit by a notch, to AA, today, penalizing the government of the world's second-largest economy for failing to curtail its fiscal deficit or revive its faltering economy.     The move, which equated Japan's creditworthiness with that of Italy, the lowest among the Group of 7 major economies, dealt a blow to the fiscal overhaul program of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi by making Japan's immense debts more expensive and burdensome.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Avesco Reports a Loss
abstract: Shares of Avesco slide 29 percent in Great Britain after company reports $1.7 million loss in six months ended Sept 30, in contrast to $3.4 million profit during same period year ago; graph (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Two American executives gain control over a big share of the operations of UBS.
abstract: Promotions of top two American executives at UBS AG, John Costas and Joseph Grano, were obscured by sudden ouster of chief executive Luqman Arnold; Costas is now chief executive of UBS Warburg, bank's global investment banking arm; he has gained seat on bank's executive board alongside Grano, who runs brokerage business of Paine Webber; Costas is succeeding Markus Granziol, who will remain chairman of UBS Warburg; UBS is moving Paine Webber from under Warburg and having Grano report to new chief executive Peter Wuffli (Market Place column) (M)

headline: On Any Window or Wall, a Portable Touch Screen
abstract: Nearly 300 people create a van Gogh portrait on tabletop using multicolored M&M candies in demonstration of how people can manipulate devices while in communications with computer without ever touching anything wired to computer; Dr Claudio Pinhanez, who leads deveolopment of this technology at IBM, says projector could one day transform surfaces like walls and windows into active yet unwired touch screens; envisions wide range of applications, from beaming interactive menus onto restaurant tables to projecting lessons onto each student's desk; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Prisoner Starts Hunger Strike
abstract: Liu Yaping, Chinese-born permanent resident of United States being held by Chinese police for nine months, starts hunger strike at hospital where he is being held prisoner; he was charged with minor economic crimes that usually carry only fine (S)

headline: To Help Land, Australians Rethink Role Of Kangaroos
abstract: Value and treatment of kangaroo are now subjects of renewed debate in Australia; scientists, ranchers, environmentalists and government officials promote new land care strategy of kangaroo ranching to halt chronic soil degradation and diversify sources of farm income; animal welfare activists say mass harvesting of prolific kanagroos could lead to extinction of several major species (M)

headline: Slowing the Search, Reading the Tea Leaves, Securing the Skies
abstract: Overview of events in war in Afghanistan and on terrorism (M)

headline: NATO Says U.S. Has Proof Against bin Laden Group
abstract: The alliance, finding Washington had "clear and compelling proof" that Osama bin Laden was behind the Sept. 11 attacks, said it would fight if it is asked.

headline: Putin Shakes Up Russian Navy After Receiving Report on Sub
abstract: Russia's navy is reportedly reeling after Pres Vladimir V Putin moves over weekend to fire or punish 14 of its high-ranking officers for 'serious shortcomings' in training and daily duties; many observers conclude that Putin's actions are belated response to disastrous sinking of Kursk nuclear-powered submarine in August 2000, which killed 118 crewmen and civilians on board (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cuts At Military Contractor
abstract: Military contractor BAE Systems says it will end production of regional jetliners and cut more than 1,650 jobs because of falling demand for new aircraft after Sept 11 terrorist attacks (S)

headline: Promotion at Times Co.
abstract: Kenneth A Richieri is promoted to deputy general counsel of The New York Times Co; he will remain vice president and general counsel of New York Times Digital (S)

headline: Vasily Mishin, 84; Led Soviet Race to Moon
abstract: Dr Vasily P Mishin, who helped preside over Soviet Union's failed effort to beat United States to Moon, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline: Time Finds a New Role for Life In Special Issues and Hardcovers
abstract: Time Inc, in latest incarnation of its Life magazine, plans ad-free, single-topic, premium magazines to be issued every six weeks; current issues include rapidly executed retrospective of Sept 11 attacks and their aftermath (M)

headline: For the Moment, All Quiet On the Northern Front
abstract: Political factors seem to have made front lines 35 miles north of Kabul one of least bombed places in Afghanistan, spurring soldiers to flee to front for quiet night before driving home in morning; rebel commanders complain Taliban has been allowed to reinforce lines at front; lack of American bombing at front deters Northern Alliance from taking Kabul before accord is reached on makeup of new government (M)

headline: Argentine Leader Announces Debt Revision and Subsidies
abstract: Argentine Pres Fernando de la Rua, in last-ditch effort to avert costly debt default, announces partial restructuring of Argentina's crushing $132-billion debt, subsidy package for the poor and tax breaks for business; photo; says peso will continue pegged to dollar to avoid high inflation (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen drops on speculation that Bank of Japan will cheapen currency to help pull economy out of slump; in New York, dollar settles at 121.33 yen, up from 120.96 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Marks & Spencer Sells 9 Stores
abstract: Marks & Spencer, troubled British retailing group, agrees to sell nine Spanish stores to El Corte Ingles, Spain's leading retailer (S)

headline: COCA-COLA JOINT VENTURE BUYS PHILIPPINE DRINK COMPANY
abstract: San Miguel, Philippine food and beverage company, and its joint-venture partner Coca-Cola agree to pay 14 billion pesos ($269 million) for Philippines' second-largest soft drink company, Cosmos (S)

headline: China's Heir Apparent in Debut on the World Stage
abstract: Article profiles China's vice president Hu Jintao, heir apparent to aging Jiang Zemin, who is making first visit to Russia and Western Europe in common diplomatic trip filled with meaning; it is seen as another calibrated step in Hu's cautious but apperently effective ascension, one that under peculiarties of Chinese politics requires him to keep head down; photos (M)

headline: Taliban Withdrawing From Kabul as Rebels Move Toward Capital
abstract: Taliban forces retreat from Kabul, Afghan capital, after string of successes by US-backed Northern Alliance, which halts advance on outskirts of city; rebels are greeted by hundreds of joyful residents celebrating in streets; Northern Alliance commanders seem eager to keep pledge to Washington that forces will not enter Kabul; senior Pakistani intelligence official says Mullah Muhammad Omar, Taliban's supreme leader, ordered withdrawal of forces so US planes would halt bombing of Afghan cities allowing Taliban and alliance to fight on equal terms; scenes of chaos in and around Kabul described; maps (M)

headline: Merrill Lynch Picks New Strategy Chief
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company chooses Richard Bernstein to be chief US investment strategist (S)

headline: The Warlord, in Charge Again, Thanks the West but Wants It Gone
abstract: It seems as if things are returning to normal in Herat, especially if you are Ismail Khan, a legendary and highly independent warlord here, whose forces chased away the Taliban.    That was Monday, when Mr. Khan, commanding Northern Alliance troops, liberated this city in far western Afghanistan.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Rhodia Trade Halted
abstract: French market regulator halts trading in Rhodia stock after shares jump 23 percent on speculation that rivals BASF and DSM are vying to acquire specialty chemical maker; graph (S)

headline: Discord Delays Choice of Interim Leader for Argentina
abstract: Argentine Congress is deadlocked as it attempts to ratify new president who will serve until presidential elections are held; eventual leadership change is likely to be easy part in dealing with mounting economic crisis; economists say new interim president will preside over largest debt default in history and potentially chaotic devaluation; photo (M)

headline: Employees Are Shouldering More of Health Care Tab
abstract: Employers are requiring workers to pay larger share of their medical costs, but health care inflation continues despite higher deductibles and per-use fees; some health economists argued that shifting costs to employees would make consumers more cautious about medical spending, checking health care inflation, but others say higher costs will lead some people to postpone needed treatment, adding to later costs; graphs (M)

headline: GRANDDAUGHTER OF FOUNDING FAMILY GETS CRUCIAL JOB
abstract: Ford Motor Co names Elena Ford group brand manager of Mercury (S)

headline: Vitamin Producers Fined $752 Million
abstract: European Commission fines eight vitamin producers total of just over 855 million euros ($752 million) for involvement in number of cartels that fixed prices and market shares of vitamin products in 1990's; Hoffmann-La Roche is singled out as ringleader and ordered to pay 462 million euros ($406 million), by far biggest fine European Union's competition authority has ever levied against single company; BASF of Germany, which is also found to have helped coordinate cartels, is fined 296 million euros ($260 million); photos, including one of Jurgen Strube, chmn of BASF (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Neutrality Is Old-Fangled, Leader Says
abstract: Austrian Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel says nation's neutrality is 'old convention' that no longer fits complex reality, rite marking nation's independence (S)7

headline: South Korea Sees Prospects Of Its Leader Steadily Ebb
abstract: Emergence of recent weeks of crowd of presidential candidates, first in opposition parties and then in party of South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung, signals Kim's once formidable powers are fading; Kim's popularity has plummeted as Pres Bush's suspicion of North Korea has undercut reconciliation effort that gave him aura of political miracle worker; civic movement that once strongly backed him now blames him for not pushing economic reforms more vigorously; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Pressplay To Allow Home CD'S
abstract: Pressplay, online music service backed by Sony Music Entertainment and Universal Music Group, will allow subscribers to create compact discs from downloaded music; about 100,000 songs will be available (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Abrupt End To Royal Tempest
abstract: britian: abrupt end to royal tempest*

headline: Nuremberg Journal; The Architect Who Speared His Own Nazi Demon
abstract: Interview with architect Gunther Domenig on his work turning grandiose former official Nazi building, Nuremberg, Germany, into documentary center on Nazi era; museum is form of atonement for city, spiritual home for Nazis; photos (M)

headline: 'Pragmatic Palestinian' Draws Road Map to Peace
abstract: Sari Nusseibeh, Palestinians' political representative in Jerusalem, lacks real power but has important bully pulpit, which he choses to use to promote ideas that he believes offer Palestinians and Israelis way out of their mess; his central idea is that Israelis and Palestinians must each give up some of their most cherished dreams; says for Israel that means sharing sovereignty in Jerusalem, and for Palestinians it means surrender of their claim to 'right of return'; photo (M)

headline: For AOL, Goals Are Deferred, Not Denied
abstract: Comcast's acquisition of AT&T Broadband forces AOL Time Warner to defer, but not abandon, its objective of becoming the dominant cable force; analysts says AOL Time Warner might be better off for not having bought AT&T's cable unit, now AT&T Comcast, because of huge challenge of integrating it into its own cable operations, but they also expect company to look to buy other cable companies in order to keep up with rapid consolidation in industry; photo (M)

headline: EchoStar to Receive Loan
abstract: EchoStar Communications says Credit Suisse First Boston will provide $2.75 billion short-term loan to help finance its planned purchase of its satellite-television rival, Hughes Electronics; says financing will replace temporary loan from Hughes's parent, General Motors; says it has also lined up $2.75 billion loan from Deutsche Bank (S)

headline: American Express Reports Profit Dropped by 60% in 3rd Quarter
abstract: American Express Co reports third-quarter net income of $298 million, down from $737 million in 2000 period (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Airline's Step Hurts Travelocity
abstract: Travelocity.com Inc's stock falls $5.83, or 29 percent, to $14.07 after it is downgraded by Prudential Securities analyst Mark Rowen on news that Continental Airlines has eliminated commissions on travel sold on Web; graph (S)

headline: Foundation Gives Way On Chief's Big Dream
abstract: Profile of Kenneth L Lay, Enron Corp chief executive, focusing on his faith in market forces to build his empire, same market forces that caused it to collapse; photo; drawing; graphs (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Will Cut Jobs
abstract: Prudential, Britain's second-largest insurer, will cut 2,100 jobs and sell subdivisions to Credit Suisse Group; plans to focus on life insurance business (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: ABB Speeds Layoff Plans
abstract: Swiss-Swedish electrical engineering group ABB expects its profit to fall 10 percent this year and will speed plans to cut 12,000 jobs, nearly 8 percent of its work force; says sales in first nine months rose 4 percent, to $16.9 billion (S)

headline: Breakup Bucks Trend In Mining
abstract: *Australian mining company WMC Ltd rejects $5.8 billion takeover proposal from Alcoa, partner since 1960's, calling offer inadequate; WMC instead plans to split company into two, spinning off its 40 percent stake in alumina venture with Alcoa; venture is Alcoa World Alumina and Chemicals (S)

headline: Blair Leaves British Awed Or Seething Over His Role
abstract: Article discusses British Prime Min Tony Blair, who exhibits new eloquence and stature in his role as premier American ally following Sept 11 terrorist attacks; some Britons are less sanguine about his new role, saying he is neglecting England's business for loftier stage; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Citizens Ends Purchase Plans
abstract: Citizens Communications ends talks with Verizon Communications to buy about 63,000 phone lines in Arizona and California for $233 million (S)

headline: Moved by Mexicans' Laughter
abstract: Jennifer Clement, American interviewed about how it feels to live abroad following Sept 11 terrorist attack on US, talks about living in Mexico City (S)

headline: Diplomats Rush to Kabul To Secure an Early Edge
abstract: Small procession of diplomats have returned to their shuttered embassies, or in some cases ruined ones, in Kabul to struggle for contacts, information and influence in Central Asia; disparate group is comprised of Iranians, Russians, Indians and Turks is united by one main factor: desire to ensure that neither Taliban nor anything like them ever again take power and turn Afghanistan into haven for terrorists; key question is whether that quest for stability will take priority over support for individual Afghan factions, which would spark another round of civil war; arrival of diplomats that support Northern Alliance is certain to be regarded with suspicion by Pakistan, which held enormous influence in Kabul when Taliban were in power but has not yet dared to reopen its embassy; Britain and France have also sent senior diplomats to size up political situation and encourage broad-based post-Taliban regime that would represent Pashtuns, country's dominant ethnic group, and not just Northern Alliance, which is led primarily by ethnic Tajiks and Uzbeks; Russian team is housed in Kabul Hotel because its embassy compound is wreck filled with about 23,700 refugees; Russian delegation is headed by senior Foreign Ministry official, Aleksandr Oblov, and includes Leonid Khokhlov, who Western officials say is lieutenant general representing Russian Defense Ministry; Russians' presence marks their first return since Soviet occupation of Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: Belgium Is Hindering Investigation, U.S. Says
abstract: American investigators say that Belgian authorities have denied them access to suspects and evidence in their inquiry into European network linked to Osama bin Laden and a thwarted plot to blow up American Embassy in Paris; senior American law enforcement official says Washington has pleaded with Belgians to hand over phone numbers and names found when they arrested two men two days after Sept 11 attacks; one of them, Nizar Trabelsi, is believed to have been recruited as suicide bomber for attack on American Embassy in Paris; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ARCHER DANIELS MIDLAND CO., Decatur, Ill., the grain processor, said it had increased its stake in a German grain trader, Toepfer International, to 80 percent from 75 percent. Terms were not disclosed.    BOEING CO., Chicago, the airplane maker, said that it had signed a $400 million contract with the U.S. government to upgrade 35 AH-64A Apache helicopters to next-generation AH-64D Apaches for the Egyptian Army. Delivery is scheduled to begin in 2003.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Juniper Buys Start-Up
abstract: Juniper Networks acquires Pacific Broadband Communications for $200 million in stock (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vivendi Selling BSKYB Shares
abstract: Vivendi Universal is selling $1.5 billion worth of shares in the British Sky Broadcasting Group, or about one-third of its holding in the pay television company. The sale is intended to give the French media company ''breathing room for various opportunities of strategic partnership in U.S. television,'' the company said. Vivendi is in talks to acquire the entertainment assets of USA Networks. It will receive only a fraction of the proceeds from the sale, because the stake has already been used as collateral on a 4.2 billion euro ($3.77 billion) loan from Deutsche Bank. The European Commission had required Vivendi to dispose of its stake in BSkyB in return for clearance of Vivendi's acquisition of Seagram, which would combine the Universal Studios entertainment assets with Vivendi's Canal Plus.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline: U.S. and 21 Other Nations Vow To Spend Billions on Afghanistan
abstract: United States and 21 other nations vow to spend billions of dollars to reconstruct Afghanistan after war, aid conference at State Department called by US and Japan; some officials privately estimate cost at $10 billion; Sec Colin L Powell cites need for long reconstruction program; Undersec Al Larson says focus is on projects that can deliver quick benefits to large numbers of people; United Nations and World Bank are expected to administer most of aid; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Immigration Accord With Greece
abstract: Turkey and Greece agree that Greece will be able to return illegal immigrants to Turkey; long-sought deal comes as Greece fears new wave of illegal refugees from US bombing campaign in Afghanistan (S)

headline: An Elusive bin Laden, Loss of a Bomber, Twin Tower Science
abstract: Overview of events in war on terrorism, including shifting deadlines for Al Qaeda forces hidden in Tora Bora caves, contradictory reports from Pakistan about whether Taliban or bin Laden forces might have crossed border, crash of B-1B bomber into Indian Ocean near Diego Garcia, immigration authority's new crackdown on Middle Easterners with invalid visas, and scientific probe of what caused collapse of twin towers (M)

headline: Are Ethics an Elective?
abstract: Survey of business school students by MBA Jungle magazine finds a good number are willing to put ethics aside to get a position and better pay (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: New Zealand: Bid For Energy Drink Maker
abstract: Groupe Danone of France bids $121 million for New Zealand's largest fruit drink maker, Frucor Beverages Group; graph (S)

headline: Honda Opens a U.S. Factory and a Front Against the Big 3
abstract: Honda Motor executives charge that three major US automakers have double standard on fuel economy and are not willing to face environmental implications of their increasing reliance on sales of pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles; fuel economy requirements for these vehicles have not increased since 1980's; Honda dedicates new minivan assembly plant in Lincoln, Ala, where it intends to hire 2,300 workers; GM, Ford and DaimlerChrysler are currently laying off employees and contemplating further plant closings (M)

headline: 'Delicate Balance' Awaits Buyer of Brooks Brothers
abstract: Marks & Spencer announces it is selling Brooks Brothers, 175-year-old clothing chain, to Retail Brand Alliance Inc of Enfield, Conn, for $225 million in cash; that is about a third of $750 million that Marks & Spencer paid for business in 1988; photo (M)

headline: Accounting Firm Is Bracing for an Onslaught
abstract: Enron debacle is building into set of knotty problems for Arthur Andersen, accounting firm that audited Enron's books for more than decade; Andersen spokesman says that SEC had issued subpoenas to accounting firm and that it had supplied information requested; firm also announces that scope of peer review would be significantly expanded and would include review of procedures at Andersen's Houston office, which handled Enron audits; Andersen braces for wave of lawsuits by disgruntled shareholders whose investments plunged in value (M)

headline: Some Companies That Have Spread Out
abstract: Here is a sampling of companies that are dispersing their workers — whether to be better prepared for disasters, to shorten workers’ commutes or to make more efficient use of space.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: In Bush's Words: Attack on '2 Terrorist-Supporting Financial Networks'
abstract: Excerpts from Pres Bush's announcement of crackdown on international financial organizations helping Al Qaeda (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Manufacturing Turns Down
abstract: Sales and profit at largest manufacturers in Japan collapse in July-Sept quarter along with downturn in spending on technology globally; pretax profit fell 32.5 percent in third quarter (S)

headline: Pakistan's Leader Reassures China of Their Special Bond
abstract: Pakistan leader Gen Pervez Musharraf receives lavish welcome in China as two countries affirm longstanding friendship amid shifting Asian alliances brought about by United States-led war on terrorism in Afghanistan; state visit is one of series of events to commemorate 50 years of diplomatic relations between China and Pakistan; though China has generally supported war effort, new cooperation between US, which it views as primary global competitor, and its old friend Pakistan has raised some concerns; photo (M)

headline: First Boston Says Justice Dept. Has Ended Initial-Offerings Case
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston says Justice Department has dropped criminal probe into how it distributed shares in initial public offerings; probe centered on whether firm offered clients sought-after initial offerings in 1999 and 2000 in exchange for illegal kickbacks and pledges to buy more shares after initial sale; firm and other underwriters still face Securities and Exchange Commission civil probe (M)

headline: Al Qaeda Fleeing Toward Pakistan, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters have fled from the caves of Tora Bora, and Osama bin Laden may be among them, according to United States intelligence officials.

headline: Lebenthal to Be Acquired by the MONY Group
abstract: Lebenthal & Co, New York institution made famous by its quirky ads extolling the virtues of tax-free municipal bonds, is being acquired by MONY Group for about $25 million; Alexandra Lebenthal will stay on as president and chief executive of Lebenthal; her father and Lebenthal division chairman, James Lebenthal, will become chairman emeritus and serve as consultant; photo (M)

headline: Indictment by Spanish Judge Portrays a Secret Terror Cell
abstract: Long indictment by Spanish Judge Balthazar Garzon against eight purported members of allegedly clandestine terror cell that may have helped prepare September 11 terrorist attacks against US is made public; discloses clear links to apartment in Germany, where Mohamed Atta, hijackers' suspected ringleader, lived as well as intercepts of telephone conversations indicating preparations for attack; provides best portrait yet of Al Qaeda European cell as it is believed to have taken root over number of years; says eight men posed patiently for years as middle-class householders, only occasionally slipping into shadows to recruit young Muslim fighters for Osama bin Laden's training camps or to commit crimes to raise money for guns and explosives; describes evolution of cell since 1994, when group of radicals sought to take over mosque in central Madrid in order to impose more fundamentalist teachings; other findings in indictment discussed; alleged ringleaders of cell identified as Anwar Mohamed Saleh and Imad Eddin Barakat Yarkas; their activities as recruiters for Al Qaeda described; photo (M)

headline: Ruling to Dissolve Independent Russian TV Network Draws Protests
abstract: Moscow court has decided to dissolve Russia's last independent national television network, TV-6, leading to outcry by journalists and human rights leaders who say decision leaves Russians with little choice of news; network belongs to Boris A Berezovsky, self-exiled businessman, and Russian oil company Lukoil; Lukoil filed court documents this summer claiming that network was in financial trouble and should be put out of business; network says business is booming and real source of suit is manipulative government; TV-6 is preparing appeal (M)

headline: A Niche Brewer Is Making Waves
abstract: Profile of South African Breweries, known as SAB; London-based brewer, which has computerized, highly-automated plant on South Africa's eastern coast, is able to produce 15,000 bottles of Castle lager every minute, twice the industry average; it takes only 13 people to run plant, keeping operating costs very low; for reasons of history and inclination, SAB has carved niche for itself outside big industrial countries; with new deals to apply its expertise in South America and Asia in last week, company is cementing its position as largest brewer in emerging markets and is attracting attention of rivals; company announces that it has agreed to acquire controlling stakes in two Chinese breweries; photo of Interbrew of Beligum chief exec Hugo Powell (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Belarus Wants Quick Wedding
abstract: Talks on long-proposed union of Russia and Belarus strike new sour note as Pres Alekasndr Lukashenko of Belarus accuses Kremlin of foot-dragging on plans to meld two countries' economies, while Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin says union's success rests on gradual implementation; photo (S)

headline: USX-MARATHON TO BUY CMS WEST AFRICA HOLDINGS
abstract: USX-Marathon agrees to buy CMS Energy's stakes in oil and natural-gas fields in Equatorial Guinea for $993 million in cash (S)

headline: Major Clients Award Big Accounts to 2 Shops
abstract: Major advertisers are making decisions on large accounts; Toyota Motor Sales USA selects Burrell Communications Group in Chicago as its first agency of record to create advertising aimed at black consumers; other account changes noted (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Is Up At Puma
abstract: Puma says third-quarter profit more than tripled, setting off sharp rally in its stock price; net income rose to 17.5 million euros ($16 million) from 4.5 million euros year earlier; sales increased 32 percent, to 197.1 million euros ($180.2 million); photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Asian News Programs
abstract: News Corp, seeking to capitalize on increasing demand from Pakistani and Indian emigres for news in their native languages, signs deal with Telewest, Britain's second-largest cable operator, which will begin showing progamming from Asian Star News and Star Plus channels on Oct 19; channels are leading providers of news and entertainment in Central Asia (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Lawmaker Resigns Post
abstract: Tony Yengeni resigns South African parliamentary post after being charged with fraud and corruption (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Lifting Status Of Prostitutes
abstract: German government passes bill giving 400,000 prostitutes working rights and removing stigma from their profession (S)

headline: Slowdown Also Hurts Bonuses
abstract: National economic slowdown causes reduction af annual bonuses for executives, middle managers and individual workers (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip Makers May Merge
abstract: Hynix Semiconductor expects to sign memorandum of understanding with Micron Technology in January that could lead to merger of two companies (S)

headline: 2 Big Chip Makers Raise Forecasts
abstract: Intel and Advanced Micro Devices raise their financial forecsts for current quarter, saying their personal computer microprocessors are selling better than expected; Intel says it cannot keep up with orders for its newest chip line, Pentium 4 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RF MICRO DEVICES INC., Greensboro, N.C., a maker of proprietary radio-frequency integrated circuits, agreed with I.B.M. Corp., Armonk, N.Y., to buy I.B.M.'s engineering unit for chips used in global positioning systems. Terms were not disclosed.    TEAMSTAFF INC., Somerset, N.J., a provider of personnel services to businesses, said it would buy a nationally based, professional employer company with more than 20,000 employees within 30 to 60 days. Terms and the company's name were not disclosed.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Nov 11 report on visit to US of Alberta, Canada energy minister, Murray Smith, which misstated government estimate of recoverable crude oil in province's oil-sands reserves; it is 315 billion barrels, not 22.1 billion

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Australia: Candidate Flaunts Wart
abstract: Dave Tollner, candidate for Australian Parliament who has been charged with drunken driving, drops into bars and passes out coasters that say 'Have a drink on Dave Tollner' (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar climbs after US-backed forces enter Kabul, Afghan capital, and Taliban militia flees; in New York, euro settles at 88.13 cents, down from 89.50 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rises
abstract: Germany's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose in September to 9.4 percent from 9.3 percent; economists at Deutsche Bank predict unemployment could creep to 9.5 percent by end of year and nearly 10 percent by end of 2002 (S)

headline: Okinawa Justice Is Tilted Against Them, Americans Say
abstract: American military personnel on Okinawa charge that Japanese justice is tilted against them, intensifying tensions over US presence on island; photos; map; alleged rape of Japanese customer by Air Force sergeant Timothy Woodland in June brought intense investigation and angry protests, while murder of 62-year-old American, Gerald C Fearr, one week later was allegedly treated in perfunctory manner; husband of owner of 3F restaurant, involved in both cases, died after being struck by Japanese man in altercation; police charge Riki Matsuya with assault but not murder, saying Fearr died of heart attack (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Increases
abstract: 4.6 percent slump in imports lifts Canada's trade surplus to 4.7 billion Canadian dollars ($2.9 billion) in September, from 3.9 billion Canadian dollars ($2.4 billion) in August (S)

headline: Post-Enron, All Eyes On Rating Agencies
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column says Enron Corp's collapse should move credit rating agencies to be more aggressive in their scrutiny of corporate debt and equity issues; notes that major rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's and Fitch, have access to company data unavailable to brokerage and accounting firms and investment banks, all of which have been shamefully discredited by Enron Corp debacle; notes also that corporate bond market has grown threefold in past five years and has become as volatile as stock market; chart (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Craig Braasch was named vice president for global advertising and promotions at the Burger King Corporation, Miami, part of Diageo.

headline: Mildred R. Newman, 81, Psychologist and Popular Author
abstract: Mildred Rubenstein Newman, New York psychologist whose vastly popular books helped meet an American yearning for emotional self-help and self-betterment in 1970's, dies at 81 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechnya Death Toll
abstract: Russia says 3,434 Russian soldiers have died in Chechnya and more than 11,000 have been wounded since military mounted second operation there, in October 1999; association of soldiers' mothers says total may be 10,000 dead (S)

headline: EMERSON ELECTRIC IS PLANNING TO CLOSE 10 FACTORIES
abstract: Emerson Electric Co plans to close 10 plants and lay off unspecified number of workers in next few years (S)

headline: Central America Reminded Of Its Own Era of Conflict
abstract: United States is courting allies in its war against terrorism among Central Asian nations, some saddled with human rights problems; some in Latin America offer cautious advice from their own bitter experience from era when US supported Latin American dictatorships with atrocious human rights records (M)

headline: F.C.C. Is Expected to Lift Airwave Spectrum Cap
abstract: Federal Communications Commission is expected to vote to gradually eliminate cap on amount of airwave spectrum that mobile phone companies can acquire in single market; move, which could lead to greater consolidation in wireless communications industry, is favored by Verizon Wireless, AT&T Wireless and other large wireless carriers; big companies argue spectrum shortage is limiting their availability to improve service in urban areas plagued by congested airwaves; supporters of current ownership cap say it encourages competition by preventing large companies from acquiring most of spectrum in given geographic area (M)

headline: Missile Impasse: The Shape of the Deal
abstract: In the end, neither President Bush, nor President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia wanted to pull the plug on the relationship they have built in the short season of summitry they started only last June.    After a three-day summit meeting on the Texas prairie where Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin had their most intimate talks since they first laid eyes on each other in Slovenia this summer, it seemed astonishing that there was no advance on the main issue that divides them -- how to structure a new framework for strategic arms that will bind the United States and Russia well beyond their terms of office.

headline: U.S. Widens Search For Terrorist Assets
abstract: The Bush administration gave the Treasury Department authority to seize assets of 22 suspected terrorist groups, including two Muslim organizations, Hamas and Hezbollah. The move broadened the antiterror campaign beyond Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda, and signaled the administration's growing confidence in the stability of the antiterror coalition.     Several Arab nations have urged a narrow focus on Mr. bin Laden, and some State Department officials worried that yesterday's move could undermine the coalition.

headline: Sharon Makes Apology
abstract: Israeli leader Ariel Sharon's apology for saying US risks appeasing Arab nations noted

headline: Officials Predict Upturn in Unstable South Korean Economy
abstract: Bank of Korea governor, Chon Chol Hwan, and Finance Min Jin Nyum both predict South Korea's economy will grow by 4 percent in 2002; Bank of Korea says gross domestic product rose 1.8 percent in third quarter from 2001 period; Jin says government will be unable to balance budget for at least another year because of efforts to spur economy (M)

headline: Nepal Rebels End Cease-Fire, Carrying Out Wave of Attacks
abstract: At least 36 police officers and soldiers were killed as Maoist rebels ended their four-month cease-fire with a wave of attacks.

headline: A growing list of airlines resume image advertising in the aftermath of Sept. 11.
abstract: Delta Air Lines is set to join growing list of large carriers to return to image advertising, with revamped version of its pre-Sept 11 campaign; resumption of image compaigns is important to airlines as way of preserving brand equity as they struggle to reverse steep sales slump after terrorist attacks and to media companies, which have lost tens of millions of dollars in previously reliable revenue; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Belize: Hurricane Imperils Coastal Areas
abstract: Thousands of Belize City residents are evacuated in anticipation of hurricane threatening coastal areas of Belize, Guatemala and Honduras; photo (S)

headline: Powell Tries to Ease Tension As Kashmir Pressure Builds
abstract: State Sec Colin L Powell phones Pakistani leader Pervez Musharraf and Indian Min Jaswant Singh twice each to urge them to calm tensions mounting since terrorist raid on India's Parliament; says State Department has added Pakistan-based Lashkar-e-Taiba (Army of the Pure) and Jaish-e-Muhammad (Army of Muhammad) to its list of terrorist organizations and hopes to work with India and Pakistan to shut them down; appeal comes amid largest military buildup in years along 2000-mile border; Indian army cancels parades set for several major cities because of buildup; State Department says Lashkar-e-Taiba has links to Al Qaeda and has gotten funds from Osama bin Laden; map; photos (M)

headline: Restructuring Will Make I.N.S. Dual Focus Agency
abstract: Attorney General John D. Ashcroft said today that the Immigration and Naturalization Service was being restructured to better serve law-abiding immigrants and keep out terrorists and troublemakers.

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Media Acquisition
abstract: World Business Briefing: Australia: Media Acquisi

headline: In Village Where Civilians Died, Anger Cannot Be Buried
abstract: Tiny remote village of Madoo, Afghanistan, grieves for 55 civilians killed by US bombs December 1; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Infineon Posts Wider Loss
abstract: Infineon says its loss widened to 523 million euros ($468 million) in quarter ended Sept 30; graph (S)

headline: Burger King Names McCaffery Ratner
abstract: Burger King Names McCaffery Ratner The Burger King Corporation in Miami, part of Diageo, has named McCaffery Ratner Gottlieb & Lane in New York to handle several project assignments including product advertising and the development of local and national promotions centered on music and radio. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Moderate Muslims Fear Their Message Is Being Ignored
abstract: Since the September  attacks, Al Azhar  the revered mosque, the distinguished university, the leading voice of the Sunni Muslim establishment -- has renewed with accustomed grace the roles it has played in the world of Islam for more than 1,000 years.    It has sought to advise Muslims around the world that those who kill in the name of Islam are nothing more than heretics. It has sought to guide, to reassure Westerners against any clash of civilizations.

headline: Gauging the Power Of the Drug Lobby
abstract: Matthew Smith letter defends utilization of lobbyists by pharmaceutical industry (Nov 4 article)

headline: Floats Like a Butterfly, Eats Gas Like a Buick
abstract: H

headline: Thank You, Tech Support
abstract: Nancy Ross letter comments on Sept 13 article on computer tech support

headline: Do All Airlines Deserve A Taxpayer Rescue?
abstract: There is debate over whether all airlines should receive federal loan guarantees because of decline in air travel after Sept 11; lawmakers insist that taxpayers should not prop up airlines already destined to fail, but it is extremely difficult to determine in industry where airlines can fly through multiple bankruptcies and still find success; pressure from state and national politicians to make sure their home airlines survive is so enormous that it may be difficult for panel, known as Air Transportation Stabilization Board, to deny guarantee to any applicant; America West chairman, W Douglas Parker, says his carrier will apply for loan guarantees despite fact that business has picked up since terrorist attacks; photo (M)

headline: DANAHER IS PAYING $325 MILLION FOR MARCONI BUSINESS
abstract: Danaher Corp agrees to buy Marconi PLC's Commerce Systems division for $325 million to expand sales of environmental-testing products and services (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: No Agreement In Refugee Talks
abstract: Nepal and Bhutan, two Himalayan nations that are among the world's poorest, did not manage to settle a longstanding dispute over refugees in two days of talks but the Nepalese Foreign Ministry said that the countries had agreed to continue discussions. About 100,000 Hindus fled mostly Bhuddist Bhutan about a decade ago and settled in United Nations-sponsored camps in Nepal.     Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

headline: Music Unit And Movies Will Receive More Scrutiny
abstract: the operations: music unit and movies will r

headline: Northwest Reduces Fares as Much as 25%
abstract: Northwest Airlines cuts some advance-purchase fares aimed at leisure travelers by 25 percent in bid to revive passenger demand (S)

headline: Suitors Line Up to Compete For Cable TV Unit at AT&T
abstract: Bids are due from competing suitors of AT&T's cable television division, largest US cable TV operation, with 14.4 million customers; AOL Time Warner, Comcast and Cox Communications are expected to submit formal offers; photo (M)

headline: PRODUCTION FLAWS DELAY TWO NEW DRUGS FROM LILLY
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co say FDA regulators are not satisfied with company's efforts to correct quality control problems and are continuing to delay introduction of two new drugs--Zyprexa and Forteo (S)

headline: Dow Jones Says Net Meets Estimates, but 4th Quarter Looks Weak
abstract: Dow Jones & Co earned $16.7 million in third quarter, compared to loss of $33.9 million year earlier; sales dropped 21 percent, to $397.6 million; company says fourth-quarter profit will miss analysts' forecasts (M)

headline: Venezuela Doesn't See 'Carlos' as a Terrorist
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez's government says Venezuela does not consider Venezuelan-born assassin Carlos, Illich Ramirez Sanchez, a terrorist because he did not commit crimes in Venezuela; assassin is jailed for life in France; Venezuelan ministers also question US evidence linking Osama bin Laden to Sept 11 terrorist attacks and use of force against bin Laden in Afghanistan (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Granada's Profit Falls
abstract: Granada PLC reports earnings of 98 million pounds ($139 million) from continuing operations in its last fiscal year, compared with 105 million pounds a year earlier; reports loss of 132 million pounds, however, when investments and special charges are included; that compares with profit of 550 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Toshiba Scraps A Phone Venture
abstract: toshiba scraps a phone v

headline: Saudis Assail 'Media Blitz' Against Them In the West
abstract: Saudi Arabian defense minister Prince Sultan and ambassador to Washington Prince Bandar bin Sultan denounce what they call unfair and biased Western news coverage; they say media portrays Saudi Arabia as teaching hatred of non-Muslims in its schools and of being supportive of Osama bin Laden; Prince Bandar, in interview on CNBC, says Saudis condemn Sept 11 attacks and consider bin Laden and his followers evil, but Western media refuse to convey this in their coverage (M)

headline: Severance Packages Growing, Survey Finds
abstract: Lee Hecht Harrison survey of layoff policies finds nearly 60 percent of 925 companies surveyed have formulas in place to give top executives two weeks of severance for each year of service, up from 40 percent three years ago (S)

headline: A Double Tax Break May Not Be Dead Yet
abstract: IRS moves quickly to close loophole that Philip J Holthouse, Los Angeles accountant, has exploited to double tax exemption permitted on capital gains realized on sale of primary residence; ruling is expected to be challenged in court (S)

headline: Enron Paid $55 Million For Bonuses
abstract: Enron Corp reportedly paid out $55 million in bonuses to about 500 employees just days before it filed for bankruptcy and laid off 4,000 people; Enron spokesman confirms bonuses, describing them as 'retention incentives' for crucial employees; bankruptcy experts say payments are almost certain to be closely scrutinized--and probably challenged--by Enron's creditors; Labor Department opens investigation into how Enron managed its employees' 401(k) retirement plans; says employees lost up to 90 percent of value of their accounts; Labor Sec Elaine L Chao comments; Enron spokesman Mark Palmer defends bonus payments as necessary; Amalgamated Bank, activist shareholder, files lawsuit accusing 29 Enron officers and directors of engaging in 'massive insider trading' and making 'false and misleading' statements about company's financial performance while selling about $1.1 billion worth of stock over last three years (M)

headline: LTV Seems on the Verge of a Shutdown
abstract: LTV Corp will soon shut down after more than half century in business, barring government-supplied loan; company will ask bankruptcy judge to end its labor contract if help does not arrive by Dec 19; shutdown would leave about 70,000 retirees and recent employees with no or reduced pensions and health care benefits, and force government to pick up at least some of costs that remain; pension costs are at least $2 billion; LTV's management has concluded that its losses, $2 million per day, are simply too large; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Cuts Profit Forecast
abstract: World Business Briefin

headline: Juniper Posts Loss but Exceeds Wall St. Forecast
abstract: Juniper Networks posts loss of $29.7 million for its fiscal third quarter compared with earnings of $58.1 million year earlier; revenue was $201.7 million (M)

headline: Toshiba Will Abandon Commodity Chip Business
abstract: Toshiba Corp abandons commodity memory chip business to concentrate on custom-designed chips, where profit margins are higher; will sell plant in US to Micro Technologies and scrap proposed alliance with Infineon Technologies; is considering whether to halt production of dynamic random access memory chip in Japan by June 2002; photo (M)

headline: Bayer Halves Price for Cipro, But Rivals Offer Drugs Free
abstract: Three big pharmaceutical companies offer large quantities of their antibiotics free if Food and Drug Administration will approve their use for treatment of anthrax; Johnson & Johnson offers its Levaquin, Bristol-Myers Squibb offers its Tequin, and GlaxoSmithKline says it will provide two of its older medicines for anthrax; Tequin and Levaquin said to be chemically very similar to Cipro; offer of free drugs comes days after Bayer agrees to sell 100 million tablets at nearly half price; executives in generic drug industry say Bayer is still at least breaking even and may even be making large profit; Bayer refuses to discuss whether it is making profit on deal; Eli Lilly and Pfizer have offered to provide drugs at cost (M)

headline: Blair Says He's Seen Proof of bin Laden Role
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair says that he has seen incontrovertible evidence linking Osama bin Laden to Sept 11 attacks on America; statement is intended to offset doubt about whether such evidence exists; Gordon Brown, chancellor of exchequer, announces that Britain will take lead in freezing assets in campaign against bin Laden; photo (M)

headline: The Sandwich Generation Takes a New Gulp
abstract: James Schembari column on situation of 'sandwich' generation, his, which must often care for both aged parents and adult children, many of whom have recently been laid off; drawing (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Bank of America chooses Omnicom Group division Doremus to handle its business-to-business account (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit For Phone Gear Maker
abstract: Marconi Spa reports operating profit of 5 million pounds in second quarter, after reporting loss of 227 million pounds in first quarter (S)

headline: CONTRACTORS TOLD TO END WORK ON FIBER-OPTIC NETWORK
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc, which posts unexpected third-quarter loss earlier this week, tells contractors to stop work on its fiber-optic network to pare costs (S)

headline: American Express Will Cut Up to 6,500 From Payroll
abstract: American Express Co, which has laid off 7,700 employees, plans to eliminate additional 5,500 to 6,500 jobs; its slumping travel division will bear brunt of effort to curb expenses; photo (M)

headline: Campbell Profit Falls
abstract: Campbell Soup Co says its fiscal first-quarter profit fell to $171 million from $204 million year earlier; sales rose 9.4 percent, to $1.73 billion (S)

headline: A New Suit Against Online Music Sites
abstract: More than 30 music and film studios file copyright-infringement lawsuit aimed at new generation of music- and movie-sharing Internet sites, including MusicCity.com, Grokster and Consumer Empowerment BV; MusicCity, subsidiary of Screamcast, says it will vigorously contest lawsuit (M)

headline: Mideast Cease-Fire: Who Will Be the First to Scrap It?
abstract: Mounting tit-for-tap violence continues to impede Pres Bush's efforts to secure long-term Isrsaeli-Palestinian peace; many believe only reluctance of each side to be first to end talks keeps Israelis and Palestinians from scrapping truce; Israeli tanks bombard Beit Lahia, Gaza Strip, while Israeli bulldozers ravage area farmland, in response to fatal attack on Israeli settlement of Alei Sinai; Palestinian snipers fire into crowd of thousands of Jewish worshippers, Hebron; map; photo (M)

headline: New Legal Powers, Fresh Anthrax Worries, Resilient Taliban
abstract: Overview of situation in wake of Sept 11 attacks on New York and Washington, including highlights of new anti-terrorist legislation, anthrax worries and Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld's concerns about whether Osama bin Laden can be captured or killed (M)

headline: Prilosec Infringement Suit Starts
abstract: Opening statements are made in trial of patent-infringement lawsuit brought by AstraZeneca, maker of Prilosec, against four generic drug makers -- Andrx Group, Pharmaceutical Resources Inc, Dr Reddy's Laboratories and Kremers Urban Development Company (S)

headline: Union Is Subject of Vote At Nissan Tennessee Plants
abstract: Nissan Motor Co workers in Smyrna, Tenn, vote more than 2 to 1 to reject United Automobile Workers; union has never been able to organize in plant operated solely by foreign automaker; victory was much needed for UAW, whose membership has shrunk to less than 700,000 from 1.5 million over last two decades (M)

headline: A Big Purchase Of Saks Shares
abstract: Orient Star Holdings, affiliate of Carlos Slim Helu, wealthiest investor in Mexico, acquired 578,000 shares of Saks Inc last month; share price has fallen 52 percent since Sept 11 terrorist attacks (S)

headline: S.E.C. Seeks to Force Enron Executive to Testify in Inquiry
abstract: The S.E.C. asked a federal judge to force Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, to testify in an S.E.C. investigation into the accounting at the giant energy company.

headline: Memories Swaddled In Packing Peanuts
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on buying glass Christmas tree ornaments online; drawing (M)

headline: As Fiscal Engine Stalls, the Mechanics Line Up
abstract: As Congress struggles to pass stimulus package, debate breaks out among economists over whether $75 billion to $100 billion that House and Senate seem willing to spend will be enough to pull economy out of a downturn; with declaration expected as early as Nov 26 that economy is officially in recession, some experts talk about needing fiscal package that starts at $100 billion and ranges up to $400 billion; photo (M)

headline: Boeing Tries to Reassure Seoul On Plans for an Advanced Jet
abstract: Boeing Co, stung by losing to Lockheed Martin in competition to build the Joint Strike Fighter for the United States, moves quickly to reassure South Korean officials that it is still ready to build advanced fighter jets for overseas customers; Boeing is competing with Dassault Aviation of France, mulitnational Eurofighter consortium and Rosoboronexport, Russian state trading company, for $4 billion, 40-jet order from South Korea (M)

headline: New Economy; In an era of tighter security, how much cyberfreedom are we willing to surrender?
abstract: Legislation before Congress would assure private companies that if they share information with government about their experiences with hackers and other types of cyberattacks, that information would be shielded from public disclosure; proponents say such assurances are needed to prompt companies to divulge data that could help in building national defense for Internet; critics says legislation is unnecessary and could block average Americans' access to information crucial to assessing public policy; drawing (M)

headline: Fire Apparently Spread In Sunken Russian Sub
abstract: fire apparently sprea

headline: Alcatel Plans To Eliminate 10,000 Jobs
abstract: Alcatel will eliminate additional 10,000 jobs and expects to report loss of $4.5 billion for year; work force will have been reduced by 30 percent since January 2001, down to 77,000 employees from 110,000; company reports loss of $502.7 million in third quarter, compared with profit of $268 million year earlier (M)

headline: Business; Champagne Houses Waiting Nervously For the Corks to Pop
abstract: Sales of champagne and other sparkling wines drop in US after Sept 11 terrorist attacks; LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, parent of numerous famous champagne manufacturers, issues third profit warning; industry is unsure about traditional New Year's Eve sales prospects; photos; chart (M)

headline: Reassessment After the Unthinkable Happens
abstract: Crisis management has become center of strategic thinking at businesses across US in aftermath of September 11 terrorist attacks as many executives now realize that disasters are not as hypothetical as they once seemed; often called business-contingency planning, it encompasses everything from protection of electronic data to coping with catastrophes that threaten very survival of company; Bob Neihoff, who handles contingeny planning at Oppenheimer Funds, describes coping with terrorist attacks on World Trade Center, where company had headquarters; photos (M)

headline: Trade Talks Hinge on Finesse of U.S.
abstract: US trade envoy Robert Z Zoellick plays key role at world trade talks in Qatar, trying to assert firm US leadership and foster openness while pursuing narrower American interests; photo (M)

headline: High Cost of Being Well: Benefits at a Premium; Employees Will Pay A Sharp Increase For Insurance Plans
abstract: Amount employees pay for health insurance is rising again after few years of stable or even declining costs and is expected to go up even more sharply next year; small companies, which face higher charges, require their employees to pay greater share of total cost of health insurance; besides higher monthly premiums, many employees will also pay more of cost of their prescription drugs; some plans are also raising deductibles and co-payments for doctor visits and even adding co-payments for hospital stays; Martin Blank, senior partner at Accent Food Services in Austin, Tex, says family coverage for its employees will rise 57 percent; David Scott Sandoval, who works for University of Southern Colorado, says his monthly premium for family health coverage will increase by $291 in December; graphs; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Starbucks Stock
abstract: Shares in Starbucks Coffee Japan surge on first day of trading; company will use $149 million (US) it raises to add 180 new shops to its 300-store chain over next three years (S)

headline: Can an Aging Michael Jordan Still Lift Brands He Endorses?
abstract: Michael Jordan's continuing appeal as marketing superstar assessed in light of his return to basketball with Washington Wizards at possibly diminished physical level; he earned some $35 million in retirement last year from endorsements, down from career peak of $47 million; photo (M)

headline: Peace Talks To End War In Congo Finally Begin
abstract: Long-awaited Congo peace talks open in Addis Ababa, amid doubts about its ability to end war (S)

headline: Stocks Post Solid Rally
abstract: Stocks rose sharply, offering a glimmer of hope that the extreme economic slowdown reported immediately after the attacks may have been overstated. Page C1.

headline: Dell Rebounds After a 2nd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Rebounding from a loss in the July quarter, the Dell Computer Corporation reported a third-quarter profit of $429 million yesterday. Its earnings fell by a third from the period a year ago but edged past Wall Street's estimates.    Dell, the world's leading vendor of personal computers, which account for about half its business, continued to drive down its selling prices and take market share from competitors. Dell was the only major PC vendor to grow in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, analysts said.

headline: Starcom Chosen In Disney Review
abstract: Walt Disney Co names Starcom North America, Bcom3 Group subsidiary, to handle its media planning and buying account (S)

headline: Imports Climb At Biggest Ports
abstract: Imports through ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif, two largest in United States, rise in October from year-ealier period as shipments of toys, clothing, consumer electronics and other holiuday merchandise arrive; imports to Port of Los Angeles, country's largest, rise 5.9 percent to 265,700 containers; shipments to Long Beach rise 1.1 percnt to 238,200 containers (S)a

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: 'Ruthless' Pursuit Of Embezzlers
abstract: South Korean government bans 100 corporate and bank officials from leaving country as it investigates embezzlement of more than $5 billion pumped into ailing companies (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Usenet Archive Is Posted On Web
abstract: Google, search engine, restores decades of early Internet history by putting archive of 700 million Usenet newsgroup messages dating back to 1981 online (S)

headline: People
abstract: Wally Heyward is named chief executive at Relay Sports and Events Marketing (S)

headline: Attacks at Hubs Could Disrupt Phone Lines
abstract: Public safety experts and telecommunications executives worry about possibility of attacks on telephone system, century-old network of copper wires and newer fiber optic strands that wind their way through critical but vulnerable hubs; service for more than 30 million phone lines in largest cities could be interrupted if there were successful physical attack on 100 or so most important central offices; worries about phone network's exposure to saboteurs has grown since Sept 11, when collapse of World Trade Center caused nearby switching operations in one of nation's busiest central offices to shut down temporarily; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose as United States stocks gained, reflecting expectations the nation's economy will rebound before the rest of the world. In New York, the euro settled at 87.97 cents, down from 88.43 cents.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graph plots decline of dollar against euro in New York after Conference Board reported consumer confidence index dropped to its lowest level in more than seven years; euro settled at 90.50 cents, up from 90.32

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Petroleum Purchase
abstract: BG Group of Britain acquires oil and natural gas fields of Enron Corp in India for $338 million (S)

headline: Treasury Market Is Faced With Incomplete Trades
abstract: US Treasury market is still faced with billions of dollars of incomplete trades since terrorist attacks; traders say one result is some short-term financial pain for big investors, unwillingness to trade in part of market and some difficulty for investors who want to offset some risk by hedging with Treasury securities (M)

headline: S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING NAVIGANT CONSULTING
abstract: SEC is investigating whether Navigant Consulting violated securities laws in 1998 and 1999; Navigant shares reached record $54.25 in Sept 1999 before newspaper Barron's questioned Chicago-based management consulting company's reported growth rate; stock fell 45 percent on Nov 22, 1999 when chief exec, Robert Maher, was ousted and company said it was reviewing $17 million in loans to him and other execs (S)

headline: A New Western Focus on Russia, 'Where the Oil Is'
abstract: Russia's output of crude oil, driven by handful of production-oriented oil companies like Yukos, creates big problems for OPEC in its struggle to contain worldwide oil glut that is depressing prices; Yukos hopes to increase output by about a third, to 1.6 million barrels a day, by 2005; has attracted Western production experts to help realize ambitions to become major international oil company; photo; chart (M)

headline: Chechen Refugee Camps: Once a Haven, but After Two Years Still Not a Home
abstract: Russia's war against separatist rebels in Chechnya has been going on for more than two years, and thousands of Chechens remain housed in primitive refugee camps, afraid to go home or no longer having home to return to; scene in Znamenskoye camp described; photo (M)

headline: Vanity Fair's Depiction Upsets Capitol Hill Women
abstract: An article in Vanity Fair about three flirtatious young women on Capitol Hill has infuriated some young female staff members in Washington D.C.

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Indians Occupy Ranches
abstract: Members of Brazil's Pataxo Ha-Ha-Hae tribe occupy eight ranches in Bahia to protest allegedly illegal occupation of their ancestral lands by cocoa and cattle interests (S)

headline: Irish Rebury 10 Republicans Hanged by British in 1920's
abstract: Ireland buries remains of 10 Irish Republican Army volunteers who were executed by British during country's war of independence 80 years ago, with display of both solemnity and pomp; state funeral, only 13th in country's history since independence, brings much of Dublin to standstill for more than six hours as thousands line streets; photo (M)

headline: Spain to Study U.S. Requests To Extradite Terror Suspects
abstract: Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar meets with Pres Bush at White House and says he will weigh any United States request to extradite eight men charged with roles in Sept 11 terrorist attacks; both leaders put polite face on demand by Spanish officials that men be tried by civilian court, not military tribunal; laud each other for fighting terrorism; Bush earlier met with United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan, who seeks better security for aid workers trying to feed starving civilians in Afghanistan; Sec Colin L Powell and aid group officials attended meeting; photo (M)

headline: Afghan Leaders Say Agreement Is Near on Shape of Security Force
abstract: Afghan foreign minister Dr Abdullah Abdullah says talks on shape and duration of international security force are nearing end, although various factions continue to oppose having large contingent in country; photo (M)

headline: Amgen-Immunex Deal Spurs Forecasts About Others
abstract: Amgen's $16 billion purchase of Immunex is largest of spate of acquisitions sweeping biotechnology industry and portends change in structure of industry and its relationship to shareholders; some believe that more consolidations are bound to occur; photo (M)

headline: Royal Baby Is Due Soon, And Apathy Grips Japan
abstract: When Japan's stuffy and secretive Imperial Household Agency coyly announced at a rare news conference in April that Crown Princess Masako was ''showing signs of pregnancy,'' the news was briefly, but richly, celebrated.    A smiling prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, then new to his office, said that for Japan it was ''the first bright news in a long while.'' There were huge headlines in all the newspapers and toasts proffered by everyone from television personalities to members of Parliament.

headline: It's the Cars, Not the Tires, That Squeal
abstract: Freedom of open road is being compromised as more and more intelligent systems, known generally as telematics, are added to cars to help drivers find their way, pay tolls, get help in emergencies and otherwise ease their life; technology in the offing will even allow state to monitor violations of emissions standards remotely; some privacy advocates fear that incentives to share information will only grow, along with possibility that tracking data could fall into wrong hands or even be sold; federal regulations protecting information gathered from telematics are unclear; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Warns Zimbabwe That Next Year's Election Must Be Fair
abstract: Bush administration official Walter H Kansteiner meets with Zimbabwe's ministers of finance and foreign affairs and warns them that time is running out to create environment for fair national elections next year; Kansteiner's visit follows overwhelming vote in House of Representatives for bill offering Zimbabwe economic incentives if it eases recent authoritarian moves but urges Pres Bush to punish Zimbabwe if it fails to act; Pres Robert Mugabe, in office since 1980, says national elections will take place in Mar; he faces major re-election challenge from Movement for Democratic Change; his government's recent crackdown on opposition supporters and efforts to limit international monitoring of elections have alarmed many countries (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Many Are Using Internet To Seek Spiritual Aid
abstract: Survey conducted by Pew Internet and American Life Project finds that 25 percent of adult Internet users, about 28 million people, have gone online to find religious and spiritual material (M)

headline: Food Drops Go Awry, Damaging Several Homes
abstract: Several wooden crates full of relief food, dropped by parachute from American planes, smash into at least four houses in village near Herat, Afghanistan; no is hurt; parachute and food crate also damage centuries-old shrine; photo (M)

headline: Nigeria Army Said to Massacre Hundreds of Civilians
abstract: Nigerian Army reportedly massacres hundreds of civilians in eastern state of Benue in probably worst violations by military since country ended nearly 16 years of military rule in 1999 and voted in civilian government; attacks, coming at time of widespread ethnic and religious violence, raises issue of whether Pres Olusegun Obasanjo, former military ruler, has full control over army, which has history of coups in Nigeria's four decades of independence; army, which has denied attacks, was apparently retaliating for killing of 19 soldiers in area; map; photo (M)

headline: Trade Panel Backs Steel Makers, Enabling Broad Sanctions
abstract: International Trade Commission, in ruling sought by Pres Bush, finds United States steel makers have suffered serious injury from foreign competition; ruling will let Bush impose hefty duties or quotas on steel imports; United Steelworkers of America president Leo W Gerard hails ruling; free trade advocates score it (M)

headline: New Campaigns
abstract: American Stock Exchange is introducing advertising campaign carrying theme 'Opportunity, made fresh daily'; campaign is by New York office of DDB Worldwide (S)

headline: Profit Is Down 33% at the Big Board
abstract: New York Stock Exchange says third-quarter profit fell 33 percent; reports income from operations of $17.3 million, compared with $25.9 million year earlier and $19.9 million in second quarter; revenue rose 2.5 percent, to $217.4 million (S)c

headline: New Government Wants End to U.S. Bombing
abstract: KABUL, Dec 28 (Reuters) - Afghanistan is demanding the United States halt its bombing, possibly within days, since almost all remaining border hideouts of the Taliban and Osama bin Laden have been destroyed, a Defence Ministry spokesman said on Friday.

headline: Air Attacks Are Greeted Quietly in Pakistan
abstract: News of the American air attack may have burst across the United States, but here in this city near the Afghanistan border it traveled slowly and then mostly stayed indoors.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Where Donald Trump sees trouble in Atlantic City, bondholders see an effort to cut a deal.
abstract: Donald Trump says he may not make about $90 million in interest payments due on his Atlantic City casinos in November because debt-saddled casinos are confronting increased competition in weak economy; some bondholders do not take his threat seriously, suspecting that he may be trying to take advantage of decline in bond prices to cut favorable deal for himself; photo (M)

headline: Illegal Immigrants Bring Halt to Channel Tunnel Traffic
abstract: The Channel Tunnel was closed to freight traffic for 11 hours today after dozens of asylum-seekers broke into a freight yard near Calais and tried to hide on trains bound for Britain.

headline: Reliant Energy Quarterly Net Falls 25%
abstract: Reliant Energy Inc says third-quarter net income fell to $290 million from $389 million year earlier; revenue rose to $12.5 billion from $9.5 billion (S)

headline: Deal Salvages Idea of Online Private Equity
abstract: Assets of Offroad Capital, failed online investment bank, have been bought by owners of New York Private Placement Exchange, privately run electronic trading network for shares of companies that are not public; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: GENERAL MILLS EXPECTS EARNINGS DECLINE
abstract: General Mills Inc says its earnings in quarter ending Nov 25 will fall; says it will cut 1,000 jobs in connection with acquisition of Diageo PLC's Pillsbury operations (S)

headline: Czechs Fear That U.S. Radio Station Is Target in Their Midst
abstract: US-led airstrikes against Afghanistan have raised fears among some Czech government officials that Radio Free Europe, based in Prague since 1995, could become target for terrorism; top officials in recent days have suggested that radio service should move out of city center; Jiri Ruzicka, director of country's domestic security service, says Radio Free Europe is building that creates security risk for capital; similar warnings have come from prime minister, defense minister and head of country's foreign intelligence service Tom Dine, radio service's president, says he discussed issue with Czech officials, but none specifically requested that service move (M)

headline: Rebels to Get American Envoy
abstract: Bush administation, showing impatience over efforts to replace Taliban in Afghanistan, names veteran diplomat James F Dobbins ambassador to Afghan opposition (S)

headline: NATO Says 4 Arrested Near Sarajevo Are Suspected of Terror Activities
abstract: Spokesman for NATO-led peacekeeping force in Bosnia says four people have been detained near Sarajevo on suspicion of terrorist-related activity; declines to give details about those arrested, or say whether authorities acted on request or information from United States government in wake of Sept 11 attacks on New York and Washington; authorities in Muslim-Croat federation that makes up half of Bosnia have been working since Sept 11 to dispel any suspicion of offering haven to Islamic extremists (M)

headline: Pakistani Police Kill 3 Protesters and a 13-Year-Old
abstract: Three anti-American protesters and 13-year-old boy are shot dead by Pakistani police officers as demonstrators try to storm police station in Kuchlak, town near Afghan border; deaths come on second day of violent protests against American-led airstrikes on Afghanistan; longer air attacks on Afghanistan continue, greater danger that protests could threaten stability of Pakistan; public opinion poll says 62 percent of Pakistanis oppose involvement in war; photo; map; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: AT&T IS SAID TO BE REQUESTING NEW BIDS FOR CABLE UNIT
