abstract: AT&T asks three companies that are vying to acquire its cable television business to submit new proposals; they are AOL Time Warner, Comcast and Cox Communications (S)

headline: A Mainstay of U.S. Job Creation Is Hit Hard by Sept. 11
abstract: Service sector of US economy, main engine of job creation since World War II, has been dealt powerful blow by events of Sept 11; 111,000 service positions were lost from September to October, out of 619,000 jobs that disappeared overall; decline is sector's largest drop ever; travel-related businesses are particularly hard-hit, as is retail trade; photo (M)

headline: C.I.A. Is Said to Have Sought Help From Syria
abstract: Top CIA official from clandestine-espionage arm of agency met recently with Syrian intelligence officials in Damascus about helping United States investigate and defeat Osama bin Laden's terrorist network; Syria has history of cooperating with and sponsoring Islamic militant groups and may be able to provide insight into connections among Islamic terrorists across Europe and Middle East; substance of discussions between CIA and Syrian officials has not been determined; communications lines have been opened with several other countries that US has accused in past of sponsoring terrorism, such as Libya and Sudan (M)

headline: British Commander Calls Long Ground Raids Likely
abstract: Britain's top military officer said today that ground troops may have to operate in Afghanistan for weeks at a time if they are to ferret out Osama bin Laden.

headline: Death Toll Could Climb in Swiss Alps Tunnel Crash
abstract: Fire continued to rage in the Gotthard Tunnel today, more than a day after an early-morning collision claimed the lives of at least 10 people.

headline: Good at Her Job, She Walked Away
abstract: Michelle Kennedy describes her job at credit card company, where she tried to persuade people who had given up their cards to take them back, and how she finally walked away from job; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Shake-Up At EM.TV
abstract: EM.TV & Merchandising, owner of M

headline: More and More, Other Countries See the War as Solely America's
abstract: Portraits of United States as lonely, self-absorbed bully taking out its rage about Sept 11 terrorist attacks on defenseless Afghanistan are on rise from intellectuals and editorialists around world; more and more, war is being seen abroad as 'America against Osama,' and not as Bush administration portrays it, 'all of us against terrorism'; intense rush of sympathy following Sept 11 seems to have faded everywhere but in Tony Blair, prime minister of Britain who continues to jet around globe to recruit support for cause; photo (M)

headline: Anxious Fate of Kabul, a Coming Showdown and a Busy U.N.
abstract: Overview of day's events in war in Afghanistan: Northern Alliance reportedly descends on capital, Kabul, as foreign ministers and ambassadors grapple with crucial issue of what to do with Afghanistan once Taliban are gone (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Mobile Emergency Response Project
abstract: Aether Systems, which develops software and wireless data products and services, says it will provide federal, state and local officials with hand-held devices enabling them to share information, even as they respond to emergencies; Aether and state officials say device, called PocketBlue, will improve efficiency of homeland defense effort (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Talks End
abstract: Standard Chartered ends talks to buy 75 percent of Egyptian American Bank (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Jospin Inquiry Dropped
abstract: Magistrate, citing lack of evidence, drops probe into charges French Prime Min Lionel Jospin was involved in paying two people for nonexistent jobs at development agency he led before coming to power (S)

headline: Free Music Service Is Expected to Surpass Napster
abstract: Forthcoming data is expected to show that number of people exchanging music on Fast Track network, free service based in Amsterdam, exceeds use of Napster at its peak; record labels assert that Fast Track abets copyright infringement (M)

headline: Indiana Utility Deal
abstract: NiSource Inc, owner of Indiana's largest gas and electric utility, agrees to sell its Indianapolis Water division to City of Indianapolis for $515 million, meeting requirement for federal approval of its acquisition of Columbia Energy Group (S)

headline: TORONTO-DOMINION UNIT WILL BUY STOCK-OPTIONS FIRMS
abstract: toronto-dominion unit will buy stock

headline: JETS POUND TALIBAN SITES A 2ND NIGHT; F.B.I. AGENTS SHIFT ANTITERROR TACTICS
abstract: US military forces pound Taliban targets in Afghanistan for second consecutive day; B-2 stealth bombers flying from US join carrier-based aircraft in strikes as anti-American demonstrations roil Muslim capitals and Bush administration steps up planning to oust Afghan regime; slightly scaled down attacks include Tomahawk cruise missiles and B-1 bombers flying sorties from island of Diego Garcia in Indian Ocean; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, in preliminary assessment, says progress was made toward disabling military airfields and eliminating air defense sites that protect Taliban and Al Qaeda terrorist network of Osama bin Laden; says warplanes attacked Afghan ground forces associated with both Al Qaeda and and Taliban leadership under Mullah Muhammad Omar north of Kabul, where they have been fighting rebel Northern Alliance; British Defense Sec Geoffrey Hoon suggests first phase of attacks may be over within days; widespread demonstrations against US attacks in Muslum capitals and especially in Pakistan discussed; maps; Pres Bush seeks to bolster antiterrorism forces at home by formally installing former Pennsylvania Gov Tom Ridge as head of new cabinet post for homeland defense; maps (M)

headline: Russians Are Unfazed by Anthrax, a Common Rural Problem
abstract: Russians share Americans' fear of suffering bioterror attack of anthrax, despite fact that anthrax is one of life's risks in rural parts of country, where residents are regularly exposed to farm animals that carry the disease; 55 percent of 2,221 callers to Moscow radio station's call-in poll say they fear becoming targets; experts say Russians, like Americans, have more to fear from mass hysteria; Dr Veniamin L Cherkassky, Russia's leading expert on anthrax, is highly skeptical of anthrax's potential to deliver terrorist apocalypse (M)

headline: Support for bin Laden Is Still High in Pakistan
abstract: Glossy posters of Osama bin Laden atop a white stallion or brandishing a Kalashnikov are selling as fast as they are printed in Quetta's chaotic bazaar. Osama T-shirts and chocolates wrapped in his bearded face are popular, too.    Support for Mr. bin Laden and sympathy for ordinary Afghans being subjected to withering American bombing remain high in Pakistan, particularly here in the border region, which is dominated by tribal loyalties and religious firebrands.

headline: CLOTHING RETAILER SEEKS TO CLOSE 48 STORES
abstract: Casual Male Corp, biggest specialty retailer of large-sized men's clothing, asks bankruptcy judge for permission to close 48 unprofitable stores and holds sales at locations (S)

headline: Business Inventories in U.S. Fell Only 0.1% During August
abstract: Commerce Department reports business inventories fell 0.1 percent in August, smallest drop in seven months; drop in stockpiles, which comes after 0.5 percent decrease in July, brigns their value to $1.18 trillion; graph (M)

headline: The Women, Veils Shed, Demonstrate
abstract: Several hundred Afghan women demonstrate for women's rights, Kabul, first such demonstration in five years; march ends abruptly when Northern Alliance security tells organizers they cannot assure their safety; women vow to march again; some 60 female teachers, students and school directors meet with Ismail Khan, Herat's new leader, to press for immediate resumption of education for girls and greater rights for women; Khan urges women to help counter illiteracy; photo (M)

headline: Gateway Reports Loss of $520 Million in Third Quarter
abstract: Gateway Inc lost $520 million in third quarter compared with profit of $132 million year earlier; sales declined to $1.4 biillion compared with $2.5 billion year ago (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: 'Bloody Sunday' Ruling
abstract: London's High Court rules that 36 British soldiers do not have to go to Londonderry to testify in inquiry into 1972 'Bloody Sunday' clash in which troops killed 14 unarmed protesters; court says soldiers' fear that their lives could be in danger is reasonable (S)

headline: Persuading Audiences To Pay to Listen
abstract: For nation's two producers of satellite radio, XM Satellite Radio Holdings and Sirius Satellite Radio, 2002 will probably answer quetion that will make or break them: are listeners frustrated enough with mainstream radio progamming to pay monthly for bigger selection, much as they now pay for cable television? (M)

headline: Stocks End Session Lower Despite Rate Cut
abstract: Stocks retreated late this afternoon from a modest rally that followed the Federal Reserve's decision to cut short-term interest rates by an expected quarter of a percentage point.

headline: Shanghai Journal; Jiang's a Poet Up There With Mao (on Billboards)
abstract: The words of a poem flashed onto the projection screen at the front of a darkened auditorium of an elementary school here and the teacher, Jiao Feng, asked the more than 40 assembled third graders to identify the author.    ''Grandpa Jiang,'' shouted a 9-year-old wearing the red neckerchief of a Young Pioneer, the Communist Party club that cultivates children as potential party members. Then the class recited, ''Gazing from afar at the guest pine leaning against the heavenly capital peak . . .''

headline: Former Head of Enron Denies Wrongdoing
abstract: Former Enron Corp chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling denies wrongdoing, interview; says he was stunned by Enron's collapse in wake of his Aug resignation and by disclosure that Andrew S Fastow, his former right-hand man, made over $30 million from dealings with investment partnerships linked to Enron; says he never invested in such partnerships, which he says were Fastow's idea (M)

headline: Okavango Delta Journal; A Sleepy River's People Fight to Keep Old Ways
abstract: Okavango Delta Journal on how Wayeyi people in swamps of northern Botswana are battling against erosion of rural traditions and indigenous languages as urbanization and assimilation creep relentlessly across African continent; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Utility To Buy British Network
abstract: Electricite de France will buy power distribution network and coal-fired power generator in Britain from TXU Corp of Dallas for around $2.4 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Trinidad And Tobago: Elections Set
abstract: Prime Min Basdeo Panday calls for national elections in Trinidad on December 10, following months of political discord (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Marsh & McLennan Revises Health Benefits for Families  Soon after Sept. 11, Marsh & McLennan announced that it would provide the families of 295 employees killed in the attack with a year of full health insurance benefits. Senior executives considered the offer generous, but family members argued that a company with $10 billion in annual revenues could surely do more.    Marsh & McLennan has decided to extend health coverage to the families for three years. But it will pay for the coverage not from corporate accounts, but from the MMC Victims Relief Fund, a charity established by the company to help provide for the families of the 295 employees who died. [Page A1.]

headline: Bethlehem Steel Financing
abstract: Bethlehem Steel Corp wins bankruptcy court approval of $450 million credit line (S)

headline: Analysts Scale Back Earnings Estimates
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston analysts reduce earnings estimates for 2001 and 2002 for Interpublic Group of Companies, Omnicom Group and WPP Group (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Parts Maker Lays Off 1,600
abstract: Kemet Corp, maker of electronic parts for cellphones and hand-held computers, will lay off 1,600 workers, its second job reduction of 2001; sales are down by two-thirds (S)

headline: A Sophomore in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Rachel, American teenager living with her parents in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, talks about what it is like living abroad following terrorist attacks on US on Sept 11 (S)

headline: Qualcomm Plans Globalstar Airborne System
abstract: Qualcomm Inc, citing Sept 11 hijackings, says it has developed airborne communications systems that can be used to improve existing aviation safety services; technology functions on Globalstar Telecommunications' money-losing satellite phone system, allowing two-way communications between aircraft and ground-based network; Qualcomm owns minority stake in Globalstar (M)

headline: Business; When a Workplace Dispute Goes Very Public
abstract: Golf tournaments, auto races and other high-profile events sponsored by Merrill Lynch have been visited since May by airplanes towing banners reading 'Merrill Lynch Discriminates Against Women,' a protest organized by former and current women brokers who are not satisfied with how Merrill Lynch has acted in three years since settling their class-action lawsuit against company; lawsuit alleged that office managers favored male brokers by assigning them larger and more active accounts; Merrill says it has investigated distributions questioned by brokers and remedied any that it considered inconsistent with company policy; photo (M)

headline: The Legacy of the Taliban Is a Sad and Broken Land
abstract: Afghanistan left behind by fleeing Taliban is sad and broken land; in five years that Taliban ruled, one million refugees joined million others who already left and refused to come home, and six million Afghans, quarter of country, are unable to find enough food; real legacy of Taliban rule lies deeper; journey around country reveals deep psychological wounds in people still struggling with torment of government regarded by many as oppressive and strange; nearly one in eight families in Kabul is believed to be headed by widows, and most have children; under Taliban, they were not permitted to work; Taliban flourished outside gaze of world's remaining superpower, United States, finally giving succor to terrorists that would invite its own doom; photos (L)

headline: Tora Bora: Deep Ravines Hide Many Enemies
abstract: Trek through vaulting peaks, deep ravines and pristine beauty of Tora Bora shows more complicated denouement of Al Qaeda than Afghan forces claim; bodies of Al Qaeda fighters are hauled out of caves and anti-Taliban forces do control most of terrain, but they move about warily because smattering of Al Qaeda troops still loom, and because they fight among each other; one officer, Faqir Muhammad, defies commander and guides two reporters into remote landscape, led by nervous soldiers with machine guns; photos; troops describe fierce combat that rooted out Al Qaeda (M)

headline: Seeing Digital Pictures On Screen Without a PC
abstract: Eastman Kodak introduces two new digital cameras whose memory cards can be pulled out and plugged into DVD player for viewing on television sets; photo (S)

headline: A Bankruptcy Filing Might Be the Best Remaining Choice
abstract: Enron Corp may have little choice but to enter bankruptcy after collapse of possible deal with Dynegy Inc; some of Enron's most valuable assets are already pledged to lenders, and it is unclear what might be left for holders of its debt and equity and which obligations could be satisfied (M)

headline: Beware Calling A Bottom Too Soon
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column notes that stocks have rebounded since Sept 11, but warns against prematurely declaring that market has hit its bottom; graph (M)

headline: Reed Buys Riverdeep Stake
abstract: Reed Elsevier acquires stake of about 3.8 percent in Riverdeep Group for $25 million; Riverdeep and Reed's Harcourt Education Group will develop digital educational products for kindergarten through 12th grade (S)

headline: In West Bank And Israel, Another Day Of Violence
abstract: Violence erupts on several fronts between Israeli forces and Palestinians as troops retain tight hold on six Palestinian-ruled towns; therre are clashes in Jerusalem, Nablus and Lebanese border and gun battles in Bethlehem; maps; photo (M)

headline: U.S. BROADCASTING $25 MILLION OFFER TO FIND BIN LADEN
abstract: US steps up efforts to persuade Afghan people to turn over Osama bin Laden, with American military aircraft broadcasting radio message announcing $25 million cash reward for information leading to his location or capture; broadcasts, which identify other leaders of Al Qaeda terrorist organization thought to be hiding in Afghanistan, are latest element of US strategy to rely heavily on anti-Taliban rebels and other Afghans to help reveal whereabouts; Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld stresses special operations forces will not mount cave-by-cave hunt, but will continue applying pressure by setting up roadblocks and gathering intelligence; suggests US will rely more heavily on bombing raids and anti-Taliban Afghan forces; US warplanes carry out heavy strikes around Taliban stronghold of Kandahar; Rumsfeld says Taliban's leader, Mullah Mohammad Omar, will not be allowed to negotiate his escape from city and that seeking asylum in foreign country or receiving amnesty within Afghanistan will not be acceptable to US; in addition to radio broadcasts, warplanes are dropping thousands of leaflets in Afghanistan asking for help in hunting bin Laden; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar climbs, lifted by gains in US stocks and speculation and expectations economy will recover in coming months; in New York, euro settles at 90.30 cents, down from 91.07 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Steel Maker Seeking Help In Chapter 11
abstract: Bethlehem Steel Corp files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; company, which has not made money since 1998, says it lost $152.2 million in third quarter, compared with loss of $34.8 million year earlier; revenue fell 17 percent, to $825.4 million from $988.8 million; chairman Robert S Miller Jr says events of Sept 11 put steel demand into free fall, and terms of of financing packages company are negotiating are getting worse; Miller says he has asked government for assistance with costs and taxes; Bethlehem and other American steel companies have been suffering from cheaper imports; some analysts doubt whether government will comply; they expect American steel industry to consolidate and Bethlehem is unlikely to remain independent (Market Place column) (M)

headline: A Watch List for 2002; People and Trends Shaping Media and Technology
abstract: Article on some of interesting players and ideas in media and technology for 2002; says for 2002, media and technology companies are sure to capitalize on some sucesses of 2001, trying to keep hold of profitable enterprises and seeking to build on what is left of e-commerce world; photos (M)

headline: Andy Grove's Tale of His Boyhood in Wartime
abstract: Interview with Intel Corp chairman Andrew S Grove on his new memoir Swimming Across; book focuses on Grove's youth in Hungary under Nazi occupation and later a Communist Government, ending 10 years before he joined Intel; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Tunnel Migrants Sent To Jail
abstract: Three Iraqis and one Afghan, alleged ringleaders, are sentenced to four months in jail in France for role in storming of Channel Tunnel by more than 500 asylum seekers trying to reach Britain (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Joining Antiterror Pacts
abstract: North Korean government says it intends to sign five international antiterrorism conventions, apparently hoping to have its name removed from US list of countries that support terrorism (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: World Briefing

headline: Drop Continues In Inventories
abstract: Commerce Department reports wholesale inventories fell 0.1 percent in August, to $298.7 billion, lowest since June 2000; wholesaler sales rose 0.6 percent in August (S)

headline: The Heartland Hunkers Down; Cincinnati Area Is Taking Job Losses in Stride, for Now
abstract: Economic downturn has been gradual but may be worsening in Cincinnati metropolitan area, 13-county area in Ohio and Kentucky where median income and mix of companies roughly mirror nation as whole; unemployment rate is still relatively low, despite recent surge of job cuts, and few among newly unemployed express desperation about finding work; graphs; photos (M)

headline: FINANCIAL PRINTING BUSINESS ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS
abstract: Bowne & Co, whose main business is financial printing, plans to cut jobs because it had third-quarter loss caused by decline in initial public stock offerings and mergers and acquisitions (S)

headline: AUTOMAKER FORMS UNIT TO OVERSEE BRITISH-BASED BRANDS
abstract: Fo

headline: Pakistani Warns of Image Problem
abstract: Photo of Pakistan Pres Pervez Musharraf and British Prime Minister Tony Blair at news conference in Great Britain

headline: What Free Medication?
abstract: D Mendel letter questions Fred Brock's October 7 Seniority column on pharmaceutical companies pvoviding free medications for people who qualify for them

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Poor Outlook For Educational Publisher
abstract: Pearson says full-year profits at its educational publishing unit will rise less than analysts have been expecting; was counting on division to offset slump in advertising at Financial Times, its newspaper; company's total profits for year will rise 10 percent, to about 352 million pounds (S)

headline: In Their Heartland, Defiant Taliban Let Refugees Meet the Press
abstract: Taliban still talk defiantly in their southern Afghanistan stronghold, where they remain in control; organize tour of area for foreign journalists to show what they call effects of American bombing on ordinary Afghans; journalists visit refugee camp; Najibullah Sheerzio, Taliban aide, denies reports Mullah Muhammad Omar, Taliban supreme leader, has ceded power to local tribal leaders, interview; photos (M)

headline: Alarm Rings at NBC as 'Today' Loses Ground; ABC Morning Program Narrows Gap. Will Katie Couric Stay?
abstract: Indications that Today show may be losing ground in ratings to ABC's Good Morning America cause alarm at NBC; some staff members are unhappy with departures of a number of production executives and question ability of their replacements; complain that program's organization and focus have become uncertain; some are concerned that Katie Couric may not sign another long-term contract when current one expires in May; photo (M)

headline: Blocking Spam
abstract: Bill Stoller letter comments on problem of spam for America Online subscribers (Oct 11 article)

headline: WITH TARGET LIST, U.S. PRESSES HUNT FOR AFGHAN FOES
abstract: American military works down target list of cave networks in systematic hunt for Taliban, Osama bin Laden and other Al Qaeda leaders in Afghanistan; they drop guided missiles, giant bomb and copies of leaflets offering $25 million bounty; they have particularly targeted areas south of Kandahar, largest Taliban stronghold still resisting opposition forces; heavy fighting breaks out in Kunduz, other heavy concentration of Taliban and Al Qaeda forces, even as senior Northern Alliance leader says Taliban officials have agreed to surrender city encircled by his forces; fighting suggests that Taliban leaders negotiating surrender might not have full control over their forces, or even be able to agree among themselves; Pentagon official emphasizes that Americans are not playing central role in negotiations--except to reinforce Bush administration's position that Al Qaeda fighters who surrender must be taken as prisoners of war, and not granted safe passage to freedom; map (M)

headline: Moscow Journal; The Worker's State Is History, and Fashion Reigns
abstract: Article on proliferation of luxury clothing boutiques in Moscow, where fashion is highest expression of consumption, especially among city's nouveau riche; photos (M)

headline: SNAP-ON, A TOOLS CONCERN, TO PAY SPX $44 MILLION
abstract: Snap-On Inc says it will pay $44 million to a rival, SPX Corp, after federal arbitrator decides it improperly used SPX's patented technology for equipment that tests car engines (S)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   9.50       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   6.00       Federal funds   1.81   1.79   6.44       3-month T-bills   1.65   1.64   5.11       6-month T-bills   1.75   1.73   5.30       10-yr. headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Julia Brady was named a senior client strategist at the Via Group, Portland, Me. She had been an associate at the Stamford, Conn., office of McKinsey & Company.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Kurile Islands Fishing Dispute
abstract: Korean officials express concern that Japan tries to persuade Russia to keep Korean fishing boats away from disputed southern Kurile Islands (S)

headline: U.S. Rescues 8 Aid Workers South of Kabul
abstract: Eight Western aid workers held by the Taliban in Afghanistan have been released, U.S. officials said on Wednesday.

headline: AOL-AT&T Cable Talks Said to Be Advancing
abstract: AOL Time Warner's tentative discussions about acquiring the cable television business of AT&T have edged forward, with AOL Time Warner signing a confidentiality agreement that could allow the talks to move to a new stage, people close to the negotiations said.    Executives from AOL Time Warner began speaking with their AT&T counterparts about a cable deal over the summer. But after the Sept. 11 attacks, the talks were relegated to a back burner.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Tunnel To Reopen For Cars
abstract: St Gotthard Tunnel in Switzerland will reopen to cars; ban on trucks follows deadly accident and fire in October (S)

headline: Anthrax Scare Reaches Europe Despite Lack of Known Cases
abstract: Buildings have been evacuated and people sent to hospitals for observation as an anthrax scare spread across and beyond Europe.

headline: Team Is Ready to Publish Full Set of Dead Sea Scrolls
abstract: Dr Emanuel Tov of Hebrew University in Jerusalem will announce completion of project to publish full set of Dead Sea Scrolls; their discovery 54 years ago was considered sensation in 20th-century archaeology; project involves 900 scrolls and commentaries in 38 volumes; some of scrolls date from 250 BC, while others are as recent as AD 70; they were found between 1947 and 1956 in caves at Qumran, nine miles from Jericho in what is now West Bank; photo (M)

headline: Newsweeklies Run to Keep Up On Tricky Turf
abstract: At 11 a.m. Friday, about two dozen Newsweek staff members gathered around a conference room table. The photo department had just been reopened after an anthrax scare that proved to be a false alarm. And word had spread that morning of new activity by United States Special Forces on the ground in Afghanistan, throwing up in the air the contents of the issue closing the next day.    ''I think we should go ahead and work up a special ops cover,'' began Mark Whitaker, Newsweek's editor, ''but I think that for the moment we should stick with 'sleepers,' '' a feature called ''The Terrorist Next Door,'' about Al Qaeda cells in the United States and overseas.

headline: Rebels' General Came, Saw, and Said Nothing
abstract: Two thousand Northern Alliance troops and two dozen tank crews gather expectantly on treeless, dirt-covered hillside in Jabul-Seraj for inspection by Gen Muhammad Fahim; new chief of alliances forces says nothing, appearing ill at ease as he struggles to replace assassinated leader Ahmed Shah Massoud; photo of Afghan rebel president Burhannuddin Rabbani; map (M)

headline: Unblinking Eye For the Unique
abstract: Jonathan M Tisch, chairman and chief executive of Loews Hotels, writes My First Job column on being cameraman at television station during senior year in college; photos (S)

headline: Levin to Retire From Post as Chief Executive of AOL Time Warner
abstract: AOL Time Warner said that its chief, Gerald Levin, will retire in May and would be succeeded by Richard Parsons, the company's co-chief operating officer.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Company Plans a Buyback
abstract: Board of Cia Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela, or CANTV, approves share buyback in latest wrinkle of takeover dispute involving several multinational investors; company will offer $30 per share for about 15 percent of outstanding stock, in addition to dividend of $550 million to be paid in two installments; offer comes after hostile bid by AES Corp to seek control of company for $24 per share (S)

headline: Everyday People, Extraordinary Day
abstract: Throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, untold thousands of people in jobs ranging from hospital clerk to grade-school administrative assistant, brought skills and initiative far outside their job descriptions to help when World Trade Center was attacked; Paul Amico, construction supervisor with NY Waterway who helped direct evacuation of people by ferry from Lower Manhattan after attack, comments; photo (M)

headline: A Bright Spot in a Bleak Holiday Retailing Season
abstract: A Bright Spot in a Bleak Hot

headline: Air Force Set to Run Recruiting Campaign
abstract: US Air Force will begin running on November 4 first phase of $50 million recruitment campaign aimed at Americans 16 to 24 years old; campaign is first from GSD&M, new Air Force agency in Austin, Tex (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Medical College Overseer Accused
abstract: Two Indian High Court justices order removal of Dr Ketan Desai as president of Medical Council of India, which oversees medical education; charges Desai with corruption and misuing post (S)

headline: Pitney Bowes Is Casting Off Copier and Fax Units Today
abstract: Pitney Bowes formally turns over its copier and fax business to its shareholders; analysts predict that, without those low-growth, low-profit divisions dragging it down, company's mailing business will thrive; spun-off copier and fax business will operate under name Imagistics International (M)

headline: Palestinian Is Killed After His Shooting Spree
abstract: A Palestinian went on a shooting spree in a bustling commercial area in southern Jerusalem today, wounding four Israelis before he was killed by a soldier.

headline: A Full Charge Of Genocide For Milosevic
abstract: UN war crimes tribunal issues sweeping new indictment of former Serb Pres Slobodan Milosevic, charging him with genocide in connection with forcible removal of non-Serbs from large areas of Bosnia during war there; indictment completes picture of Milosevic as chief architect of three Balkan wars that tore up Yugoslavia; holds him responsible for killing of more than 7,000 Muslims in Srebrenica in July 1995 (M)

headline: The Week's Schedule of Equity Offerings
abstract: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Anworth Mortgage Asset, Santa Monica, Calif., 13 million shares. Friedman, Billings, Ramsey.    Ceres Group, Cleveland, 14 million shares. Friedman, Billings, Ramsey.

headline: WARNER BROS. AND SANRIO TO DEVELOP CARTOON PRODUCTS
abstract: Warner Brothers division of AOL Time Warner will join with Sanrio Company of Japan to develop and license products that include cartoon characters (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Look For Asylum System
abstract: Britain plans radical reform of asylum system; will issue identification cards with photographs and fingerprints to asylum seekers and house them in reception centers, paying for their room and board and giving them spending money to replace current vouchers (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pearson Outlook Falls
abstract: Pearson PLC says annual profits will be 'significantly' lower than initially forecast because of falloff in advertising; chief executive Marjorie Scardino comments; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Allows Area Codes For Cellphones
abstract: Federal Communications Commission will allow states to establish area codes for cellphones and pagers (S)

headline: I.R.A. Relents on Arms, Saves Peace Accord
abstract: The Irish Republican Army declared today that it had taken a long-sought step to begin dismantling its arsenal of weapons and bombs.

headline: Still Defiant, Milosevic Hears the Atrocities Read Out
abstract: Former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic makes third appearance before UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague, where he is confronted with accusations of bloodshed in Balkans, charges he has previously ignored; is forced to listen to full-reading of charges that lasts almost four hours; lengthy procedure, ordinarily waived, is court's response to his ongoing defiance; he maintains court is illegal, has scorned all court documents delivered to him in prison cell and has refused to enter plea; judges and other tribunal officials are concerned that he may try to make mockery of court with tirades and refusal to cooperate; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Yen drops on confirmation of recession in Japan; dollar settles at 125.62 yen; graphs; table of exchange rates (S)

headline: Berkshire Set To Acquire Apparel Giant
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway, holding company and investment vehicle controlled by Warren E Buffett, will acquire Fruit of the Loom, underwear and apparel company, for $835 million in cash; Buffett cites strength of brand name and managerial talent of John Holland, former chief operating officer, who was called out of retirement to run company, which is now operating under Chapter 11 bankruptch protection (M)

headline: Berlin's Support of the U.S. Puts Greens in Uneasy Spot
abstract: Article discusses political situation in Germany, with Greens, normally pacifist party, supporting Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's decision to join American-led coalition in war on terrorism; maintaining solidarity and support in Germany for Washington, however, will be difficult over extended period, and Schroder may have to turn to liberal Free Democrats for support in next election (M)

headline: Times E-Mail Report
abstract: NYTimes.com, Web site of The New York Times, will introduce free, daily e-mail newsletter focusing on financial news; newsletter, DealBook, will be edited by Andrew Ross Sorkin (S)

headline: Crisis Deepens In Argentina; Aid Is Sought
abstract: Argentine government scrambles to contain far-reaching economic crisis; economic minister Domingo Cavallo flies to Washington, DC, to try to convince World Bank to release $1.3 billion cash that government needs to avoid defaulting on its $132 billion in debts; photo (M)

headline: In This Company's Struggle, God Has Many Proxies
abstract: ServiceMaster, which was founded in 1947 by evangelical Baptist and has long declared its primary mission is to honor God, hired its first outsider in January, Jonathan P Ward, former R R Donnelley & Sons executive, to run company in light slumping stock price and profits; Ward calls meetings to order by quoting book of Isaiah, but he is also heeding calls to change corporate priorities; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: No Talks With U.S.
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's supreme ruler, rejects call by reformist members of Parliament for direct talks with United States; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: U.S. Plans Missile Radar
abstract: South Korea's semi-official news agency says United States plans to set up radar site in South Korea to detect ballistic missiles and guide intercepters to destroy them (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Publisher Plans E-Books For Children
abstract: Random House will begin selling children's books in electronic formats (S)

headline: Shocked Germany Weakens Cherished Protections
abstract: In unprecedented move, Berlin's Humboldt University gives information on 23 Arab students to German government; action represents important change in country where personal data usually is well protected, but safeguards are loosened as Germany becomes locus of investigation into Sept 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington; Germany, shocked and embarrassed by its use as haven for Islamic terrorists, moves to increase surveillance of suspected groups and centralize oversight of intelligence agencies run by states; airport security is tightened and movement within country may be restricted (M)

headline: Raising Munich, Sharon Reveals Israeli Qualms
abstract: Israeli officials are quick to try to contain damage done by Prime Min Ariel Sharon's outburst against United States, in which he invokes appeasement of Hitler in 1938 to warn Washington against making deals with Arab states at Israel's expense (News analysis); but exaggerated or not, statement exposes frustration many Israelis feel with Bush administration's antiterror campaign, and a serious political problem this campaign poses for Sharon (M)

headline: Germany Ready to Send Force of 3,900; Not Clear if They Would Be Combat Soldiers
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder says Germany will mobilize up to 3,900 specialized troops to support United States in war against Taliban in Afghanistan; calls decision historic; US is under pressure to accept European military aid, despite its resistance to 'coalition war,' to help spur popular support for war in Europe; photo (M)

headline: Unionist Bloc Stalls Latest Ulster Peace Bid
abstract: Protestant hard-liners block David Trimble's bid for re-election as first minister of Northern Ireland Assembly, post he resigned during summer to protest IRA action on arms (M)

headline: Pakistan Is Trying to Put The Best Face on the Deal
abstract: Pakistan struggles to put best face on deal reached for international government in Afghanistan; Pres Pervez Musharraf wishes new leaders success, but privately, Pakistani officials express concern about dominance of Northern Alliance in new administration and by absence of anyone among 30 new leaders with close ties to Islamabad; Pakistan is one of only three countries that recognized Taliban until Musharraf sided with American-led coalition after Sept 11 terrorist attacks; Pakistan now struggles to find allies in post-Taliban environment in Afghanistan, where friendly government is considered essential to Pakistan's national security (M)

headline: Europeans Pledge Troops, if Necessary
abstract: European nations express support for American-led attacks on Afghanistan and pledge to send troops if necessary; overview of European newspaper editorial pages, which also support military action, but opine as to whether action can really end terrorist threat; photo (M)

headline: A Juggling Act for a Pakistani Newspaper in Britain
abstract: Daily Jang, London Pakistani newspaper, like other Muslim and Arab press in Britain, struggles to balance readers' skepticism of American and British military actions in Central Asia with Prime Min Tony Blair's message of war on terror, not on Islam; editor, Zahoor Niazi, cites grievances shared by his Muslim readers; says he is under increasing pressure to tone down material that might incite violence; photos (M)

headline: Deepening Wrinkles in the New Economy
abstract: McKinsey & Co study says strong productivity gains of late 1990's were concentrated in only 30 percent of private sector and are likely to be whittled away in coming months and years; study is most detailed look at 1995-2000 period published so far; finds long-term productivity growth rate is likely to fall back to about 2 percent (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Nuclear Phase-Out Approved
abstract: German Parliament aproves plan to phase out nuclear power over next two decades; plan would gradually close all of country's 19 nuclear plants, which supply one-third of Germany's electricity; legislation also phases out highly disputed shipment of nuclear waste to reprocessing centers in France and Britain (S)

headline: 401(k) Participants Hold On
abstract: New study finds that most participants in company 401(k) plans rode out stock market decline last year without altering their investment allocations (S)

headline: Media Group Plans To Enliven a City
abstract: Representatives of entertainment and commercial production industry, including associations, unions and suppliers, are forming We Love New York coalition that will work to bolster theater, television, film and advertising in wake of World Trade Center attacks; effort grows from tasks production crews performed at ground zero (S)

headline: Bush and Putin Expected to Agree to Reduce Nuclear Arsenals and to Fight Terrorism
abstract: Pres Bush and Pres Vladimir Putin are expected to close number of agreements at upcoming summit in Crawford, Tex, that could profoundly change post-cold-war trajectory of relations between US and Russia; are expected announce deep cuts in offensive nuclear arsenals that have been overlapping threats from era of superpower competition; are poised to establish strong bond of cooperation in struggle against terrorism; Putin has indicated he is ready to reach accord allowing US to proceed with rigorous testing of anti-ballistic missile systems as long as Bush will agree to preserve 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty as cornerstone of strategic stability (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Satellite Radio Network Is Delayed
abstract: Sirius Satellite Radio will begin service on Feb 14 instead of Dec 31; will charge $12.95 a month for 100 channels; service will be offered first in Denver, Houston and Phoenix, and expand nationwide by September; graph (S)

headline: Jail Awaits Irish M.P. Who Balked On Finances
abstract: Liam Lawlor, high-profile member of Ireland's Parliament, faces jail term for contempt of court, having failed to cooperate with tribunal investigating corruption in planning and development process throughout 1980's and 1990's (S)

headline: NKK of Japan in Talks to Sell National Steel to U.S. Rival
abstract: National Steel and its main shareholder, NKK Corp of Japan, hold talks about selling National Steel to rival US Steel; sale would be part of plan to allow six large US steel makers to merge into one company (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Acquires Wireless Operations
abstract: Verizon Wireless will acquire wireless operations in California, Georgia, Ohio and Tennessee from Dobson Communications for about $465 million (S)

headline: Ad Declines Force Magazines To Make Cuts
abstract: Magazines, facing steep advertising revenue declines, continue to shrink staffs and pages, cut back on salaries or benefits, and merge or even cease publication; moves by several magazine publishers noted (S)

headline: Black Employees, in Lawsuit, Accuse Cargill of Discrimination
abstract: A group of 25 black employees of Cargill Inc., the agricultural business that is one of the world's largest private companies, filed a federal lawsuit yesterday accusing the company of widespread racial discrimination.    The civil lawsuit, which was filed in Minneapolis, seeks class-action status on behalf of an estimated 1,000 blacks who work or have worked in salaried positions as managers or professionals in the last six years.

headline: Pakistan Orders the Taliban To Close Karachi Consulate
abstract: Pakistan orders Taliban consulate in Karachi to close in continuing effort to silence Taliban and restrain Islamic militancy; photo (M)

headline: The Thought That Counts In Charitable Giving
abstract: Michael W Gerrity letter comments on Dec 2 Love & Money article about charitable giving

headline: Market Place; Financing has dried up for biotechnology start-ups with big dreams for fighting disease.
abstract: Barnaby J Feder Market Place column on struggle of smaller biotechnology startups to attract venture capital; notes limited crowd of biotechnology venture capitalists are giving most of funds to more mature start-ups, with products nearer to market, cutting amounts they are willing to invest and demanding larger shares of companies (M)

headline: Video: Pentagon Releases bin Laden Tape
abstract: Osama bin Laden contentedly recalled the Sept. 11 suicide attacks against America on a videotape released Thursday by the Pentagon:

headline: Technology That Aims To Do Good
abstract: Tech Museum of Innovation, three-year-old science and technology museum in San Jose, Calif, holds awards benefit to honor technology specialists who 'improve the quality of life around the globe'; photo (M)

headline: Experts' Top Choices, Gone Awry
abstract: Big investment firms pool their analysts' collective wisdom into 'best ideas' mutual funds; investors like the concept, but, almost without exception, these funds fail to match overall market and often lag behind competition in their categories; photo; graph (M)

headline: Did Russian Gas Giant Just Glimpse The Future?
abstract: Vote by Gazprom board to buy back control of Purgaz, gas-producing subsidiary that slipped from company's control in 1999 in transaction that investors call questionable, is important victory for Alexei Miller, executive hand-picked by Pres Vladimir V Putin to run Russia's giant gas monopoly; he has been battling old-guard Gazprom managers and hungry oil companies, all eager to grab pieces of business while company is in disarray; photo (M)

headline: Wartime Forges A United Front For Bush Aides
abstract: Crisis and war force greater level of unity on Pres Bush's circle of national security advisers, even as significant differences persist in their priorities for long-term struggle against terrorism and conflicts that give rise to it; Secretary of State Colin L Powell, called invisible before Sept 11, is now regarded as consummate pragmatist, whose long experience in Army and as chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff has brought realism to American diplomacy in time of war; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, parodied as Dr Strangelove pre-Sept 11, has emerged as dominant spokesman for war effort; Condolezza Rice, national security adviser once criticized for stoking Bush's go-it-alone instincts, emerges as decisive vote in councils of war; Powell, Rumsfeld and Rice still differ, but they keep news of their differences to minimum as they seek to marshal diversity of views for Bush to consider; new sense of unity will be tested in coming weeks, as tensions rise between India and Pakistan, and between Israel and Palestinians; at issue will be question of how deeply US should intervene in longstanding disputes; photo (M)

headline: Zimbabwe Proposes Keeping Reporters Out
abstract: Zimbabwe proposes new law that would effectively bar foreign journalists from working in country in latest effort to curtail international scrutiny as nation braces for 2002 presidential election; proposed law would allow only citizens of Zimbabwe to work as correspondents for foreign newspapers and television stations (M)

headline: Baxter International Closes Two Plants
abstract: Baxter International Inc shuts down two plants that make blood filter that may be linked to deaths of more than 50 kidney patients worldwide; facilities are in Ronneby, Sweden, and Miami Lakes, Fla; 256 workers are dismissed (S)

headline: Intel Says Design Innovations Will Aid Chip Performance
abstract: Intel is set to announce semiconductor design innovations that it expects will help it double performance of microchips every 18 to 24 months through 2010, extending trend known as Moore's law; says innovations will put it on course to be able to mass-produce microchips with a billion transitors -- 25 times as many as today's Pentium IV chips -- as early as 2007 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: VA Linux Becomes VA Software
abstract: VA Linux Syxtems Inc changes name to VA Software Corp (S)r

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE THE NETHERLANDS: WEAK QUARTER FOR BANK ABN Amro Holding said third-quarter profit fell 40 percent, as the bank put aside more money to cover loans that might go bad. Net income dropped to 476 million euros ($426 million), or 30 euro cents a share, from 796 million euros, or 52 euro cents a share, a year earlier. The large Dutch bank doubled its provisions to cover potential losses from bad loans to 308 million euros in the period. Of those provisions, 115 million euros was set aside at ABN Amro's North American commercial bank, which lends to small and medium-size businesses.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT).

headline: U.S. TAKES BIG ROLE IN AIRLINES' CRISIS
abstract: Government and industry officials say Air Transportation Stabilization Board will wield extraordinary power in determining which airlines will get $10 billion in federal loan guarantees and on what terms; David M Walker, board member, predicts several carriers will be forced out of business, leaving survivors with tighter grip on nation's biggest metropolitan airports (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Picks Up
abstract: Britain's third-quarter output rose greater-than-expected 2.2 percent from 2000 period (S)/

headline: Warnings to the Taliban, Diplomatic Difficulties and Israeli Concerns
abstract: Daily overview of situation in America and abroad in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks; American forces mobilize in and around Central Asia; Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld returns home from visits to five nations without any assurance of cooperation with coalition; intelligence agencies must work cooperatively and end turf wars; American insurance industry seeks emergency government aid (M)

headline: Strains of Hope in City Under Bombing
abstract: Few accounts by witnesses of first days of American bombing have filtered out of Afghanistan; unidentified Afghan who was witness says many Afghans who are deathly afraid of Taliban quietly cheered when bombing began; says they have little love for what US did years earlier when it poured money and weapons into hands of guerrilla factions that in time used those weapons to start civil war; those resources also went into hands of Osama bin Laden; photos (M)

headline: Murky Picture Emerges of Life Under Bombardment
abstract: Picture of life during bombardment of Afghanistan emerges, but it is difficult to discern rumor from reality; Pakistani intelligence reports that no senior members of Taliban or Al Qaeda have been killed (M)

headline: Blair Set to Come Out Strongly for British Integration With Europe
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair presses British compatriots to jettison their traditional skepticism toward European integration and see it as opportunity to extend their nation's influence; he is expected to deliver speech that British newspapers are depicting as among 'most pro-Europe speeches' he has ever given to domestic audience; speech may not mark beginning of headlong British rush into membership of euro, given sensitivities in Britain about European Union (M)

headline: In Nobel Talk, Annan Sees Each Human Life as the Prize
abstract: Kofi Annan, secretary general of United Nations and co-winner with UN of 2001 Nobel Peace Prize, uses Nobel lecture in Oslo to make impassioned case for continued importance of UN as promoter of peace and champion of individuals rights in unstable and unequal world; says US must not lose sight of its principles in pursuing war against those responsible for Sept 11 terrorist attacks; says $947,000 that comes with Peace Prize, which is to be shared between him and UN, will be pooled for single project to benefit UN; tight security surrounds ceremonies; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Web Postings Bring 4-Year Sentence
abstract: Chinese pro-democracy activist Wang Jinbo is sentenced to four years in prison for posting articles on overseas Internet sites that demanded reassessment of government's 1989 decision to send in troops to break up student demonstrations in Tiananmen Square (S)

headline: Afghan Warfare: Taliban Trick Throws Rebels Into Retreat
abstract: Northern Alliance forces are tricked into ambush by Taliban in Kunduz, in northeastern Afghanistan, and forced into panicked retreat; come under fire after entering city in belief that Taliban commander had switched allegiance and invited them to enter; event underscores fluid allegiances and conflicting loyalties that very likely will form backdrop of any Afghan government that succeeds Taliban; if, as alliance leaders say, they will refuse to work with any members of Taliban in new Afghan government, they may have to exclude many soldiers in their own ranks; photo (M)

headline: XEROX REPORTS WIDER LOSS IN 3RD QUARTER
abstract: Xerox Corp says third-quarter loss increased to $211 million from $191 million in year-earlier period; sales fell 13 percent, to $3.9 billion from $4.5 billion (S)

headline: After Afghanistan
abstract: Pres Bush's next move in war against Al Qaeda and other 'global reach' terrorist groups in dozens of other countries remains unsettled and unsettling question as defeat nears for Taliban in Afghanistan; deep reservations exist among allies in Europe, Mideast and Russia over push by some in Bush administration to expand military operations to other nations and topple Pres Saddam Hussein of Irraq; pulverizing effect of first phase of war in Afghanistan signals Bush favors innovative tactics that quickly exploit enemy weaknesses with ruthless air attacks under doctrine in which use of force is unrestrained by borders or allies (M)

headline: Pokémon Get Their Own Player: Gotta Market Them All
abstract: Nintendo releases game player called Pokemon Mini, cross between Nintendo Game Boy and another Japanese fad from past, Tamagotchi; player with one game sells for $40; photo (S)

headline: 'Humanity Is Indivisible'
abstract: Excerpts from Nobel lecture of Kofi Annan, secretary general of United Nations and co-winner with UN of 2001 Nobel Peace Prize

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Regulators Talk To Microsoft
abstract: European Commission said that although it has talked informally with Microsoft Corp about its latest operating platform, XP, agency is not conducting formal investigation (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Chip Plant Opened
abstract: Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp completes construction of silicon wafer fabrication plant, Shanghai, China (S)

headline: Business Travel; A UAL unit will use Airbus Corporate Jetliners for trans-Atlantic and domestic shuttle service.
abstract: Joe Sharkey Business Travel column on United Air Lines' new business-jet subsidiary, Avolar, which will use as many as 15 Airbus Corporate Jetliner models for trans-Atlantic and domestic shuttle service for corporate customers and other clients like sports teams (M)

headline: 3 Countries Distribute Special Packets of Coins : The Euro Hits the Streets
abstract: BRUSSELS—  COUNTDOWN TO THE EURO 2002 series

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Commodities feature; natural gas prices rise on technical buying, afters sell-off earlier in week (S)

headline: North Korean Death Rate Is Said to Be Up Sharply Since 1994
abstract: World Health Organization president Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland says North Koreans are dying at rate more than forty percent higher than in 1994, when first floods and famine struck; puts death rate now at 9.3 per 100 people, up from 6.3 seven years ago; asks South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung for more medical aid (M)

headline: Microsoft Customers Balk At Automatic Upgrades
abstract: Some of Microsoft's large corporate customers balk at Microsoft's new software licensing program that would require them to buy maintenance contracts that will essentially determine what upgrades they buy; Microsoft holds program is aimed at simplifying upgrade process; says only 20 percent of customers face higher costs; consortium of British companies has filed complaint with British government holding program will cost businesses added $1.3 billion (M)

headline: Cable Companies Sign On For Excite@Home Service
abstract: ExciteAtHome, which filed for bankruptcy protection, signs agreement with group of cable companies, including Comcast Corp and Cox Communications, to maintain high-speed Internet access for their customers; AT&T, which had most customers of ExciteAtHome service, is not involved in deal (M)

headline: Argentine Leader in Talks to Avert Default on $132 Billion Debt
abstract: Pres Fernando de la Rua holds intensive talks with opposition governors, labor leaders and legislative leaders in bid for support for new economic plan and debt restructuring to prevent default on Argentina's $132 billion public debt; rules out default or devaluation (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Silver declines as demand from photographic film makers falls; graphs (S)

headline: Making Sure the Rich Stay Rich, Even in Crisis
abstract: Profile of Maria Elena Lagomasino, chairwoman of J P Morgan Private Bank, unit of J P Morgan Case that serves people and families with at least $25 million net worths; it is mainstay of rapidly growing industry of advising the superwealthy; photo (M)

headline: MKS TO BUY EMERSON ELECTRIC FOR ABOUT $251 MILLION
abstract: MKS Instruments Inc, maker of instruments used to produce computer chips, agrees to buy semiconductor-equipment manufacturing unit of Emerson Electric Company for about $251 million in stock (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Grayer Than You Think To the Editor:.

headline: Longtime Equity Strategist Is Resigning at Prudential
abstract: Greg A Smith, one of Wall Street's least bullish investment strategists, resigns from Prudential Securities; his views on market outlook noted; photo (M)

headline: Buenos Aires Journal; Home From Cuba, Soccer Star Kicks Some Shins
abstract: Argentines are transfixed by bittersweet return of revered soccer great Diego Armando Maradona after two years in Cuba, where he was treated for cocaine abuse; Maradona, 41, overweight and sluggish, plays with national team against international all-stars in exhibition match in his honor; photos (M)

headline: A Generation Holds Its Course
abstract: Harris Interactive reports that most baby boomers plan no changes in their investing or savings as result of Sept 11 terrorist attacks (S)

headline: Rumsfeld Rejects PlanTo Allow Mullah Omar 'To Live in Dignity' : Taliban Fighters Agree to Surrender Kandahar
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Afghanistan's Taliban militia said Thursday that it had agreed to surrender its last remaining stronghold, the southern city of Kandahar, to a prominent anti-Taliban commander and would begin giving up its weapons on Friday.

headline: DataBank; Investors Seem to Ignore Discouraging News
abstract: Summary of week's market activity; graphs (S)

headline: Reports Swirl Out of Afghanistan Of Panic and Taliban Defections
abstract: Taliban's top Islamic clerics reportedly have left their Kandahar headquarters to escape risk of United States bombing; other senior Taliban officials have reportedly fled to Pakistan or sent families there; other accounts reaching Pakistan depict gathering panic among population and disappearance from major cities of many Taliban soldiers and policemen, signalling either mass defection by Taliban fighters or regrouping for guerrilla war; Dr Abdullah Abdullah, anti-Taliban alliance official, says many Taliban officers might be willing to switch sides; sees popular uprising possible in Kabul; table of Taliban arsenal; photos (M)

headline: USA Networks Settles a Dispute
abstract: USA Networks pays $20 million for minority stake in National Leisure Group to settle dispute over cancellation of agreement to buy National Leisure; USA Networks will also promote cruises and other vacation packages sold by National Leisure on travel-themed cable television channel that USA plans (S)

headline: Second Bidder, From France, Reported for Body Shop Chain
abstract: Division of BNP Paribas offers $356 million to purchase Body Shop, beleaguered retailer of health and beauty products; main rival bidder is Texas Pacific Group (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: We Killed Judge, Separatists Say
abstract: The Basque separatist group E.T.A. said it had carried out the killing  of a judge last week in the Basque region and a car bombing in Madrid that wounded 95 people. The group said it had shot Judge José Maria Lidón as he left his home in Bilbao because ''the judicial system is another instrument of aggression with which to punish Basques and to absolve those who oppress the Basque homeland.''   Emma Daly (NYT)

headline: Shoplifting Is Adding to Retailing Difficulties
abstract: Rising tide of shoplifters adds to woes that erode retailers' profit margins; events of Sept 11 seem to escalate pilferers' compulsions for thievery (M)

headline: Berlin Cameron in Talks About Being Acquired
abstract: Berlin Cameron & Partners, midsize independent advertising agency, is in serious conversations about being acquired; widespread speculation points to WPP Group as likeliest suitor (S)

headline: Elite Troops Patrolling Desolate Swaths of No Man's Land
abstract: US marines in southern Afghanistan probe deeper into chaotic swaths of territory near Kandahar, no-man's land which is still under control of Taliban; map; photo (M)

headline: Switching to the Euro:The Art of Rounding Up
abstract: FRANKFURT—  COUNTDOWN TO THE EURO 2002 SERIES

headline: Seriously. People Seem Ready for a Good Laugh.
abstract: Onion, satirical New York-based online newspaper, unleashes its usual deadpan parody of standard newspaper blather in its first issue since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; its account of attackers afterlife in Hell, much discussed in online forums, proves cathartic for many readers; readers jam Web site and respond with overwhelmingly positive e-mail; photo (M)

headline: Some I.B.M. Software Tools To Be Put in Public Domain
abstract: International Business Machines Corp to put $40 million of its software tools in public domain as first step toward founding an open-source organization for developers called Eclipse; over 150 software companies are lined up to join Eclipse community; IBM aide Scott Hebner says IBM will not control Eclipse (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Vivendi Universal Plans To Challenge Media Giants  Vivendi Universal of France has lined up a set of deals intended to challenge the American entertainment giants in their struggle to dominate the production and distribution of movies and television programs.    The company will place its programming on five satellite television channels, giving Vivendi its own distribution capabilities for the first time. As soon as Monday, Vivendi hopes to announce an agreement giving it control of USA Networks. At the same time, Vivendi may announce that it is putting its American movie and television holdings under the control of one of the entertainment industry's most experienced executives, Barry Diller. [Page A1.]

headline: Greetings Without Fear
abstract: Fears about anthrax spreading by mail have not lowered holiday sales of Hallmark Cards; they are 2 to 4 percent ahead of same period in 2000 (S)

headline: Scary Decorations? Not This Halloween
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on buying costumes and other Halloween items online; photo (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Michael T. Kennedy; Stein Roe Intermediate Bond Fund
abstract: Carole Gould column profiles Michael T Kennedy, manager of Stein Rowe Intermediate Bond fund; photo; chart (M)

headline: BRISTOL-MYERS PLANS JOB CUTS; SELLS CLAIROL
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company is cutting about 1,000 jobs, including 350 in New Jersey, and may announce more reductions as part of a drive to cut costs and eliminate overlapping operations. The cuts were from functions like the corporate staff and global business that recently went through a ''redesign process,'' Peggy Ballman, a spokeswoman, said yesterday. Bristol-Myers, the fifth-largest drug maker, employed about 44,000 in its continuing operations as of Dec. 31, according to a regulatory filing. Bristol-Myers is focusing more on pharmaceuticals under Peter Dolan, who became chief executive in May. Separately, the Procter & Gamble Company completed its $4.95 billion purchase of the Clairol hair-care business from Bristol-Myers. Procter & Gamble, maker of Pantene and Head & Shoulders shampoos, said it would decide how many jobs to eliminate and which factories to close in the next 90 days as it combines operations. Clairol, based in Stamford, Conn., has 4,000 employees. The acquisition adds $1.6 billion in annual sales through brands like such as Nice 'n Easy and Miss Clairol hair color and Herbal Essences shampoos. (Bloomberg News)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Arrests In Killing Of Soldiers
abstract: Nigerian police arrest four people connected with killings of 19 soldiers in central village of Benue in October; killings led army to begin three-day attack on 16 villages and towns, where hundreds of civilians were massacred (S)

headline: For Digital Music Lovers, A Disc That's Just Right
abstract: Philips Electronics' new eXpanium EXP401 portable audio player stores music on recordable CD's that are almost two inches smaller than standard compact discs; photo (S)

headline: VERIZON WIRELESS NEAR TO COMPLETING PUBLIC OFFERING
abstract: Verizon Wireless Inc says it hopes to complete initial public offering to raise up to $5 billion by mid-2002 (S)

headline: Threat of Terrorism Leaves Trade Summit Plans in Doubt
abstract: Bush administration officials say threat of terrorism has left in doubt arrangements for first global trade summit in two years, to be held in Qatar; trade officials weigh alternative sites, such as Singapore or Geneva; meetings are scheduled for November 9 to 13 (M)

headline: Germany, Under New Antiterrorist Law, Bans a Radical Muslim Group
abstract: Germany invokes its new antiterrorism law to ban radical Islamic Caliphate movement, as well as 19 associated organizations; also carries out more than 200 raids in seven citites; photo; Caliphate is led by Turkish citizen, Metin Kaplan, who is suspected of Al Qaeda ties and is jailed in Germany (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic: Arrests In Killing
abstract: Police in Dominican Republic arrest five men in killing of Sen Dario Gomez which was thought to be political but now appears to have been botched robbery attempt (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Enron Chief Will Give Up Severance
abstract: Enron Corp chairman and chief executive, Kenneth L Lay, gives up severage package worth $60.6 million in effort to appease employees outraged that he stands to profit from merger with Dynegy Inc; value of employees' stock options and their 401(k) accounts evaporated this fall as Enron shares plummeted aimd concerns over company's accounting practices (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Government Sells Bank
abstract: Irish government sells last of its state-owned financial institutions, ACC Bank, to Rabobank of Netherlands for 165 million euros ($146 million) as part of continuing effort to privatize state company to comply with European Union competition regulations (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: New Talks, Old Words
abstract: North and South Korea open talks, but remain far apart on key issues of security and family reunification; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Parts Maker Closes 12 Plants
abstract: French auto equipment maker Valeo will cut 5,000 jobs, or 6.5 percent of its work force, and close 12 plants across Europe; plants will be closed in France, Germany and Spain; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Earthlink Founder Plans New Venture
abstract: Sky Dayton, founder of Earthink, will unveil natonwide wireless Internet service; venture, Boingo Wireless, will offer users flat-rate access to highspeed wireless networks at more than 750 locations; photo (S)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON UNIT WILL PAY $45 MILLION SETTLEMENT
abstract: Lifescan division of Johnson & Johnson agrees to pay $45 million to settle class-action lawsuit brought by consumers claiming that meters used to test diabetics' blood-sugar levels were defective; more than 100,000 plaintiffs will receive about $300 each; paid $60 million in civil and criminal penalties a year ago for concealing known defects in its SureStep blood-glucose monitoring devices (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Compaq Recalls Cords And Adapters
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp will recall about 1.4 million power adapters used with some of its Armada and Prosignia notebook computer models sold between September 1998 and July 2001; recall comes after reports from Consumer Product Safety Commission that five of alternating current adapters overheated and four of those caught fire; no personal injuries or property damage reported (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Final Agreement Reached With Bayer on Cipro Price  Federal officials and Bayer executives reached final agreement on a deal that will nearly cut in half the price that Bayer charges the government for the anthrax drug Cipro.    Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, sought to allay concerns about the price and availability of Cipro by emphasizing the discount and large shipments that Bayer promised. [Page B8.]    Four of the nation's biggest drug companies offered specific services to help the government prepare to battle germs and diseases that could be used by terrorists. [C2.]

headline: Article 2001100991708902291 -- No Title
abstract: Document is not available. A template could not be found for NYT_Article #1002531119820.

headline: Home Depot Ratchets Down Its Estimate of Profit Growth
abstract: Home Depot Ind reduces company's expected earnings growth to increase of 18 to 20 percent a year for next three years; last year, they had predicted growth rate of 23 percent to 25 percent for company (S)

headline: Few Money-Laundering Controls
abstract: A new Congressional report has found that the vast majority of brokerage firms have no procedures in place to prevent money laundering.    Under the antiterrorism legislation signed into law last month by President Bush, federal agencies are to establish rules by next June requiring that brokerage firms combat money laundering by  verifying their customers' identities and by reporting suspicious transactions to law enforcement agencies.

headline: Microsoft Is Resisting Licensing Of Its Code
abstract: Microsoft is trying to head off demands that it give rivals licenses to use basic code of its operating system as way of settling antitrust action against it in Europe; Microsoft, in confidential written response to European Commission's allegations that company had abused Windows' market dominance, writes that imposing compulsory licensing would violate international copyright law; 102-page document is given to other companies involved in litigation, including Sun Microsystems, when it was filed with commission; Sun's complaint to European competition regulators in 1998 led to commission's investigation of Microsoft (M)

headline: The Online Holiday Outlook; No Longer a Novelty, Web Is Now Vulnerable To the Weak Economy
abstract: Internet has lost frenzied quality of earlier holiday shopping seasons and may take its place as simply another sales channel; online extensions of biggest brick-and-mortar chains are scaling back marketing and dropping unprofitable lines; growth of online shopping seems to be leveling off; online retailing is expected to reflect performance of retail economy as whole; graphs; tables; photo (M)

headline: Antimissile Weapon Hits Target in Latest Test, Pentagon Says
abstract: US military officials say that prototype antimissile weapon demolished mock warhead high above Pacific Ocean in second consecutive success for Pentagon's costly missile defense program (M)

headline: U.N. Seeks Meeting of Afghans to Fill Vacuum in Kabul
abstract: UN rushes to fill void in Kabul, Afghanistan, created by unexpected flight of Taliban; will convene meeting of Afghan representatives to quickly to start work on provisional administration, and to deploy an international security presence in capital until national force is readied; Lakhdar Brahimi, special envoy for Afghanistan, tells Security Council establishing order in Kabul as soon as possible is especially important since city carries 'immense symbolic value;' stresses any plan must be broad-based and developed from within country to stand chance of acceptance, and that diplomats should not appear to be imposed by victorious powers; makes plea to world not to abandon Afghans as it did before; photo (M)

headline: More Deaths, More Questions, More Bombs
abstract: Overview of Oct 22 events related to terrorist issue, including anthrax attacks and military action in Afghanistan (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Euro Zone: Inflation Slows
abstract: Inflation in the 12-country euro zone fell to 2.4 percent in October from 2.5 percent a month earlier, the European statistical office Eurostat said yesterday. Inflation across the 15-member Union fell to 2.2 percent from 2.4 percent during the same period. The highest inflation levels were recorded in the Netherlands at 5 percent and Portugal at 4.2 percent.   Paul Meller (NYT)

headline: The Inner Workings of a Plot to Blow Up the U.S. Embassy in Paris
abstract: Uncovered plot to blow up American Embassy in Paris has given law enforcement officials across Europe glimpse of how Osama bin Laden has operated in their midst and has offered clues about Sept 11 terrorist attacks, as well as how future plots might unfold; at center of plot was Jamal Beghal, Frenchman of Algerian origin who had fallen into drug use and petty crime; Beghal, waiting for signal from bin Laden's operatives in Afghanistan to strike, was arrested in transit, and he talked, spilling to French interrogators details of what could have been one of deadliest terrorist attacks in France in more than decade; photo (M)

headline: Words of Confidence About Afghanistan Mission and Central Asian Peace
abstract: Excerpts from news conference given by Pres Bush and Gen Tommy R Franks on progress of war in Afghanistan (M)

headline: 2 Food Companies Hire New Agencies
abstract: 2 Food Companies Hire New Agencies.

headline: More Gloomy Economic News as Consumer Spending Slumps
abstract: National Assn of Purchasing Management reports manufacturing in October 2001 turned in its worst performance since 1990-1991 recession, with consumer spending showing biggest drop in almost 15 years; factory index fell to 39.8, from 47 in September; Commerce Dept reports consumer spending fell 1.8 percent in September, in aftermath of terrorist attacks; Labor Dept reports number of people filing initial claims for jobless benefits fell by 10,000 in most recent week, to 499,000; reports construction spending declined 0.4 in September, fifth consecutive monthly drop; graphs (M)

headline: Was the French Ruling on Yahoo Such a Victory After All?
abstract: A federal ruling that U.S. protections of free speech trumped a French order requiring Yahoo to remove Nazi materials has some legal experts speculating that little has changed.

headline: Health and Sports Officials Join In World Fight Against Smoking
abstract: World Health Orgn joins with top athletes and sports organizations, including auto racing and soccer, to begin global effort to eliminate tobacco advertising in sports world; WHO contends that such a campaign is essential to break link between smoking and glamorous sports world; WHO's country members meet in third round of negotiations to hammer out global antitobacco treaty; WHO sees tobacco-free sports as first step in worldwide advertising ban on tobacco products (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Opposition To Hynix Plan
abstract: Korea Exchange Bank, lead creditor for Hynix Semiconductor, encounters opposition from some creditors opposed to new $5.3 billion plan for rescuing company; HSBC Holdings and two regional South Korean banks will pull out of plan if possible by selling their loans to other creditors; since Hynix owes them $27 million out of total debts of $6.8 billion, their reluctance is not likely to derail approval of plan; other creditors have objected to component in plan that calls for infusion of nearly $800 million in fresh loans (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Enron Seeks Bankruptcy And Takes Dynegy to Court  Enron filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, but sought to remain in business with the support of its creditors.    The company also said it sued Dynegy for billions of dollars in damages for withdrawing its buyout offer. [Page A1.]    Steve Jobs Rejects Microsoft Plan  Apple Computer's chairman and chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, says that Microsoft's proposal to settle antitrust lawsuits would allow it to dig into the education market, one of the few Microsoft does not dominate. Microsoft has proposed giving away $1 billion in software, hardware and expertise to the nation's poorest schools to end 100 class-action lawsuits. [C3.]

headline: HEALTHSOUTH SAYS FIRST QUARTER WILL EXCEED FORECASTS
abstract: HealthSouth Corp says first-quarter earnings will be about 27 cents a share, exceeding forecasts (S)

headline: KODAK SCHEDULES SHAREHOLDER VOTE ON OPTION PLAN
abstract: Eastman Kodak sets shareholder vote on its plan to revalue stock options after 22 percent 2001 drop in its share price (S)

headline: Surrender Deal May Hinge on Amnesty for Mullah Omar
abstract: The Taliban agreed on Thursday to surrender the city of Kandahar, but negotiators had yet to resolve the fate of Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader.

headline: Official Says Resisting Bill On Terror Puts Britain at Risk
abstract: Home Sec David Blunkett warns that British alliance with US makes it likeliest European target for terrorists and that 'naive' parliamentary resistance to antiterrorism legislation increases risk; reacts to House of Lords' addition of seven limiting amendments to hard-line measure government is rushing through Parliament (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Suharto Kin's Trial Opens
abstract: Ari Sigit, grandson of former Pres Suharto of Indonesia, goes on trial on weapons charges (S)

headline: Berlin Cameron Agency Won't Seek G.M. Work
abstract: Berlin Cameron & Partners decides not to compete for General Motors; Saturn account (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Talks On Asylum Seekers
abstract: Indonesia's Foreign Min Hasan Wirayuda says country plans conference on flood of Middle Eastern asylum seekers passing through en route to Australia, which is refusing to accept them (S)

headline: Energy Industry Shudders Again After Downgrade of Dynegy Debt
