abstract: Shares of electricity and natural gas companies fall after Moody's Investors Service downgrades of Dynegy bonds to lowest investment-grade rung; company tries to restore confidence by announcing that it will trim spending, reduce debt and raise new cash by selling shares in 2002; wariness on Wall Street prompts Dynegy and other independent power plant operators to cancel plans to build new generating facilities; photo (M)

headline: A High-Powered Deal Maker Is Named to Lead Lazard
abstract: Bruce Wasserstein, a Wall Street deal maker who rose to prominence in the 1980's, is taking the top job at Lazard L.L.C., an investment bank adrift after a string of defections.    Mr. Wasserstein sold his own investment boutique, Wasserstein Perella & Company, to Dresdner Bank just over a year ago, and became executive chairman of Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, as the investment banking division was renamed. But that relationship soured after Dresdner was acquired in March by the huge German insurer Allianz A.G., people close to the companies said.

headline: A Way to Catch Up On Retirement Savings
abstract: Treasury Department issues regulations to carry out provisions of tax law that lift cap on contributions to 401(k) and 403(k) retirement plans and IRA's and allow people over 50 to make 'catch-up contributions' to such plans (S)

headline: BRITISH AIRWAYS PROFIT SHARING STUDY IS URGED
abstract: Three major US airlines file motion seeking that British Airways provide US regulators with more information as part of its application for permission to share sales and profits on some flights with American Airlines (S)

headline: U.S. Missions Are Stocking Antibiotics
abstract: State Dept orders diplomatic missions to stock up on antibiotics to counter any attack using anthrax (M)

headline: Philippine Troops Hunt Elusive Foes
abstract: Abu Sayyaf guerrillas on Philippine island of Basilan number fewer than 100, but they are able to elude 5,000 government troops because they are protected by island's thick jungle, intimate with its creeks and caves and ravines and nourished and protected by sympathetic villagers, to whom they give part of ransom money paid for kidnapped foreigners; photo; map (M)

headline: A Jukebox That Holds Enough To Get You From Here to 2002
abstract: D-Link's new portable hard drive, intended for toting around music, offers 10 gigabytes of memory, enough for over 130 hours of music at standard MP3 quality; photo (S)

headline: Terror Money Hard to Block, Officials Find
abstract: Despite progress in unraveling finances of September 11 terrorist attack against US, federal investigators report difficulty in dismantling overall financing of Al Qaeda, which is far-flung and diversified to extent that it could survive, even if Osama bin Laden is captured or killed; vast, murky and expansive financial web described; organization uses amalgam of private enterprises, corporate shells and charities that are structured like financial archipelago with connections hidden beneath surface; photo (M)

headline: Change and Fear in Colombia Rights Panel
abstract: Some supporters of specialized human rights unit within Colombia's national atty general's office, which, working under death threats, has investigated some of most horrific massacres and assassinations, begin to criticize new atty general, Luis Camilo Osorio, who they fear may stall investigations against right-wing paramilitary groups and rogue military officers; they fear that Osorio, close ally of Pres Andres Pastrana, was selected to mend relations between Pastrana and an army bruised by recent investigations; military officials have been implicated in some mass murders (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: JOHNSON CONTROLS, Milwaukee, said it had won a contract with J. C. Penney, Plano, Tex., to maintain systems at 1,080 stores.    PEOPLE'S POTTERY, Rochester, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, listing assets and debts both of $10 million to $50 million.

headline: U.S. Wireless Talks Go On, With Court Deadline Today
abstract: Federal officials and executives from several wireless communications companies are still trying to reach settlement over disputed ownership of $16 billion worth of wireless spectrum licenses; government has filing deadline if it wants Supreme Court to hear dispute; at issue are more than 200 wireless licenses that Federal Communications Commission auctioned in January for about $16 billion, after previous owner of airwave spectrum, NextWave Telecom, filed for bankruptcy (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: F.T.C. Challenges Merger
abstract: Federal Trade Commission says it will challenge MSC Software Corp's 1999 acquisition of Universal Analytics and Computerized Structural Analysis and Research; MSC is global supplier of engineering software called Nastran; two companies were only other companies that provided advanced versions of Nastran; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Portuguese TV Venture Stalls
abstract: Chairman of PT Multimedia, Portugal Telecom unit that began first interactive TV service using Microsoft software, says company will delay expansion of service because of technical glitches; PT Multimedia's TV Cabo is world's first cable network to provide interactive television over broadband network using Microsoft system (S)

headline: London Journal; This Mild Schoolboy, Lost in the Islamic Inferno
abstract: Article on Ahmed Omar Sheikh, son of well-to-do Pakistani merchant who migrated to Britain, dropped out of London School of Economics and joined gang that kidnapped British tourists in India on behalf of Kashmiri separatist group now viewed as one of myriad Islamic groups possibly linked to Osama bin Laden; Sheikh's journey from middle-class security to perilous and violent life of terrorism is mystery to his former associates, friends and family; photos (M)

headline: MGM Loss Reflects New Accounting Rule
abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer reports $16 million third-quarter loss, compared with profit of $27.1 million in 2000 period; says net income would have been record $28.2 million without change in accounting rules for marketing costs (M)

headline: Thunderous Attack Heard in Kabul
abstract: Sending bright flashes of light and loud concussions rolling across the farming plain just 35 miles north of Kabul, American military forces began what looked like a steady bombardment.

headline: 2 Enron Roles Raise Questions Of Allegiance
abstract: Frank Savage's dual role as executive and director of Alliance Capital Management, which aggressively bought Enron stock through its downward spiral, and Enron director has raised questions about his allegiances and whether Alliance's position as money manager was compromised; many fund companies bar executives from sitting on boards of companies in which they invest; Alliance denies conflict, noting he was not involved in money management (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Job Cuts At Bank
abstract: Deutsche Bank plans toï

headline: Yielding (or Not) to the Magic of Exotica
abstract: Charles Herold reviews two computer games, Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura from Troika Games and Road to India from Microids; photos (M)

headline: Kuwaitis Still Missing 11 Years After Invasion
abstract: Relatives of 605 Kuwaitis missing since Iraqi invasion and occupation in 1990 fear they have been forgotten, despite marches, protests, UN reports and Amnesty International condemnations; photo; map; most of those sent to prisons in Iraq and never heard from again were civilians who refused to cooperate with occupying force (M)

headline: Flextronics to Cut Jobs After Loss
abstract: Flextronics International Ltd, second-largest manufacturer of electronics, reports fiscal second-quarter loss and says it is cutting 10,000 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force; loss was $329.8 million, compared with net income of $49.9 million year earlier; sales rose 5.4 percent, to $3.24 billion (S)

headline: Grand Jury Indicts Ex-I.R.S. Employee
abstract: Elmer K Mackey, former Internal Revenue Service employee, is indicted on charges of taking $2,750 in seven separate bribes, plus part of initial $5,000 bribe, to delay collection actions against taxpayer; that person was represented by income tax preparer who was undercover agent for Treasury Department's inspector general for tax administration (S)

headline: Troops Seize Airstrip NearTaliban Base : U.S. Marines Land in Afghanistan
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Hundreds of U.S. Marines consolidated a bridgehead Monday at an airfield in southern Afghanistan, poised to dramatically increase pressure on the Taliban in their final redoubt of Kandahar and to intensify the hunt for Osama bin Laden.

headline: Hewlett Urged to Abandon Compaq Merger
abstract: Matrix Asset Advisors says Hewlett-Packard should drop its proposed $19.6 billion purchase of Compaq Computer Corp as shares fall and rivals gear up to take customers; Matrix owns more than 531,000 shares of Hewlett-Packard and more than 826,000 shares of Compaq (S)

headline: Business; In a Chorus of Caution, Some Still Chant Boldness
abstract: Most US companies scale back on all types of spending amid uncertainty created by Sept 11 terrorism, but a few executives plunge ahead, hoping to take advantage of current environment and get ahead of rivals; photo (M)

headline: F.D.A. CLEARS JOHNSON & JOHNSON BIRTH CONTROL PATCH
abstract: F.D.A. Clears Johnson & J

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls as military strikes on Afghanistan fuel concern that economic recovery will be delayed; in New York, dollar settles at 119.38 yen, down from 120.34 yen; graph; chart (M)

headline: Reporters in Afghanistan: Fear, Numbness and Being a Spectacle
abstract: Impressions of New York Times reporter Amy Waldman as she travels through Afghanistan, especially describing interviews she conducts with women concealed from head to toe in burkas; photo (M)

headline: Interpublic Group Acquires an Agency
abstract: Interpublic Group of Cos acquires Trans World Marketing; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Sales To Fall
abstract: Japanese Automobile Manufacturers Assn projects that sales of Japanese automobiles will probably decline for second consecutive year in 2002 as fallout from Sept 11 terrorist attacks on US continues to cripple global economy (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Execution Moratorium Lifted
abstract: Filipino Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo lifts moratorium on capital punishment and says kidnappers should be executed as soon as possible; ransom kidnappings are entrenched in Philippines (S)

headline: HotJobs.com Tells Suitor to Surpass a Rival Bid From Yahoo
abstract: hotjobs.com tells suit

headline: Oil Prices Decline on Pessimism Over Russian Production Cuts
abstract: Crude oil prices fall on speculation that Russia will not reduce its daily output beyond 50,000 barrels already announced for remainder of 2001, just a quarter of what OPEC would prefer; graphs (M)

headline: Bombs Aim To Put Heat On Taliban And Pakistan
abstract: The American bombing of Taliban front-line defenses north of Kabul today appeared intended to put pressure not only on the Islamic extremist rulers of most of Afghanistan, but also on their traditional backers in Pakistan, Western diplomats said.    The Pakistanis have insisted that any post-Taliban government in Afghanistan be friendly to Islamabad, and do not want the Northern Alliance, which opposes the Taliban, to take over Kabul. But American intelligence officials and foreign diplomats have voiced frustration with the slow pace of Pakistan's efforts to negotiate a broad-based coalition of Afghan groups that might combine with the Northern Alliance in a new government.

headline: OWNER OF GRAND OLE OPRY TO SELL CHRISTIAN MUSIC LABEL
abstract: Gaylord Entertainment Co, owner of Nashville's Grand Ole Opry, is seeking to sell its Word Entertainment Christian music label; reports third-quarter loss widened to $45.2 million, compared with $19.1 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Outlook
abstract: Fiat SpA will not meet its 2001 targets for operating profit and debt reduction; plans to cut car production in Italy by 100,000 units by end of year (S)

headline: Bayer Agrees to Charge Government a Lower Price for Anthrax Medicine
abstract: Bayer AG agrees to sell United States government 100 million tablets of anthrax drug Cipro by end of year for 95 cents each and donate another 2 million tablets beginning next week; government gets option to buy more of drug at lower prices; Health Sec Tommy G Thompson, stressing deep discount and large shipments planned, holds there is no need to hoard Cipro or other antibiotics; Johnson & Johnson says it will ask Food and Drug Administration to approve use of antibiotic Levaquin to treat anthrax; offers to donate 100 million tablets to government; Bayer says it wants FDA to approve its drug Avelox to treat anthrax; Bristol-Myers Squibb says it has already asked FDA to approve Tequin; Sen Charles E Schumer, who led criticisms of price and availability of Cipro, hails deal; scores Bayer for continuing to charge pharmacies $4.67 a tablet (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Planned
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Alamosa Holdings, Lubbock, Tex., eight million shares. Salomon Smith Barney, J. P. Morgan Securities and Merrill Lynch.

headline: Bailout for Airlines Showed the Weight Of a Mighty Lobby
abstract: Article traces airline industry's successful campaign for multibillion-dollar bailout, masterful lobbying effort that began day after terrorists hijacked four airliners on Sept 11; platoons of well-connected lobbyists, including Linda Hall Daschle, wife of Senate leader, quickly settled on simplest plan of seeking cash and loan payments at time when airlines were still grounded and nation was shocked; speed with which Congress agreed to $15-billion package, just 11 days after attack, is testimony to lobby's power and skill; photo; Sen Peter G Fitzgerald, who cast lone Senate vote against deal, describes full-court press by usually unpopular industry to convince Congress that giving out billions in taxpayer cash was only way to 'save the republic'; same lobby also managed to weaken airport security measures following 1988 Pan Am 103 bombing, and more recently headed off passenger bill of rights and got Pres Bush to block strike; 27 in-house lobbyists are augmented by lobbyists from 42 Washington firms; lineup includes former White House aides, Cabinet members and lawmakers; lobbying was aimed at few key leaders including Repr Richard Gephardt, Sec Norman Mineta and Bush chief of staff Andrew Card; Repr George Miller tells how 'big dog got the bone,' even as pleas to protect airline workers were ignored (M)

headline: Where's bin Laden? Here's One Hunch
abstract: Hajji Zaman Khan Ghum Shareek, Jalalabad, Afghanistan, commander of Eastern Shura, region's self-proclaimed government, says American forces are on ground in area and have enlisted local commanders to help search for Osama bin Laden in isolated mountain hide-outs south of city; reports asking scouting party of tribal leaders to go to Tora Bora, where he suspects bin Laden and senior Al Qaeda network leaders are hiding; photo (M)

headline: Drugs Aside, Drugstores Feel the Pain Of Prudence
abstract: Mark Husson, food and drug retailing analyst at Merrill Lynch, answers questions on outlook for drugstore chains like Rite Aid, CVS and Duane Reade, which are in a slump; photo (M)

headline: Japan Talks Tough After a Naval Battle
abstract: Japan's prime minister, a nationalist who has raised the profile of the country's military, called for increased territorial vigilance after the Japanese Coast Guard traded heavy fire with a vessel suspected of being a North Korean spy ship. The ship sank just inside an economic zone claimed by China, and its crew of 15 is believed to have drowned.    Article, Page A9.

headline: Florida Community Can't Shut Down 'Voyeur Dorm'
abstract: Recently, a federal appeals court handed municipal officials in Tampa, Fla., another setback in their effort to relocate a company that operates an adult Web site known as Voyeur Dorm.

headline: KPMG Is Paying $9 Million To Settle Medical Fraud Case
abstract: KPMG agrees to pay $9 million to settle government accusations that it helped group of hospitals in Florida and Kentucky defraud Medicare through use of bogus expense claims; government lawsuit against KPMG is outgrowth of multiyear probe of company now known as HCA-The Healthcare Co; Federal investigators have said in court records that they think HCA and its predecessor companies engaged in corporatewide effort to cheat government by misrepresenting certain expenses, which were then reimbursed by Medicare; at issue is complex, little-understood program known as federal cost-reporting system, under which government has paid billions of dollars to hospitals and other health care providers, including hundreds of millions of dollars in payments each year to HCA (M)

headline: Technology & Media; A Surge in Demand To Use Biometrics
abstract: Sept 11 terrorist attacks spur rapid interest in biometrics, which utilizes equipment that identifies people using characteristics thought to be unique to each individual; demand benefits device manufacturers and large information technology integrators; shows no sign of abating; photo (M)

headline: Networks See Threat in New Video Recorder
abstract: ABC, CBS and NBC are suing SonicBlue, charging its latest personal video recorder would deprive them of revenue and reduce their incentive to create programming by allowing users to record programs without commercials, rather than merely enabling them to fast-forward throught them; new unit also lets viewers send stored programs to other users over Internet, feature networks say infringes on their copyrights; networks seek to block sales of device; photo (M)

headline: North Korea Is Muted On ABM Pact
abstract: North Korea notes international community's concern about Pres Bush's decision to withdraw from 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, but adds no criticism of its own; governing party newspaper holds ties with United States have reached 'point of explosion' because of Bush administration's policies; conflicting signals suggest North Korea might be open to dialogue with US and South Korea (M)

headline: Afghan Talks Advancing, But Crucial Issues Remain
abstract: Four Afghan factions negotiating shape of provisional government for Afghanistan begin to offer names of possible council members, but they have not grappled with vital issues like how many seats each faction might get or what role former king might play; nor has there been much talk about multinational security force that might help keep peace in Kabul; Yunus Qanooni of Northern Alliance does appear to be more open about possiblity of foreign security force as part of broader agreement on future government (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Agreement WitH I.M.F.
abstract: The International Monetary Fund said it had reached agreement with Indonesia on economic reforms that must be carried out in return for the release of the next $360 million allotment of a $5 billion economic support program. The reforms, to be carried out in the next year, include reducing public debt and improving the justice and banking systems.   Seth Mydans (NYT)

headline: BNP PARIBAS BUYS MAJORITY STAKE IN CAPSTAR PARTNERS
abstract: BNP Paribas SA acquires 60 percent of Capstar Partners LLC (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Abkhazia: Withdrawal Offer By Putin
abstract: Pres Vladimir Putin offers to withdraw Russian peacekeepers from Abkhazia, separatist Georgian region, to calm dispute with Georgia, which accuses Russia of sending Islamic fundamentalist guerrillas to disrupt Abkhazia's rulers

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: A Lifeline From The U.S.
abstract: Mexico says remittances from Mexicans living in US will top $9 billion this year and probably replace tourism as nation's second-largest source of foreign revenue behind oil exports (S)

headline: Retailers Battle For Loyalty of British Shopper
abstract: LONDON—  The tough fight for business among Britain's fashion retailers just got tougher. A spate of initiatives launched this autumn is raising the temperature to boiling point.

headline: AT&T SELLS OFF WIRELESS STAKE FOR $1.4 BILLION
abstract: at&t sells off wireless stR

headline: Cookies and Spam Provide The EU Much to Chew Over
abstract: PARIS—  The European Union's proposal to protect Internet users from an unappetizing meal of cookies and spam has become a lot harder to digest than expected.

headline: Mahathir's Malaysia: No Gays Allowed
abstract: Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who has made homophobia national policy, tells BBC that even British cabinet member would be ejected if he arrived with 'boyfriend' (S)

headline: Msgr. Mattia Pei Shangde, 83, Unofficial Bishop of Beijing
abstract: Msgr Mattia Pei Shangde, Catholic priest imprisoned for his loyalty to pope and regarded as unofficial bishop of Beijing, dies at 83 (S)

headline: Making Better Toys and Jumbo Jets by Sharing the Rough Draft
abstract: Collaborative design in three dimensions is made possible by innovations called 'rapid prototyping'; these innovations allow greater collaboration, shorter cycle times, higher quality and wider customizing; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertising Concern Lowers Outlook
abstract: world business b

headline: Restoring the Heart of Ford
abstract: Nicholas V Scheele, Ford Motor Co's new chief operating officer and president of automotive operations, is preparing plan on how to revive company, whose profits have been turning into losses; faces even bigger task than turnaround he engineered at Jaguar or improvements he made at Ford of Europe; analysts expect him to bring some of innovations he used in Europe to US; Scheele comments; photos (M)

headline: Sweet Memories
abstract: Karen Cole Huttlinger letter comments on Michelle Slatalla's Nov 29 column on buying candy online, which mentioned Fannie May candy

headline: Accounts
abstract: Two agencies owned by Interpublic Group of Companies, Draft Worldwide and Golin/Harris International, secure Symbol Technologies advertising account (S)

headline: U.N. Says Four Billion Will Be Living in Hunger by 2050
abstract: United Nations Population Fund puts world's population at 6.1 billion, double what it was in 1960; projects it will reach 9.3 billion by 2050, with all of growth in developing nations and population stable in industrialized world; says two billion people already lack sufficient food, number expected to rise to 4.2 billion by 2050 (S)

headline: Uzbek Who Exposed Rights Abuses to Be Honored in New York
abstract: Ismail Adilov, Uzbek human rights monitor invited to United States to speak about his imprisonment and torture at hands of security police in Tashkent, is granted permission to leave country; will be honored in New York by Human Rights Watch in awards ceremony at Cathedral Church of St John the Divine; Adilov's travel has been uncertain for weeks (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Diamond Agreement
abstract: De Beers reaches agreement to buy $800 million worth of diamonds a year from Alrosa of Russia; agreement allows Russia to more than double volume of rough-cut diamonds it sells outside cartel (S)

headline: Credit Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills, tomorrow's sale of four-week bills and Wednesday's sale of two-year notes.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.92 percent and on a six-month bill 1.98 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 3.22 percent.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Protesting A Neo-Nazi March
abstract: Shopkeepers on Kurfurstendamm in Berlin will black out windows to protest expected neo-Nazi march on national holiday to mark reunification of Germany (S)

headline: Australian Doctors Admit Helping Patients Die
abstract: Case of doctor acquitted of murdering dying patient and survey indicating many surgeons have hastened death for terminally ill are renewing debate in Australia about laws that bar doctors from helping patients end their lives; survey finds one in three general surgeons had given patients drugs intended to hasten death and one in five had done so without patient's knowledge or consent (M)

headline: F.D.A. APPROVES SALE OF ULCER DRUG MADE BY ANDRX
abstract: Shares of Andrx Corp, drug maker, rise about 8 percent after regulators approve its generic version of AstraZeneca's ulcer medicine Prilosec, world's best-selling drug (S)

headline: U.S. Watchful As Iran Envoy Seeks Weapons From Russians
abstract: Iran's defense minister Ali Shamkhani arrives, Moscow, to conclude long-delayed talks on large purchase of Russian arms long opposed by US; agenda will likely also include discussions of Tehran's role in global campaign against terror and will be monitored closely by US (S)

headline: Investing; It's Not What They Know, but Whom
abstract: Gerson Lehrman Group, Leerink Swann & Co and Off the Record Research, boutique research firms, connect investors with industry specialists to provide information difficult to get elsewhere; many investment professionals do not trust depth, objectivity and exclusivity of research available through brokerage firms and investment banks; drawing; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: India Is Asked For Help To Fight Rebels
abstract: Government of Nepal asks India for helicopters and ammunition to fight Maoist rebellion that began in 1996 and has cost about 350 lives in just past week; spokeswoman says Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee of India has assured King Gyanendra that India is ready to give whatever help is needed (S)

headline: Who Pays If Argentina Devalues Its Currency?
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column on prospect of devaluation of Argentine peso; notes that different ways of going about it would produce different sets of winners and losers; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CAL-MAINE FOODS, Jackson, Miss., the country's largest egg producer, said it had decided against taking the company private, citing poor economics and general market turmoil.    CALPINE, San Jose, Calif., an independent power company, said it would build a $400 million power plant outside Fort Mills, S.C., and had asked regulators to license a $605 million power plant in San Joaquin, Calif.

headline: World Tourism Officials Look Hard for Optimism
abstract: Delegates to World Tourism Organization meeting in Osaka, Japan, believe world tourism will continue to expand in long term despite terrorist attacks; Francesco Frangialli, organization's secretary general, says air security issues will be resolved, consumer confidence will return, and after bad fourth quarter of 2001, world tourism will resume growing by 4 percent per year; says some countries, like China, will probably gain, while others, like US, will probably lose; photo (M)

headline: A New Story For 2 Rivals From the 70's
abstract: Article on Bob Woodward of Washington Post and Seymour M Hersh, now with New Yorker, competing while reporting on America's battle against terrorism; both had previously competed in 1970's while reporting on Watergate scandal; photo (M)

headline: Shares Rise Despite Poor Earnings and Economic Figures
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 172.92 points, to 9,377.03; Nasdaq composite index rises 36.77 points, to 1,708.08; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 16.42 points, to 1,089.90; tables; graph (M)

headline: NORTHROP HALTS SHIP PROJECT; 1,750 WORKERS AFFECTED
abstract: Northrop Grumman stops building two 1,900-passenger cruise ships for American Classic Voyages, move that will idle about 1,750 employees, or 17 percent of staff, at its Pascagoula, Miss, shipyard; move comes less than week after American Classic Voyages filed Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and failed to get federal loan to complete ships (S)

headline: More Swissair Problems
abstract: Plan to salvage Swissair's core flight operations by transferring them to financially healthier regional subsidiary, Crossair, is again in doubt; cost estimates for transition have soared to $2.5 billion, and cash to keep Swissair flying until Oct 28 takeover date is drying up; combined new carrier must file winter schedule with international authorities by Oct 22 (S)

headline: U.N. Will Send Food to Zimbabwe's Hungry
abstract: UN World Food Program will send food aid to more than half million Zimbabweans, reflection of deepening hunger crisis on country that has traditionally been one of Africa's most self-sufficient; drought, violent land takeovers and crumbling economy cited (S)

headline: A Traffic Jam of Résumés
abstract: Heavy volume of resumes sent online to prospective employers causes traffic jam, confounding job seekers' desire for rapid response (S)

headline: Innovation Is Back, With Attitude
abstract: Innovation is seen alive and well; review of some of technologies that may someday becopme regular fixtures in our homes and garages; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Steel Maker Cuts Outlook
abstract: Nippon Steel Corp, Japan's largest steel maker, cut its profit outlook for this year by 35 percent as it scrambles to cut production amid falling steel exports and sagging domestic construction industry (S)

headline: Bin Laden Family, With Deep Western Ties, Strives to Re-establish a Name
abstract: Bin Laden family, with strong Western ties, is striving to re-establish its name in wake of terrorist attacks on US that are linked to Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network; Abdullah bin Laden, Harvard Law School alumnus, has set out to protect family name by seeking out advisers in law and political consulting; family is owner of Saudi Binladin Group, corporate giant with tens of thousands of employees and business dealings with companies like General Electric and Motorola Inc; American business executives say family members do business with array of financial institutions, including Goldman, Sachs, Citigroup and Deutschebank; until earlier in month, family also had stake in Carlyle Group, Washington investment firm with ties to luminaries in politics; chart; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; Small Gains in a Quiet Holiday Week
abstract: Stock market performance in week ended Dec 28 reviewed; graphs; tables (S)

headline: Personal Business; It's Not Grandma's Clearance Sale. It's Online and Worth Billions.
abstract: Retailers and manufactuers are going online to conduct clearance sales and unload returned goods, closeouts and other orphaned merchandise; realize more rapid sales, better prices and fewer middlemen online and can thus recoup more on such goods than they could a decade ago; options are many, for buyer as well as seller; photos (M)

headline: People
abstract: Steven Farella, chief executive at Media Planning, resigns (S)

headline: Argentina's Provinces Struggle to Stay Afloat
abstract: Gov. Alfredo Avelín is an eccentric country doctor known for his homespun philosophy, his poetry and a peculiar habit of playfully slapping the faces of visitors to his office.     So perhaps it is not surprising that the other day he broke into a full-throated rendition of the tango classic ''It's a Kid's Dream'' when asked about President Fernando de la Rúa's plans to balance the federal budget to avert a national financial collapse.

headline: 3 U.S. Servicemen Killed by 'Friendly Fire' Near Kandahar
abstract: Three American servicemen were killed today and 19 were wounded when a B-52 bombing mission north of Kandahar in Afghanistan went astray, the Pentagon said.

headline: Bid for Italian Bank's Latin American Unit
abstract: Banco Itau SA tenders unspecified bid for IntesaBci SpA division Banque Sudameris SA excluding its Peruvian and Argentine businesses (S)

headline: Private Sector; Bringing Up Baby Einstein
abstract: Walt Disney Co's acquisition of Baby Einstein Co last week noted; Baby Einstein's owner Julie Aigner-Clark comments; photo (S)

headline: A Former U.S. Envoy Links Greek Politicians to Assassin Group
abstract: Tensions between Greece and United States rise after former American Amb Thomas Niles, during appearance on Greek television, links nation's ruling political elite to terrorist group held responsible for series of assassinations of Americans and others in recent years; he says he gave Greek authorities list of potential suspects in 1995 and that government did not follow up; government scores Niles (M)

headline: Mortgage Delinquency Rate Hits 10-Year High
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Association reports that mortgage delinquency rate rose to 4.87 percent in third quarter, a 10-year record (M)

headline: Taliban Arab, Like Many, Longs for Home but Faces a Doubtful Fate
abstract: Fate is uncertain for hundreds of foreign soldiers who fought with Taliban and who are now imprisoned by Northern Alliance; they are foreign soldiers in civil war; their rights are uncertain, and no one--neither Northern Alliance, which took them, nor foreign countries, which spawned them--seems to want them anymore; many of men say they heeded call of aged mullahs who told them to wage holy war, and men set off with little sense of where they were going or what their war was about; many say they tried to leave very day they landed; some prisoners of Northern Alliance in Mazar-i-Sharif, including Fahad Nasir, Saudi Taliban fighter, Pakistani Taliban members Muhammed Jamalhuddin and Amzah Zia Shah, and Abdul Satar Nafisi, Pakistani who says he was journalist captured along with Pakistani soldiers, comment; photos (M)

headline: German Coalition a Bit Shaky as Greens Ask Bombing Pause
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's coalition looked a little shakier today, after a senior Green Party politician called on the United States to pause in its bombing of Afghanistan.

headline: Palestinians Still Stunned by Shooting by Their Own Police
abstract: Palestinians in Gaza are stunned and outraged that their own police would use same tactic as Israeli soldiers--firing live bullets--to quell demonstrations, shooting dead two young Palestinians protesting United States airstrikes on Afghanistan; say shootings will undermine Yasir Arafat's strength; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swissair Employees Protest
abstract: Employees of Swissair Group halt several flights at Geneva's airport, protesting possible cut in pay and loss of benefits as airline's operations wind down; they demonstrate against Crossair, Swissair's former regional subsidiary (S)

headline: New Currency Won't Really Arrive Until Its Baptism on the Street : Buck?Maggy?Euro Needs Handle, Too
abstract: PARIS—  When Europeans exchange their moolah for the euro, they will begin a journey that will reshape not only culture but vocabulary.

headline: Charms of Bittersweet Solidarity
abstract: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column discusses changed rules of workplace following Sept 11 terrorist attacks; bemoans piles of mail that remain unopened due to anthrax fears, and ubiquitous identification tags worn by employees; drawing (M)

headline: Amgen Is Said To Make Offer Of $18 Billion For Immunex
abstract: Amgen Inc is negotiating to acquire Immunex Corp for about $18 billion in what would be biggest merger ever in biotechnology industry; payment would consist mostly of Amgen stock; three other large deals among biotechnology companies have been announced in recent weeks (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Thomas Clark was named vice president and co-creative director at Catalyst Communications, South Plainfield, N.J. He had been associate creative director at Integrated Communications, Parsippany, N.J.

headline: Foes Claim Taliban Are Killing Soldiers Who Seek to Defect
abstract: Northern Alliance forces say foreign soldiers fighting for Taliban are klilling Afghan Taliban comrades in desperate effort to hang on to encircled city of Kunduz; refugees and alliance soldiers say foreign Taliban soldiers have gathered in city for what appears to be last stand; say they gunned down more than 400 Afghan Taliban soldiers trying to defect to Northern Alliance in mass shooting, prompted in part by defection of local Taliban commander; Arab and Pakistani soldiers with Taliban are reportedly shooting young civilian men of Uzbek and Tajik ethnic groups suspected of trying to escape territory controlled by Northern Alliance; photos (M)

headline: President Named At G. P. Putnam
abstract: Carole Baron, longtime publisher of commercial fiction and president of Dutton division of Penguin Putnam, is named president of its G P Putnam & Sons division of as well; fills position that was held by Phyllis Grann (S)

headline: LAWSUIT AGAINST BANK OF NEW YORK IS DISMISSED
abstract: Federal Judge Denny Chin dismisses shareholder lawsuit against Bank of New York that accused 19 senior officials of permitting bank to launder money when it expanded in Russia during 1990's (S)

headline: Next Step: To Establish A Just Rule For the City
abstract: Capture of Mazar-i-Sharif brings both opportunity and potential risk for Bush administration in Afghanistan; if handled well, city could become model of enlightened power sharing, encouraging defections from Taliban and signaling hope for stable postwar government, but, if handled badly, city could serve to harden resolve of Taliban as they retreat to their stronghold in southern Afghanistan and call on sympathies of their Pashtun ethnic kin in northern provinces of Pakistan (M)

headline: Dubai Clinic Denies Report Bin Laden Met With CIA
abstract: PARIS—  A wave of skepticism and outright denials greeted a French newspaper report Wednesday that Osama bin Laden had been hospitalized in a Dubai clinic for kidney care for 10 days in July and met there with a U.S. intelligence operative — just weeks before the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

headline: Bank Chief Vows to Stay in Post for Full 8-Year Term : ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged
abstract: FRANKFURT—  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED October 13th, 2001:

headline: EUROPEANS FINE ARCHER AND OTHERS FOR PRICE FIXING
abstract: European Commission fines Archer Daniels Midland Co and five other companies total of 57.5 million euros ($52.7 million) for price fixing and antitrust violations in market for sodium gluconate, chemical used mainly for cleaning glass and metal; other companies are Akzo Nobel NV, Avebe BA, Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Co Ltd, Jungbunzlauer AG and Roquette Freres SA (S)

headline: Little Children in the Middle as Adults Battle in Belfast
abstract: Young girls who walk through working-class Protestant area of Belfast on way to their Roman Catholic elementary school continue to face daily abuse; crowd of angry protesters has thinned to few dozen; police have been providing security for six weeks at cost of $73,000 a day; parents fear psychological damage; Protestants complain political reforms carried out by tottering home-rule government have left them feeling ignored and vulnerable; photo (M)

headline: First Boston Seen Settling Kickback Case
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston is expected to pay $100 million to securities regulators to end investigation into whether it received kickbacks from buyers of hot stock offerings in late 1990's; penalty would amount to small fraction of investment banking fees and commissions firm reaped from underwriting technology stocks; regulators accuse firm of demanding that customers pay back some of their profits (M)

headline: Santarém Journal; Chicago Boy Makes Good (as Amazon's Bishop)
abstract: Interview with James M Ryan, former Chicago native who is Roman Catholic bishop emeritus of Santarem, Brazil; has served diocese, which includes 125,000 square miles of Amazon jungle, for past 60 years and is highly regarded among parishioners and Brazilians; retired in 1985; map; photos (M)

headline: To Be Young, Eager and Unwanted
abstract: Anna Bumenthal column on being laid off in tough job market; drawing (M)7

headline: AT&T's Board To Meet Today On Cable Sale Or a Spinoff
abstract: AT&T Corp's board will meet to decide whether to sell company's cable television operation or instead spin it off as independent company; AOL Time Warner, Comcast Corp and Cox Communications have each submitted bids to acquire business (M)

headline: Remembering, or Forgetting, A Donor's Name on Campus
abstract: William F Bagley Jr letter on Dec 9 article about philanthropist A Alfred Taubman, recently convicted in price-fixing scheme; discusses naming buildings after individuals

headline: Financial Officer Named
abstract: Coach Inc names Michael F Devine 3d chief financial officer, succeeding Richard Randall, who resigned (S)

headline: Phone Giants In Europe Shift Focus
abstract: European telecommunications companies, in effort to put free spending and rapid debt run-ups of last few years behind them, are searching for ways to squeeze revenue growth from existing assets; signs of new thrift are underscored by joint venture between BT Group and Marconi, and deal involving MMO2, wireless arm spun off by BT; BT-Marconi venture would convert about 30,000 pay phones into Internet terminals over three years; MMO2 reaches agreement to lease some unused capacity on its network to Hutchison 3G UK Holdings, which plans to begin new advanced digital phone service in Britain before end of 2001 (M)

headline: Residents in Rebel Village Tell of Rockets Fired by Taliban Forces
abstract: Residents of Charikar, Afghanistan, Northern Alliance village, say Taliban forces fired rockets at market, killing two people and wounding dozens; see move as retaliation for American airstrikes; urge continuation of bombing raids, interviews; Northern Alliances forces respond by shelling suspected Taliban position above bustling town; map; photos (M)

headline: The Caprice of Coffee
abstract: Price of raw coffee has plunged worldwide, and many growers are planting other corps, trying to become ore efficient or going out of business; situation is especially acute for farmers in Colombia; nowhere has bust been more devastating than in Latin America, which produces 60 percent of world's coffee and where some economies are heavily dependent on coffee exports; 60 coffee-growing countries are producing too much, resulting in oversupply and price slump; in year ended Sept 30, they churned out 115 million 132-pound bags, while world consumption reached only 108 million; much of glut has come from surge in production in Vietnam, where coffee is cheap because of labor costs and subsidies; Vietnam has surpassed Colombia as world's second-largest coffee producer; production there rose from million bags in late 1980's, to 13 million in last year; Brazil, number one grower, is also increasing production at low cost because farms are highly mechanized; map; photo (M)

headline: Brazil Gives Priority to Reaching Accords
abstract: Brazilian delegation to World Trade Organization talks lands in Qatar, hoping to lay groundwork for new accords even as trade liberalization is losing momentum around world; trade accords are a priority for Brazil as it tries to pare its huge current account deficit; but even with Brazil's currency, the real, down around 25 percent since January, exports have barely budged as global economic slowdown has scared investors away (M)

headline: Giovanni Leone, Italy's Ex-President, Dies at 93
abstract: Former Pres Giovanni Leone of Italy dies at age 93; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: World Briefing

headline: International Business; In Japan, a Lack of Political Will To Act Decisively on the Economy
abstract: Japan faces several more years in economic doldrums because of weak political leadership, weak control over government finances and huge corporate debts; reforms proposed by Prime Min Junichoro Koizumi, from having banks write off of billions of dollars in bad loans to letting weak companies fail, are stymied by traditionalists in his own party who want to use his reformist image to perpetuate their own power; photo (M)

headline: LIMITED AND INTIMATE BRANDS LOWER EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: Limited Inc and its Intimate Brands unit reduce their fiscal third-quarter earnings forecasts (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Treasury securities prices rise; 10-year note gains 9/32, to 102 21/32, and yields 4.66 percent; 30-year bond climbs 20/32, to 102 18/32, yielding 5.20 percent; table of key rates; graph (S)

headline: New Leaders Send a Signal By Hanging Bandit's Body
abstract: Northern Alliance, demonstrating willingness to impose harsh order over largely lawless territory around Aliabad, Afghanistan, attacks band of suspected robbers and hangs bullet-riddled body of man on public display for two days from tank barrel; men who killed suspected bandit say their severe brand of justice is effective deterrent and will keep roads safe (M)

headline: Reports Show New Signs of Weakness
abstract: More evidence emerged today that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks caused a severe deterioration in the nation's already-weak economy, as consumer demand contracted more sharply than Wall Street anticipated.

headline: Executions And Looting As Alliance Nears Kabul
abstract: Northern Alliance soldiers mark their advance toward Kabul with executions of Taliban soldiers and widespread looting; Taliban bodies and bunkers are plundered; looting and executions suggest that alliance soldiers, who have received extensive backing from United States, might prove difficult to control as their victories build; alliance forces are able to broach Taliban lines near Bagram Air Base and Khalazai when Taliban soldiers quickly leave their posts; American bombing raids appear to have destroyed enough Taliban tanks and artillery to swing battle in favor of alliance; photos (M)

headline: Taklimakan Journal; Eons of Tension Crowd a Remote Chinese Tomb
abstract: Beijing government is wary of Islamic holy site in far-western China's Taklimakan Desert; China is fighting small separatist movement in predominantly Islamic region, which has history of bloody clashes between its Muslims and Buddhists, its Turkic peoples nad Chinese; Muslim Uighur people of region often come to pray at tomb of Imam Asmu, general thought to have brought Islam to far-western China thousand years ago; region's devout Muslims consider tomb a sacred place and regard Imam Asmu, who was killed at site in battle with Buddhist soldiers, as Islamic hero; Chinese government is wary of such sites where faith can galvanize into political activism; photos; map (L)

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: The Koreas: A North-South Road
abstract: Negotiators from North and South Korea meet at base of Mount Kumkang in North Korea to discuss reopening an east coast road link (S)

headline: U.S. Imposes a Second Duty On Canadian Lumber Imports
abstract: Commerce Department accuses Canadian lumber producers of unfair trade practices and imposes double-digit duty on their exports to US; says it will impose antidumping duties averaging 12.6 percent on imports of softwood lumber, flooring and siding from six Canadian producers; duties, which range from 5.9 percent to 19.2 percent, are second imposed in last three months; countervailing duty of 19.3 percent was imposed on Aug 17; companies hit by duty noted (M)

headline: The Ad Council, criticized for its response to Sept. 11, moves ahead with plans to remake itself.
abstract: Advertising Council in New York is moving ahead with ambitious plans to reorganize its operations to better respond to significant changes in its mission after Sept 11; reorganization, centering on initiative named Ad Council Coalition Against Terrorism, comes after critics complained about myriad elements of organization's response to terrorist attacks; critics contend that council managers were too slow in marshaling Madison Avenue to respond, have produced fragmented series of one-shot campaigns rather than cohesive response, and have been too eager to take orders from Bush administration rather than develop their own strategy (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Israeli Minister Vacates Home After Assassination Warning
abstract: Israeli cabinet minister Danny Naveh and family move out of home in Israeli town near West Bank after warnings from security officials of possible assassination attempt by Palestinians (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar settles at 127.38 yen, three-year high; graphs (S)

headline: After ABM Treaty: New Freedom for U.S. in Different Kind of Arms Control
abstract: Ana

headline: Avista Shares Fall 12% to 21-Year Low
abstract: Shares of Avista Corp fall 12 percent after company reports third-quarter loss of 69 cents a share, compared with net in come of $34.5 million, or 72 cents a share, during year-earelier period (S)

headline: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA TO ACQUIRE BARCONET
abstract: Scientific-Atlanta Inc, maker of cable television set-top boxes, will purchase communications equipment maker, BarcoNet NV, for about $154 million to add to its presence in Europe and Asia (S)

headline: U.S. Questions if Arafat Can Lead the Palestinians
abstract: Bush administration is questioning whether Yasir Arafat can lead Palestinians; drops its public calls for Israeli restraint in wake of deadly suicide bombings and shootings by Palestinians; it is unclear whether policy shift is tactical move to pressure Arafat to dismantle terror groups or strategic change; administration denies United States has given Prime Min Ariel Sharon approval to eliminate Arafat as Palestinian leader; denies Israeli airstrikes on Palestinian Authority offices were aimed at Arafat; State Sec Colin L Powell holds terrorist attacks were also assault on Arafat's authority; calls Israeli reprisals justified (M)

headline: Belgium Says Swissair Suits Seek Almost $1.75 Billion
abstract: Public and private lawsuits against Swissair Group, which owns 49.5 percent Belgian carrier Sabena, demand almost $1.75 billion as compensation for Swissair's failure to provide money to help Sabena avoid collapse (M)

headline: Argentina Limits Withdrawals as Banks Near Collapse
abstract: Argentine Pres Fernando d

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Plotter Against King Extradited
abstract: Jose Javier Arizcuren Ruiz, former military leader of Basque separatist group ETA who is accused by Spain of plotting to kill King Juan Carlos, arrives in Madrid after fast-track extradition procedure under which he will be tried in Spain and then returned to France to finish 10-year sentence there (S)

headline: Visas for Foreign Students at an Anxious Time
abstract: Staff at Thunderbird, graduate school of international management in Glendale, Ariz, attended by foreign students, has been concerned about calls for six-month moratorium on student visas after terrorist attacks; there are now more than 500,000 foreign students in US; Thunderbird program director Marylee Carter comments; photo (M)

headline: Turner's Foundation to Spend Millions to Fight Bioterrorism
abstract: Nuclear Threat Initiative, foundation headed by media mogul Ted Turner and former Sen Sam Nunn, decides to increase spending aimed at deterring bioterrorism and threat of germ weapons; foundation is expected to spend about third of its estimated $50 million in grants each year on combatting bioweapons and bioterrorism (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: E.ON In Talks To Sell Unit
abstract: E.on, German conglomerate that has been shedding industrial companies to focus on its core business of power generation, says that it is in negotiations to sell its aluminum-making subsidiary to Norsk Hydro of Norway (S)

headline: Stocks Drop In Europe But Recover
abstract: European stocks recover from early declines following steadier opening on Wall Street; trading is calm across Continent after onset of American and British strikes against Afghanistan; Dow Jones Stoxx Index of shares of 50 European companies recovers from drop of 116.81 points, to close down 0.86 of a point to 3,384.19; in London, benchmark Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 shares recovers from low of 4,900.7, to close down 0.06 percent, to 5,032.7 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Slows
abstract: Brazil's inflation rose only 0.28 percent in September compared with 0.7 percent in August; central bank increases its 2001 inflation projection to 6.5 percent (S)

headline: Does the U.S. Still Trust Markets to Work?; If Every Bailout Could Be Like Chrysler's
abstract: Floyd Norris article says government bailouts of airlines and possibly insurance industry in wake of Sept 11 pose problems that do not exist with bankruptcy reorganization; says rescue of Chrysler Corp in 1983, which is being cited as model for today's bailouts, worked because company was overhauled as part of package that entailed sacrifice on part of workers, suppliers, lenders and dealers, whereas airline bailout comes with virtually no strings attached (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Big Investment In Genencor
abstract: Dow Corning will invest up to $35 million over next two years in Genencor International research program aimed at creating biotechnology products based on combination of biological materials and silicon (M)

headline: Reducing Dependence On Any Kind of Oil
abstract: Claude M Gruener letter on October 14 article holds US needs to start cutting oil consumption and accelerate use of solar and wind energy sources

headline: Did Ken Lay Understand What Was Happening at Enron?
abstract: WHAT a tangled web was weaved by Enron. Both investors and managers seem to have been misled.    ''Enron became overleveraged,'' Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's chairman and chief executive, said this week, adding that things went wrong in ways that ''I could not have ever contemplated.'' He pointed to investments that ''performed far worse than we ever could have imagined.''

headline: Billions Served Daily, and Counting
abstract: Electronic mail marks its 30th birthday; has become such a fixture in so many people's lives that it is hard to imaging life without it; some 9.8 billion e-mails are sent each day; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee prices for March delivery rise 2.7 cents, to 49.6 cents a pound; graph; table of commodities indexes (S)

headline: Incredibly Shrinking AT&T And the Armstrong Agenda
abstract: There are indications that within few years there may not be independent company called AT&T; what used to be company's core, its consumer long-distance telephone business, seems to be doing vanishing act, shrinking by almost 20 percent per year; what was recently beacon of growth, its wireless operation, has been spun off to company's shareholders and can no longer cover for other divisions; most valuable part of AT&T is its cable television business, AT&T Broadband; Oct 2000 plan to spin off unit by next year has been up in air since Comcast Corp made unsolicited bid last summer to acquire cable business for $44.5 million; no matter who owns it, AT&T brand is probably too valuable to let die; but depending on financial structure, deal with a Bell company could mean end of AT&T as independent company; chairman C Michael Armstrong says what will survive are AT&T assets and people and brand and customer relations that we have created; former Pres Clinton's recent comment that Armstrong has toughest job in world noted (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: President Signs Land Reform Law
abstract: Ukraine Pres Leonid Kuchma signs land reform law that will let land be bought and sold starting in 2005 (S)

headline: NBC Signs Couric, Making Her Top-Paid in TV News
abstract: NBC and Katie Couric, the anchor of its morning "Today" show, agreed today to what is believed to be the largest financial deal ever signed in television news.

headline: Jordan McGrath Case Is Arnold Lead Agency
abstract: Jordan McGrath Case & Partners in New York, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising, is becoming the New York office for the lead agency of the unit, known as Arnold Worldwide. To reflect the change, Jordan McGrath will be renamed Arnold McGrath Worldwide.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: New Shares For Bank
abstract: DBS Group Holdings raises $2.1 billion through private placement of new shares to offset over $5.5 billion cost of buying Dao Heng Bank earlier this year; new shares cut Singapore government's stake in bank to under one-third (S)

headline: Independents to Join Book Data Collection
abstract: Bookscan, which seeks to compile first accuarate weekly data about book sales, reaches accord to pay American Booksellers Association, largest independent bookstores group, for its help in signing up stores; publishers say data could enable them to forecast demand for new books more accurately and focus marketing efforts more effectively (M)

headline: LTV ASKS BANKRUPTCY COURT IF IT CAN SELL MILLS
abstract: LTV Corp has asked bankruptcy Judge William T Bodoh for permission to close its steel mills and put them up for sale because it does not have enough cash to continue operating; has also asked Bodoh for permission to reject its labor agreements; company has 7,800 employees and around 45,000 retirees (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Settlements' Growth Slows
abstract: Israel reports number of Jewish settlers in West Bank and Gaza Strip rose 4.4 percent, Jan-Sept, to 204,900, well below average annual growth of about 8 percent in recent years; slowing seen linked to frequent Palestinian attacks on settlers (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Reprieve For Hynix
abstract: Hynix Semiconductor wins another reprieve with approval of rescue package that guarantees $500 million in loans from its principal state-owned creditors in South Korea; package also provides banks to exchange about $3 billion in loans for equity in Hynix, whose total debt is now about $8 billion (S)

headline: Brokerage Firm Sells Loan Unit
abstract: Metropolitan West Securities LLC will buy securities lending operations of Cantor Fitzgerald LP (S)

headline: Taliban Say They Want to Negotiate With the U.S. Over bin Laden
abstract: Afghan Amb Abdul Salam Zaeef, while repeating Taliban's long-standing position that Osama bin Laden will not be turned over without proof he was involved in terrorist attacks on US, adds what sounds like desperate appeal for talks to avert military strike; suggests Afghans might agree to turn bin Laden over to third country; rejects British Prime Min Tony Blair's threat to topple Taliban regime for refusing demand for bin Laden; seems to be trying to counter efforts by US and Pakistan to lure moderate Taliban elements into defecting to new opposition alliance; photo (M)

headline: Whose Pain Is It, Anyhow?
abstract: David C White letter comments on attempts by large corporations to receive preferential treatment, including tax breaks, from government after Sept 11 (Nov 4 Mark Watch column)

headline: Caught in Terror's Undertow
abstract: Derby, Eng, rethinks its dependence on manufacturing after Rolls-Royce, jet engine manufacturer and city's biggest employer, cuts almost 2,000 jobs there on account of cancellation or postponement of airline orders in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks; city depends on manufacturing for 28 percent of all economic output, more half again the average in Britain, where services increasingly drive economy; photos (M)

headline: In Mr. Gore's New Job, a Drexel Connection
abstract: In Mr. Gore's New Job, A Drexel Connection.

headline: A Family Is Left 'Sad and Happy' by a Violent Death
abstract: Palestinian family of Daoud Abu Sway praises 46-year-old father of eight for blowing himself up outside Jerusalem hotel in hopes of killing Israelis; photos; few injuries but no deaths resulted (M)

headline: Roll Over, Shakespeare, the Future Is Here
abstract: In her new book, trend spotter Faith Popcorn has seen the future. It's a real mouthful.

headline: Gelsenkirchen Journal; A Different Germany Takes to the Soccer Field
abstract: Gerald Asamoah is first African-born black to play for Germany's national soccer team; his blackness, magnified by his rise to status of player for national team, has invigorated national discussion about what it means to be German; although 9 percent of Germany's residents are noncitizens, country has until recently rejected notion that it could be land of immigration rather than country that allows foreigners to live there as 'guest workers' or political refugees; Asamoah's application for citizenship was approved in near-record time, common practice for gifted sportsmen or other desired immigrants; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Unemployment Rises
abstract: Britain's unemployment rose to 3.2 percent in October from 3.1 percent in September (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Surge In AIDS Orphans
abstract: South Africa predicts country will ahve more than two million AIDS orphans by 2010 (S)

headline: AT&T Is Close To Dissolving British Deal
abstract: British Telecommunications and AT&T are close to reaching agreement to end joint venture that provides telecommunications services to businesses; joint venture, Concert, was formed in 1998 to serve companies with offices around world; disappointing sales and mounting losses are leading companies to examine ways to reorganize venture (M)

headline: RICOCHET, A WIRELESS CONCERN, SOLD TO AERIE NETWORKS
abstract: Remaining pieces of Ricochet, high-speed wireless network run by Metricom Inc, are sold to Aerie Networks, privately held network services company (S)

headline: A Big Fall Evoking Nasty Old Memories Of a Run on a Bank
abstract: Floyd Norris Market Place column likens Enron's collapse to run on bank in days before deposit insurance; sees it as reminder for big players in unregulated markets that their financial health must be beyond doubt because they lack insurance to reassure customers when rumors spread (M)

headline: Putin Says Russia to Study Plan for Broader NATO Role
abstract: Pres Putin tells NATO Sec Gen Lord Robertson that Russia will give urgent attention to proposal to give Russia equal voice with alliance members on certain issues, such as terrorism; Robertson, in Moscow, stresses that Putin is not seeking either full NATO membership or veto over major decisions; photo; Robertson also makes clear that NATO intends to enlarge membership next year, likely including three Baltic states once part of Soviet Union (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Says Ramadan Won't Halt U.S. Attacks
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld flies to Islamabad to meet with Pakistan's president, Gen Pervez Musharraf; says American bombing attacks must continue through Muslim holy month of Ramadan because Taliban maintains military and political 'concentrations of power' throughout Afghanistan; Musharraf warns of 'negative fallout' in Muslim workd if bombing continues during Ramadan; Rumsfeld says Taliban no longer functions as government, but is using power in enclaves throughout country to impose its will on Afghan people; claims Taliban leaders are hiding in mosques, hospitals, schools and homes; says threat of additional terrorist attacks will continue so long as Taliban shelters Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda leaders in Afghanistan; says this necessitates continued bombing, even during Ramadan; photo (M)

headline: Multinationals at the Gate
abstract: China is preparing to defend its huge yet fragile economy from invasion by foreign companies once its members in World Trade Organization is ratified; China's membership is certain by early 2002, starting process that will transform its economy in ways that are already causing anticipation and anxiety among those who expect to be affected; China's beleaguered farmers are among those most threatened by changes country agreed to make to become WTO member; duties on imported agricultural products are to be reduced over time to 17 percent from average of 22 percent now, and reduction will be even greater for some American farm produce; import quotas will be relaxed; both changes will greatly increase competition farmers face from imports; photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Lisa Marie Faller, executive vice president heading client services and new business at FKQ Advertising and Marketing, Clearwater, Fla., was named president.

headline: 4 Foreign Journalists Are Shot And Possibly Killed in Ambush
abstract: Four foreign journalists are reportedly kidnapped and shot dead by armed gunmen on Afghan highway halfway from Jalalabad to Kabul; fifth man, translator, is reported missing; witness says gunmen claimed to be Taliban; journalists' bodies have not been found; they are Maria Grazia Cutuli, reporter for Italian daily Corriere della Sera, Julio Fuentes from El Mundo in Madrid, and Harry Burton, Australian television cameraman, and Aziz Haidari, Afghan-born photogrpher, both working for Reuters; journalists were in second and third cars of eight-car convoy; their cars were stopped at gunpoint by men clad in style favored by Taliban; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Far East Hit By Forest Fires
abstract: Some 35 forest fires ravage almost 200 square miles in Russia's far east, near China border (S)

headline: A Personal Shopper For Online Bargains
abstract: Several Web sites list prices of merchandise at variety of different stores, and many offer ratings of online vendors as well; among them are PriceGrabber.com, Shopper.com, MySimon, PriceScan.com, DealTime and AddAll.com; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: Warming Trend Continues
abstract: North and South Korea agree to new round of family reunification visits in Dec; extend talks to discuss economic issues (S)

headline: Pepsi Files Suit To Stop Dasani Talks
abstract: PepsiCo goes to court to prevent executives from former agency, Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding, from meeting with new client, Coca-Cola Co, PepsiCo's competitor; Cook County Circuit Court issued restraining order last week against Foote, Cone, preventing its executives from meeting with Coca-Cola to discuss new account, Dasani bottled water; Dasani was among $250 million in business shifted by Coca-Cola to Foote, Cone after agency was dismissed by PepsiCo on $350 million worth of accounts that included Dasani rival, Aquafina water; PepsiCo suit contends that agency is still custodian of Aquafina trade secrets (S)

headline: Lending Slows, Forcing Delays Of Some Deals
abstract: Young companies or those with a lot of debt have found it nearly impossible to borrow money since terrorist attacks in US because lenders have been unwilling to commit more money and investors have backed away from high-yield bonds; slowdown is making it hard for business to finance expansions and its forcing some to delay acquisitions; even before attacks, market for financings by banks to less-established companies had been weak for more than one year; S&P/Portfolio Management Data says over all, loans to highly leveraged companies are down more than third from last year; bankers say they expect participants in leveraged-loan market to remain wary even as shock of terrorist attacks fades; delay of $1 billion loan to Land O'Lakes Inc to acquire Purina Mills Inc for $230 million noted (M)

headline: P&O PRINCESS EXPECTS EARNINGS ON HIGH END OF FORECAST
abstract: P&O Princess Cruises says its 2001 earnings will be on high end of earlier forecasts (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Fearing A Nuclear Disaster
abstract: Environmental groups to stage protests to block trainload of nuclear waste on way to storage near Gorleben, Germany (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Isuzu To Shift Manufacturing
abstract: Facing mounting losses and an impatient parent company, the Japanese automaker Isuzu Motors Ltd. will stop making sport utility vehicles in Japan and move their production to the United States. Isuzu, which is 49 percent owned by the General Motors Corporation, will build its Trooper, Rodeo and Axiom S.U.V.'s entirely in the United States,  starting with next year's models. Isuzu sold 83,000 S.U.V.'s in North America in 2000, down 36 percent from 1995, its best year. The automaker said it expected to sell 3,500 sport utility trucks in Japan this year as competition with other makers increased.   Ken Belson (NYT)

headline: Afghans Say Civilians Are Imperiled by U.S.
abstract: Pro-American Afghan commanders in eastern part of nation say civilians are being killed in American hunt for Osama bin Laden; say bad intelligence has caused mistakes in American bombing; say bombing of four villages near Tora Bora has left 80 or more people dead or wounded; Pentagon denies bombing civilians in area; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Election Disaster For Leftists
abstract: Center-right parties win 15 of 16 mayoral elections in Sicily in surprise rout of Italian leftists (S)

headline: Team of American Military Personnel Arrives in Rebel Territory in Afghanistan
abstract: Senior official in Northern Alliance reports that six-member team of American military personnel has landed in alliance territory north of Kabul to inspect new airstrip and to carry out covert activities; whether sluggish and fractious opposition alliance will actually carry out attack near Kabul is unknown; alliance exercises and arrival of American team suggests effort may be under way to begin attack before winter and Islamic holy month of Ramadan; photo (M)

headline: Roar of the Warplanes Overhead Bolsters the Hopes of the Rebels
abstract: The roar of the first jet this afternoon prompted reflexive fears of an enemy attack on this rebel-held territory. But when another and then another jet thundered overhead, flying so high they could not even be seen, it dawned on people what might finally be happening: the end of their years of isolation and defeat.     As night fell, the news spread. The Americans were starting to bomb the Taliban front lines.

headline: Bauhaus Rigor Meets Folkloric Flair in Expatriates' Collections : German Cool:Strictly Eccentric
abstract: PARIS—  On a skinny counter at Galeries Lafayette sits a tiny black purse, with rings to attach it to the fingers and a furry side turned to the palm. How cool is that! The fashion crowd circles in awe the "Shopping Support" installation of Bless — the German design duo Ines Kaag and Desiree Heiss.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: World Briefing

headline: USA Networks' Stock Plan
abstract: USA Networks, media and electronic-commerce company, wants to increse number of preferred shares to 100 million from 15 million for possible use in making acquisitions (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Buys Chip Inspector
abstract: Applied Materials, world's largest manufacturer of chip-making equipment, purchases computer chip defect-detection business of Schlumberger Semiconductor Solution (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline To Halt Some Flights
abstract: Japan Airlines will halt flights on six routes to Europe and extend suspension of trans-Pacific flights to offset decline in air travel (S)

headline: After Defeat, Journey to Uncertain Fate
abstract: Trucks crammed with foreign Taliban prisoners captured by Northern Alliance Gen Abdul Rashid Dostum outside Kunduz, Afghanistan, wait in Khulm for word on final destination; fate of foreign prisoners is murky, with alliance commanders bickering over whether they should be tried and executed or turned over to United Nations; trucks were bound for fortress that is now site of prisoner uprising; prisoners are mostly Pakistanis; photo (M)

headline: Charter Buys Internet Gear
abstract: Charter Communications has agreed to pay $81 million to the High Speed Access Corporation for equipment to provide fast Internet service to Charter customers.

headline: To Strengthen Military Ties, U.S. Beats Path to India
abstract: Bush administration's push for closer military ties with India gathers momentum during recent visits here by senior American officials; United States and India announce specific agreements to move forward with joint military exercises and American military sales to India (M)

headline: Follow the Debt Loads to Default
abstract: Moody's Investors Service says that likelihood of North American corporations defaulting on their debt over coming year has increased to 4.1 percent from 3.3 percent previously (S)

headline: Welch, of G.E., Signs On at Clayton, Dubilier
abstract: John F Welch Jr, former chairman of General Electric Co, joins leveraged buyout firm of Clayton, Dubilier & Rice as special partner (M)

headline: Searching for Gifts When the Spirit Is Weak
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on doing holiday shopping online; drawing (M)

headline: U.S.-Based Muslim Charity Raided by NATO in Kosovo
abstract: NATO troops raid offices of American charity in Kosovo as part of investigation linnking at least two large Muslim charities based in Illinois to fund-raising for Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda terrorist network; raided are two offices of Global Relief Foundation, which raises millions of dollars a year; NATO statement cites credible intelligence information on terrorist links; Global Relief and Benevolence International Foundation deny allegations and charge anti-Muslim smear (M)

headline: Airlines Match Delta's Cut-Rate Fares
abstract: Most major airlines match Delta Air Lines in cutting fares as much as 50 percent on routes worldwide to draw travelers back to airplanes (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Broadcaster Reduces Forecast
abstract: RTL Group, European television broadcaster controlled by Bertelsmann, reduces its profit forecast, saying it does not expect advertising slump to end for at least six months (S)

headline: Sharon Calls for Support After 2 Rightists Quit Cabinet
abstract: Israel's Prime Min Ariel Sharon urgently appeals for continued support after two far-right ministers quit cabinet, accusing him of buckling under US pressure to take softer line toward Palestinians; he denounces defections, which he says have given Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat 'great pleasure;' defections dent his majority but leave him with overpowering coalition in Parliament (M)

headline: Brazil Takes a Trade Stance and Offers a Warning to U.S.
abstract: US trade legislation excluding some of Brazil's main exports from negotiations for Free Trade Areas of the Americas prompts warning from Foreign Min Celso Lafer that any attempt by Bush administration to narrow negotiating agenda will be met with 'symmetric' response from Brazil; trade bill requires Bush to seek Congressional approval before reducing tariffs on nearly 300 products, among them some of Brazil's most important exports, including sugar, soybeans and orange juice (M)

headline: Investing; Can Xbox Electrify Microsoft Suppliers?
abstract: As Microsoft enters video game market with release of its Xbox console, some investors place their bets on allied companies like Flextronics, which is manufacturing Xbox console, and Nvidia, which provides graphics chip for unit; Microsoft, to meet sales estimates of 1 million to 1.5 million game players before end of year, is moving well beyond its normal marketing channels; Xbox release includes cross-promotions with partners like Taco Bell and MTV; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bankruptcies Rise
abstract: Corporate bankruptcies in Japan rose 11.7 percent in October from month year; analysts expect pace to accelerate and total bankruptcies for 2001 to reach 20,000 (S)

headline: Sharon Apologizes Over Dispute With U.S.
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon apologizes for what he calls misunderstanding of his warning thta US risks appeasing Arab nations as Europe appeased Hitler before World War II; says he has spoken with Sec Colin Powell several times and dispute is ended; also says US has not unfairly pressured Israel to resolve Palestinian conflict to help US gain Arab allies in war against Islamic terrorism; photo (M)

headline: Carol Burnett, Armed With Old Clips, Is New Hit
abstract: CBS special featuring old clips and outtakes from The Carol Burnett Show, which last aired in 1978, attracts almost 30 million viewers; most television industry executives are stunned; graph; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Rejects Any Deal for Head of Taliban to Flee Kandahar
abstract: The United States will not support any effort to allow Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban's supreme leader, to escape from Kandahar, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today.

headline: Private Sector; Questioning His Midas Touch
abstract: Newmont Mining and its chief executive, Wayne W Murdy, are targets of environmental and antiglobalization movements; Newmont recently announced deals to acquire Normandy Mining Ltd and Franco-Nevada Mining Corp, creating world's largest gold producer; photo (S)

headline: Details Emerging On a WPP Deal
abstract: WPP Group provides details of reorganization of media agencies (S)

headline: Mortgage Limit Is Raised to $300,700
abstract: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac raise limit on single-family home mortgages by 9.3 percent, to $300,700, opening up lower-cost financing to more people (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Lender May Take Stake In Broker
abstract: Bipop-Carire, Italy's leading online brokerage firm, agrees to possible integration in which Banca di Roma, leading Italian lender, will acquire 10.3 percent of Bipop (S)

headline: RECKSON SELLS ITS STAKE IN A NEW YORK CITY PROPERTY
abstract: reckr

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Myanmar: Former Leader Failing
abstract: Gen Ne Win, former strongman in Burma, is reported to be in very serious condition in hospital in Singapore (S)

headline: Arms, Books And Noose Were Fixtures At Terror Lair
abstract: Article describes former Al Qaeda terrorist camp in Rishkhor, Afghanistan, that was destroyed by American warplanes; photo (M)

headline: ID, Please? Digital Wallets Are Getting Another Try
abstract: Microsoft and Sun Microsystems are marketing Web identity services for online shopping that offer single sign-in access to multiple Web sites from any Web-connected device and faster and easier online payment; crucial to their success is consumers' confidence that identities of users signing in will be verified and that personal and financial information is kept safe and will not be used improperly; Microsoft's Pastport service has stirred concern because all personal and financial data will be entered in its database; Sun's Liberty Alliance program does not have single centralized database; drawing (M)

headline: Readmit Inspectors, President Tells Iraq; 'Or Else' Is Unstated
