abstract: Pres Bush calls on Iraq's Pres Saddam Hussein to readmit UN arms inspectors to determine if country is developing weapons of mass destruction, warning he will face consequences if he fails to do so; declines to say what consequences may be; seemingly broadens administration's definition of terrorism to include development of weapons that would terrorize nations; is backed by Sec of State Colin Powell, who says Hussein should heed Bush's statement as very sober and chilling message; remarks come amid internal debate within administration over next stage of war on terrorism, including whether US should take military action in efforts to oust Hussein; criticisms of Bush by conservative Republicans for not moving forcibly against Hussein, whose survival continues to torment Washington decade after Persian Gulf War, noted (M)

headline: Consumers Look At Corporate Conduct
abstract: Poll conducted by RoperASW for Cone Inc, Boston marketing company, suggests consumers are paying much closer attention to corporate conduct in aftermath of September 11 terrorist attacks (S)

headline: Serb Turnout in Kosovo Vote Seen as an Encouraging Step
abstract: Kosovo's Serbs turned out in much greater numbers than originally thought in elections on Saturday, showing that they see a future despite the Albanian domination of their province and securing a real level of power in a new provincial assembly, Western officials said today.    Most Serbs appear to have voted just before polls closed, and after dark so they would not be seen by community leaders opposed to taking part in the vote for a 120-seat assembly. The elections were devised by the international officials who have ruled Kosovo since the war over it ended in June 1999 and NATO troops arrived here.

headline: Some Suppliers Say Kmart Has Pressed For Deals
abstract: Kmart Corp pressures some companies that supply its products to give it cash back and make other concessions to help its own bottom line; has to find some way to cut costs if it is going to deliver on its promise to bolster profits; high-pressure tactics suggest that management's program, including low prices, is failing to produce desired levels of sales and profits at time of sluggish sales; some manufacturers say Kmart has delayed payments without any notice; others have been asked to give back money because their products did not produce profits Kmart wanted last season; still others have been urged to cut prices to Kmart's recently anointed food and beauty distribution partner, Fleming Companies, or risk losing business (M)

headline: Kodak Realigns Operations As Slump in Demand Persists
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co is realigning its businesses along product lines rather than geographic ones (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Sonera To Raise Cash
abstract: Sonera, after posting record third-quarter loss of 325 million euros ($292 million), says it will sell discounted shares to existing stockholders to raise $900 million (S)

headline: German Greens Patch Rift And Support Use of Military
abstract: Members of Germany's Green Party defy pacifist roots and vote overwhelmingly in favor of sending German soldiers to Afghanistan in war against terrorism; vote patches over agonizing internal debate that threatened to break apart governing coalition between Greens and Socialist Democratic Party of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business Diary
abstract: DIARYThose Online Bargains Aren't Always Bargains.

headline: Trade Deal Near for Broad Access to Cut-Rate Drugs
abstract: Trade ministers attending international summit in Doha, Qatar, all but clinch deal that would give developing countries greater access to cut-price drugs to fight epidemics, defusing most inflammatory dispute between rich and poor nations that had threatened to scuttle talks; breakthrough creates sense of momentum as mediators seek consensus on multiyear agenda for global trade liberalization; negotiators warn substantial differences remain to be settled before talks end on November 15; US help in brokering deal, despite strong opposition from multinational pharmaceutical companies, discussed (M)

headline: Air New Zealand's $360 Million Rescue
abstract: New Zealand government will pay up to $360 million to rescue Air New Zealand, country's only major airline, which has been plagued by financial trouble; government, which privatized airline in 1989, would end up with stake of more than 80 percent; Singapore Airlines and Brierley Investments, two largest investors, have agreed to provide equity through earlier emergency financing package (S)

headline: Washington said to Fear Use of galileo by Enemy in a War : U.S. Out of Line on Global Positioning, EU Says
abstract: PARIS—  The European Commission said Tuesday that the United States had sought to block the deployment of a European system of navigation known as Galileo, with the Americans arguing that an enemy could turn it against the West in the event of a war.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Threat To Ex-President's Trial
abstract: Trial of Joseph Estrada, deposed Philippines president, threatens to veer into chaos as presiding judge, Anacleto Badoy, says one of his senior colleagues is trying to oust him (S)

headline: U.S. Businesses Taking Steps To Protect Company Mail
abstract: News of possible terrorist attacks using one of nation's oldest, least sophisticated means of communication--United States mail--prompts many companies to take hard look at how they run their mailrooms; law firms, advertising agencies and even big manufacturers have joined media companies in announcing new mail-handling procedures; it is unclear how prospect of potentially lethal letters might affect way American companies do business (M)

headline: High-Level Murmurings That bin Laden Is Dead
abstract: Hunt for Osama bin Laden continues on both sides of Afghan-Pakistan border amid some high-level speculation that terrorist leader died in US bombing of Tora Bora caves, or even, as Pakistan paper claims, of 'lung complication' in mid-December; paper gives account of funeral, but no source; Gen Pervez Musharraf and Gen Tommy Franks suggest bin Laden is dead (M)

headline: Canada's Health Care Shows Strains
abstract: Canada's government-administered health service, long praised by Canadians, is in trouble; how to fix it without 'Americanizing' it is problem; system leaves no one without essentially free access to most doctors and hospitals; federal and provincial governments share in paying bills, about $63 billion annually, from tax revenues and other income; soaring costs are now straining system; photo; chart (M)

headline: Nasdaq Above 2,000; Dow Breaks 10,000
abstract: Stocks surged today as investors rallied around a new and unexpected sign of growth in business spending.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: JOHNSON & JOHNSON, New Brunswick, N.J., the health care and consumer products maker, agreed to work with Caprion Pharmaceuticals Inc., Montreal, to develop the first test for variant Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease, the human form of mad-cow disease, with Johnson & Johnson getting exclusive global marketing and distribution rights if a test is developed. Terms were not disclosed.    SKILLSOFT CORP., Nashua, N.H., a Web-based business training company, agreed to acquire Books24X7.com, Norwood, Mass., a provider of digital Internet content to businesses, for $32.4 million in cash and stock.

headline: Taliban Remain in Kandahar, Their Southern Citadel, and Say They'll Fight to the Last
abstract: As much of Afghanistan began to cast off the effects of seven years of Taliban rule, the southern city of Kandahar, the Taliban's citadel, remained in the movement's hands today, a stubborn refuge for hard-liners.    After a report on Friday that the Taliban's supreme leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, planned to relinquish power to two commanders, Taliban officials said today that little had changed and that the movement would fight to the last.

headline: Air Canada Puts Best Face On a Big Loss
abstract: Air Canada reports third-quarter loss of $100 million, but says that costs are falling and its finances are stabilizing; will reduce capacity less than previously forecast; no-frills carriers are taking some of its business away; photo (M)

headline: Boeing's Cuts Hit Goodrich
abstract: Goodrich, a leading maker of aircraft landing gear, will incur up to $230 million in costs to close 16 manufacturing facilities, in part because of Boeing's decision to cut production of its 717 aircraft; previously announced 2,400 layoffs (S)

headline: Embracing Canadian Energy
abstract: Many Canadian energy producers have been acquired by American companies in last 12 months; Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers says that since October 2000, American companies have paid more than $20 billion on acquisitions in Canada, pushing foreign ownership up to 48 percent; Westcoast Energy is being acquired by Duke Energy for $3.5 billion; Calpine Corp has spent $1.7 billion in three deals over last year and is building power plant near Calgary; National Energy Board in Ottawa estimates Canada's gas resources at 555 trillion cub fee, equal to about 25 years of United States' consumption at current rates; graph (M)

headline: Major Critic of Interim Government Is Appointed to Afghan Defense Post
abstract: Gen Abdul Rashid Dostum, who controls area in and around Mazar-i-Sharif, and had originally threatened to boycott agreement on new Afghan government reached in Bonn, Germany, is appointed to post of deputy defense minister; Dostum, who is ethnic Uzbek, has number of troops loyal to him; he is described as man with checkered past in area of human rights, as well as shifting allegiances; photo of interim leader Hamid Karzai with Dostum (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   5.00   5.00   9.50        Discount rate   1.50   1.50   6.00        Federal funds   2.06   2.13   6.51        3-month T-bills   1.75   1.80   6.20        6-month T-bills   1.69   1.75   6.07        10-yr. headline: Japan Is in Recession Again, With U.S., as Germany Slips
abstract: Japanese economy officially enters recession as statistics show gross domestic product contracting for second consecutive quarter (M)

headline: Another Reform Politician in Iran Is Sentenced to a Prison Term
abstract: Abdullah Ramazanzadeh is latest reformist close to Pres Mohammad Khatami of Iran to receive jail term, as country's hard-line judiciary steps up pressure against efforts aimed at more social and political freedom; Ramazanzadeh is found guilty of 'spreading lies' against conservative Guardian Council and sentenced to six months in jail; during four-year tenure as governor general for Kurdish area, he sought more freedom for Kurds (M)

headline: Andean Trade Renewal Stalls
abstract: Legislation backed by Bush administration to renew and expand Andean Trade Preference Act, which has helped Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru fight narcotics trafficking by lowering tariffs on flowers, clothing and other exports to US, is thwarted by last-minute split in Congress; streamlined version is included in economic stimulus package, but it will only extend agreement for six months; American farmers and textile manufacturers contend agreement costs them jobs; photo; map (M)

headline: Officers and GIs Shun Duty There : Seoul Resists U.S. On New Barracks
abstract: SEOUL—  Midlevel U.S. military officers find the prospect of life in South Korea so repugnant that a third of them turn down the chance to come here in command positions, even though they know they will probably have to retire with no more promotions.

headline: Nations Move to Send Troops to Keep Order in Afghanistan
abstract: A United Nations resolution has opened the way for multinational military efforts to maintain law and order in Afghanistan and to provide aid in rebuilding the country.

headline: Sale of U.S. Vision Falters
abstract: US Vision, which sells eyeglasses and contact lenses through JC Penney Co department stores, announces that Norob, acquisition company formed by some shareholders, has canceled agreement to buy company for about $24.9 million (S)

headline: Business; A Phone Upstart, Still Annoying the Giants
abstract: Z-Tel Technologies, small, publicly traded residential-phone company based in Tampa, Fla, seeks to win customers away from big regional companies like Ameritech and Verizon Communications by offering discounted plans for local and long-distance service that include features like voice mail and call waiting, along with call-forwarded and unlimited calls to family members who are also Z-Tel customers; Gregory Smith, chairman and chief executive, says he must walk fine line between developing good relationship with regional companies, on which Z-Tel depends for installing service for new customers, maintaining lines and dealing with service problems, and complaining about them to local and federal regulators when he contends they do not play by the rules or charge too much for their lines; photo (M)

headline: Airline Sees Sept. 11 as a Turning Point
abstract: Christine T Y Tsung, chief executive of China Airlines in Taiwan, says terrorist attacks of Sept 11 may be turning point for airline because United Airlines, its rival in flying between Taiwan and US, is an American airline and therefore possible terrorist target in minds of some flyers; says China Airlines has lured some passengers away from United and hopes these jittery converts will become permanent customers; photo (M)

headline: Expanded Spy Powers, Post-Taliban Bickering, an Anthrax Clue
abstract: Overview of day's events in terrorism investigation and war in Afghanistan (M)

headline: Chief-Designate At AOL Asks Turner to Stay
abstract: Richard D Parsons, next chief executive of AOL Time Warner, asks Ted Turner, company's estranged vice chairman, to remain with company; Turner's contract expires in few weeks; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: World Briefing

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Electricity Restrictions Eased
abstract: Brazil eases electricity rationing as vacation season approaches (S)

headline: Media Group Plans to Enliven a City
abstract: Representatives of the entertainment and commercial production industry — including associations, unions and suppliers — are forming a coalition called We Love New York that will work to bolster theater, television, film and advertising in the aftermath of the attacks on the World Trade Center.

headline: Ford Denies Top Executive Will Leave by Year's End
abstract: Ford Motor Co denies chief executive Jacques A Nasser will leave at end of year; Nasser has been under pressure as Ford's struggles have intensified and sales have declined; suggestion of Nasser's departure was posted on Forbes.com; photo (M)

headline: It's Creepy, Yes, but Also Important
abstract: Abby Ellin column on importance of having a will, even for people just starting out; photo (M)

headline: European Union Tries to Pressure Arafat, but Not Exclude Him
abstract: European Union leaders struggle to forge unified stand that puts more pressure on Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, without undermining him; Bush administration appeals to its European allies to distance themselves from Arafat complicate effort; photo (M)

headline: CENTURYTEL BUYING 675,000 VERIZON PHONE LINES
abstract: CenturyTel Inc to buy about 675,000 phone lines in Alabama and Missouri from Verizon Communications Inc for $2.16 billion (S)

headline: Lebanon to Resist U.S. Sanctions on Hezbollah
abstract: Lebanese government reportedly will reject US pressure to freeze assets of Hezbollah or interfere with Shiite Muslim organization's 'resistance' to Israel; State Department has put Hezbollah and 21 other groups on terrorist list; Hezbollah has become part of Lebanese establishment, with legislators and wide social service network; former premier Selim al-Hoss, charges US supports 'terrorist state' of Israel; photo (M)

headline: Account News in Advertising
abstract: Account News in Advertising

headline: After Prison, a Saudi Sheik Tempers His Words
abstract: Sheik Salman al-Awdah, religious scholar and force in rise of Saudi political opposition, spent almost five years in prison for harsh criticisms of government and is still not allowed to speak at mosque or university or to travel abroad; photo; sheik uses private lectures to renew tempered calls for government to consider reforms, while also denouncing Sept 11 terrorist attacks and admonishing young Saudis not to heed calls for jihad (M)

headline: GOLDMAN SACHS SELLS 10% STAKE IN SOUNDVIEW
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group sells its 10 percent ownership of SoundView Technology Group, technology-focused investment bank, for $20 million to group including General Atlantic Partners (s)

headline: Afghan Rebels Are Nervous As Food Supplies Run Low
abstract: Afghan rebels are nervous as food supplies run low; officials of rebel Northern Alliance fear that influx of refugees from nearly Taliban-controlled territory could overwhelm it and other aid efforts (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: New Review Of Corruption Case
abstract: Turkey's Court of Appeals will review lower court ruling overturning prison sentences for senior police officer, intelligence official and 12 others convicted of taking part in organized crime (S)

headline: Aluminum Merger Deal Starting to Look Later Than Sooner
abstract: Alcoa's talks to acquire WMC Ltd, nickel miner, reportedly are snagged over price and other issues (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Rebound In Search Of a Reason
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Place column says recent gains in stock market may not prove sustainable; suggests that rally is not based on any data signaling economic recovery, but rather on investors' rush to be on board for next bull run (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Pays Call on Troops And Afghans
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld is first senior Bush administration offical to visit Afghanistan since start of American military response to Sept 11 terrorist attacks; visit is not announced until just hours before his plane touches down at air base at Bagram; he visits with American troops and with Afghanistan's provisional leaders; his repeated theme is that war is not yet won; tells Hamid Karzai, provisional head of government, and Gen Muhammad Fahim, incoming defense minister, that much work remains in hunting down Taliban and members of Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network; says it is still too soon to declare Afghanistan liberated from terror, terrorism and terrorists; says Washington is likely to support international peacekeeping force being considered to help restore order in Kabul, by contributing logistical support, intelligence and transportation, and that US might agree to have American forces stand by with 'quick reaction capability' as backup should peacekeeping force run into trouble; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: When It Comes to Poker, Working Together Is Against the Rules
abstract: Online poker develops a following despite its questionable legal standing; online world eliminates element of 'reading' fellow players, the emotional element of game, and gives greater significance to math, to pure value of given hand; absence of face-time prompts debate over relative ease of cheating on Internet and across a table; photo (M)

headline: Koizumi Calls for Vigilance After Japan Sinks Suspicious Boat
abstract: Japanese Coast Guard trades heavy fire with vessel suspected of being North Korean spy ship, causing it to sink just inside economic zone claimed by China; Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi calls for increased territorial vigilance; sunken ship's entire crew of 15 is believed to have drowned (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Ariba Replaces Financial Officer
abstract: Ariba names Jim Frankola chief financial officer, replacing Robert Calderoni, who was promoted chief executive and president in October; company's shares rise 69 cents, or 14.9 percent, to $5.32; graph (S)

headline: The Man Behind the Curtain In the Hewlett-Compaq Merger
abstract: Richard A Hackborn, veteran Hewlett-Packard executive and member of board, is now key man in company's effort to convince large shareholders to vote in favor of its merger with Compaq Computer Corp; is highly regarded throughout computer industry as both skilled technologist and shrewd strategist, whereas company's chairwoman and chief executive, Carleton S Fiorina, is seen as an outside, a general manager instead of someone who deeply understands technology; photo (M)

headline: Afghan Factions Work On a Draft Agreement
abstract: Delegates from four Afghan factions are in Bonn, Germany, to negotiate over draft of agreement for post-Taliban government drawn up by United Nations; it calls for 28-member executive administration, international security force for capital, and symbolic role for former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah; delegates and diplomats say that if parties agree on draft, four factions will propose 15 names each, complete with biographies and suggested portfolios, to UN special envoy for Afghanistan, Lakhdar Brahimi, who is chairing conference (M)

headline: Raytheon Moves to Reduce Debt
abstract: LEXINGTON, Mass., Oct. 22 (Bloomberg News) — The Raytheon Company said yesterday that it would offer 29 million common shares, expected to raise $1 billion, to reduce debt, a move analysts said was intended to keep its credit rating from being downgraded to junk status.

headline: Lego Tinkered With Success, And Is Now Paying a Price
abstract: lego tinkered with success, and is now paª

headline: Bush Details Plan to Help Insurers on Future Terror Claims
abstract: Bush administration proposes to pay vast majority of losses of insurance industry from any terrorist attacks next year and to cap industry's liability at $12 billion; plan calls for government to pay 80 percent of first $20 billion of claims next year and 90 percent of next $80 billion; if claims exceed $100 billion, Congress would determine how they would be paid; proposal would also limit industry's liability from terrorist claims to $23 billion in 2003; insurers would pay all of losses on first $10 billion; in 2004, industry's liability would be limited to $36 billion; insurers would pay all losses on first $20 billion in claims (M)

headline: Tying Russia to West, Putin Unveils Strategy, But Risks a Backlash
abstract: Article discusses Russian Pres Vladimir Putin's decision to join West in war on terrorism; challenge is to create cohesion within Russia; public opinion polls show Russian people have widely divergent opinions about terrorist attacks, and Putin's decision may put him at odds with electorate (M)

headline: Tokyo Announces Its Stimulus Package
abstract: Japan's Finance Min Masajuro Shiokawa says government will spend 1 trillion yen ($8.3 billion) to stimulate economic growth this year; stimulus package is much smaller than expected, and it illustrates worsening difficulties governemnt of Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi is having steering between conflicting urgent demands: that it get country's runaway budget deficit under control and that it act to keep economy from sliding further into recession; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Online Shopping Strengthens
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings reports that Internet retailers enjoyed sharp uptick in business on day after Thanksgiving (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Book Raises Questions of Publishing Rights
abstract: Commemorative book published by AOL Time Warner's America Online and Warner Books units about Sept 11 terrorist attacks, which includes comments that AOL subscribers posted online, fuels debate over who owns rights to such material; but case will probably not be litigated since proceeds from small paperback, Because We Are Americans: What We Discovered on September 11, 2001, are being donated to relief efforts (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Start-Up Gets $90 Million
abstract: PhotonEx, start-up company developing equipment to cut costs and increase capacity and flexibility of communications networks, says it has raised $90 million in its third round of financing (S)

headline: Russia Seeks Belated Peace Dividend
abstract: People who run Russia's companies and oversee its economy want US to do more to facilitate integration of their economy into that of rest of world's; American officials say they cannot move faster than Congress and other countries' governments will allow; one problem area is Russia's status under American antidumping laws, which penalize countries that are deemed to have tried to increase their market share in US by selling goods below cost of production; Russia wants to join World Trade Organization as soon as it can, both to gain easier access to foreign markets and to gain tools to defend its manufactured products there; better trade ties will probably be on agenda during meetings between Pres Bush and Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin in Washington (M)

headline: Neiman Marcus Profit Slips 54%
abstract: DALLAS, Nov. 29 (Bloomberg News) — The Neiman Marcus Group said today that its profit dropped 54 percent in its fiscal first quarter as the recession sapped demand for designer goods and expensive jewelry.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Suppliers Cut Off Daewoo
abstract: Daewoo Motor closes its three major plants after suppliers withhold shipments until auto maker pays its $1.2 billion in overdue bills; suppliers suggest that General Motors, which has agreed to take over Daewoo, make payments (S)

headline: Countdown To The Euro: Euro:It's More Than Just a Pretty Penny
abstract: PARIS—  In the biggest currency swap in history, more than 300 million Europeans in 12 countries will start using the euro as their day-to-day money Tuesday, irrevocably casting their old marks, francs, lire, pesetas and other national currencies into the trash can of history.

headline: Annan, Accepting Nobel Prize, Restates U.N.'s Continuing Goals
abstract: OSLO, Dec. 10 — Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations, used the occasion of the 2001 Nobel Peace Prize lecture today to make an impassioned case for the continued importance of the United Nations as a promoter of peace and a champion of individual rights in an unstable and unequal world.

headline: PRESIDENT WEIGHS WHO WILL FOLLOW TALIBAN IN POWER
abstract: Pres Bush reportedly has begun discussing how United States and its coalition partners can help Afghans quickly form new government should Taliban government fall; focuses on creating viable and broad based coalition government, beginning economic rebuilding and providing security force to keep peace; fears power vacuum and renewed civil war that could spur emergence in few years of new threat similar to Taliban; Pentagon reports bomb fired from Navy jet hit residential neighborhood, Kabul; cites apparent targeting error; Taliban leaders reject Bush's offer of second chance to surrender Osama bin Laden and stop bombing; photo (M)

headline: South Korea Launches Missile In Its First Test Since Last Year
abstract: South Korea announces that it has test-fired missile that is believed by defense analysts to have capability of landing almost anywhere in North Korea; missile fell into Yellow Sea after traveling only 62 miles, well below 187-mile limit set by multilateral Missile Technology Control Regime that South Korea joined in Mar after years of negotiations with United States (M)

headline: Personal Business; That Temptation to Cheat Has the I.R.S. on Guard
abstract: Cheating on taxes is on rise, partly encouraged by lax enforcement; IRS is taking some steps to tighten up on certain kinds of cheating, and it will be harsh on anyone convicted of cheating on taxes (M)

headline: Inspired by Chance Meetings
abstract: It was one of those moments you are completely and totally learning by doing.

headline: Share Prices Gain on Prospect of a Microsoft Settlement
abstract: Stock prices rise on New York Stock Exchange on November 1, with surge in technology issues; Dow Jones industrial average gain 188.76 points, to close at 9,263.90; Nasdaq Composite Index climbs 56.10, ending at 1,746.30; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 24.32 points, to 1,084.10; graph (M)

headline: Discounters Give Lift to Retail Sales
abstract: Retailers' sales in October rise a better-than-forecast 0.9 percent as consumers seek low prices at chains like Wal-Mart Stores and Kohl's and avoid clothing retailers like Gap; 6.7 percent increase at Wal-Mart helps to lift industry's sales at stores open at least a year; table shows results for various companies; chart (M)

headline: Holiday Air Travel Is Expected to Be Off Sharply
abstract: Air travel during holiday season, traditionally busiest travel period of year, is expected to decline sharply, deepening gloom for airlines desperately cutting fares to fill seats; Americans are showing less interest in venturing far from home over Thanksgiving holiday, with almost daily reports of new airport security slipups, and with repeated and vague government warnings of further terrorist attacks; Travel Industry Assn of America estimates air travel for entire fourth quarter will be at least 25 percent below year-earlier levels; American Automobile Assn projects 5.9 percent decline from year-earlier period in number of Americans planning to make Thanksgiving weekend trips of more than 100 miles from home (M)

headline: Tough Talk From Blair On Taliban
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair declares Osama bin Laden was responsible for terrorist attacks on United States, speech, Labor Party conference, Brighton, Eng; challenges Afghanistan's Taliban leaders to give him up or face ouster; says any action will be aimed at military, not civilians; seems to be heralding beginning of new world order in battle against terrorism, with Blair somewhere close to helm (M)

headline: With the Economy Still Fragile, the Fed Again Cuts Rates
abstract: Federal Reserve reduces target for federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 1.75 percent, eleventh cut in borrowing costs in 2001; Congress and Pres Bush hasten to revive negotiations on economic stimulus package and pledge willingness to compromise; burden for lifting economy remains on Federal Reserve because there is no assurance that Congress and administration will enact stimulus bill (M)

headline: A Pro-Taliban Rally Draws Angry Thousands in Pakistan, Then Melts Away
abstract: Crowd of nearly 15,000 gathers in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, to chant their support for Osama bin Laden, and Taliban in Afghanistan; photos; map (L)

headline: QWEST COMMUNICATIONS TO PURCHASE KPNQWEST SHARES
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc agrees to buy 14 million shares of KPNQwest NV for $64 million (S)

headline: Another Tape Ties bin Laden To Hijackings
abstract: Tape of Osama bin Laden found recently in Afghanistan shows him recounting how he listened to news reports on radio of first hijacked plane crashing into World Trade Center on September 11 and quickly told others around him that there would be more as he awaited second attack; White House officials say transcripts show bin Laden was amused that many of hijackers were unaware they were on suicide missions; weigh whether to make tapes public (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett's Post-Merger Team
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co hnames six more executive to run company after its planned merger with Compaq Computer: Susan Bowick, Debra Dunn, Allison Johnson, Dick Lampman, Bob Napier and Shane Robison (S)
