headline: Becoming A New Yorker In a Hurry; Vivendi's Chairman Seeks To Woo U.S. Investors
abstract: Profile of Jean-Marie Messier, chairman of Vivendi Universal, Europe's largest media company, who moved to Manhattan to set up his main base of operations just eight days before Sept 11 terrorist attacks; he says attacks have only strengthened his commitment to Manhattan, part of effort to forge stronger bonds with American investors and 40,000 employees he inherited with acquisition of Seagram and its Universal media operations, 5,000 of them in New York; photos; chart (M)

headline: Digital Camera Sales Surged in October
abstract: Sales of digital cameras rise 83 percent in four weeks ended Oct 27; sales of film continue declining (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Home Lender In Talks
abstract: Housing Development Finance Corp, India's leading home lender, says it is discussing takeovers with several of its rivals, including Tata Homefinance Limited (S)

headline: OPEC President Says Cartel to Cut Output Starting on Jan. 1
abstract: OPEC president. Chekib Khelil, underscoring growing resolve among largest oil-producing nations to shore up declining prices, says cartel will reduce daily oil output beginning January 1, 2002; photo (M)

headline: The Wired Teenager
abstract: Yankee Group reports growth in teenagers' shopping online, but e-mailing remains their primary Internet activity; photo; chart (S)

headline: WILLIAMS-SONOMA EXPECTS TO MEET PROFIT ESTIMATES
abstract: Williams-Sonoma Inc, owner of Pottery Barn and Williams-Sonoma chains, expects to meet third-quarter and annual profit forecasts even as sales fall below previous estimates (S)

headline: Iranians Welcome Winter With a Ritual From Ancient Persia
abstract: Iran, which is 99 percent Muslim, celebrates feast of Yalda, ancient holiday dating to earlier religious era, age of Zoroastrianism; feast marks winter solstice, and for Iranains, it is night of eating, celebrating and telling stories; Zoroastrianism was official faith in ancient Persia; current Zoroastrian community in Iran has dwindled to 100,000, but its traditions have survived all political upheavals, even arrival of Islam (M)

headline: Hard-Edged Insurance Chief Is Taking On a New and Public Face
abstract: Maurice R Greenberg, chief executive at American International group, is leading charge by insurance industry, which lost billions of dollars in September 11 terrorist attacks, for federal government to serve as insurer of last resort in any future catastrophe; has met with Pres Bush and lobbied members of Congress since attacks, which will cost company about $820 million in payments on claims; strategy is to emphasize role insurance plays in underpinning vital industries, stressing that government help for insurers is really help for economy as whole; photo (M)

headline: Soybean Processor Exceeds Forecasts
abstract: Bunge Ltd reports third-quarter net income more than tripled, to $57 million, up from $17 million in 2000 period (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AUSTRALIA MORE FALLOUT FROM ONE.TEL Repercussions continue from the failure earlier this year of the start-up telecommunications company, One.Tel, backed by Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer. Australia's securities regulator accused several former directors of breaching their duties and withholding information. The Securities and Investments Commission started civil proceedings against the former managing directors, Jodee Rich and Bradley Keeling, and the former chairman, John Greaves. Evidence shows, however, that other directors, including Mr. Murdoch's son Lachlan, above left; James Packer, above right; and Rodney Adler, did not know the

headline: U.S. Move to Extend Scope of Payroll Tax
abstract: Internal Revenue Service issues regulations requiring companies and employees to pay 15.3 percent payroll tax on exercise of incentive stock options and proceeds from employee stock purchase plans; it is first time in 30 years that payroll taxes will be assessed on incentive stock options and employee stock purchase plans (S)

headline: India Weighs Using Troops to Hunt 2 Groups in Pakistan
abstract: India said to be considering military action if diplomatic pressure fails to persuade Pakistan to crack down on Pakistan-based groups India has accused of Dec 13 attack on Parliament; India recalls its envoy to Pakistan and ends bus and train service between two nations, hoping to ratchet up pressure on Pakistan to act against groups; senior official says India has told United States, Britain and European Union that it may cross so-called line of control into portion of Kashmir controlled by Pakistan, where militant Islamic groups that India wants banned have training camps and bases of operation; United States fears escalating tensions between India and Pakistan could turn into armed conflict that would undermine its efforts to capture Al Qaeda and Taliban members fleeing from Afghanistan into Pakistan (M)

headline: Prayers Sustain Pakistani Church In Hard Times
abstract: Christians in Pakistan, tiny minority in Muslim nation, face religious tensions as modern-day Islamic prophets preach about holy war; gunmen, perhaps angered at military campaign in Afghanistan, recently entered church in Bahawalpur during Christian service and killed 15 worshipers; even before attack, pastor at church in Peshawar, near Afghan border, had asked Pakistani government for soldiers to guard Christian churches and housing developments, in case Muslims heed call of more radical mullahs to attack friends of United States; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas falls as forecasts for mild weather signals reduced demand for heating fuel; in New York, natural gas for December delivery falls 19.2 cents, or 6.6 percent, to $2.733 per million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: PROFITS INCREASE BY 68% FOR KRISPY KREME DOUGHNUTS
abstract: Profits in Krispy Kreme Doughnuts's fiscal third-quarter rose 68 percent as the company opened stores and consumers ate more doughnuts. Net income rose to $6.48 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 28, from $3.85 million, or 7 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 28 percent, to $99.8 million, the company said yesterday.  Krispy Kreme added 10 stores in California, Pennsylvania and other states, bringing the total number of stores to 198 at the end of the quarter. Krispy Kreme's sales were not hurt by a decline in consumer spending as much as other retailers' were because comfort foods like doughnuts are appealing when the economy slows, analysts said. Krispy Kreme is based in Winston-Salem, N.C.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Compaq Misses Sales Goals And Expects Quarterly Loss  Compaq Computer said that it had missed its third-quarter sales goals by as much as 12 percent and would post an operating loss, largely because of a virtual halt to its business after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.     Michael D. Capellas, the chairman and chief executive, cited additional reasons for the shortfall, including fallout from its announced merger with Hewlett-Packard. He insisted that the deal would continue. [Page C6.]

headline: Report Says Egypt Plot With Pilots Was Blocked
abstract: Egyptian security forces acknowledge that in May they arrested group of Islamic militants who were prepared to carry out attacks in Egypt; statement is in form of article in weekly magazine Al Mussawar; article blames Al Qaeda for attacks on America (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Samsung To Reverse Losses
abstract: Hwang Chang Gyu, president of division of Samsung Electronics that produces memory chips, says improved economy in second half of next year will reverse losses company has sustained this year while it begins to mass-produce 512-megabit dynamic random access memory semiconductor; says 512-megabit chip and 12-inch wafer from which it is made has gone into regular production in limited quantities, while 256-megabit chip has become its biggest moneymaker (S)

headline: Pepsi Bottling in Deal
abstract: Pepsi Bottling Group agrees to buy Pepsi Bottling Company of Macon Inc to expand its reach accross Georgia (S)

headline: The Gift Tightrope
abstract: Etiquette experts offer guidelines for exchanging holiday gifts with fellow workers (S)

headline: Demonstrators Find That the Web Is a Powerful Tool
abstract: Many of small and scattered group of Americans who disapprove of Bush administration's bombing of Afghanistan as response to Sept 11 terrorist attacks are finding Internet powerful tool for reaching out to other dissenters and forming movement; first generation of Internet activists may be spreading their message farther and faster than their predecessors in earlier, more popular political protests; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Denies Taliban Claim That Dead Man Was American
abstract: US Embassy in Pakistan says man who Taliban says died in Kandahar hospital was not US citizen, as Taliban claims; Taliban says man identified as John Bolton crossed from Pakistan claiming to be relief worker, was arrested as spy and and later fell ill and died; Quetta, Pakistan, hotel worker says a John Bolton with US passport stayed there for five months and left recently (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Third Airport For Paris
abstract: French government announces plan to build third Paris airport in Chaulnes, about 80 miles from capital; many Green Party members think airport is unnecessary, particularly in light of current decline in air travel (S)

headline: For Holiday Shoppers, Sale Is the Only Thing
abstract: Holiday shoppers flock to stores around US with rekindled appetites, lured by widespread sales and deep discounts; photos; retail activity remains sluggish in New York as economists watch to see if American consumers will pull economy out of recession; many shoppers say they are toning down spending this year, despite sales, and avoiding the frivolous in aftermath of terrorist attack; New York's woes are bad news for embattled chains like Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's, heavily dependent on Manhattan sales (M)

headline: United in Cause, Syria Allows Foes of Israel in Its Midst
abstract: September 11 terrorist attacks against US seem not to have changed balance in Syria, which harbors terrorists as matter of policy, and is on State Department's list of terrorism's sponsors; government has expressed regrets over attacks on American civilians and willingness to join others in antiterror fight, but has also called on other countries to halt Israel's alleged use of terrorism in putting pressure on its neighbors; neither government nor groups it harbors seemed to have played any role in attacks on US; photo (M)

headline: Challenge for Algeria: Berber Anger
abstract: Death of Massinissa Guermah while in police custody in Beni Douala, Algeria, eight months ago has triggered outpouring of anger among country's Berber minority, which makes up ten percent of population; thousands of demonstrators have repeatedly taken to streets, particularly in impoverished Kabylia region; Berbers have long pushed for greater cultural and political recognition but latest protests are focused on economic issues, and are winning support among Arabs in other areas of Algeria, where residents are also taking to streets; map; photo (M)

headline: Christmas Eve In Bethlehem: Santas, Songs But No Arafat
abstract: Christmas Eve is celebrated in Bethlehem with festivities but Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat is barred from attending religious observances there; Israeli government, over pleas of Bush administration, has held to position that Arafat would be barred unless killers of tourism minister Rehavan Zeevi were arrested; Palestinian gunmen critically wound Israeli motorist in what their group Al Aksa Martyrs Brigade describes as retaliation; photo (M)

headline: Economy & Business; Automakers' Big Sales Now May Cut Business Next Year
abstract: Automakers' interest-free financing deals are credited for marked upturn in automobile sales this fall but may dampen sales in 2002; number of cars sold and manufacturers' profits do not necessarily move in tandem; photo; table (M)

headline: The Stock Market Must Rise in 2002? Think Again
abstract: Mark Hulbert column says investors and analysts are wrong to believe that 2002 will bring stock market gains because there was contraction 2001; says stock market's yearly gyrations are independent of one another; graph (M)

headline: Clamping Down On Spore Sources
abstract: Facing growing fear over anthrax, the United States has signed an agreement with Uzbekistan to remove tons of deadly anthrax spores from a remote island where the Soviet Union buried them.

headline: 24/7 Service, But Who's Counting?
abstract: Matt Richtel article on 24/7 customer service as provided by AT&T and other telecommunications giants, which he says means 'normal business hours' if you want your call answered by a person rather than a machine; drawing (M)

headline: Boarder's Dilemma: Bleed or Sink
abstract: Charles Herold reviews video games on surfing and skateboarding themes; photos (M)

headline: Saudis Freeze Funds Of 66 on U.S. List
abstract: Saudi Arabia orders freeze on assets of people and organizations that United States has identified as sponsors of terrorism (M)

headline: Securing Base, U.S. Makes Its Brawn Blend In
abstract: Efforts of US soldiers from Army's 96th Civil Affairs Battalion to blend in among residents of Kabul, Afghanistan, described; many wear Afghan clothing and sport scruffy beards; are stationed at Bagram air base, 20 miles north of city; photos (M)

headline: Personal Business; For Travelers Who Want It All
abstract: Travel agents catering to upscale clientele thrive at time when others in industry are faltering (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; With thoughts of Enron still fresh in their minds, investors send Calpine shares tumbling.
abstract: Shares of Calpine Corp fall 20 percent and its its bonds are also hit as investors grow uneasy about company's ability to finance aggressive construction plan; Kit Konolige of Morgan Stanley expresses caution on company and others in energy-producing and trading sector; Peter Cartright, company's founder and chief executive, replies to Dec 9 article in New York Times comparing company's business model to Enron's (M)

headline: HORTON ACQUIRES ANOTHER HOME BUILDER
abstract: D R Horton Inc acquires Schuler Homes for $653 million in cash and stock, continuing consolidation of home construction industry; will also assume $552 million in debt (S)

headline: As U.N. Meets, Bin Laden Tape Sets Off Alarms
abstract: Scores of world leaders converge on New York for UN General Assembly meeting as Osama bin Laden's latest videotaped message provokes new security concerns for UN and its global work force; terrorist leader singles out Russian Pres Vladimir Putin, calls UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan 'criminal' and UN 'tool of crime' that sides with Western 'crusader' interests against Muslims; UN on high alert in preparation for speeches by Pres Bush and other leaders; photo; officials are struck by bin Laden's vehemence just as UN envoy Lakhdar Brahimi is trying to help form new Afghan government to displace Taliban; bin Laden, from his cave, seems keenly aware that US is working closely with Russia on military campaign; other bin Laden quotes (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Hoisting The Sub, Slowly
abstract: Russian submarine Kursk, which was lifted from bottom of Barents Sea and towed to shore, will be hoisted onto floating dock (S)

headline: H.I.V. 'Explosion' Seen in East Europe and Central Asia
abstract: United Nations yearly report on worldwide AIDS finds HIV infections are rising faster in Eastern Europe and Central Asia than anywhere else in world and are 15 times as high as they were three years ago; number of infected Eastern Europeans and Central Asians may be four to five times as high as official figures, because relatively few cases are reported; Dr Peter Piot, executive director of joint UN programs on HIV and AIDS, gives bleak picture of worsening global epidemic; map (M)

headline: Warrant Plan Hits a Snag As Italy Says It Disapproves
abstract: Justice ministers from all 15 European Union countries agree on definition of terrorism; Italy balks at list of 32 crimes to be included in European Union-wide arrest warrant that would cover all countries, preferring to limit those crimes to six that carry life sentences (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GLOBAL CROSSING, Hamilton, Bermuda, owner of a telecommunications network, won a 12-year $700 million contract to provide service to Computer Sciences, El Segundo, Calif., a computer services company. Computer Sciences won a $400 million order from Global Crossing to run its personal and mainframe computers for 10 years.    M&T BANK, Buffalo, said it would buy back about 5.3 percent of its outstanding stock, as many as five million shares, which are worth about $343 million at yesterday's prices.

headline: Slew of Supreme Court Cases to Focus on '96 Telecom Law
abstract: Supreme Court will hear telecommunications cases that lawyers say show shortcomings of landmark 1996 law that was supposed to deregulate industry and introduce competition to phone markets long dominated by monopolies; 10 suits, consolidated into three sets of cases, raise questions about costs of local phone and high-speed Internet services; outcomes could help determine how much consumers will pay for such services and how many competitors will survive to provide them; one set of cases challenges accounting methods government uses in setting rates for rival local phone companies that use regional Bell companies's networks and equipment; second deals with Federal Communication Commission's power to regulate rates utilities charge cable television operators for using their poles to provide high-speed Internet services; third deals with whether state regulators who set phone rates can be sued in federal courts; table (M)

headline: A Hand-Held Mouse for Those With an Itchy Web Finger
abstract: Fellowes introduces hand-held computer mouse called Micro Trac; suggested retail price $24.99 (S)

headline: Goldman Sachs Hires Senior Executive
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group hires Alison J Mass, high-ranking employee in investment banking operation at Merrill Lynch, for new senior executive position to manage company's relationship with corporate and institutional clients worldwide (S)

headline: Executive Bonuses Included In the Hewlett-Compaq Deal
abstract: Senior executives of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer will receive bonus payments totaling more than $55 million if the companies' merger succeeds and they stay on until September 2003, according to a document filed with the government yesterday.    But in an apparent gesture of faith in the merger, Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, and Michael D. Capellas, the chief executive of Compaq, chose not to participate in the executive retention program. Ms. Fiorina walked away from a potential bonus of $8 million, while Mr. Capellas could have received a payment of $14.4 million, according to the proxy statement being sent to shareholders of the two companies.

headline: Protecting Steel: An Economic War That All Could Lose
abstract: Floyd Norris column questions wisdom of Bush administration's push for creation of international cartel in steel industry resulting from agreements with steel-producing nations to cut production and thus raise prices; graph (M)

headline: Magazine Jobless Feel Twice Battered
abstract: Magazine business has been badly hurting, but Sept 11 terrorist attack has sharpened downturn, both in economic and psychological terms; some magazines, like Mademoiselle, close, while long-established magazines like Time, Rolling Stone and Good Housekeeping cut their staffs; photo (M)

headline: Locally, Big Discounts Draw Crowds and Dismay
abstract: Shoppers crowd stores day after Christmas, searching for bargains and big discounts, but are often disappointed with markdowns; in some areas, stores are empty; photo (M)

headline: Perchance to Live (and Fly)
abstract: Florence Kuti-George letter says events of Sept 11 should not keep people from flying

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Securities Firms Plan Online System
abstract: Technology Briefing: Securities Firms Plan Online System**È

headline: A Scaling Back, Anger in the Streets and American Determination
abstract: Overview of day's events following another day of airstrikes on Afghanistan; focuses on protests in Muslim countries and American steadfastness in time of crisis (M)

headline: Oil Prices Soar on Confusing Report About Russia's Output
abstract: Oil prices rise on report that Min Mikhail Kasyanov said group of Russian oil companies might agree to cut exports in support of Organization of Peteroleum Exporting Countries' efforts to raise prices; his language was much more equivocal than report suggested; analysts and some oil companies say export cut is very unlikely; graphs; table (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Soccer Star Arrested
abstract: Hector Chumpitaz, Peru's former soccer star, is put under house arrest on suspicion that he took bribe from former intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, to run for Lima City Council in 1998 (S)

headline: Sweeping a Tale Under Gulf Land's Pretty Rug
abstract: People in Dubai are unwilling to talk about Marwan al-Shehhi, Dubai citizen thought to have piloted one of planes that crashed into World Trade Center Sept 11; government-guided news media in United Arab Emirates have not mentioned his name; residents of his hometown deny knowledge of him; photo (M)

headline: Auto Sales Resume, but Industry Outlook Seems Worrisome
abstract: Auto sales, which virtually halted in wake of terrorist attacks on World Trade Cener and Pentagon, are beginning to resume as passage of time and new incentives bring some customers back to showrooms; most analysts sharply scale back sales estimates for year (M)

headline: ROYAL DUTCH AND SAUDI REFINING BUY INTO 2 VENTURES
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Saudi Refining Inc will buy ChevronTexaco Corp's interest in two refining ventures for $3.86 billion (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of chart in October 30 Business Day section accompanying article on cable television subscriptions in selected areas

headline: Fire Sprinkler Recall Sought
abstract: Consumer Product Safety Commission will file administrative lawsuit to force Sunbeam Corp and Grucon Corp to recall fire sprinkler that government contends poses safety hazard; companies say they are not responsible for sprinkler commission says is faulty, Star ME-1 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Death Sentences For 2 Mayors
abstract: Mu Siuxin, former mayor of Shenyang, China, and former deputy mayor, Ma Xiangdong, are gives death sentences for bribery and corruption (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Research Firm Cuts Jobs
abstract: Jupiter Media Metrix is cutting at least 195 jobs, or 30 percent of its staff (S)

headline: Israelis Offer Help and Quiet Support for U.S.
abstract: Israeli officials offer strong but quiet support for attack on Afghanistan; Palestinian reaction is ambiguous (M)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Middling Earth      There's a huge online fandom devoted to ''Lord of the Rings.'' There's a huge online contingent of students seeking homework help. These two groups do not mix well.

headline: Military Reassurances, Unexplained Attacks, a Mideast Pullout
abstract: Overview of day's events in war in Afghanistan, anthrax scare and memorial held for those killed in World Trade Center attack (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Fears Of Terror Attack
abstract: Czech government says it would like Radio Free Europe to move its headquarters away from downtown Prague, citing fears that network could be target of terrorist attack (S)

headline: CUMULUS BUYS CONNECTICUT AND NEW YORK RADIO STATIONS
abstract: Cumulus Media says it agreed to buy closely held Aurora Communications for about $223 million in stock, cash and assumed debt to gain radio stations in Connecticut and New York (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Advertising Group to Meet in China
abstract: Advertising Group To Meet in China.

headline: Israelis Attack Arafat's Compound and 7 Other Sites
abstract: Israel bombarded security offices in the West Bank and Gaza Strip today, killing at least two Palestinians and injuring scores.

headline: Package Bomb Kills American In Saudi Arabia
abstract: Package bomb explodes on shopping street in Khobar, Saudi Arabia, killing two foreigners, including an American; four other people are injured (S)

headline: Post-Soviet Poverty: Children's Burden
abstract: United Nations Children's Fund reports nearly 18 million children in former Soviet bloc live in poverty; says families struggling to cope with declining real incomes are increasingly putting children up for adoption or sending them to institutions for care; fund study finds huge disparities in way people were affected by shift to free market economy (M)

headline: U.S. Diplomat Meets Saudis Over Accounts
abstract: American diplomat William J Burns meets with top Saudi officials in Riyadh, including Crown Prince Abdullah and Prince Saud al-Faisal, for talks intended in part to seek further Saudi help in cutting off money to suspected terrorist groups; senior Saudi officials complain before meeting that US has not shared evidence necessary for them to freeze bank accounts permanently and to take other actions; Bush administration tries to play down appearance of any rift, and diplomats acknowledge that US has not provided sufficient evidence for Saudis to take further action (M)

headline: Kazakh Leader Urges Iran Pipeline Route
abstract: Kazakhstan Pres Nursultan Nazarbayev urges US to consider Iran's strategic role as transport route for huge crude oil and natural gas deposits in Caspian Sea; speaks during visit by Sec Colin Powell; photo; US has sought, since collapse of Soviet Union, to secure region's oil wealth with Wetern participation and has promoted new pipeline routes that would skirt Russia and provide outlet through Turkey; Powell responds cautiously before leaving for Moscow (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cable And Wireless Dividend
abstract: Cable and Wireless says it will pay special dividend of 17 cents a share in March and buy back up to 15 percent of its own stock worth around $2 billion; has been under pressure from investors to hand back part of $6.5 billion in cash accrued from asset sales; reports first-half earnings of $736 million (S)

headline: CANTOR FITZGERALD SHUTS FRANKFURT AND PARIS OFFICES
abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald LP is closing its Frankfurt and Paris offices as it tried to reduce expenses; firm has shifted most of its trading to its eSpeed Inc unit; about 700 Cantor employees were killed on Sept 11 in attacks on World Trade Center (S)

headline: Health Care As Main Engine: Is That So Bad?
abstract: Health care industry has been one of only parts of $10 trillion American economy that has remained healthy, and many economists say that sprawling health care industry may be only drive rof growth in near term; even when consumer spending and corporate investment pick up, health care sector is likely to expand faster than most industries in years ahead; industry is adding jobs, spending more money and outperforming many other companies; graph; photos (M)

headline: Arrests Are Said to Have Disrupted Attacks
abstract: US officials say arrests and detentions of suspected Al Qaeda operatives around world may have delayed or prevented new terrorist attacks, although they caution that major attacks in US or overseas are very likely at any time (S)

headline: Czech Journalists Face Pressure to Curb Criticism
abstract: Comic-strip characters do not usually have the power to shake real-life governments, but when Karel Brezina, a 29-year-old-Czech government minister, saw himself depicted in a satirical strip in one of the country's leading weekly magazines earlier this year, he sued.    A few months later, his boss, Prime Minister Milos Zeman, took umbrage at accusations in Respekt, a weekly investigative magazine, that his cabinet had presided over an era of unbridled corruption. He threatened to sue the magazine and put it out of business.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ebay President Joins Goldman Board
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group names Meg Whitman, chief executive and president of eBay Inc, to its board, bringing total to nine (S)

headline: Pope, Not Mentioning U.S., Urges Military Restraint
abstract: Pope John Paul II, in annual message for Catholic Church's World Day of Peace, urges military restraint in war on terrorism while not mentioning US or Afghanistan; warns of importance of carefuly limiting military action, even when action is justified; says there is right to defend oneself against terrorism, but that only terrorists themselves and not entire nations should be called to account (M)

headline: Growing Marine Force Turns Desolate Airstrip Into a High-Tech Base
abstract: US marines transform desolate airstrip in southern Afghanistan, seized eight days ago, into heavily-fortified, highly technological base of operations to support final assault on Taliban's last stronghold in Kandahar; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Yellow Book USA, Rockville Centre, N.Y., which publishes yellow pages directories, to Trahan, Burden & Charles, Baltimore, to handle its account, which had been in-house. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $20 million. Yellow Book USA is a unit of Yell, owned by Apax Partners & Company and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst.

headline: G-7 Leaders Pledge To Work In Concert to Thwart Terrorists
abstract: World's leading industrial nations agree to share intelligence information relating to financing of terrorism and to pressure other countries to prevent terrorists from using global banking system (M)

headline: Grayer Than You Think
abstract: Henry Posner letter on Oct 11 Online Shopper article notes reputable merchants may not want to pay cost of registering with online resource cited that measures customer satisfaction

headline: The Computer That Wore Galoshes and a Raincoat
abstract: Weather Channel's Web site offers downloadable desktop program that updates day's weather forecasts, barometric readings and radar map; photo (M)

headline: Taliban's Brand of Zeal May Survive Their Rule
abstract: More than 150 young Pakistanis are prisoners in old granary resembling medieval dungeon in eastern Afghan village, having volunteered to fight with Taliban, walked across mountains and into gun sites of anti-Taliban militias; fundamentalist fervor that gave Al Qaeda and Taliban life has yet not lost spark, and US bombing may be fueling sympathy even as Taliban rule is shattered (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit At Yahoo Japan
abstract: Yahoo Japan Corp reports earnings for July-Sept quarter rose to 1.3 billion yen ($10.7 million), up 91 percent from 2000 period (S)

headline: European Critics of U.S. Find That the War Gives Them Little Ammunition
abstract: European criticism of United States and war in Afghanistan is quelled because Taliban has been overthrown so quickly and images of women enjoying new freedoms are compelling; concern over civilian casualties remains high and some European supporters reiterate that they will not back attack on Iraq (M)

headline: Afghans Hope U.S. Also Wages Peace
abstract: Afghan refugees living in Pakistan watch televised images of American bombs pounding on Kandahar; express hope that after Americans get their military victory in Afghanistan, they will do what they did in Japan after World War II, and rebuild country they vanquished (M)

headline: New Economy; Solidifying trademark protection in a global market, where logos can transcend language.
abstract: International Trademark Association seeks to convince governments to enact and enforce laws to protect trademarks; Nils Montan, group's president, comments, interview; drawing (M)

headline: Pentagon Tries To Avoid Using Pakistan Bases
abstract: Pentagon shapes war plan against terrorists to minimize use of Pakistani bases for strike against Osama bin Laden and Taliban in Afghanistan, fearing extensive deployments could destabilize crucial but volatile ally, one that has tested nuclear weapons; growing anti-American sentiment in region prompts Pentagon to scramble to make new arrangements; Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld leaves for Saudi Arabia, Oman, Egypt and Uzbekistan to discuss using bases; new alliances are linking US to several authoritarian governments that have records of corruption and rights abuses but also fear radical Islamic movements; Rumsfeld points out importance of Uzbekistan's position bordering Afghanistan; US already trains Uzbeks in counterterrorism, drug interdiction and weapons smuggling; US now has more than 300 warplanes on ships and land bases from Indian Ocean to Red Sea; photo of USS Essex (M)

headline: German Chancellor Shores Up His Shaky Coalition
abstract: Germany's role as host of international conference on formation of new government in Afghanistan has helped Chancellor Gerhard Schroder shore up his coalition, which was shaken when Green Party partners, with their roots in pacifism, nearly imploded over vote in German Parliament supporting deployment of German troops in support role in and around Afghanistan (M)

headline: Strategy Shift Puts Pictures With Words
abstract: Strategy Shift Puts Pictures

headline: Equity Offerings Planned
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      America First Mortgage Investments Inc., New York, 10 million shares. Friedman, Billings, Ramsey & Company.

headline: Technology Briefing | Research: Genomics-Derived Drug To Be Tested
abstract: MLN4760, obesity drug discovered through genomics technology of Millennium Pharmaceuticals, enters clinical trials; is being developed with Abbott Laboratories (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Terra Lycos Posts Loss
abstract: Terra Lycos, Internet arm of giant Spanish telecommunications company Telefonica SA, reports better-than-expected results for third-quarter; says itnarrowed its core loss to 49 million euros ($44 million) (S)

headline: News Corporation Reports 44% Drop in Quarterly Profit
abstract: News Corp reports profit from operations in fiscal first quarter fell $83 million, or 44 percent, from $149 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 5 percent, to $3.4 billion (M)

headline: Copter Downed In Caucasus; 5 From U.N. Among 9 Dead
abstract: Five UN observers and four other people die after rebels shoot down helicopter in Abkhazia, separatist region of western Georgia on Black Sea (S)

headline: Private Sector; For a Hardened Lawyer, A Tender Personal Moment
abstract: David Boies, master litigator, is overcome with emotion as he is honored by LD Access Foundation, advocate for learning-disabled adults, for his candor about his dyslexia; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Says Top Bin Laden Aide Believed Killed in Airstrike
abstract: A leader of the Qaeda terror network is believed to have been killed in an American airstrike in the last two days, United States officials in Washington said today.

headline: Novartis Plans Drug Discount For Elderly
abstract: Novartis AG, Swiss drug manufacturer, will offer cards to low-income elderly Americans to provide discounts of 25 percent or more, beginning in January 2002, on company's brand-name drugs; those eligible would be people 65 or older, with incomes of $26,000 or less for single people and $35,000 for couples (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: New Zealand: Airline's Chief Departs
abstract: Gary Toomey resigns as chief executive of Air New Zealand after government bailout; Roger France, newly appointed director, will fill in until new chief executive is named (S)

headline: Iraqi Tells of Renovations at Sites For Chemical and Nuclear Arms
abstract: Iraqi defector says he personally worked on renovations of secret facilities for biological, chemical and nuclear weapons in underground wells, private villas and under hospital in Baghdad as recently as year ago; defector, Adnan Ihsan Saeed al-Haideri, who says he is civil engineer, gives details of projects he says he worked on for Pres Saddam Hussein's government; to support his account he provides copies of contracts; interview with Saeed is held in Bangkok, arranged by Iraqi National Congress, main Iraqi opposition group, which seeks Hussein's overthrow; if verified, Saeed's allegations would provide ammunition to officials within Bush administration who have been arguing that Hussein should be driven from power partly because of his unwillingness to stop making weapons of mass destruction, despite his pledges to do so; Richard Butler, who led United Nations international inspection effort in Iraq, says Saeed's account seems 'plausible,' but that American intelligence officials may be skeptical of such defectors, some of whom have embellished what they know to gain safe haven in US: there is no means to independently verify Saeed's allegations, but he seems familiar with key Iraqi officials in military establishment, with facilities thought to be associated with unconventional weapons, and with Iraq itself (M)

headline: Rights to Patriotic Children's Book Sold
abstract: Lynne Cheney, wife of Vice Pres Dick Cheney, has sold rights to children's book she has written about patriotism entitled America: A Patriot Primer to Simon & Schuster; book will be published in spring and illustrated by Robin Preiss Glasser; book was written prior to Sept 11 terrorist attacks in US (S)

headline: News Media Risk Big Losses To Cover War
abstract: There is never a good time for a war, but for big media and news companies, the timing of the current crisis is especially poor.    Even before Sept. 11, advertising sales, which underwrite most news operations, were already taking on water. Since Sept. 11, the advertising business has capsized.

headline: Birthing the Internet: Letters From the Delivery Room; Enough Glory to Be Shared
abstract: Les Earnest letter comments on Nov 8 article on credit for developing Internet; photo

headline: In New Leader's Village, Taliban Rules Are Just Tradition
abstract: Southern Afghan village of Karz, home of interim president Hamid Karzai, is as conservative in its Pashtun Islamic customs as Taliban; women don head-to-toe burkas when they leave home, and no girls is likely to go to school; photos (M)

headline: Del Monte Foods Reports $800,000 Loss
abstract: Del Monte Foods Co reports loss of $800,000 in its fiscal first quarter, compared with $6.4 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: A Finger in the Wind Suggests It's Already 2002
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column says it is possible that stock market rally anticipated for 2002 has already happened and that selloff in bond market is also at an end; notes that housing market was not affected by recession and therefore cannot fuel economic recovery; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Chip Maker Slips
abstract: STMicroelectronics says third-quarter profits fell 91 percent; expects sales and growth for fourth quarter to remain at third-quarter levels; graph (S)

headline: India's Premier Rejects Pakistani Bid for Talks, Citing Attack in Kashmir
abstract: India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, bluntly rejects invitation for talks with Pakistan's military ruler, Gen Pervez Musharraf, citing attack against Indian air base in Srinagar by Islamic militants from group based in Pakistan as example of Pakistani-supported terrorism; Musharraf says Pakistan will retaliate if India strikes militants' training camps on Pakistani side of line that separates portions of Kashmir each country controls; heated oratory signals that Sec of State Colin Powell's recent visits failed to calm flaring tempers; maps (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: New Power To Dismiss Leaders
abstract: Vietnam's increasingly influential national assembly approves constitutional amendment that gives it power to hold no-confidence votes and to dismiss government leaders, including president and prime minister; power does not extend to Communist Party hierarchy and ruling politburo (S)

headline: You Can Never Be Too Thin (or Cheap)
abstract: Ian Austen assesses lower-cost flat-panel liquid crystal display computer monitors priced for houseld users; photos (M)

headline: Delegates Meet in First Step Toward Post-Taliban Rule
abstract: Representatives from rival political and ethnic factions in Afghanistan meet in Bonn, Germany, for informal consultations prior to conference aimed at organizing broadly based and representative post-Taliban government; organized by UN but dominated by Western allies and Afghan proxies, conference is intended to produce transitional executive administration for Kabul and parts of country not held by Taliban; photos (M)

headline: Mood on the Exchange Floor Somber on Second Day of Attacks
abstract: As new attacks by the United States against Afghanistan began today, workers on Wall Street seemed newly somber.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro drops after German business-confidence survey hits eight-year low and government there says economic growth has stagnated; in New York, euro settles at 89.90 cents, down from 90.47 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Warnaco Reduces Its Credit Line
abstract: Warnaco Group receives court approval to decrease its bankruptcy credit line by $125 million and make other changes (S)

headline: U.S. Raids on Taliban Troops the Heaviest Yet
abstract: American

headline: A Call to Hire 'Singaporeans First'
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Although it is assured of an easy victory in Singapore's general elections Saturday, the government of Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong is having to fend off potentially damaging opposition charges that it favors foreigners in the job market at the expense of citizens.

headline: Panel of Iran Parliament to Review Foreign Policy
abstract: Iranian parliament names panel to study country's international relations in face of possible US military strike against Afghanistan (S)

headline: For 12 Nations at Midnight Monday: 'Happy Euro Year!'
abstract: Euro notes and coins are set to begin replacing national currencies in 12 European nations; companies and public institutions have spent heavily preparing for changeover; transition has been remarkably smooth so far; photo (M)/

headline: The Beauty of Future Aircraft Maintenance May Be Skin-Deep
abstract: Maintenance work on cars and airplanes is now dictated by number of miles logged, but researchers are at work on systems that will use radar-like signals to detect when structure of mechanical part is about to fail and alert users as to whether immediate action is needed to correct problem; photo (M)

headline: Juniper Networks Has Reduced Fourth-Quarter Profit Forecast
abstract: Juniper Networks halves its fourth-quarter profit forecast and cuts its sales estimate as customers pare spending (S)

headline: The To-Do List That Knows Where You Are
abstract: IN the wired world of the 21st century, it seems impossible to forget anything. A cartoon pops up on your computer screen reminding you that it's a friend's birthday. An exclamation mark surfaces on your palmtop alerting you to a looming project deadline. Every once in a while your cellphone breaks into spasms of music to signal your next appointment.     And yet you forget -- your reading glasses when you are rushing to work, your coat when you are going to the cleaners, your receipts when you are driving 30 miles to see your tax lawyer.

headline: New Software Patent Law For Europe Looking Limited
abstract: European Union appears to be moving toward unified regulations for software patents that would be less encompassing than regulations in US and Japan; competition officials at European Commission meet with their colleagues in charge of drafting new law for union, to press their case for limiting its scope; their concern is that overly protective patent regulation could hinder competition by helping large software manufacturers maintain their dominant positions; approach being adopted by commission would allow patents only for software of technical nature, and it would not permit patents on business methods (M)

headline: French Uproar Over Right to Death for Unborn
abstract: French high court causes uproar with landmark ruling that damages must be paid to Nicolas Peruche and his family because his birth 18 years ago was result of medical error; decision is seen as signal that unborn child has right to be aborted, or at least that handicapped child has right to recognition that his or her birth was mistake; Peruche cannot hear or speak, is largely blind, has weak heart and must use wheelchair; advocacy group for the handicapped sues court over decision; photo; ethical issues discussed (M)

headline: Outcomes Differ for Insiders and Small Investors at Global Crossing
abstract: Collapse of Global Crossing's stock from $61.375 two years ago to 82 cents today has been financially devastating to many people in upstate New York, but not to some Global Crossing executives and directors, who have done quite well, cashing out to varying degrees during last few years; Gary Winnick, who helped found company in 1997, has sold shares for more than $600 million; other company insiders who sold earlier this year include David A Walsh, president and chief operating officer, Joseph P Clayton, director, and Lodwrick Cook, co-chairman; meanwhile, investors and workers who owned shares in old Rochester Telephone, which was swallowed up by Global Crossing, saw their shares in low-risk utility converted into shares in high-risk start-up; photo; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Troops on Call
abstract: Listing of military commitments to international fight against terrorism of Britain, Germany, Canada, Australia, Italy, France, New Zealand, Turkey, Japan, Jordan, Belgium, Czech Republic and Poland (M)

headline: COCA-COLA BOTTLER'S PROFIT TO BEAT FORECASTS
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises announces that cost cutting and higher prices and sales will result in net income of 80 cents to 85 cents a share in 2002, above analysts' estimates (S)

headline: Israel Debates the Cost of Dealing With Arafat
abstract: News analysis on debate within Sharon government in Israel over whether to begin international campaign to undermine Yasir Arafat's legitimacy as leader of Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: In Turbulent Bond Market, Enron's Woes Exacerbate Turmoil
abstract: Swift downfall of Enron Corp contributes to extreme turbulence in US Treasury securities market in recent weeks, when signs of strengthening economy prompted movement out of Treasuries; traders who were still betting on lower interest rates were crushed and forced to sell even more, depressing prices and pushing rates up even further; trades that appear to have gone awry for Enron are believed to involve sale of hundreds of thousands of Eurodollar futures, which are frequently used to bet on direction of interest rates or to hedge against fluctuations in oil prices; graph (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Lisa Bowers was named marketing director at the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association.

headline: A Digital Spider's Web to Help Protect High-Security Areas
abstract: Researchers at Penn State devise inexpensive way to detect attempt to penetrate perimeter fence and sound an alarm; system is based on taut wire equipped with low-cost off-the-shelf vibration sensors linked to computers programmed to analyze and respond to signs of intruders; is intended to monitor borders of airfields, military installations, reservoirs and other vast areas with pressing security needs; photo (M)

headline: THE BOSS; 'That Girl' Goes Tailgating
abstract: Labor Sec Elaine L Chao writes The Boss column, describing her family's immigration from Taiwan, their culture, her upbringing and life with her husband, Sen Mitch McConnell; photo (M)

headline: NBC and Amazon Aim Store at Viewers
abstract: NBC Connect in New York, division of NBC sales and marketing that develops multimedia advertising packages, and Amazon.com will create online store that will enable viewers of programs on NBC broadcast and cable networks and stations to buy merchandise mentioned in or related to programs (S)

headline: A Cybernaut Plans Software for Navigating TV
abstract: Carl Malamud will shortly unveil NetTopBox, television viewers' program guide that employs technologies that help people navigate World Wide Web; cross-referencing within software gives greater depth and breadth than printed guides or guides found on any cable service; photo (M)

headline: The ''A'' List of Companies
abstract: Edward A Snyder letter comments on Nov 25 review of Jim Collins book Good to Great: Why Some Companies Make the Leap and Others Don't

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Leading Indicators: Sept.    TUESDAY  None

headline: Merrill Set for Changes That Will Cost Thousands of Jobs
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co starts preparing investors for big changes in its operations that will inevitably involve eliminating thousands of jobs; Merrill has been cutting costs and dismissing employees before E Stanley O'Neal was promoted to president and chief operating officer this summer, but he plans to accelerate pace of change; O'Neal, who is expected to succeed David H Komansky as chief executive within two and half years, has appointed new leaders of each of firm's major businesses and given each of them few weeks to decide how and where to slash costs; changes will probably include shrinking certain operations and closing or selling others, especially parts of Merrill's international brokerage business; Merrill reports third-quarter earnings fell 52 percent, to $422 million from $885 million year earlier; new revenue fell about 16 percent, to $5.15 billion from $6.14 billion; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Motorola To Offer Instant Messenger
abstract: AOL Time Warner and Motorola agree to alliance allowing Motorola to build AOL's Instant Messenger feature into its wireless devices (S)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Allen Basis, regional advertising director at Risk & Insurance magazine, Horsham, Pa., was promoted to advertising director.

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   5.00   5.00   9.50        Discount rate   1.50   1.50   6.00        Federal funds   2.06   2.04   6.46        3-month T-bills   1.85   1.92   6.08        6-month T-bills   1.92   1.99   6.00        10-yr. headline: Patents; Two new systems try to protect office buildings from chemical or biological attack.
abstract: Two new systems to protect office building personnel from chemical or biological attacks are patented by Noel Pearman, Honeywell Inc engineer; one system would deploy variety of decontamination fluids, and other would seal building ductwork (M)

headline: Thousands of Pakistanis Demonstrate but Police Hold Down the Violence
abstract: Thousands of demonstrators take to streets across Pakistan to protest American attacks on Afghanistan and their country's support for American-led alliance; big display of troops and weaponry keeps violence to minimum in what appears to be victory for Pres Pervez Musharraf's get-tough policy with protesters; biggest demonstration occurs in Karachi; photos (M)

headline: Tourism ads that started running after Sept. 11 are getting a midcourse correction.
abstract: Travel industry advertising, which stressed safety and travel freedom issues after Sept 11, turns more upbeat as Americans become less reluctant to travel (M)

headline: Numbers Prove U.S. Economy Has Retreated
abstract: Government reports economy contracted at inflation-adjusted 0.4 percent annual rate, July-Sept, first significant quarterly drop since 1991; analysts say Sept 11 terrorist attacks played key role, pushing already-weak economy over brink; expects deeper fourth-quarter drop; Pres Bush calls for quick action to spur economy, speech; Sec Paul G O'Neill urges Congress to approve stimulus package, consisting mostly of tax cuts; Democratic leaders, after meeting with Bush, holds tax cuts he seeks do not provide companies with new incentives to invest; photo (M)

headline: Chrysler Names Manufacturing Executive
abstract: Chrysler names Thomas W LaSorda executive vice president for manufacturing, as automaker cuts production costs in plan to end losses; LaSorda, 47, who will begin job Jan 1, will replace Gary L Henson, 59, who is retiring (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: A Fix For Internet Explorer
abstract: Microsoft releases patch that fixes security flaws in its Internet Explorer browser software (S)

headline: Stocks Fall, With Notable Losses in Some Muslim Lands
abstract: Financial markets across Asia fall after American and British military strikes against Afghanistan; investors flee from countries with large, potentially restive Muslim populations; Indonesia's currency and stock market tumble amid fears that military action will provoke backlash from Islamic militants; market declines are recorded in Philippines and Malaysia; photo (M)

headline: Uncompromising as Enemy, Often Agreeable as Friend
abstract: Israel is in shock that Palestinian gunmen could assassinate government minister, but there is little surprise that Tourism Min Rehavan Zeevi was target in killing; Zeevi, former general, has spent last dozen years as blunt standard-bearer for right wing in Israel; he hs mercilessly heckled Parliament leaders who tried to make peace, and referred to Yasir Arafat as 'Hitler'; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Sun Unveils Web Platform
abstract: Sun Microsystems introduces first phase of its Sun One, or Open Net Environment, software platform, suite of products that are designed to let customers create and deploy Web services that function on range of devices; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: SOFTWARECOURT EXTENDS FREE SPEECH PROTECTION In a setback for the movie industry's efforts to block distribution of software that can break through copy protections on DVD's, a California appeals court overturned on First Amendment grounds an earlier order that barred publication of the program. Movie studios have argued that the software is a tool and as such is not subject to free-speech protections. But the California court ruled that the software code was

headline: Pressing Greens, German Leader Wins Historic Vote on Sending Troops to Afghanistan
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder forces his junior coalition partner, the Greens, to support government in confidence vote over German paticipation in war in Afghanistan; vote gives Parliament's approval to deployment beyond Europe of German troops in combat role for first time since 1945; but narrowness of margin shows how far German government must travel to become reliable foreign-policy partner that Schroder wants it to be; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Computer Concern For Sale
abstract: Cedar Group, British computer company, says it is in talks to sell itself for less than half its market value because it is running out of cash; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rises
abstract: German unemployment rises for 11th straight month in November, increasing by 17,000 to seasonally adjusted 3.9 million; unemployment rate is unchanged at 9.5 percent (S)

headline: Telling a Tale, But Not Loudly
abstract: Kit Miller article expresses satisfaction with her year-old Web site promoting I Was Born a Black Woman, documentary film that she produced about Benedita da Silva, first black woman in Brazil's Senate; photo (S)

headline: Seeking Escape At the Cinema
abstract: Sept 11 terrorist attacks did not spur Americans to stay home from movies; top 10 films in Sept 10-30 period took in $156.7 million, up 7 percent from year-earlier period; table of top films; photo (S)

headline: Why Not Credit Cards, Too?
abstract: A Z Hamburg letter comments on Nov 18 article Economic View column, suggesting lowering credit card interest rates to give economy an immediate stimulus

headline: Mixing Palm With Phone: Another Try
abstract: David Pogue column assesses Samsung's new device combining Palm organizer with cellular phone; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Most Parties Will Go On, Even If They're Quieter
abstract: DIARYMost Parties Will Go On, Even If They're Quieter.

headline: Business; In Uncertain Times, Where Can Mergers Thrive?
abstract: Merger specialists Martin Lipton and Steven Koch discuss current business mood and outlook for year to come; interview; photo (M)

headline: Turnaround Prospects After Two Bad Years
abstract: Interview with Steve Galbraith (Morgan Stanley) on stock market outlook for 2002; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Trying to Restore Confidence in Enron to Salvage a Merger
abstract: Enron Corp and Dynegy Inc try to bolster confidence in Enron's weakened energy-trading business as companies' negotiators continue talks on revising terms of their merger; renegotiated deal would halve acquisition price, to roughly $4 billion; Dynegy also seems prepared to raise cash infusion into Enron by $250 million; ChevronTexaco, Dynegy's biggest investor, has already pledged $1.5 billion cash (M)

headline: Retailers Post Dismal Sales For November
abstract: Retailers post Nov sales growth that was below already low expections; sales at stores opened at least year grew 2 percent, tepid number inflated by calendar quirk that moved week of selling season to Nov from Dec; Gap Inc posts 25 percent year-to-year sales decline; Wal-Mart Stores posts 4.3 percent gain; graph; table; photo (M)

headline: Bailout Plan For Swissair Called Unfair By Rivals
abstract: Deal that Swiss government struck with country's biggest businesses to put together national airline from remnants of Swissair runs into criticism from rivals and European Union; Swissair's rivals, British Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, say $1 billion bailout gives Swissair unfair advantage; European Union officials suggest that they might try to block arrangement (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Oil Prices Drop Sharply As Russia Rebuffs OPEC  Oil prices plunged as Russia, the biggest oil producer after Saudi Arabia, rejected OPEC's challenge to stabilize prices by sharply cutting production. Prices in New York dropped 11.6 percent. They have fallen 21 percent this week.    The decision on Wednesday by OPEC to delay a production cut unless other major exporters did the same amounted to the declaration of a price war, analysts said. [Page A1.]    Profit at Dell Beat Expectations  Rebounding from a loss in the July quarter, Dell Computer reported a third-quarter profit of $429 million. Its earnings fell by one-third from results in the period a year earlier but edged past Wall Street's estimates. Michael S. Dell, the chief executive, said Pentium 4 chips from Intel, the Windows XP operating system from Microsoft and new wireless networking products from several vendors are leading the industry to its next upgrade cycle beginning next spring or summer. [C3.]

headline: People
abstract: Foote, Cone & Belding names Dana Anderson president and chief executive of its Chicago office, succeeding Brian Williams, who resigned (S)

headline: Amazon Plant Proliferates Again in African Lake, Causing Economic Peril
abstract: Water hyacinth, South American plant, is proliferating again in Africa's Lake Victoria after being controlled in late 1990's, threatening livelihood of fishing villages; local fishermen fear repeat of mid-1990's, when plant clogged most of shoreline, ensnarling fishing boats and killing fish; authorities in Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda mount new drive against hyacinth; photo (M)

headline: THE FIGHT AGAINST TERRORISM / According to Plan: Rumsfeld Shrugs Off Doubts About the War
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld shrugged off doubts about the U.S. campaign in Afghanistan on Sunday, saying that the ruling Taliban militia were no longer functioning as a government and that their effective power and control had been reduced to enclaves.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Abkhazia: Rebel Zone Bombed
abstract: Self-proclaimed government of Abkazia, breakaway region of Georgia, reports bombing lawless Kodori Gorge, where rebels shot down UN helicopter; Georgia and Russia, which tacitly supports separatists, accuse each other of inflaming tensions while peace talks are under way (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Peter F. Spano; Preferred International Value Fund
abstract: Carole Gould column profiles Preferred International Value fund and manager Peter F Spano, founder and general partner of Mercator Asset Management; he calls himself a 'relative value' investor; photos; table (M)

headline: Why the Best Action Is Often No Action at All
abstract: Maü

headline: Truce Helps Revive Hope For Peace In Sri Lanka
abstract: Truce agreement agreed to by Sri Lanka's newly elected government and ethnic Tamil rebels goes into effect; Prime Min Ranil Wickremesinghe reiterates that his government will ensure free movement of food, medicine and nonmilitary supplies into large northern areas of country that rebels countrol (M)

headline: Shares Fall on Unexpected Drop in Consumer Confidence
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 110.15 points, to 9,872.60; Standard and Poor's 500-stock index declines 7.92 points, to 1,149.50; Nasdaq composite index closes down 5.26 points, at 1,935.97; graph (M)

headline: Web Addresses Sprout New Suffixes, Needed or Not
abstract: World Wide Web addresses are beginning to appear with seven new suffixes even though it is unclear how urgently they are needed now that dot-com frenzy has subsided; they are .biz, intended for business purposes; .info, open to any use; .name, for registration by individuals, .pro, for professionals like lawyers, accountants or physicians, .museum, to be used by museum groups; .aero, for air transport industry, and .coop, for co-operative businesses or organizations; also appearing online are growing number of alternatives that exist outside official domain name system; drawing (M)

headline: DataBank; Breaking the Benchmarks, in Reverse
abstract: Summary of week's market activity; graphs (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAYPersonal IncomeAug.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: S.E.C. Gives Funds a Break on Ads
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission grants mutual funds two-month delay to comply with its rule that mutual fund advertising that mentions after-tax performance or claims that a fund is tax-efficient also must include fund's actual after-tax returns (M)

headline: Shackles Off, Russia's Muslims Are Still Chafing
abstract: Article in series The Force of Islam describes faith's revival in post-Soviet Russia, where 13- to 20-million Russian Muslims are secular after decades of religious repression but young people are becoming more observant; Russian Islamic University in Kazan, founded in 1998, has support of former Communist who rules Tatarstan; region that once had about 18 mosques now has more than 1,000, including grand building rising inside walls of government fortress; photos; map; Pres Vladimir Putin is encouraged by conservative Muslim leaders and Pres Mintimer Shaimiyev to pay more attention to Islamic education so that young radicals trained in Arab countries do not gain dominance (M)

headline: Manhattan Prosecutor Criticizes Caymans Tax Pact
abstract: Dist Atty Robert M Morgenthau is critical of agreement Treasury Secretary Paul H O'Neill signed with Cayman Islands in attempt to curb tax cheating; tax experts also are critical, noting that tax evaders have 25 months to switch tax havens and obliterate records of their former misdeeds (M)

headline: Bin Laden Letter Calls Upon Pakistanis to Defend Islam
abstract: Western and Arab news organizations receive copies of letter handwritten in Arabic, carrying Osama bin Laden's signature, urging Pakistan's Muslims to defend Islam against what it calls Christian crusade; letter is given relatively little coverage by Arab and Western news programs (M)

headline: In Cable, The Race Approaches A Far Turn
abstract: Interview with Tom Wolzien, analyst at Sanford C Bernstein & Co, on outlook for cable industry, particularly prospect of further consolidation; photo (M)

headline: 3 Ex-Guards at Bosnia Camp Are Sentenced by Hague Panel
abstract: United Nations tribunal in Hague sentences three former guards to prison for brutalities committed at Bosnian Serb-run prison camp, Keraterm; sentences Dusko Sikirica, former camp commander, to 15 years, Damir Dosen, shift commander, to five years, and Dragan Kulundzija, shift commander, to three; three pleaded guilty to some charges in deal with prosecutors (M)

headline: Tribal Area of Pakistan Gives Refuge to Qaeda Fighters Fleeing Caves
abstract: Hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters, chased from Tora Bora caves, have crossed mountains into Pakistan's untamed tribal areas; Pashtuns of remote Tirah Valley offer sanctuary to anyone who seeks it; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Last Missile Silo Destroyed
abstract: Ukrainian and American officials gather 180 miles south of Kiev to witness destruction of nation's last intercontinental ballistic missile silo, symbolic act that leaves Ukraine officially a nonnuclear state; photo (S)

headline: Milosevic Calls Tribunal Unfair, Infantile and 'a Farce'
abstract: Former Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic tells international tribunal planning to try him for range of war crimes that he will fight until tribunal is overthrown; calls trial 'farce;' Carla Del Ponte, chief prosecutor, indicates she plans lengthy and complex case; photo (M)

headline: Dinner Guest of bin Laden Identified as Saudi Fighter
abstract: Saudi seen on videotape visiting and flattering Osama bin Laden is identified by Saudi official as Khaled al-Harbi, legless former fighter in Afghanistan, Bosnia and Chechnya, and not, as first thought, religious scholar named Ali Sayed al-Ghamdy; official says Harbi has never been arrested by Saudis or included on security watch list (M)

headline: Americans Rescue Soldier Who Fell Ill
abstract: American officials report that US personnel conducted risky mission in rugged, rain-swept terrain of northern Afghanistan to rescue Army Special Operations soldier who fell ill while assisting front-line rebel troops opposed to Taliban; say soldier is receiving medical care at undisclosed location out of Afghanistan while rest of his Special Operations team continues its secret mission near enemy lines; say rescue mission did not involve US military personnel, suggesting that it was led by Central Intelligence Agency; modest number of American Special Forces have been operating in territory held by Northern Alliance for several days, helping to resupply insurgents and to improve accuracy of American bombing raids against Taliban front-line forces (M)

headline: Relief Extends to Student Loans
abstract: Sallie Mae, nation's largest lender to students, forgives education loans held by spouses of people killed or disabled by World Trade Center attacks (S)

headline: Cancún Dreaming: Will a Sleepy Town Be Next?
abstract: Mexican government invites various investors and developers to nearly 45,000 acres it owns along Gulf of California near of Loreto, which it hopes to turn into golf-centered resort area; has committed nearly $500 million to develop property so far and is anticipating another $500 million in private investments over next five years; photo; photo (M)

headline: Avoiding the Risks Of Seeming Exploitive
abstract: Book publishers face delicate problem of not seeming exploitive of national crisis as they publicize books pegged to terrorist attacks; book industry is also being hurt by reluctance of television and radio producers to book appearances by authors to spur sales of books not related to crisis; photo (M)

headline: Ethan Allen Import Plan
abstract: Ethan Allen Interiors Inc announces that several Philippine companies will manufacture some furniture it designs and retails (S)

headline: Terror War Offers Russia New Hope For Membership
abstract: Russia's prospects for membership in World Trade Orgn are seen improved, with United States taking softer line on issue; Russia sees membership as crucial to its effort to remake its checkered reputation as tough place to do business; concerns over Russia's ability to transform its markets and come up with changes in its legal system that would help protect contract and property rights have shadowed seveal years of accession talks (M)

headline: Berlusconi, Courting Left, Gains Support for Strikes
abstract: Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi secures bipartisan support for Italian participation in American-led military strikes in Afghanistan, mollifying left and Islamic leaders still ruffled by his recent criticism of their religion with talk of heavy Western investment for Palestinians; Western diplomats are skeptical, wondering how such investment might precede peace plan in Israel; Berlusconi will meet with Pres Bush in Washington on Oct 15 (M)

headline: Requiem for a Cheerleader: Silicon Alley Magazine Is Dead
abstract: Publisher Jason McCabe Calacanis folds Silicon Alley Reporter, magazine known for its unabashed boosterism of New York's new media entrepreneurs, in response to collapse of Internet boom; plans new magazine, Venture Reporter, about venture capital investing; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina, Brazil: Talks On Region's Economy
abstract: Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil and Fernando de la Rua of Argentina meet along with their finance ministers, Brasilia, in bid to resolve growing differences over economic policy (S)

headline: AOL Time Warner's Hits
abstract: AOL Time Warner movie divisions -- Warner Brothers, New Line Cinema and Fine Line Pictures -- gross $1.36 billion through Dec 2; photo; charts (S)

headline: Facing the Problems Of Coffee Growers
abstract: Melissa J Pugash leter on falling prices of raw coffee beans and havoc it is causing coffee-producing countries (Oct 28 article)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWAREA HEWLETT DIRECTOR IS CRITICIZED In a letter to shareholders, the top executives of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer criticized a Hewlett board member, Walter Hewlett, whose opposition to the two computer makers' planned merger has cast the deal in doubt, and challenged him to offer a better plan.

headline: Pro Bono Accounts
abstract: Twin Towers Fund, New York, pro bono account will be handled by interactive unit of Merkley Newman Harty & Partners, New York (S)

headline: U.S. MAKES INROADS IN ISOLATING FUNDS OF TERROR GROUPS
abstract: US is forging closer ties with United Arab Emirates, whose free-wheeling financial system may have been used by Osama bin Laden and terror network; is making progress in efforts to enlist Emirates, one of three nations with diplomatic ties to Afghanistan's Taliban-led government, in detecting and deterring movement of money by militant networks; Emirates and US officials are discussing how to keep track of hawalas, or informal banking networks that terrorists have used to move money; say outcome may be new partnership against terror in critical Middle Eastern financial hub; photo (M)

headline: Officials Gather in Nairobi Slum To Quell Deadly Rent Clashes
abstract: Pres Daniel arap Moi and other Kenyan politicians converge on Kibera slum on outskirts of Nairobi to try to quell violent clashes between poor tenants, mostly of Luo and Luya tribes, and their landlords, largely Nubians who trace their ancestry back to Sudan; many Kenyan blame these same elected officials for clashes (M)

headline: ARGENTINE LEADER, HIS NATION FRAYED, ABRUPTLY RESIGNS
abstract: Pres Fernando de la Rua of Argentina resigns, swamped by violent protests and looting that has erupted after his government fails to reverse deepening economic crisis; resignation comes following violent food riots and protests in Buenos Aires and several other cities; at least five demonstrators are killed, bringing death toll to 21 since protests began on Dec 19; country has widening budget deficits and is heavily indebted to foreign lenders; it is battling to prevent more defaults; it lacks coherent economic and monetary strategy and has no consensus as to what should be done; de la Rua's resignation puts country's immediate future in hands of moderate opposition party that controls Congress and has blocked many of his policies; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Offer For Psinet's Japanese Unit
abstract: Cable and Wireless submits bid to acquire Japanese operations of PSINet, bankrupt Internet services company, for $10.2 million in cash and will assume $25 million in liabilities (S)

headline: OMNICARE BUYING AMERICAN PHARMACEUTICAL ASSETS
abstract: ominicare buying america

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Arnold Worldwide lays off another 20 employees, or 3 percent of its staff; General Motors Corp signs agreement with William Morris Agency under which agency will seek entertainment marketing deals for GM in realms including movies, television, music, sponsorship and sports; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Making sure that search engines give a site a nice perch on their page. Some companies have ideas.
abstract: Merchants and marketers increasingly pay money to search engines to insure that links to their Web sites appear at top of pages of customers' search listings; photo (M)

headline: New Economy; A writer chronicling the Internet revolution recalls living the experience he covered.
abstract: Eric J Savitz article on reporting on bankruptcy of his former employer, Standard Media International, parent of defunct magazine Industry Standard; notes Internet newsmagazine shared spectacular rise and precipitious fall of dot-coms it chronicled (M)

headline: New York City May Issue More Notes, Mayor Says
abstract: Mayor Giuliani says New York City will issue more notes to help finance recovery from attacks on World Trade Center (S)

headline: Shock Reverberates in Developing World : Vast Global Toll Forecast From the Sept. 11 Attacks
abstract: ROME—  As many as 40,000 children under the age of 5 will die and some 10 million more people will be condemned to poverty because of the terrorist attacks in the United States on Sept. 11, the president of the World Bank said Sunday.

headline: Private Sector; The Healing Power of Art, From an Aerospace Veteran
abstract: Watercolors by Daniel M Tellep, retired aeronautical engineer, are on display in Forbes Magazine Galleries, in show sponsored by Business Committee for the Arts to benefit victims of Sept 11 attacks; photo (S)

headline: ALLIANT AGREES TO BUY AMMUNITION UNIT FROM BLOUNT
abstract: Alliant Techsystems acquires Blount International's ammunition unit for $250 million in stock; Blount is 85 percent owned by Lehman Brothers; says second-quarter income rose to $18.9 million from $16.1 million year ago (S)

headline: Business Travel; How much is that in euros? Navigating the new Europe without francs, marks or lire.
abstract: Business Travel column notes some Web sites to help international business travelers get information about conversion of 12 European countries' currencies to new Euro (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Imation Cleared To Sell Tape Drives
abstract: California court rules that Imation Corp may continue selling tape-drive cartridges based on Quantum Corp's technology, but orders Imation to pay Quantum 30 percent royalty on each cartridge (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry Sales Fall
abstract: Great Universal Stores says sales at its Burberry retail stores declined 15 percent in three weeks after terrorist attacks in US; before attacks, sales had been growing, and for six months to Sept 30 showed increase of 31 percent; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Nortel To Supply Chinese Company
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp will supply about $78 million of equipment and software to China Mobile Communications Corp; graph (S)

headline: Roger J. Boisvert, 50, Canadian Who Ran Web Service in Japan
abstract: Roger J. Boisvert, one of Japan's leading Internet pioneers, died on Sept. 30 during a robbery in Los Angeles. He was 50 and lived here.    Mr. Boisvert was shot after he and a friend became lost in the Hawthorne section of Los Angeles early in the morning. They stopped their car alongside a highway and called Mr. Boisvert's hotel. They were studying a global positioning system map in the car when a robber approached and demanded money. Mr. Boisvert, the passenger, handed over his money and the driver handed over his cellphone, which was connected to the hotel at the time.

headline: Vanquished Yield Arms To Victors
abstract: Northern Alliance units begin to disarm Taliban soldiers who surrendered in Kunduz, Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: Seeking a Kabul Coalition, Killings in Kunduz and Bodies in the Rubble
abstract: Overview of day's events in war on terrorism, including fighting fires that continue at World Trade Center, counting bodies at Mazar-i-Sharif following Taliban's surrender of city, and seeking to form broad-based government in Kabul

headline: Firestone Said to Reach Tire Settlement
abstract: Bridgestone/Firestone Corp is expected to pay $41.5 mil

headline: Sent Home To Sit and Wait By the Phone
abstract: About 4,000 Enron Corp employees are summarily dismissed and escorted by police from company's two Houston office buildings; confusion reigns over their employment status; mounted police disperse throngs of exiting workers (M) y

headline: Philanthropist, or Fount Of Funds for Terrorists?
abstract: Yasin al-Qadi, who is among prominent Saudis who those in need of charity or shrewd business advice could turn to, is now considered by US government to have tansferred millions of dollars to Osama bin Laden through charities and trusts like Muwafaq Foundation supposedly established to feed hungry, house the poor and alleviate suffering; Bush administration has put Saudi Arabia, one of its most important Middle East allies, in delicate bind by describing Muwafaq as front for bin Laden's terrorist network; Muwafaq Foundation has been administered by some of kingdom's leading families (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economic Output Increases
abstract: Statistics Canada reports Canada's real gross domestic product grew at 0.3 percent annual rate, Oct, compared with 0.8 percent Sept drop; warns underlying economic weakness persisted in Oct; graph (S)

headline: The G.E. Racehorses, One Year Afterward
