abstract: DIARY The G.E. Racehorses, One Year Afterward.

headline: CLEVELAND-CLIFFS TO CLOSE IRON PLANT INDEFINITELY
abstract: Cleveland-Cliffs will indefinitely idle Cliffs & Associates iron plant in Trinidad and Tobago because of low prices for its products; 85 workers will lose jobs (S)

headline: Bin Laden Sought Iran as an Ally, U.S. Intelligence Documents Say
abstract: Secret United States intelligence reports say representatives of Osama bin Laden contacted Iranian intelligence agents in mid-1990's in attempt to forge anti-American alliance of terror between Iran and bin Laden's Al Qaeda network; say Iranian intelligence agents expressed willingness to meet personally with bin Laden in Afghanistan, but it is unclear if meeting ever occurred, and if so, whether any agreement was reached; intelligence reports, which remain classified, provide some of most concrete evidence ever disclosed of bin Laden's attempts to forge alliance with major Middle Eastern country just as he was starting his terror campaign against US: since Sept 11, debate in US has been over whether bin Laden sought contact with Iraq; report shows he and his allies were instead eager to turn to Iran, which has longer history of support for terrorist acts against US and Israel; but Iran, dominated by Shiite Muslims, tends to support Shiite-based extremist groups rather than Sunni Muslim extremists like Al Qaeda; US official discounts any alliance, saying Al Qaeda and Iran would have made strange bedfellows (L)

headline: U.S. Charts A High-Tech Strategy for Afghan War
abstract: PARIS—  U.S. forces in Afghanistan will rely heavily on new high-tech weapons to produce a fast-moving, hard-hitting force designed to break the ruling Taliban militia and eventually root out the bin Laden terrorist network, experts said Tuesday.

headline: KRAFT FOODS IS OFFERING EARLY RETIREMENT
abstract: Kraft Foods, which is integrating Nabisco Holdings into its business, is offering some workers in US early retirement in program that is expected to eliminate 1,000 jobs (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Social Democrats Seek Coalition
abstract: Berlin Social Democrats begin talks to form coalition with former Communist Party of Democratic Socialism, after negotiations with Greens and Free Democrats fail (S)

headline: Conseco Posts Loss And Lowers Outlook For 4th Quarter
abstract: Conseco posts fiscal second-quarter net loss of $410.6 million, compared with loss of $489.5 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: President Urges U.S. To End Attack
abstract: Indonesian Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri, in her first state of the nation address since assuming power just over 100 days ago, calls on US to bring attack on Afghanistan to quick end, backing away from initial support under pressure from Islamic militants; photo (S)

headline: MARINES AND ARMY MAY SCOUR CAVES, U.S. GENERAL SAYS
abstract: Gen Tommy R Franks, commander of American forces in Afghanistan, proposes that US marines or Army troops be deployed to comb wild terrain of Tora Bora to determine fate of Osama bin Laden and other Al Qaeda leaders; his proposal stems from recognition that Afghan allies may not have ability or will to establish control over Tora Bora; American military officials say final decision might come in several days, and first troops could arrive soon after; dispatching troops could entail political complications; unlike in northern Afghanistan, this conservative Pashtun region of country is suspicous of Americans, and senior Northern Alliance commanders routinely refuse to acknowledge help they receive from American Special Forces; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld makes no reference to Franks's proposal, but indicates he has assurance from Hamid Karzai, Afghan leader, that American military could continue to operate in Afghanistan until 'pockets of resistance' are eliminated; photos; map (M)

headline: Macao Journal; In a Gamblers' Haven, Betting on a Theme Park
abstract: Macao is hoping to clean up its image as down-in-the-heels gambling haven and bring in more tourism; among efforts are theme park being built by tycoon David Chow and government plan to open $2 billion gambling industry to competition; Macao will issue three new casino licenses, and prospect of serving China's vast gambling-crazed market is attracting scores of bids; Stanley Ho, Hong Kong billionaire who has had casino monopoly since 1962 is expected to win one license and at least one is expected to be awarded to a Las Vegas company; map; photos (Macao Journal) (M)

headline: Evidence on bin Laden, Pressure From Bush and the Grim Task
abstract: United States and its allies move close to military action in Afghanistan on several fronts (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas futures soar on forecast for colder-than-normal weather in Northeast; natural gas for November delivery rises 19.5 cents, or 7.8 percent, to $2.681 per million British thermal units; graph; chart (S)

headline: Drug Issue Casts a Shadow on Trade Talks
abstract: Dispute over setting aside patents that limit cheap drug supplies is threatening to derail new round of World Trade Organization trade talks set to begin next week in Doha, Qatar; group of 38 African nations is seeking more leeway under trade group's intellectual property agreement, which US and Switzerland say already ensures adequate supplies of drugs when there is health crisis (M)

headline: Comfort Shopping, Premium Pricing
abstract: Susie Hilfiger, founder and owner of Best & Co, Greenwich, Conn, retailer of costly clothing and furnishings for children, believes worries over economy, terrorism and anthrax will not hurt her business and may even help it; spending has come to be regarded as patriotic since Sept 11, and while splurging on oneself may seem indulgent, purchases for children reinforce sense of family; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Widens Net to Snare Terror Assets; Expands List
abstract: Bush administration imposes stringent financial sanctions on Hamas, Hezbollah and 20 other suspected terrorist organizations; move is sign that admistration feels confident enough in Arab countries' support for action against Osama bin Laden to include anti-Israeli groups that have considerable support in Arab world; US has long frozen Hamas and Hezbollah assets in US, but members of Congress have urged stronger action; new list includes other Arab groups, three Colombian groups, Real Irish Republican Army and Basque group ETA; latter are included to show US is not just focusing on Israel and Palestinians; photos of Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah and Hamas founder Ahmed Yassin (M)

headline: A New Generation Gap?
abstract: Judy Massey letter replies to Nov 4 Seniority column, defending 'baby boom' generation's response to Sept 11 terrorist attacks

headline: Spending Rate Is Pointing To a Rebound
abstract: University of

headline: Primedia Reports A Wider Loss
abstract: Primedia reports third-quarter loss of $277.9 million, compared with loss of $43 million year ago; sales rose 4.2 percent, to $418.6 million (S)

headline: Customizing Every Call
abstract: Panasonic plans to offer two new very lightweight wireless phones; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Power To The Provinces
abstract: Italian voters approve referendum endorsing constitutional changes to increase regional autonomy at expense of central government's power (S)

headline: European Union Set to Vote on Data Law
abstract: European Union lawmakers are expected to ignore request by Bush administration to revise data-protection law they are drafting to allow authorities greater access to information about telephone calls and Internet messages; Pres Bush in October sent list of 47 measures he wanted Europe to take to assist in war on terrorism (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Oil Company Breakup
abstract: Japan said that it would dismantle the Japan National Oil Corporation, a state-run oil producer with $19 billion in debt, in the next three years and issue shares in a new company to be wholly owned by the government. The government will set up a clearing company to liquidate or sell shareholdings Japan National Oil has in exploration companies. Proceeds will be used to pay off debt, said Taro Aso, policy chief at the ruling Liberal Democratic Party.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: VeriSign Profit Accelerates
abstract: VeriSign, which provides Internet security and domain-name registration services, says revenue for third quarter was $255.2 million, up from $173.1 million year earlier; pro forma quarterly profit rose to $59.7 million from $36 million (S)

headline: Reconsidering an F.D.I.C. Limit
abstract: Federal Deposit Insurance Corp chairman, Donald Powell, recommends that $100,000 limit on federal insurance for deposits in banks and savings and loans be raised for Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh accounts (S)

headline: People
abstract: Media Edge names Rino Scanzoni president for broadcast for North America; he succeeds Robert Igiel, who retired (S)

headline: Mourners Speak of Piety, Not Revenge
abstract: the funerals: mourners speak of p7

headline: Accounts
abstract: Castrol Worldwide, part of BP PLC, consolidates its advertising account to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of WPP Group (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Novell To Lay Off 1,400
abstract: Novell, a maker of networking software, said it would eliminate 19 percent of its work force, or 1,400 jobs, and take a charge of $55 million in an effort to become profitable again despite the slowing information-technology market. Novell, based in Provo, Utah, said preliminary financial results from the fiscal fourth quarter, ended Oct. 31, showed that it beat analysts' estimates and its own forecasts by a penny a share. Excluding the restructuring charge, largely related its acquisition of the consulting firm Cambridge Technology Partners, Novell said it would report earnings of 1 cent a share, compared with break-even during the year-earlier period. Quarterly revenue is expected to be $306 million.   Chris Gaither (NYT)

headline: A Phone That Fits the Bill
abstract: Michael Mase letter on Sept 27 article cites cellphone he keeps for emergencies

headline: French Steel Maker Moves Closer to Takeovers
abstract: Usinor of France breaths new life into its faltering $2.76 billion bid to acquire two European rivals and become world's largest steel maker by sweeting takeover terms and winning approval for merger from European regulators in Brussels; new terms would give shareholders in two acquired companies, Aceralia of Spain and Arbed of Luxembourg, greater share of combined company (M)

headline: Deadline Set on Cellphone Emergency Calls
abstract: Federal Communications Commission gives Verizon Wireless Inc and four other mobile phone companies more time to start installing gear that pinpoints location of customers dialing 911 and expresses disappointment at delays that cause decision; criticizes AT&T Wireless Services Inc and Cingular Wireless, accusing them of neglecting requirements and saying companies may be fined; carriers were to start selling upgraded equipment by Oct 1; commission orders companies, which also include Sprint Corp's Sprint PCS unit and Nextel Communications Inc, to submit quarterly progress reports on adapting networks and equipment, beginning Feb 1 (M)

headline: Times Internet Snag
abstract: Access to Internet from New York Times is disrupted, preventing updating of New York Times on Web for four hours (S)

headline: To the Stranger, a Wild Land, Strangely Awesome
abstract: Reporter's Notebook describes night sky in Afghanistan, where natural world looms large; stars and moon are very bright without competition from electric lights; cratered landscape is harsh; there is no bridge across Kokcha River so people cross on horseback; elements dictate life in land where rains--and hunger--can force people to move; describes working in mud-brick hut that operates with gas-powered generator and no plumbing; photo (M)

headline: Anger Erupts At Mosque, Site of Raid And Arrests
abstract: Anger Erupts At Mosque, Site of Raid And Arrests**Members of Islamic Cultural Center and mosque in Milan, Italy, protest raid and arrests at center, saying investigations there are trumped up and racist; since Sept 11, officials in Italy and US have been describing place as Europe's logistical center for Al Qaeda terrorist network; center has played recurring role in various terrorist investigations; police say they obtained wiretap evidence of contacts between leader in Milan and adviser to those responsible for 1993 bombing of World Trade Center; key witness in trial of four Al Qaeda members in 1998 bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania testified that he had visited center, too; terrorist suspect who worked at center was arrested two weeks ago at Milan train station; investigators raided center on Nov 29, taking second man employed there into custody; police say both of arrested men are Al Qaeda recruiters (M)

headline: Feeling Vulnerable At Heart of Wall St.
abstract: Attacks exposed New York Stock Exchange's vulnerability to terrorism; exchange's chairman Richard A Grasso must figure out how to make exchange less vulnerable, even as it faces growing competition from Nasdaq and other new trading systems; exchange says it may postpone building long-planned new trading floor and 900-foot tower across street from its current headquarters; is considering building secondary trading site outside Lower Manhattan, plan that could cost tens or even hundreds of millions of dollars; Grasso insists that exchange will remain vital part of New York; graphs; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Suit Over Diana Crash Dismissed
abstract: france: suit over diana crash dismis

headline: Bin Laden's Statement
abstract: Following is the translated text of Osama Bin Laden's latest statement, as posted on the British Broadcasting Corporation's web site.

headline: East Africans Rekindle Regional Grouping
abstract: Daniel Arap Moi, Yoweri K Museveni and Benjamin W Mkapa, presidents of Kenya, Uganda, and Tanzania, re-establish East African Community, nearly quarter-century after economic and political union was disbanded because of regional strife; inaugurate joint legislative assembly to handle regional policy matters and court to settle cross-border disputes; initially intend to reduce trade barriers and slash bureaucracies currently interfering with regional growth (M)

headline: Coors Acquires A Big Brand In Britain
abstract: Adolph Coors Co to buy Bass Brewers's Carlinÿ

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: US Airways Chief Resigns; Chairman to Succeed Him  The chief executive of US Airways, Rakesh Gangwal, resigned, departing at one of the most critical times in the airline's history. He will be succeeded by Stephen M. Wolf, who has served as chairman for three years.    The airline said that Mr. Gangwal's decision was a personal one based on his interest in working in the field of private equity and venture capital investing. [Page C2.]

headline: I Think I Hear Voices
abstract: Joel Savishinsky letter comments on Nov 22 article on bad cellphone manners

headline: Arafat Halts Crackdown; Israel Breaks Links to Him
abstract: Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority suspends its stated plan to crack down on extremist groups attacking Israeli civilians, holding Israeli military assault blocks such police work; Israel attacks Palestinian targets in West Bank and Gaza Strip in retaliation for West Bank ambush that killed 10 Israelis; breaks security and diplomatic links with Palestian Authority, calling Arafat 'irrelevant;' Israeli tanks take up positions near compound, Ramallah, where Arafat is effectively trapped; United States envoy Anthony C Zinni weighs abandoning peace mission; meets with Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon; photo (M)

headline: Departures Continue on Madison Avenue
abstract: TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, is laying off employees at its United States offices, in New York; Playa del Rey, Calif.; and San Francisco. The layoffs are to total fewer than 20 people, around 2.5 percent of its United States staff of 800.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: 23 Men Sentenced On Gay Sex Charges
abstract: Egypt's Emergency State Security Court sentences 23 men accused of homosexuality to prison sentences ranging from one to five years; acquits 29 others (S)

headline: Uzbeks Near Border Praise Attacks on Taliban
abstract: Uzbeks near Afghan border welcome arrival of US forces for military campaign in neighboring Afghanistan; anti-Taliban disposition is unifying force across Uzbekistan, compared with elsewhere in Muslim world where aerial bombardment has inspired rallies, riots and cries for jihad; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Safety Fears Shut Fertilizer Plant
abstract: French authorities close fertilizer plant near Bordeaux following explosion at similar factory in Toulouse on September 21 that killed 29 people and injured several thousand (S)

headline: In Pakistan, Blair Repeats Allies' Goals
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair makes five-hour visit to Pakistan, nation of 140 million Muslims, bearing a promise central to preparations for allied military thrust into Afghanistan--that that target will be Osama bin Laden and, perhaps, Taliban government, but not ordinary Afghans or their Islamic faith; Blair, standing beside Pres Pervez Musharraf, cites 'overwhelming and compelling evidence' that bin Laden and his Al Qaeda orgn were involved in attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon; photo (L)

headline: Powell Says Muslim Nations Should Be Peacekeepers in Kabul; 3 Offer Troops
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell says he expects advancing Northern Alliance forces to mass north of Kabul within 24 hours, and it might be necessary to send international 'coalition of the willing,' led by soldiers from Muslim nations, to secure capital and prepare ground for interim government; says Turkey, Bangladesh and Indonesia have offered forces for such an operation to buttress 'bridging political structure' under United Nations control; excludes deployment of Americans in this force; expresses frustration at Taliban's continued hold on southern Afghanistan, and failure thus far to mobilize rebellion or orchestrate defections of prominent local leaders in region, where majority Pashtuns mostly refuse to break with Taliban; says Pakistan could do more to undermine Taliban control; photo (M)

headline: Disney TV Units to Show 'Harry Potter' and Sequel
abstract: Warner Brothers sells basic cable and broadcast television rights to film Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone and next film in Harry Potter series to Walt Disney Co in deal worth at least $130 million (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Opposition Holds Reins, Briefly
abstract: Ramon Puerta, new Argentine Senate president, declares that he would not abuse his powers as acting pres when Pres Fernando de la Rua is out of country by signing presidential decrees and subverting government's policies; Puerto photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Nomura Investor To Open Fund
abstract: Guy Hands, private-equity specialist, reportedly negotiates his departure from Nomura Holdings to set up separate fund called Terra Firma Capital Partners; will take 70 members of his team with him; Nomura will invest in new fund, for which Hands wants to raise $2.7 billion; photo (M)

headline: And the Winners in the Case Are . . .
abstract: Collapse of Enron Corp may present largest windfall ever for American bankruptcy lawyers; more than 100 lawyers attend first hearing, at federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan; legal proceedings may last for years, as court seeks to sort out what went wrong at Enron, who is to blame and what assets remain to satisfy company's obligations; Judge Arthur J Gonzalez will preside; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Start-Up Buys Magazine
abstract: Tom.com, Internet start-up owned by Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing, pays $47.5 million for Business Weekly Media Group, publisher of Taiwan's largest business magazine; photo (S)

headline: VORNADO REALTY ADDS ALL OF CHARLES SMITH COMMERCIAL
abstract: Vornado Realty Adds All Of Charles Smith Commer

headline: Net Climbs 18% at MBIA, a Bond Insurer
abstract: MBIA Inc, bond insurer, reports 18 percent increase in 2001 third-quarter net, to $154.5 million, compared with $130.7 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Disparities of Wealth Are Seen as Fuel for Terrorism
abstract: PARIS—  You can write off the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 as the crazed act of a fanatical gang hell-bent on causing mayhem at any cost. Or you can try to understand the attacks' root causes by taking a closer look at the world whose fragile pattern of power they upset.

headline: Signs of Change In Terror Goals Went Unheeded
abstract: Intelligence officials now say that cryptic message intercepted by Central Intelligence Agency last year from Al Qaeda member boasting that Osama bin Laden was planning 'Hiroshima' against America was telling sign of drastic shift in last three years in Al Qaeda's ambitions and global reach; say United States failed to grasp group's transformation from obscure group of Islamic extremists into world's most dangerous terrorists; key factor in shift was bin Laden's decision to act as franchiser of terrorism, providing financial and logistical aid to locally sponsored plots brought to his group by Islamic extremists; extent of group's US operations has stunned Federal Bureau of Investigation; chart; photos (M)

headline: Online Piracy Fight: Next Up, Consumers
abstract: Brisk trade of copyrighted music and movies continues unabated; industry in 2002 is likely to focus on group that has so far remained on sidelines in battle against Internet piracy; pirates themselves; graph (M)

headline: Reynolds Agrees to Buy Santa Fe Natural
abstract: R J Reynolds Tobacco Holdings agrees to buy Santa Fe Natural Tobacco for $320 million in cash, surpassing bid from Rothmans of Canada (S)

headline: Special Forces Hunt Al Qaeda On the Ground
abstract: American officials say more than 100 American commandos are in southern Afghanistan, carrying out covert operations against Taliban and Al Qaeda leaders; say aim of operations is to find bin Laden and Taliban leaders, and to show Taliban that American military can operate on adversary's turf; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says bin Laden has proved elusive, and that he might have access to helicopter to escape from Afghanistan; says American military will keep up pressure during Ramadan by continuing airstrikes; counsels patience for strategy that depends on proxy forces, air power and commandos but not substantial numbers of American ground troops; emphasis of American-led military campaign is changing from bombing of Taliban troops to hunt for enemy leaders (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Orders Extend Slump
abstract: Semiconductor Equipment Materials International reports slumping North American sales and orders for November; new orders total $612.3 million (S)

headline: The Risk Of Not Weighing Risk
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on study conducted by Alice Cornish, analyst at Prudential Securities, which forecasts that pretax profits of companies in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index will drop by average 2.5 percent in 2002 because of higher insurance prices; says brokerage firms advising investors to buy stocks now are ignoring such constraints on corporate earnings, which were already in decline and are sure to be stunted further by increased costs associated with security and risk since Sept 11; table (M)

headline: Botswana Weighs Bill to Place Tighter Control on Journalists
abstract: Botswana's government proposes legislation that would allow authorities to determine which journalists and newspapers can operate in country and permit police to seize any publications deemed offensive; proposed law stirs furor in Botswana and abroad; letters of protest are sent to Pres Festus G Mogae, warning that government's recent efforts to stifle press taint country's image as one of Africa's most respected liberal democracies (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Downsizing the Military
abstract: Russia announces plan to trim its 1.2-million-member armed forces by 200,000 servicemen and officers by 2003 as part of effort to free up money to better train and equip remaining forces (S)

headline: Peruvian Leader's Image Problems Add to Political Woes
abstract: Peruvian Pres Alejandro Toledo has mounting image problems that are distracting from his efforts to revive economy hobbled by three years of political unrest; faces intense public scrutiny of his work habits and private life; photo (M)

headline: Finding a Criminal In a Crowd of Faces
abstract: FaceFinder technology developed by Viisage Technology of Little Rock, Ark, is being considered for airport security; system compares faces with those in database; system compares faces with those in its database, recognizing criminals or suspects; company chairman Tom Colatosti comments; photo (S)

headline: PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS NAMES GLOBAL EXECUTIVE
abstract: Priceü

headline: A Holy Quest in Tibet: Prostrate, and Miles to Go
abstract: Buddhist devotion is fading among Tibet's younger, urban residents, but it remains resilient source of joy for most Tibetans out on grasslands and mountains, persisting through temple-burning of Mao's Cultural Revolution, controls on staffing and activities of monasteries, Chinese Communists' condemnation of exiled Dalai Lama and growing incursions of modern culture; every year thousands of Tibetans undertake arduous pilgrimage to Lhasa and its holy sites; they prostrate themselves every three steps of way, in journey that can take months; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Havel Back In Hospital
abstract: Czech Pres Vaclav Havel falls ill again, this time with viral infection in his right lung (S)

headline: Oil Prices Jump 6% After Talk of Cutbacks
abstract: Crude oil jumps over 6 percent, nearing $20 a barrel, after Norway says it will cut output and Russian oil executives signal they will follow suit if ordered to by government; Norway says it will cut output by 100,000 to 200,000 barrels a day if other non-OPEC nations make similar cut; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Equipment Maker Reports A Loss
abstract: Applied Materials lost $82 million in its fourth quarter on sales of $1.26 billion; photo (S)

headline: Basque Suspects Held in Bombing in Madrid
abstract: Spanish police arrest two people associated with Basque guerrilla group ETA in rush-hour car-bombing in Madrid; photo; 100 people are wounded, though not apparent target, government official Juan Junquera (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar is little changed after Federal Reserve cuts interest rates; in New York, euro settles at 89.73 cents, up from 89.71 cents; dollar trades at 121.06 yen, down from 121.80 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Community: Confidence Down
abstract: European Commission says business confidence in euro zone dropped in September to its lowest level since January 1997; says consumer confidence remained flat at five-year low (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic: Senator Slain
abstract: world briefing; dominican republic: senator

headline: Russia and U.S. Optimistic on Defense Issues
abstract: Russia and United States signal they are near breakthrough on key strategic issues that have divided them since Pres Bush took office: American plan to build missile defense and Russia's troubled relations with expanding NATO alliance; Secretary of State Colin L Powell and Foreign Min Igor S Ivanov hold meeting in Shanghai that is said to have created 'favorable conditions' for upcoming meeting between Bush and Pres Vladimir V Putin at summit meeting of Asian and Pacific leaders; momentum in strategic arms negotiations follows Putin's announcement last month that he is opening Russian air space to American airlift of military and relief cargoes to Central Asian republics for deployment on Afghanistan's northern frontier; Washington and Moscow regard Sept 11 terrorist attacks on US as watershed event in international relations, offering opportunities for Putin and Bush to battle common enemy; Putin may now overcome objections of domestic critics who say he is compromising Russian security by making concessions in Washington; Bush can now promote greater role for Russia in Western security, citing Putin's strong support for American intervention in Central Asia; photo (M)

headline: Morgan Stanley Ends Small-Investor Push in Japan
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co says it will close its only retail brokerage outlet in Japan because there is little chance venture will turn profit; about 100 workers of unit, Morgan Stanley Nippon Securities, which opened in January, will be laid off, and storefront office in Nihonbashi section of Tokyo will be closed; Morgan Stanley's institutional brokerage and asset management businesses in Japan, which employ about 1,500 people, are not affected; photo (M)

headline: Afghan E-Mail Seen as Too Geek to Be True
abstract: Jon Katz, columnist for Slashdot.org online news site, gets lots of skeptical comment when he reports about receiving e-mail message from Afghan programmer who says he has taken his old computer out of hiding now that Taliban are out of power and is downloading movies he missed during year when computers were banned; skeptics ask how Commodore computer of 1980's could play movies (M)

headline: When the Sender Courts the Senses
abstract: Dr Itiro Siio develops coffee system as community-building tool for workplace; device consists of coffee machine with heat sensor, wireless transmitter and several scattered units that yield coffee aroma; system sends signal to aroma units on workers' desks to alert them when coffee is being made in lounge; is one of many being developed to please senses while presenting information; photo (M)

headline: POLYMER GROUP SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 600 JOBS
abstract: Polymer Group Inc, specialty fabric maker, to cut about 600 jobs, 14 percent of work force; puts fourth-quarter restructuring costs at under $150 million before taxes (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Chief of Compaq Is Quick on His Feet
abstract: Chiefs of merging Compaq and Hewlett-Packard, Michael D Capellas and Carleton S Fiorina, attend computer industry expositionin Orlando, Fla, and respond to questions about their impending merger; photo (S)

headline: ChevronTexaco Sets 500 More Job Cuts
abstract: ChevronTexaco says that it will increase number of job cuts it plans by 500, to 4,500, as part of plan to save $1.8 billion annually by March 2003 (S)

headline: 3.9% OF MERRILL LYNCH WORK FORCE ACCEPTS BUYOUTS
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that more than 2,600 employees, or 3.9 percent of its work force, took the buyouts offered as part of the efforts of Stanley O'Neal, its president, to trim expenses and improve profitability at the company. Merrill, with 65,900 employees as of Sept. 30, earned $6,403 per employee in the third quarter, making it the least profitable of the five biggest Wall Street firms. This year Merrill is the top-ranked arranger of United States bond sales, the top seller of convertible bonds, the No. 2 underwriter of global stock sales and the No. 2 mergers adviser, according to Bloomberg data. Merrill will not say how many employees it hopes to cut. Most employees had until Nov. 9 to decide whether to accept the buyout offer. Departures were subject to approval by managers.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jet Maker's Strategy
abstract: Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA will deliver 18 of its new Legacy corporte jets in 2002 as company diversifies its range of products (S)

headline: Bin Laden and His Followers Adhere To an Austere, Stringent Form of Islam
abstract: Article describes Wahhabism, austere and conservative strain of Islam that drives Osama bin Laden and his followers; Wahhabis oppose change or modernization that deviates from fundamental teachings of Koran; photo (M)

headline: With Many Leaders Absent From Talks on Post-Taliban Rule, a Kabul Meeting Is Suggested
abstract: Four Afghan factions begin talks, Bonn, on setting up representative, interim administration to govern nation still at war; diplomats, noting many factional leaders remain in Afghanistan and have sent deputies, say another conference, held in Kabul, may be needed; photo (M)

headline: Settlers Find Solace in an Isolated Gaza Community
abstract: Article describes life of settlers in Netzarim, one of 22 Israeli settlements in Gaza Strip that are home to estimated 7,500 Israelis and are major cause of tensions between Israelis and Palestinians; isolated settlement has more than three soldiers for every four residents; maps; photo (M)

headline: Polo Ralph Lauren Profit
abstract: Polo Ralph Lauren says net income was $47.8 million in fiscal second quarter ended Sept 29 compared to loss of $62.8 million year earlier; revenue rose 1.6 percent, to $595.7 million from $586.2 million (S)

headline: Hewlett Heir in New Action Against Merger
abstract: Walter B Hewlett, oldest son of Hewlett-Packard co-founder, makes preliminary proxy filing calling proposed $24 billion acquisition of Compaq Computer over-priced and unnecessarily risky; urges shareholders to vote against it (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Electronics Venture
abstract: Toshiba Corp and Matsushita Electric Industrial Co, which makes Panasonic brand, will combine divisions that make liquid-crystal display screens for electronic devices; Toshiba will own 60 percent of venture, which will hold 12 percent of Japan's 1.38 trillion yen ($11.5 billion) market; Japanese liquid-crystal makers are looking to cut production costs in face of tough competition from manufacturers in South Korea and Taiwan (S)

headline: 5 Palestinian Schoolboys Killed by an Explosion in Gaza
abstract: Five Palestinian boys walking to school are killed when powerful explosive detonates beneath them in Gaza Strip, near Israeli settlement in Khan Yunis; boys, all related, range in age from 6 to 14; Palestinians say they wer killed by unexploded Israeli tank shell, remnant of recent fighting; Israeli authorities say Palestinian explosive might be to blame; deaths come as Bush administration prepares to dispatch two envoys to Israel, in its first intensive drive for peace in Middle East; photos (M)

headline: Mideast Crisis Point
abstract: Analysis of Israel's decision to break off contact with Yasir Arafat and conduct military operations in Palestinian cities after latest terrorist attack; even though Israel says it is fed up, government stops well short of actually declaring that Oslo peace agreement is dead; Israeli security cabinet statement calls Arafat 'irrelevant' to Israel, but goes on to say that Israel has no intention to assassinate Arafat or hurt him; that message is intended to allay fears, in Washington and other capitals, that Israel might take drastic measures that could further threaten stability in region; practical consequences of isolating Arafat are unclear, since Israelis have had little to no contact with him in last 14 months; immediate question is whether suspension of contact extends to all members of Palestinian Authority; riskier matter is cabinet's decision to deploy forces for military operations in cities in West Bank and Gaza Strip (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Supermarket Venture
abstract: Royal Ahold agrees to combine its supermarkets in Central America with Costa Rica's CSU into joint venture with 253 stores and $1.3 billion annual sales (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Plan Is Rejected For Sale of Fruit of the Loom
abstract: Bankruptcy Plan Is Rejected For Sale of Fruit of the Loom*È

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: New Stock Rallies
abstract: Shares in France's Credit Agricole rise 5.6 percent above their offer price in their market debut; only 18 percent of bank's shares are available for trading, and fund mangers demand 17 times amount available; bank sells $2.6 billion in shares at 16.6 euros (S)

headline: Minding Our New E-Manners
abstract: Collaborative software requires new social skills, new etiquette of its users; drawing (M)

headline: Downbeat Before, Downbeat After
abstract: The mood among Wall Street's mergers-and-acquisitions cognoscenti was downbeat even before the Sept. 11 attack. Volumes were off, and deals trickled in at about half the rate of last year. But they still had hope for a fourth-quarter recovery-until that fateful morning. Now, Wall Street's M&A mavens have returned to their pre-attack view, and acknowledge that M&A won't pick up again until well into 2002.

headline: China Offers Its Wary Support for Attacks
abstract: Chinese government offers cautious support for American and British attacks in Afghanistan; fears terrorism within its own borders, especially in western province where Islamic separatist movement is simmering (M)

headline: Recession, Then a Boom? Maybe Not This Time
abstract: Fundamental changes in economy are likely to restrain recovery from current recession; economists say that today's more stable economy means less severe downturns than heretofore and less robust booms; photos; charts (M)

headline: Not-So-Funny Jokes in Indonesia
abstract: Christopher Purdy, American living in Bangkok, Thailand, talks about living abroad following terrorist attacks on US on Sept 11 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Clinches $1 Billion Contract
abstract: Sprint Corp awards Nortel Networks $1.1 billion, four-year equipment contract to upgrade its telecommunications network; new network will permit multiple phone calls and Internet connections to share same phone line, allowing Sprint to offer new services (S)

headline: KINDER MORGAN ENERGY TO PURCHASE TEJAS GAS
abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP will buy Tejas Gas LLC for $750 million to expand its natural gas delivery system in Texas (S)

headline: A Manual for the Traumatized
abstract: McGraw-Hill is providing free only access to The Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Sourcebook: A Guide to Healing, Recovery and Growth, by Glenn R Schiraldi, to help people anxious, distressed and traumatized by Sept 11 terrorist attacks; author is Glenn R Schiraldi (S)

headline: 2nd Wave of Troops Arrives in Uzbekistan
abstract: More United States military personnel and equipment arrive at former Soviet air base in Uzbekistan, preparing for American-led military campaign; photo (M)

headline: With Enron's Fall, Many Dominoes Tremble
abstract: Enron Corp's failure is having repercussions not just on nation's energy industries, but is being felt through retailing, real estate, insurance, banking, Internet services, newspaper publishing, plastics and glass manufacturing, all of which Enron touched its its boundless appetite for risk and growth; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Gas Producer Acquisition
abstract: Burlington Resources plans to buy Canadian Hunter Exploration of Calgary, Alberta, for $2.1 billion; deal will increase Burlington's gas reserves 12 percent, to 11.5 trillion feet (S)

headline: Enron Auditor Raises Specter of Crime
abstract: Joseph P Berardino, chief executive of Arthur Andersen, longtime Enron Corp auditor, tells Congress that Enron engaged in 'possibly illegal acts' before its collapse and misled auditors by withholding critical information; acknowledges that Andersen auditors made mistakes with 'professional judgement about appropriate accounting treatment of Enron entities; Enron claims it always fully cooperated with Andersen personnel; Enron executives in New York present creditors with plan for company to survive by spinning off its prized energy-trading operations and emerging as more convention energy producer and wholesaler (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Primedia Tries to Recover From Its Internet Party
abstract: Primedia, magazine publisher, is trying to recover from failed Internet acquisitions; company is loaded with debt and struggling to bolster revenues as advertising declines; company is scrambling to sell, close or shrink businesses; breaking up Primedia will probably not generate much profit; Primedia's stock has plunged to $2.06 per share, from high of $34.87 on March 31, 2000; investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts owns 67 percent of Primedia; Henry Kravis comments; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Stocks Close Up After Push by Technology Issues
abstract: The stock market managed to close higher today after being mired in negative territory for most of the trading session.

headline: Enron Leaves Void In Commodity Trades
abstract: Collapse of Enron Corp has left void in commodity trading of broadband communications capacity; bandwith market collapsed before it was even able to attain liquidity necessary to thrive; disappearance of bandwith trading altogether is now being discussed (M)/

headline: Senators Express Skepticism About Microsoft Settlement
abstract: Democrats and Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee today voiced deep skepticism of the Bush administration's proposed settlement of the antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation.

headline: Tribal Commanders Make New Offer for Al Qaeda Surrender
abstract: Afghan tribal commanders set a new deadline today for the surrender of Osama bin Laden's embattled fighters trapped in the snowcapped mountains here after efforts to arrange a turnover of weapons this morning broke down.

headline: Taliban Fight On in Kandahar, Shakily
abstract: Fighting intensifies in and around Kandahar, Afghanistan, and several reports suggest that it may soon be wrested from Taliban control; if city falls, Taliban wll no longer hold major Afghan town and will be forced to flee; photo; map (M)

headline: German Bank Is Said to Prepare Bigger Bid for British Phone Lines
abstract: Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale reportedly plans to raise its bid for British Telecommunications's fixed-line business (M)

headline: Nissan and Renault Are Said to Fortify Tie
abstract: Nissan Motor and Renault reach cross-shareholding agreement that will deepen their existing alliance; Nissan will buy up to 15 percent of Renault; Renault will exercise options to increase its stake in Nissan to 44.4 percent from 36.8 percent by converting warrants into stock at price of 400 yen a warrant, or about 200 billion yen ($1.6 billion) total (M)

headline: World Bank Arm Lifts China Stake
abstract: World Bank Arm LifÔ

headline: Taliban Envoy Talks of a Deal Over bin Laden
abstract: Taliban Foreign Min Wakil Ahmed Muttawakil, in secret talks in Pakistan, appeals for American bombing pause in Afghanistan, while moderates in Taliban government seek to persuade supreme leader Mullah Muhammad Omar to agree to formula for handover of Osama bin Laden; talks come amid widespread rumors of Muttawakil's defection; his presence in Pakistan, apparently without Omar's approval, suggests intensive American bombing is causing policy shift in Taliban leadership; plea for bombing pause reportedly relayed to Sec Colin Powell, who is on one-day visit; Pakistani officials are optimistic Powell's visit will compress political process, accelerating steps to form post-Taliban government and clear way for American military commanders to pound Taliban front-line troops into disarray, defection or disintegration; photos (M)

headline: Government Role at Issue In Proposal to Help Industry
abstract: As nation's leading insurers have coalesced around aid package to protect them against losses from future terrorist attacks, ideological rift has developed within Bush administration and in Congress about government role in protecting industries in distress; conflicting advice being presented to Pres Bush remains big obstacle to passage of bill that several lawmakers are preparing to introduce shortly; while leading senators are leaning toward setting up government-backed insurer like one that exists in Britain, officials say that deep divisions within administration in recent days have delayed administration from issuing its own proposal; industry executives say it is essential that Congress adopt aid package because many policies expire at end of year, and reinsurers, who insure insurers, have already announced their intention to pull out of business of offering terrorist coverage (M)

headline: Market Place; Despite a downturn and the terror attacks, Cisco manages a quarter-to-quarter sales increase.
abstract: Market Place column on improved outlook for Cisco Systems, which posts first fiscal quarter loss of $268 million, compared with year-earlier earnings of $6.5 billion; cites sales gain from previous quarter; photo (M)

headline: Berlin Cameron Agency Won't Seek G.M. Work
abstract: Berlin Cameron Agency Won't Seek G.M. Work Berlin Cameron & Partners in New York has decided not to participate in a review now getting under way for the Saturn division of General Motors to select an agency to create campaigns for the new Ion coupe and sedan. Billings were estimated at $30 million to $100 million.

headline: Powell Tries to Allay Worry Of Senators on Muslim Rage
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell meets with Senate Foreign Relations Committee to assure committee that military action against Osama bin Laden will not inflame Muslim world; stability of Pakistan, which some fear may be unable to withstand internal pressures from Islamic militants, is overriding concern; photo (M)

headline: Arthur D. Little in Talks to Sell Majority Stake
abstract: Arthur D Little, consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass, has entered into exclusive negotiations to sell majority stake in firm to group of private investors, led by Whitney & Co and Safeguard International Fund; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: Wal-Mart Settles Job Bias Suits
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc settles 13 job discrimination lawsuits filed by Equal Employment Opportunity Commission; agrees to pay penalties of $6.8 million and to change its hiring practices (S)

headline: Israel Begins Withdrawal of Its Troops From Ramallah
abstract: Israel starts withdrawing forces from Ramallah, which has been quiet in recent days; troops and tanks remain in Jenin and Tulkarm, and ring Ramallah; photo; three Palestinian gunmen ambush Israeli patrol near Nablus, fatally shooting one officer before being killed; Israelis say they would be out of Jenin if Palestinian Authority would arrest 4 or 5 militants; two men sought in murder of Israeli die in car explosion; Israelis scoff at Yasir Arafat's claim that he has begun arresting extremists (M)

headline: Taliban Foe Tells of Calm, Quiet Assassins
abstract: Masood Khalili, wounded sole survivor of suicide attack that killed Ahmed Shah Massoud, commander of anti-Taliban Afghan forces, describes that attack; Khalili is ambassador to India for deposed government of Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: Foreigners Allied With Taliban Cling to a Surrounded Stronghold
abstract: Refugees fleeing the besieged Taliban stronghold of Kunduz said today that large groups of Arabs and Pakistanis fighting alongside the Taliban had taken control of the city, arresting hundreds of civilians and, in speeches, vowing a fight to the death.     The refugees, walking across the front lines here, said that these foreign soldiers had arrived in Kunduz by the thousands in recent days after the Taliban defeats in cities across northern Afghanistan. They said the men had taken over all of the important buildings and military installations in and around the city, including the airport and the front lines. The foreign fighters are apparently so distrustful of local Taliban soldiers that they are barring their entrance to many areas across the city, the refugees said.

headline: INVESTING WITH/John J. McCabe And Mark F. Trautman; M.S.B. Fund
abstract: Carole Gould column profiles investment profile of MSB Fund, a large blend fund, and its co-managers, John J McCabe and Mark F Trautman; chart (M)

headline: Hewletts Vow to Oppose Hewlett-Packard Merger With Compaq
abstract: Hewlett family says it will vote against proposed takeover of Compaq Computer Co by Hewlett-Packard Co; announcement by family, which controls 5 percent of Hewlett-Packard, could undo deal; Packard family, which owns about 10 percent of Hewlett-Packard, has hired financial advisers to help assess deal and is still considering its position; value of deal has dropped from $25 billion on day before it was announced to about $21 billion; Walter B Hewlett, son of company's co-founder, William Hewlett, and member of board, says deal creates too much uncertainty and that company would create more value for shareholders independently (M)

headline: Gain for Trade Bill That Some See as Aid in Terrorism Fight
abstract: House Republicans announce compromise agreement that will give Pres Bush power to negotiate trade accords with limited Congressional involvement, which administration contends will help recruit allies in fight against terrorism; prospects of passage remain uncertain because bill faces strong opposition from Democratic leaders; administration seeks to start worldwide round of trade negotiations at summit meeting in Qatar in November; some see threat to America coming from people who live in poverty, however Democrats, unions and environmental groups remain wary, and fear that fast track authority will run roughshod over controls and assurances they consider vital (M)

headline: Sorest Loss in Colombia Mine Collapse: The Children
abstract: sorest loss in colombia

headline: Fed Cut Rates, Fearing Attacks' Economic Impact
abstract: Minutes of Federal Reserve's Sept 17 conference show Fed policy makers lowered benchmark interest rate half percentage point for fear terrorist attacks might weaken US asset prices and economy (S)

headline: Israelis Invade Bethlehem for First Time in Year of Battle
abstract: Israeli troops and tanks invade Bethlehem, seizing several buildings and trading gunfire with Palestinian fighters; this is first push by Israel into city itself since current conflict began year ago; raid leaves three Palestinians dead; Israel says it is acting to suppress shooting that erupted after death, in car explosion, of Atef Obaiyat, Palestinian militia leader on Israel's most-wanted list; photo; map (M)

headline: Some Views on How to Steer the Economy Toward Recovery
abstract: Alan B Krueger, Jeff Madrick, Virginia Postrel and Hal Varian comment on ways Bush administration and Congress can respond to economic downturn now clearly under way; photos (M)

headline: NEWPORT NEWS RECEIVES REVISED OFFER FROM NORTHROP
abstract: Newport News Shipbuilding receives revised buyout offer from rival military contractor, Northrop Grumman, that would lock purchase price at $2.6 billion; under proposal, new stock-price range would be set to determine how much of payment of $67.50 a share would come in stock, with balance paid in cash (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Aid For Russia To Destroy Weapons
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair and Pres Vladimir Putin sign treaty under which Britain will help Russia get rid of 40,000-ton stockpile of chemical weapons (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Grenade Hits Kashmir Market
abstract: Grenade thrown at Indian security vehicle in crowded market injures 17 people in Srinagar, Kashmir (S)

headline: U.S. Judge Questions Plan For Deal in Microsoft Case
abstract: Judge J Frederick Motz questions whether Microsoft's $1 billion plan to give computers to schools to settle consumer antitrust claims would give it unfair advantage in one of the few markets where it faces competition from Apple Computer; many view proposed remedy as devious and grossly inadequate (M)

headline: Taliban Troops Abandon Capital Without a Fight
abstract: Capping their stunning victories in the north, Afghan opposition fighters rolled into Kabul today after Taliban troops abandoned the capital.

headline: AIRBORNE TROOPS RELIEVING MARINES AT KANDAHAR BASE
abstract: Pentagon orders soldiers from 101st Airborne Div to relieve Marine Corps in southern Afghanistan, paving way for longterm American military presence in country; Army's mission will be same as that of Marine Corps: guarding scores of Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners awaiting interrogation, securing airfield for use by cargo planes carrying military and relief supplies, and searching for remnants of Taliban army near Kandahar; Pentagon says Marine Corps will not necessarily leave region soon; it has not ruled out using marines or Special Operations forces to comb through caves in Tora Bora for signs of Osama bin Laden; photo; map (M)

headline: A 2nd Night of Protests by Palestinians Angry at Arafat
abstract: Using stones, guns and small explosives, hundreds of Palestinians vented their disgust this evening with Yasir Arafat's governing Palestinian Authority, clashing with Palestinian security forces who seemed as frightened as they were furious when the mob surged against them.     As leaders on both sides shouted for calm amid the gunfire, one screaming security officer tried to charge the demonstrators with his semiautomatic rifle but was dragged away by comrades. Demonstrators grabbed metal rods from a construction site and hurled rocks at the police, but most people on both sides were aiming their guns at thin air, and no injuries were reported.

headline: Parent of American Airlines Posts Record Quarterly Loss
abstract: AMR Corp, parent of American Airlines, posts largest quarterly loss in its history after already difficult quarter turned into financial disaster by Sept 11 terrorist attacks; AMR lost $414 million compared with profit of $313 million year earlier; sales fell 8.4 percent, to $4.8 billion from $5.3 billion; chief executive Donald J Carty says company lost $550 million to $650 million in revenue after Sept 11 (M)

headline: GLOBAL CROSSING PLANS TO SELL DESKTOP TRADING UNIT
abstract: Global Crossing, owner of worldwide phone and data-transmission network, says that it had agreed to sell its IPC Trading Systems unit to investment group, Goldman Sachs Capital Partners 2000, for $360 million (S)

headline: New Unemployment Claims Drop Sharply
abstract: Labor Dept reports that number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits plunged last week to lowest level in one-and-a-half months, suggesting that pace of layoffs may be slowing; initial jobless claims dropped by 46,000, to 450,000, in week ended Nov 3; graph (S)

headline: A Former Boss Tries to Put Honeywell on a New Path
abstract: Lawrence A Bossidy, who came out of retirement in July to take reins of Honeywell International, discusses plans for returning company to health it had in April 2000, when he retired; says company was demoralized by failure of General Electric Co acquisition bid, which he did not favor, and had made no progress in cutting costs and integrating disparate cultures of Honeywell and Allied Signal, whose merger in 1999 formed current company; notes blow Sept 11 delivered to company, which depended on aerospace business for 40 percent of its sales and even more of its profits (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Loss Narrows At Priceline
abstract: Priceline.com, Internet travel agency, reports 2001 third-quarter loss of $3.59 million, compared with loss of $199.1 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Console Shootout: The Sequel
abstract: Charles Herold article assesses two video game consoles, Microsoft's Xbox and Nintendo's Game Cube, which join Sony PlayStation 2; photos (L)

headline: These Guys Got Game: An Empire in the Making
abstract: Article on Anschutz Entertainment Group, disparate collection of properties that began five years ago with $100 million investment by billionaire Philip F Anschutz; in September, Los Angeles gave AEG go-ahead to develop $1 billion, 27-acre entertainment district, complete with theaters, shops and 45-story hotel; in nearby Carson, AEG is building $100 million tennis and soccer training center; on Nov 16, Kodak Theater, which AEG operates, opens in Hollywood, new home of Academy Awards; chief executive Timothy Leiweke comments; chart; photos (M)

headline: Bush Advisers Press for Help For Insurers
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill and R Glenn Hubbard, chairman of White House Council of Economic Advisers, tell lawmakers that nation will face economic crisis if Congress fails to quickly guard insurance industry against losses from any future terrorist attacks; administration's proposal would have government pay at least 80 percent of any claims next year; while clear consensus emerges among senior lawmakers that Congress must do something in few remaining weeks of legislative session, there is widespread disagreement about how to proceed; Sens Bill Nelson and Paul S Sarbanes express reservations about bailout package; photo (M)

headline: Pact to Cut Steel Production Doesn't End Risk of Trade War
abstract: Representative from 39 nations announce agreement in principle to cut steel production by about 10 percent over next decade after two days of talks in Paris intended to ease world's glut of steel; agreement is not binding, and it does not eliminate risk of serious trade war between US and other big steel exporters; US International Trade Commission last week recommended tariffs of up to 40 percent on imported steel products and Pres Bush is supposed to decide on what action to take by third week in February; Peter Carl, European Commission's director general in charge of trade issues, warns US is dangerously close to inciting spiral of trade sanctions (M)

headline: Israel Rebuffs U.S. Demand To End Its West Bank Raids
abstract: Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres meets in Washington with Pres Bush and Sec of State Colin Powell and rebuffs their demand that Israel pull out of Palestinian-controlled areas of West Bank; says security forces of Yasir Arafat must first arrest men who murdered Israeli Tourism Minister Rehavam Zeevi; Bush and Powell balance call for immediate Israeli withdrawal with demands on Arafat for arrests in Zeeve's murder, along with suspects in terrorist attacks on Israelis; photo (M)

headline: Everyone Wants to Be a Contrarian (and to Argue)
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column notes current difficulty of defining 'contrarian' investment strategy -- behaving contrary to majority expectations -- because majority expectations are not clear; concludes that market's likely propensity is downward; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: In Crisis Zone, a Wireless Patch
abstract: Some businesses in Lower Manhattan that lost high-speed Internet connection on Sept 11 are regaining it by means of new wireless technology called Wi-Fi, which broadcasts high-speed Internet connection over zone that extends several hundred feet from a working Internet connection; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Will Buy 3.2% Stake in Korea Telecom
abstract: Microsoft will pay $500 million for 3.2 percent ownership of Korea Telecom, giving it potential for selling wide range of services through South Korea's leading provider of broadband Internet connections; Korea has world's highest broadband penetration; Korea Telecom also provides 98 percent of country's conventional telephone service (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: England: Euthanasia Case To Go To Top Court
abstract: British Law Lords, in ruling that will test law banning euthanasia, agree to hear terminally-ill woman's request to allow husband to help her die without being prosecuted; Diane Pretty, 42, is paralyzed with motor neuron disease (S)

headline: Investing; Some Restaurants Thrive in Slowdown
abstract: Sales at several large inexpensive, casual-dining restaurant chains rebound after brief decline following terrorist attacks; analysts and money managers share their views on industry and specific stocks; graph (M)

headline: Bush Voices Pride in Aid, But Groups List Hurdles
abstract: Pres Bush promotes his relief fund for Afghan children at Red Cross headquarters in Washington, but international relief groups complain that American bombing campaign has made it virtually impossible to deliver large amounts of food to starving Afghans; aid officials are especially angered by bombing of Red Cross warehouse near Kabul that stored food and shelter supplies; photos (M)

headline: International Business; With the U.S. Economy Slumping, Canada and Mexico Are Reeling
abstract: Recession in US takes heavy toll on economies of Canada and Mexico, most thoroughly integrated with American economy and subject to fluctuate with it; their pain suggests what awaits other countries that trade heavily with US; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Finding the Presence of Anthrax
abstract: Sources: Dr. Stuart Isaacs and Dr. Elizabeth Colston, both of the University of Pennsylvania

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: New Theory On Norse God
abstract: Anthropologist Thor Heyerdahl says his excavations i

headline: Making More Calendars In Microsoft Outlook
abstract: Q. Can I have more than one calendar in Microsoft Outlook, perhaps one for a special project and one for regular appointments?    A. Yes, it is possible to create a separate calendar for your special project information, by creating another Calendar folder within the Outlook program.

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Lisa Balshan was named to the new post of senior vice president for national promotions at the New York office of New Line Cinema.

headline: Reports of a Tangible Gain, Tougher Visa Rules, an Anthrax Theory
abstract: Overview of day's events on war against terrorism; anti-Taliban force claims capture of Mazar-i-Sharif in northern Afghanistan; visas to United States will be more difficult to obtain for men in specific age group, and background check will be more thorough; federal investigators theorize that domestic terrorist, loner with scientific background, is responsible for anthrax attacks (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Car Sales Decline
abstract: New-car sales in Japan fall 9.3 percent in November from month a year go, third consecutive decline; with wages and jobs disappearing, consumers are spending less on big-ticket items, including new homes, electronics and autos; that spells trouble for Japan's economy, half of which is driven by personal spending (S)

headline: Now, the Battle to Feed the Afghan Nation
abstract: Retreat of Taliban clears way for next critical phase of American campaign in Afghanistan: delivering relief for millions of hungry, cold, sick, war-weary Afghans, thousands of them at death's door; war against famine, disease and misery may prove as important as military campaign in ending generation of misrule and chaos; NATO allies will ship food, clothing, shelter and medicine to nations surrounding Afghanistan for United Nations relief organizations, private aid groups and Afghan truckers to deliver to people in ruined cities and shattered villages; immediate goal is to keep Afghans from starving this winter; broader goal is to show Afghans that American-led coalition can help them live new lives; photos; maps (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: More Job Cuts
abstract: Royal KPN, largest phone company in Netherlands, faced with crippling debt, says it will cut 1,300 more jobs over next three years to trim its work force by total of 9,300; graph (S)

headline: CBS Scores Some Points, Even During a Tough Year
abstract: Interview with CBS Television president, Leslie Moonves, who reflects on his network's strength in 2001 and expresses guarded optimism on 2002; photo (M)

headline: Layoffs Are Planned at Agencies in 2 States
abstract: Layoffs Are Planned At Agencies in 2 States.

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Independent Journalism Prizes
abstract: Group of Mexican newspaper editors, academics and directors of nongovernment organizations announce creation of independent journalism awards competition (S)

headline: A Tour Guide That Heeds Your Prompts and Preferences
abstract: Tourists with cellphones can now use them as personal city guides when taking in sights of Washington, DC, and Manhattan; photo (S)

headline: Refilling the Planes, Replenishing the Economy
abstract: Greenburgh (NY) Supervisor Paul Feiner letter on September 30 article suggests Congress approve bill allowing tax credits for rest of year for those traveling on vacation; photo

headline: Lots of Competition for 2001's Hit Toy
abstract: There is no single must-have toy this holiday season, but there are plenty of best-selling toys that may be in short supply because of faltering economy and events of Sept 11; many toy retailers have kept orders light this year because of concern about economy, but now they are betting that sales will be fairly solid during holiday season; history has shown that toy business is more resilient than other retail businesses in recession because parents tend to cut back on spending for themselves but not for their children, if they can help it; some popular toys on market discussed; photos (M)

headline: Dynegy Asks Court to Let It Buy Pipeline From Enron
abstract: Dynegy Inc argues in court that loan defaults by Enron Corp give Dynegy right to buy Enron's valuable Northern Natural Gas pipeline linking Texas to Great Lakes region (M)

headline: Tokyo Journal; Even in Ginza, Honor Among Thieves Crumbles
abstract: Tokyo Journal on turf war between crime families in Ginza entertainment district as far cry from economic boom years when gangsters stuck to own turf and honored hierarchy; picturesque gentility of yakuza gangs gives way to Hollywood-style shootings; photos; map (M)

headline: Afghan Says Fighters Are Ready to Attack Cave Complex
abstract: Over a thousand Pashtun fighters were said to be ready to attack a complex where Osama bin Laden and 2,000 Al Qaeda fighters are believed to be hiding.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Publisher Revises Outlook
abstract: VNU, Dutch publisher of Hollywood Reporter and Billboard magazine, says profits for full year will be less than expected after terrorist attacks in US cut advertising sales; says it wil cut as many as 400 jobs, or 11 percent of its staff, in business information subsidiary (S)

headline: The Case For Buying Municipal Bonds
abstract: Jerome Jacobs, chief investment officer for tax-exempt fixed-income securities at Putnam Investments, answers questions on investing in municipal bonds; photo (M)

headline: A Mayor-Elect With Money Tells Friends to Ante Up
abstract: A Mayor-Elect With Money Tells Friends to Ante Up  The Robin Hood Foundation, a charity to help New York City's poor, has a star-studded list of supporters mixing Wall Street and Hollywood. Founded by the hedge fund manager Paul Tudor Jones, its board includes Stanley Druckenmiller, former right-hand man to George Soros; Theodore Forstmann, the leveraged-buyout investor; the actress Gwyneth Paltrow; and Lachlan Murdoch, deputy chief operating officer of the News Corporation (and son of Rupert).

headline: Programmer Exposes Microsoft Flaws
abstract: Anonymous programmer publishes software on Internet that disables Microsoft technology designed to regulate what consumers do with music they buy online; holds buyers should be able to copy music to all of their computers and portable devices; Microsoft sees no serious risk to security of music sheathed in its software (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Meets Saudis and Says He's Satisfied With Level of Support
abstract: Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld seeks to solidify Saudi support for strike against Osama bin Laden's terrorist network and broader war against terrorism; meets with King Fahd and other Saudi leaders, but insists he is not negotiating access to air bases, which is confirmed by Saudis; precise extent of cooperation is unclear; speculation on whether old disputes linger discussed; photo (M)

headline: PARTIAL PULLBACK OUT OF WEST BANK STARTED BY ISRAEL
abstract: Israeli forces begin withdrawing from Bethlehem, despite Palestinian attacks hours earlier that killed five people and wounded more than 30; pullout authorized by Prime Min Ariel Sharon under intense American pressure to end invasions of six Palestinian-controlled cities in West Bank; he indicates through spokesman that military presence will continue, or even intensify, in other areas in response to Palestinian violence; Palestinians report buildup of troops near Jenin and Tulkarm, from which some of attacks were staged; principal attack was launched in Hadera in northern Israel; Palestinians in utility vehicle sprayed automatic gunfire on busy street, killing four women and injuring more than 30 people; two gunmen are shot and killed by police; militant Palestinian group Islamic Holy War claims responsibility; Israelis say attackers served on Palestinian police force; Palestinian Authority and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat condemn attacks; map; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Shell's Profit Falls
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group says third-quarter net income fell to $2.69 billion, compared with $3.25 billion year earlier (S)

headline: Three User's Manuals For Modern Management
abstract: William J Holstein reviews three books on management, which he says suggest that euphoric days of 'revolutionary' and 'radical' change in business are giving way to painstaking and detailed work of reshaping companies, department by department and division by division; books are Michael Hammer's The Agenda: What Every Business Must Do to Dominate the Decade, Michael Useem's Leading Up: How to Lead Your Boss So You Both Win, and Jim Collins's Good to Great: Why Some Companies Make the Leap and Others Don't; photo (M)

headline: Alliance Says U.S. Team Is in Its Territory, Gathering Intelligence on Taliban Positions
abstract: US reconnaissance team is in northern Afghanistan gathering information on front-line Taliban positions near strategic city of Mazar-i-Sharif; presence suggests new level of coordination with Northern Alliance; photo (M)

headline: Putin Sees Continued Alliance Despite the End of ABM Pact
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin of Russia says in newspaper interview that Bush administration's withdrawal from 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty should not crush 'spirit of partnership and even alliance' between US and Russia; his remarks seen as remarkably measured response to American decision that has inflamed even many of Russia's pro-Western politicians; Putin says rather than retaliate diplomatically, Kremlin hopes to convince US through negotiations that successor to treaty is essential to contain threat of global arms race (M)

headline: A Roster Of Awards Better Off Unawarded
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column announces Augustus Melmotte Memorial Prizes, named after stock manipulator created by Anthony Trollope; winners include Enron Corp, Conseco, Cendant and Hewlett-Packard executives, Republican lawmakers who repealed corporate taxes and some stock analysts; drawings (M)

headline: Northern Alliance Casts Doubt on Taliban Participation in Next Government
abstract: A senior official of the Northern Alliance declared today that his group would not accept any members of the Taliban in a future coalition government set up to run the country once the current Taliban leadership is driven from power.

headline: 128 Missing in Swiss Tunnel Fire; 11 Confirmed Dead
abstract: Swiss police say 128 people are listed as missing and 11 are confirmed dead after truck collision sets off inferno inside St Gotthard Tunnel, world's second longest tunnel; rescue workers battle intense heat trying to reach crash site; second fatal accident near St Bernhard Tunnel, closest alternative route, causes more confusion and further snarls traffic in heart of Europe; disaster is latest in series involving tunnel routes through Alps in recent years, raising vexing questions about whether Europe can depend on precarious and heavily trafficked passageways to ferry so much of freight that is vital to its commerce; photos; map (M)

headline: A Germany-Israel heritage travel program. So why not?
abstract: TAL Tours, Lufthansa, Israel Ministry of Tourism and German National Tourist Office combine efforts to advertise Germany-Israel heritage travel program; photo (M)

headline: Ex-King Meets Taliban Foes And 11 From U.S. Congress
abstract: Mohammad Zahir Shah, exiled king of Afghanistan, meets with representatives of anti-Taliban Northern Alliance and American Congressional delegation; king, who has been living in Rome since ouster by Soviet-backed coup in 1973, says he will return to Afghanistan despite his age (86) to make sure all ethnic groups are represented in post-Taliban government; photo (M)

headline: Nobel in Literature Goes to Naipaul, an Explorer of Exile
abstract: Nobel Prize in Literature for 2001 is awarded to V S Naipaul, eloquent Trinidad-born English writer who uses fiction, nonfiction and sometimes fusion of two to explore themes of exile, dislocation, and agonizing dilemmas of postcolonial societies; photo (M)

headline: Standoff in Macedonia Threatening NATO-Backed Peace Plan
abstract: Ethnic Albanian gunmen and Macedonian police forces remain in tense standoff around several villages in western Macedonia, once more threatening tortuous and much delayed peace process just before final parliamentary vote; former members of recently disbanded Albanian guerrilla force openly take up arms again after police search operation; rebels refuse to allow police patrols back into rebel-held villages until Paliament passes amnesty measure for rebels fighters who give up their guns; Macedonian Slav politicians appear close to reneging on agreement to grant amnesties(M)

headline: A Bazaar Erupts in Fury On a Tour of Everyday Life
abstract: Taliban allows 26 foreign journalists to make supervised visit to Kandahar to see how ordinary life is continuing there in face of American bombing; journalists--half of them Pakistani, two of the Americans--are far from popular; crowds shout 'death to America' and 'death to Bush'; excursion involves series of side trips to locations where Taliban says air raids caused civilian casualties; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Hog prices gain after report signals pork supplies will be smaller than expected next year; in Chicago, hogs for December delivery rises 1.8 cents, or 3.8 percent, to 49.65 cents per pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Lockheed Martin Is Awarded Huge Fighter-Jet Contract
abstract: The Defense Department said today that it had selected the Lockheed Martin Corporation to develop the military's next generation of fighter jets.

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Nauru: All Ashore
abstract: Last of group of 240 refugees, mostly from Iraq, disembarks from Australian Navy ship onto tiny Pacific island of Nauru; they join nearly 400 refugees from Afghanistan who were sent to island after being stranded at sea when Australia refused to accept them (S)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: David Kahn, president at the Condé Nast Image Center, part of the Condé Nast unit of Advance Publications, New York, is leaving.

headline: Technology Shares Rebound, With the Nasdaq Up 22.79
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average loses 46.84 points, to close at 9,075.14; Nasdaq Composite Index gains 22.79 points, to 1,690.20; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ends virtually unchanged at1,059.78; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Military Denies Plane Was Shot Down
abstract: Indonesian military denies Muslim rebel claim to have downed transport plane in Aceh (S)

headline: Pakistan Readies Forbidding Moonscape of Rock for 10,000 Afghans
abstract: Pakistan sets aside 400 desolate acres as camp for first 10,000 Afghan refugees who cross border to escape threat of war following Sept 11 attacks on America; presently, border is closed and only those who pay bribes or cross in remote places are getting through; shelter will be provided but Pakistan does not want refugees to be too comfortable lest they become tempted to stay; photo; map (M)

headline: I.R.S. Offers Amnesty to Companies That Admit Tax Indiscretions
abstract: Internal Revenue Service reports that tax shelters, many of them illegal, saved big companies at least $14.7 billion in federal income taxes last year; all companies are being offered amnesty in return for confessing their illegal tax avoidance; 95 companies that have already confessed their tax avoidance strategies to IRS this year shorted government an amount equal to dollar a week for every man, woman and child in America; Larry Langdon, IRS commissioner for midsized and large businesses, says this may only be tip of iceberg (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Names A President
abstract: Edward D Breen will succeed Robert L Growney as president and chief operating officer of Motorola on Jan 1; Growney will become vice chairman until he retires on March 31, 2002; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Greece: Bank Plans To Buy Rival
abstract: National Bank of Greece, country's leading bank, announces plans to buy Alpha Bank for about 4.1 million euros ($3.6 billion) in stock; acquisition will make National big enough to move into new markets (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    AmeriPath Inc., Riviera Beach, Fla., 4.1 million shares. Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Is Raising Speculation In Hollywood
abstract: Justice Dept is investigating whether movie studios' efforts to offer films online to consumers at home is anticompetitive; analysts say that as multinational companies further consolidate and cross-promote their movie, television, Internet and music properties, it is becoming harder to say who is competing with whom and how it helps or hurts consumers (M)

headline: Grounded? Safety Tips For Road Warriors
abstract: Checklist for vehicle maintenance, as cold weather approaches, to help insure safe operation (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Suharto In Hospital
abstract: Former Pres Suharto of Indonesia collapses and is hospitalized; he is 80 and has history of stroke and heart problems; photo (S)

headline: The Pope Apologizes for the Catholic Church's 'Errors' in China
abstract: Pope John Paul II apologizes to China today for 'errors' in Roman Catholic Church's missions there and expresses his strong willingness to work toward full diplomatic relations with Beijing; pope has been pressing to normalize relations with China for years, but Vatican still recognizes Taiwan, a deal breaker for Chinese, and China does not allow Catholics to recognize authority of pope; there is no immediate comment on pope's latest remarks by China (M)

headline: Brazil Searches for More Energy
