abstract: Brazil's government planners hope to harness Amazon basin's network of rivers to remedy severe energy shortages in urban areas far to south; photo; map; work is speeded up on world's third-largest dam on bend in Xingu River east of Altamira, which would increase country's hydroelectric capacity fifteen percent; photo; map; ambitious programs have so far generated only fierce opposition among local environmental and religious groups (M)

headline: The Good Old Days Were Not as Good as We Thought
abstract: Floyd Norris columnon revised economicn

headline: Earnings Picture Varies At 5 Big Drug Companies
abstract: American Home Products reports profit dropped 67 percent, to $252.1 million in third quarter, compared with $762.1 million year earlier; revenue rose nearly 7 percent, to $3.74 billion from $3.5 billion; company earned $867 million; Schering-Plough Corp's profit rose 1.7 percent, to $601 million from $591 million year earlier; sales were little changed at $2.38 billion; Bristol-Myers Squibb's earnings rose less than 1 percent, to $1.25 billion compared with $1.24 billion year ago; Pharmacia's third-quarter net income jumped 70 percent, to $428 million from $252 million year ago; GlaxoSmithKline posts 48 percent drop in net income; earnings fell to 403 million pounds ($574.1 million) compared with 768 million pounds year ago; sales rose 13 percent, to 4.99 billion pounds (M)

headline: Stopping Signals From Satellite TV Proves Difficult
abstract: Analysis: White House effort to get major United States television news oganizations to use caution before airing raw video statements from Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda followers will not prevent bin Laden from communicating by television with any followers in US; control of nation's television signals is no longer limited to coterie of US companies that White House turned to; privatization and deregulation of international satellite business, along with proliferation of advanced satellite technologies, allow images to reach American living rooms from Middle East and Central Asia, delivered by loose amalgam of companies from around world, some of which may not be willing to follow White House suggestions; great majority of homes in US have option of receiving Al Jazeera directly using satellite dish antenna; photos; map (L)

headline: For Saudi Cleric, Battle Shapes Up as Infidel vs. Islam
abstract: Article profiles Sheik Hamoud al-Shuaibi, Saudi cleric who opposes US military campaign in Afghanistan and says it is duty of every Muslim to support Afghan people and fight against America; photos (M)

headline: Networks Ask If 'Message' By bin Laden Is Really News
abstract: Television news executives consider whether to broadcast threat from Osama bin Laden's organization of more terrorist attacks, expressing reservations about becoming conduits for propaganda campaigns by bin Laden; others express concern that by broadcasting tapes, they might be furthering strategy of psychological warfare hatched by bin Laden to instill fear in American public (M) viewers, or Al Qaeda's propa

headline: Study Says Bad Data by China Inflated Global Fishing Yields
abstract: Study by University of British Columbia scientists Reg Watson and Daniel Pauly has found evidence of substantial overreporting of fishing yields from world's oceans, mainly by China; China's lower officials in past had strong incentives to say they had met government's rising targets for fish catches; apparent result was that they simply exaggerated count to match their goals; instead of rising by average of 330,000 tons per year since 1988, as recorded in United Nations data, world's catch has actually declined by average of 360,000 tons per year, according to study in current issue of journal Nature; study raises doubts about ability of fisheries to meet growing global demand for food (M)

headline: Arafat Aide Says Israel Is Preventing A Crackdown
abstract: Chief of Palestinian security forces in West Bank, Jibril Rajoub, asserts that Israeli military strikes make it impossible for him to crack down on militants, even as another Israeli raid results in more arrests and deaths of four Palestinians, one of them age 11 (M)

headline: Scramble for New Business Web Addresses Is Delayed by Added Tests and a Lawsuit
abstract: Open registration for Internet addresses ending in .biz, originally scheduled to begin tomorrow, has been pushed back to Nov. 7, according to the company that manages the .biz database, NeuLevel.    The .biz extension is one of seven new suffixes, called top-level domains, intended to provide alternatives to the .com, .net and .org names.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Handspring Raises Cash
abstract: Handspring Inc, money-losing maker of Visor hand-held computer, says it raised $48.5 million from investors, including Qualcomm Inc; graph shows price swings in Handspring stock (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Kraft Foods Signs Deals for Big Campaigns
abstract: Kraft Foods Signs Deals For Big Campaigns Kraft Foods North America in Northfield, Ill., a division of Kraft Foods, has signed agreements to buy large advertising packages from AOL Time Warner in New York and Viacom Plus, the sales and marketing division of Viacom in New York.

headline: Higher Minimums for Funds
abstract: TIAA-CREF raises minimum investment in its mutual funds from $250 to $1500 (S)

headline: Aftermarket PC Speakers For Digital Music Lovers
abstract: Logitech introduces series of high-quality speaker systems for personal computers; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Talks On Air Routes
abstract: Virgin Express, budget airline controlled by Sir Richard Branson, in continuing to hold talks with Belgian government concerning restructuring Sabena, national airline that has filed for protection from creditors; is unlikely to inject money into rescue package for Sabena, but would be more likely to acquire some regional routes in event carrier is dissolved (S)

headline: Opposition in Zimbabwe Fights Mugabe, but Also Itself
abstract: Zimbabwe heads into one of most controversial presidential elections since white rule ended in 1980, with leading opposition party pitched not only against Pres Robert Mugabe but often against itself as well; bitter factional fighting recounted (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Menem Cleared On One Charge
abstract: A federal judge ordered that one charge be dropped in the investigation of former President Carlos Saúl Menem's connections to arms smuggling to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995. Judge Julio Speroni said there was insufficient evidence that Mr. Menem had been involved in smuggling gunpowder. But Mr. Menem, who has been under house arrest since June, will remain in custody as investigators continue to look into whether he led an ''illicit organization'' set up to traffic in arms.     Clifford Krauss (NYT)

headline: DoCoMo Plans To Keep Stake In U.S. Concern
abstract: DoCoMo, cellular division of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, agrees to pay $680 million to maintain its 16 percent ownership of AT&T Wireless Services Inc (M)

headline: Russia Agrees, at Least on Paper, to Reduce Oil Exports
abstract: Russia agrees to reduce crude oil exports by 150,000 barrels per day, decision that could prompt production cuts by OPEC members and other nations; move appears to break monthlong deadlock with OPEC; cartel announced in November that it would pare daily oil production only if non-OPEC nations like Russia, Norway and Mexico followed suit, call that Russia had resisted; Russia's announcement does little to oil prices; crude oil is down 16 cents, at $19.49 per barrel, in New York trading (M)

headline: India Seeks International Support to Force Pakistan to Crack Down on Militants
abstract: Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee says India is vigorously pursuing diplomatic efforts to get Pakistan two crack down on militant groups Lashkar-e-Taiba and Jaish-e-Muhammed, which India blames for recent attack on its Parliament in which 14 people were killed; says if peaceful means fail, India will consider other options; photo of demonstrators in New Delhi protesting attacks (M)

headline: Rapid Advances by Northern Alliance Deal a Setback to Pakistan's Policy
abstract: Stunningly swift successes of Northern Alliance in Afghanistan amount to huge setback for longtime policy of Pakistan, which until terrorist attacks of Sept 11 supported ruling Taliban; Pakistan is indispensable ally in America's coalition against terrorism, but it has insisted that Northern Alliance not be allowed to take over Kabul; Pres Bush, in clear effort to help Pakistan's leader, Gen Pervez Musharraf, warns Northern Alliance against rushing into Kabul, but alliance may not stick to its agreement; immediate rout of Taliban by alliance would leave Pakistan surrounded by countries with capitals hostile to it (M)

headline: G.M. Agrees to Sell Its Satellite TV Unit In $26 Billion Deal
abstract: General Motors, in deal certain to draw scrutiny from regulators, will sell Hughes Electronics, owner of DirecTV, to EchoStar Communications for about $26 billion in cash and stock; sale would combine nation's two largest satellite television companies, creating behemoth with 16.7 million subscribers or more than even biggest US cable television company; EchoStar would control more than 90 percent of satellite television services for homes in US; combined company would use EchoStar name and adopt DirecTV brand for services; likely opposition to merger by federal regulators discussed; opposition by at least 10 members of Congress, including chairmen of several powerful committees, noted (M)

headline: In Spain, Thousands Protest New Plans for Universities
abstract: Tens of thousands of students are joined by university staff and faculty members in demonstration to protest plan to overhaul Spain's universities; Education Min Pilar del Castillo says aim is to improve quality of teaching by instituting new selection procedures for tenured professors and creating national evaluation agency that will rank colleges and improve administration of universities; critis contend overhaul is start of subtle process of privatization, that it handicap public institutions and favors private colleges, which will lead to two-tier system; most of all, they say plan is flawed because government has not proposed any new resources to put new system in place; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Nortel Will Cut Work Force by 20,000
abstract: Nortel Networks is cutting 10,000 jobs and reducing its work force by additional 10,000 jobs through sale of businesses, leaving company with fewer than half employees it had at beginning of year; Nortel's board says it will replace chief executive John A Roth with Frank A Dunn, chief financial officer; Dunn's first order of business is to warn investors of $3.6 billion loss Nortel expects to report this quarter; Nortel reaches agreement to sell Clarify, its customer billing business, to Amdocs Ltd for $200 million in cash (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street is stunned and angered by the Treasury's action on long-term bonds.
abstract: Market Place column examines decision by US Treasury to halt issuance of 30-year bond, which has stunned and angered Wall Street analysts (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Debra J. Chrapaty was named to the new post of senior vice president for technology at Organic, San Francisco.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Company Wins Contract Extension
abstract: Computer Sciences Corp, third-largest United States seller of computer services, wins five-year, $1.1 billion contract extension to run networks for United Technologies Corp; contract is now worth $3.7 billion and will expire in December 2014 (S)

headline: Vivendi Unit In a Dispute With Paris
abstract: SFR, French wireless operators controlled by Vivendi Universal, withholds its initial payment for new mobile license in attempt to press government into renegotiating both timing and total amount of fees; says it is talking to government about adapting payment to new environment in which mobile companies are struggling under crippling debt and slowing growth (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Silicon Storage Projects Profit
abstract: Silicon Storage Technology expects to post profit of 1 or 2 cents per share in third quarter, excluding items, on projected revenue of $73 million to $77 million; graph (S)

headline: LVMH Sales Dropped 5% In October
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, which manufactures and markets wide range of luxury goods, says that its sales in October fell 5 percent from period last year and that its operating profits for full year might be 15 percent lower than last year (M)

headline: Pakistan Is Reported to Have Arrested Militant Leader
abstract: Pakistan reports arrest of Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, founder of one of two Islamic militant groups accused by India of mounting attack on Indian Parliament 18 days ago; action appears to be last-ditch effort to forestall war with India; Pakistani officials have hinted that Gen Pervez Musharraf is ready to take 'new and bolder' steps to crack down on Saeed's Army of the Pure and second group, Army of Muhammad; Army of Muhammad leader, Maulana Masood Azhar, was arrested week ago; Pakistan also froze bank accounts of both groups; State Dept has added both groups to its list of banned terrorist organizations; arrests fail to mollify India or US, which continue to push for additional steps that would bring Pakistan closer to meeting India's demands that groups be suppressed and their leaders handed over to India for trial; photos; map (M)

headline: A City of Exiles Dreams of Power Regained
abstract: Capital of Afghan diaspora is in Peshawar, Pakistan, which has become meeting place for exiled commanders, politicians, mullahs and million refugees; since Sept 11, Peshawar is city of intrigue as men who were once very important make plans to be important again in imagined post-Taliban Afghanistan; even as Western leaders plot which amalgam of Afghanistan's ethnic groups might provide most representative government if Taliban are ousted, reality of region's shifting politics and allegiances is represented by likes of Abdul Haq, once renowned guerrilla fighter in jihad against Soviets who has emerged from military mothballs for chance to reclaim Afghanistan; Haq claims American bombing of Afghanistan is mistake, causing people to rally around Taliban; photos (M)

headline: Japanese Consumers Revel In Deflation's Silver Lining
abstract: Japanese consumers are reveling in newfound spending power after three years of deflation; imports and introduction of modern, highly efficient retailing are helping to sharply cut prices; cost of living in Tokyo, long one of world's most expensive cities, is finally moving closer to other places; many economists see positive benefits in deflation, although it could prolong recession; graph; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions; Textile Regulations
abstract: US declines to adopt measure at World Trade Organization meeting sponsored by developing nations that would have imposed less restrictive method of calculating growth rate for quotas on textile imports until 2005; agrees to consider measure again before July 2002 (S)

headline: Pakistan's Leader Takes Steps to Solidify Control Ahead of U.S. Air Raids
abstract: Pakistan president Gen Pervez Musharraf tightens grip on country's military by promoting two generals and restricting political opposition by placing militant cleric under house arrest just prior to commencement of US air strikes against Taliban government in Afghanistan; timing of actions indicates he expected strikes and wanted to ensure control over potentially volatile reaction; country braces for anti-American protests; photo (M)

headline: Witnesses to an Epidemic Shrug Off Shame to Fight a Dangerous Fear
abstract: witnesses to an epidemic shru

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Practicing For Nuclear Disaster
abstract: Switzerland to conduct mock exercises on coping with nuclear accident (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Producer Prices Fall
abstract: France reports manufacturers cut prices by 0.6 percent in Nov (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Central Bank President Predicts Upturn in Europe  The president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, voiced cautious optimism today about Europe's economy, predicting a moderate upturn during the next year.     The economy of the 12-nation euro zone should be expanding at an annual rate of more than 2 percent at the end of 2002, provided a recovery materializes in the United States as expected, he said. On average, growth will be almost 1 percent next year, he added. [Page C2.]

headline: Sofia Journal; Posters of Hitler Rouse Talk, and Fears, in Bulgaria
abstract: Fears of anti-Semitism arise in Bulgaria, where it has never been problem, with publication of Bulgarian translation of Mein Kampf and plastering of Sofia with 400 to 600 posters of Hitler; Galin Jordanov, editor of book's publishing house, denies having posters put up, having anything to do with fascists or anything against Jews, and insists that issue is people's desire for books that were banned during Communist years; photo; map (M)

headline: Investing; A Siren Song Sounds Again From Wall St.
abstract: Indexes of bullish sentiment among brokerage strategists and individual investors are running high, signaling to some analysts that market is in for further decline (M)

headline: Sinclair Reports Loss in Third Quarter and Reduces Estimates
abstract: Sinclair Broadcast Group, owner of 63 United States television stations, reports third-quarter loss of $29.9 million, or 39 cents a share (S)

headline: DataBank; Investors Inch Their Way Toward Optimism
abstract: Financial markets performance over past week reviewed; graphs; tables (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Milosevic Challenges His Arrest
abstract: Slobodan Milosevic files complaint against Netherlands at European Court of Human Rights, claiming he was illegally arrested, transported and held since June at detention center in The Hague; he awaits trial there on war crimes charges (S)

headline: EMERSON ELECTRIC IS SELLING UNIT TO JPMORGAN PARTNERS
abstract: emerson

headline: MP3 Players Let the Music Go On and On and On
abstract: Latest MP3 player from Remote Solutions has 540 hours of storage; photo (S)

headline: Death of a Child: How Israel's Army Responds
abstract: Article on fatal shooting of 11-year-old Palestinian boy by Israeli troops in Rafah on West Bank and investigation by human rights group B'tselem, which has provided rare glimpse of how Israeli Army probes killings, decides whether to take disciplinary action and formulates public responses; military police have begun only 10 investigations into possible illegal gunfire by troops, and only one led to court-martial, out of hundreds of fatal shootings since start of Palestinian uprising more than year ago (M)

headline: Manager Selected For PepsiCo Account
abstract: Omnicom Group names Matthew Seiler to oversee work produced by all of its agencies and divisions for PepsiCo (S)

headline: Initial Offerings Make A Comeback of Sorts
abstract: Market for initial public offerings has something of a rebound in October, with eight companies coming to market, compared with none in September and only two in August (S)

headline: VIROPHARMA TO HALT TRIALS OF HEPATITIS TREATMENT
abstract: ViroPharma Inc will halt human trials for hepatitis C treatment that company was developing with American Home Products Corp; compound did not work as well as expected (S)

headline: 2 Downing Street Neighbors in Need of a Fence
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair has traveled the world keeping the antiterror war coalition united and focused on a common enemy, but at home his powerful second in command, Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, has plunged his government into open combat.    ''When you have two people that aren't working together, and that's the prime minister and the chancellor, it doesn't lead to positive, easy decision-making,'' Mo Mowlam, a former member of Mr. Blair's cabinet, said over the weekend in a BBC interview that reignited a long-simmering feud at the heart of the Blair government. ''You know there's a battle going on, and people go to one side or the other, and I think that is just crippling for government.''

headline: IVillage Advertising Rose 19% in Third Quarter
abstract: iVillage, Web site for women, says its sales increased 19 percent in third quarter from previous quarter and its pretax operating earnings turned positive for first time; company still lost $5.9 million in quarter; revenue was $18 million, down from $29 million year earlier; chief executive Douglas McCormick comments (S)

headline: Budget Crunch; Teaching Photography With Analog Tools
abstract: College photojournalism programs are having trouble keeping up with rapid and costly shift in technology from analog to digital; students cannot afford professional-quality digital cameras and schools concentrate on providing computer labs, not cameras (M)

headline: A NATION CHALLENGED: The Ancient Is Gone, the Young Labor On; A Child's World: Long, Hard Duty And Bit of Hope
abstract: Childhood ends quickly in Afghanistan. Boys of 7 or 8 enter the labor pool, and in Kunduz some of them said they had already become shepherds or farmers or sellers in stalls. At Nazukmeer Market in Kunduz, apprentices in auto repair shops cleaned car parts or crawled under jeeps in the mud to work on trucks. Akmad Jaweed, 11, who has worked for four years at his father's shop, said: ''When I am a man I will be ready to have work and make money.''   C. J. Chivers

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: She Just Can't Win
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi reprimands blunt-talking foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, who is protesting parliament's refusal to allow her to attend UN Assembly meeting in New York (S)

headline: Support for U.S. Security Plans Is Quietly Voiced Across Canada
abstract: In contrast to statement of Prime Min Jean Chretien, Canadians voice support of United States and say Canada should cooperate with US in areas of immigration, security and antiterrorism policies; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: An Effort To Make Peace
abstract: Pres Abdiqassim Salad Hassan, head of Somalia's transitional government, meets with opposition leaders in peace talks organized in neighboring Kenya, but most of key warlords stay away (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Merchants Posted No Gain In Overall September Sales  Over all, sales at the nation's merchants did not increase at all in September, according to the first industrywide figures since the Sept. 11 attacks. It was the worst month since Goldman, Sachs started keeping its retail index in 1988 and the worst September performance comparison since Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi began keeping its index in 1970.    But the numbers underscored that retail is a tale of two types of stores: the discounters and everyone else. Sales at specialty apparel stores declined by 8.5 percent, but discounters' sales increased 4.4 percent. [Page C13.]

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (M)

headline: Powell Says U.S. Had Signs, But Not Clear Ones, of a Plot
abstract: Sec Colin Powell says that prior to Sept 11 US received 'lots of signs' that terrorists were planning attacks, but never got 'fidelity' or clear intelligence about what would happen; interview; photos; Powell praises CIA Dir George Tenet but expresses frustration that information was not sufficient to identify targets, despite summer of warnings that seemed to center on July 4 or summit meeting in Genoa; makes clear that US, while still at early stages of winning full cooperation worldwide, is offering convincing evidence that 'all paths' lead to Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network, even if not in terms of court trial; describes cables sent to US embassies outlining case, history of network and existing indictments of bin Laden for earlier crimes against US and 'civilization'; Powell stops short of stating Taliban ouster is explicit goal, but warns Taliban will pay price for harboring bin Laden and hopes Afghan people can get less repressive government, holding out hope of substantial aid if they do so; says massive relief now under way is effort to bring some level of stability there; Powell says campaign's success will be measured in restoring degree of security in society, with second measure of less terrorism with global reach; explains that even covert activities eventually produce visible results; also says he has not decided when to outline Bush administration's support for Palestinian state (M)

headline: Mexico to Ignore A Trade Ruling
abstract: Mexican government says it will ignore World Trade Orgn ruling to lift duties on high fructose corn syrup, turning instead to North American Free Trade Agreement to protect sugar producers (S)

headline: Iran Shiites Celebrate And Mourn A Martyr
abstract: iran shiites celebrate and mourn a m

headline: Taliban Leader Is Hiding in Mountain Province Near Kandahar, Afghan Official Says
abstract: Afghan regional official says Taliban leader Muhammad Omar is hiding in mountainous area near Baghram, about 100 miles northwest of Kandahar, in Helmand Province; reports on his escape recounted (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Foundation Deals Setback To Hewlett-Packard's Plans  The family foundation that is the largest shareholder of Hewlett-Packard, with 10.4 percent of the company's outstanding shares, said it would vote against the proposal to buy Compaq Computer.    The move was a setback for Hewlett-Packard and its chief executive, Carleton S. Fiorina, but the company vowed to press on with the proposed acquisition. [Page A1.]

headline: Winstar Bidders Are Given A Week More for Financing
abstract: Judge Joseph J Farnan Jr orders bankrupt Winstar Communications to continue operating and gives bidders for Winstar another week to line up needed money; company provides local phone service to customers, including 29,000 businesses and several government agencies (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Freemarkets Surges On Forecast
abstract: FreeMarkets Inc shares rise sharply after company raises its forecast for fourth-quarter revenue; graph (S)

headline: We Put a Man on the Moon, But Try Finding Orion's Belt
abstract: New device called Star Navigator, made by Excalibur Electronics, has charts showing locations and names of stars and constellations; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Colombia: Lawmaker Slain
abstract: Rep Luis Alfredo Colmenares is assassinated, Bogota; is second congressman from Colombia's war-torn Arauca province killed in week (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Farmers Rally For Land Reform
abstract: Thousands of indigenous farmers block roads in Guatemala, angry at slow pace of land reform (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Suits Over War Shrine Visit
abstract: More than 600 people, including relatives of people killed in World War II, file lawsuits against Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, saying August visit to Tokyo war shrine was unconstitutional (S)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Power Shift In Senate
abstract: Argentine election returns show opposition Justicialist party retains control of Senate and replaces ruling Alianza coalition as leading force in lower house (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: President Reins In Soldiers
abstract: Nigerian Pres Olusegun Obasanjo orders soldiers to sto

headline: ATLANTIC BANK OF NEW YORK BUYS YONKERS FINANCIAL
abstract: Atlantic Bank of New York, unit of National Bank of Greece, agrees to pay $69.6 million for Yonkers Financial Corp (S)

headline: Little Support for Iraq Attack in Group's Poll
abstract: A poll by the Foreign Policy Association shows that respondents oppose overthrowing President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   9.50       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   6.00       Federal funds   1.69   1.85   5.41       3-month T-bills   1.65   1.69   5.71       6-month T-bills   1.75   1.78   5.46       10-yr. T-infl.   3.53   3.52   3.72       10-yr. T-note   5.10   5.08   5.10       30-yr. headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Southeast Asia Bars Help by U.S. Troops in Fighting Terror
abstract: SINGAPORE—  As the United States plans whether and where to use its military against terrorists after Afghanistan and brings Southeast Asia into its sights, countries in the region have made it clear that U.S. combat troops would be unwelcome.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Steel Maker Is Named
abstract: Company formed from three-way merger of Usinor of France, Arbed of Luxembourg and Aceralia of Spain will be called Arcelor; deal is expected to close in February; Usinor chairman Francis Mer and Arbed chairman Joseph Kinch will be co-chairmen until 2004, when single chairman will be named; Arcelor is expected to be world's largest steel maker (S)

headline: European Converts to Laissez Faire See the Rush to Intervene as Heresy
abstract: European Commission has been miserly, if not hostile, toward pleas for bailouts from European companies in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks, while US is spending billions to help airlines and is considering billions more for insurance companies; Bush administration and Congress want to jump-start American economy with new tax breaks and spending, but Europe's center-left governments have thus far avoided similar pump-priming (M)

headline: Hysteria Can Be Hazardous
abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer column on health risks of taking antibiotics as precaution against anthrax and financial damage done when people visit hospitals and doctors as precautionary measure (M)

headline: Challenges of Do-It-Yourself Checkout
abstract: Scanning devices in libraries that are supposed to allow people to check out books themselves have not lived up to manufacturers' promises, and experience may be instructive to retailers like Kmart that have begun installing self-service units; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Up At Tobacco Concern
abstract: Imperial Tobacco, Britain's largest tobacco company, reports full-year after-tax profit of $521 million, up 10 percent (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swisscom Profit Up
abstract: Switzerland's big phone company, Swisscom, expects full-year profit to rise marginally beyond $2.4 billion profit last year, because of cost cuts and stabilizing prices (S)

headline: Many Households Plan A Traditional Halloween
abstract: Survey by National Retail Federation finds that many households plan traditional Halloween despite terrorist attacks of Sept 11 (S)

headline: Phillips and Conoco to Form U.S. Gasoline Giant
abstract: Phillips Petroleum and Conoco Inc will merge, creating oil company with market value of $35 billion; merger into new entity, ConocoPhillips, comes amid plummeting oil prices that have eroded value of their stocks, making them vulnerable to takeovers; Phillips shareholders will get one share of new company for each share of Phillips they hold and will end up owning 56.6 percent of combined company; Conoco shareholders will receive 0.4677 share of new company for each Conoco share and will own 43.4 percent; ConocoPhillpis will have $18.6 billion in debt, and will be nation's third-largest oil and gas company and world's sixth largest based on reserves (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economy Shrinks
abstract: Japan's economy shrank 0.7 percent in April-June period compared with previous quarter (S)

headline: Pope Rebukes Israelis and Palestinians and Pleads for Christians
abstract: Pope John Paul II sternly rebuked Israelis and Palestinians today, saying each side in the Middle East conflict was "disfiguring the Holy Land."

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Company Continues Network Upgrade
abstract: Cingular Wireless will acquire equipment from three European manufacturers, Ericsson, Nokia and Siemens, to upgrade its nationwide wireless network; it is owned by SBC Communications and BellSouth Corp (S)

headline: U.S. Takes Steps to Bolster Bloc Fighting Terror
abstract: After weeks of ignoring offers of forces from allies, the administration is expanding the coalition fighting the Taliban and Al Qaeda.

headline: A NATION CHALLENGED: ISLAM -- Cairo; Thousands Hear Call Of Prayer and Politics At World's Mosques
abstract: At Al Hussein mosque at Al Azhar University, Friday prayers turn into political rally organized by Muslim Brotherhood, group that has sought for decades to install pure Islamic state in Egypt; Sheik Sayed Muhammad Tantawi delivers sermon and uses story of Prophet Muhammad's visit to Jerusalem as opening to endorse Palestinian uprising; ends speech by praying for Muslims in Afghanistan and echoing line of Egyptian government concerning American attacks: only terrorist should be targeted, not whole people of Afghanistan; leader Saif al-Islam says America is enemy of Arabs and Muslims (M)

headline: Philip Morris Identity Crisis Never Seems To Go Away
abstract: Days after Philip Morris Companies proposed changing its name to Altria Group, small company whose name is Altria Healthcare Corp has emerged to say it has borne Altria identity since 1997 and is unhappy about potential confusion; Altria Healthcare president Warren Smedley sends letter to Philip Morris's lawyers asking company to 'do the right thing' and bring 'prudent resolution' to situation (M)

headline: Enron Credit Rating Is Cut, And Its Share Price Suffers
abstract: Shares of Enron Corp fall sharply after Moody's Investors Service lowers company's credit rating, igniting concern that it might have more difficulty raising cash it needs to finance day-to-day operations; Moody's lowers Enron's senior unsecured long-term debt ratings to two levels above so-called junk status (M)

headline: Dutch Authorities Track Movements of Bomb Suspect
abstract: The Netherlands joined efforts to establish the movements of Richard C. Reid in the days before he apparently tried to use explosives in his sneakers to blow up a plane.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: THE AMERICAS NICARAGUA: PANEL TO HEAR ORTEGA CASE The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights has agreed to hear a case stemming from unresolved sexual-abuse allegations by Zoilamerica Narvaez Murillo, a stepdaughter of Daniel Ortega, the former Sandinista leader. She said in 1998 that she had been abused by Mr. Ortega from age 11, but the case stalled when courts refused to lift his immunity as a congressman. The commission will decide only whether the government failed to provide adequate remedies.    David Gonzalez (NYT).

headline: Luxuries Are Looking Like Durable Goods
abstract: Dana Telsey, specialty goods retailing analyst at Bear Stearns, answers questions on outlook for purveyors of luxury goods; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Cuts At Optus
abstract: Cable and Wireless Optus lowers its profit and sales forecast and says it will cut 350 jobs, or 3 percent of work force (S)

headline: U.S. Got a Chance to Show It Learned Lessons of the Past
abstract: The United States commando raid in Afghanistan reflected the start of a new, fast paced and, the military hopes, determining stage of the war.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Wireless To Offer Auto Services
abstract: Verizon Wireless is expected to announce agreement to be exclusive service provider for Wingcast, company formed by Ford Motor and Qualcomm to provide cellular service in automobiles (S)

headline: Trade and Security Tie Canada Closer to U.S.
abstract: Economy of Canada has become so rigidly synchronized with that of United States that if America stumbles, they both fall, and cannot regain their feet alone; links between two countries have existed for decades, but they have grown so intense Canadian officials have little leeway in piloting nation's economy (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Police To Re-Enter Rebel Areas
abstract: Macedonian Interior Ministry says police patrols are preparing to re-enter rebel-held areas because of recent shooting incidents; announcement takes NATO peacekeepers by surprise; government has yet to announce amnesty for rebels (S)

headline: Later Video Of bin Laden May Be Public This Week
abstract: Pres Bush says videotape showing Osama bin Laden reveling in September 11 attacks proves Al Qaeda leader is guilty of 'incredible murder' and lacks conscience and soul; White House refuses to make tape public, even after administration officials suggest President is leaning toward release; senior officials say translation from Arab is being double-checked; say bin Laden seems amused that many of hijackers in attacks apparently had no idea they were on suicide missions (M)

headline: German Panel Recommends Imports of Stem Cells
abstract: Ethics panel named by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder recommends Germany allow restricted imports of stem cells for medical research; parliamentary vote in Jan is expected to clarify whether 1990 law banning all genetic research on embryos bars importing of stem cells from human embryos; parliamentary commission on law and ethics in medicine opposes imports (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Loans For Airlines
abstract: South Korean government plans to lend $195 million to Korea's two airlines, which have been hurt by decline in passengers since attacks of Sept 11; Korean Air will get $110 million and Asiana, $85 million (S)

headline: Countries Lag In Treating Mental Illness, W.H.O. Says
abstract: WHO study reports that countries around world lag in treatment of depression and other mental health disorders, leaving most of 450 million people afflicted without even basic help (M)

headline: Suddenly, Democracy Is in Bloom In Zambia
abstract: Zambia, which appeared to be lurching back to strongman rule early in year, is now awash in political pluralism; field of presidential candidates numbers 11, and as many as six are given chance of defeating Pres Frederick Chiluba; elections are also expected to produce more politically diverse parliament (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AFRICA.

headline: Fighters Uplifted Muslims, Bin Laden Aide Says in Book
abstract: Ayman al-Zawahiri, top lieutenant to Osama bin Laden, says in excerpts of his just-published autobiography that Arabs fighting in Afghanistan galvanized Muslim youth around world in taking on West; Zawahiri is often identified as tactical chief of Al Qaeda; United States has offered reward for information leading to his capture; excerpts are published in Al Sharq Al Awsat, London-based Arab newspaper, which describes book as Zawahiri's 'last will and testament'; says it describes past terrorist attacks in other countries; says some passages apparently written after Sept 11 attacks indicate he was unsure of his fate (M)

headline: My Creativity Comes in Packages
abstract: Maritza Dotel, the gift-wrapping supervisor at Saks Fifth Avenue, has wrapped presents for many famous people.

headline: Arbitration Is Sought in Lumber Dispute
abstract: Canfor Corp, Canadian lumber processor, opposing United States Commerce Department's 67 percent increase in duties on most Canadian softwood imports, asks for arbitration panel under North American Free Trade Agreement and $250 million in compensation from US; holds tariffs were levied in 'arbitrary, discriminatory and capricious manner;' US responded to preliminary study showing Canadian companies sell lumber in US below cost of production (S)

headline: Johannesburg Police Arrest Man In Killing of Former First Lady
abstract: South African police investigating murder of former first lady Marike de Klerk in her home near Cape Town arrest 21-year-old security guard at waterfront apartment complex where she lived (S)

headline: Heavy Bombing Outside Kabul as U.S. Slams Range of Targets
abstract: United States warplanes pounded a wide range of targets today, from the strategic northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif to heavy attacks on Taliban front lines north of Kabul, witnesses said.

headline: Market Place; The Big Five comment on accounting practices and the fall of Enron.
abstract: Floyd Norris column on statement on Enron's failure issued by 'Big Five' accounting firms and Op-Ed article in Wall Street Journal by Joseph F Berardino, chief executive of Arthur Andersen, Enron's outside auditor (M)

headline: Holiday Sales Outlook Roils Book Business
abstract: Article discusses bleak holiday sales outlook for book publishers; with terrorism, war and threat of recession dominating consumers' attention this fall, major publishers are having decreases in their sales of as much as 15 percent from last year's lackluster levels; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Amazon Bolsters Images
abstract: Amazon.com is trying to make it easier to browse through its book catalog on its Web site (S)

headline: IKON, DISTRIBUTOR OF PHOTOCOPIERS, TO CUT 2,600 JOBS
abstract: Ikon Office Solutions Inc, largest American distributor of copiers from Canon Inc and Ricoh Co, will eliminate about 2,600 jobs; says profit for quarter ended Oct 1 will be lower than forecast (S)

headline: Enron Allowed to Auction Off Some Assets
abstract: Federal bankruptcy court paves way for Enron Corp to auction off ownership interests in joint venture that would operate company's flagship energy commodities trading operation; move comes after Enron lawyers say contracts for supplying power would probably not be included in sale (S)

headline: Foote, Cone Quits Last AT&T Account
abstract: Foote, Cone & Be

headline: Agencies add their creativity to the campaign to urge shoppers to return to Lower Manhattan.
abstract: Some advertising agencies have developed for free advertising spots as part of campaign to encourage consumers in New York City metropolitan area to visit small businesses south of Chambers Street in Manhattan that have reported sharp drop in number of customers since terrorist attacks on Sept 11; TV spots, in addition to radio and print ads, were created by Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners for Alliance for Downtown New York; contributions by other agencies noted (M)

headline: Conflicting Tales Paint Blurry Picture of Siege
abstract: Article describe siege of Taliban stronghold of Mazar-i-Sharif and its capture by forces of Northern Alliance (M)

headline: Banks in Europe Scramble to Fill Automated Tellers With Euros by Midnight
abstract: Banks across Europe to embark on frenzied money switch on Dec 31, as they try to load most of their 200,000 automated bank tellers with new euro notes before stroke of midnight; euro coins and notes will become legal tender in 12 European nations immediately after midnight, on Jan 1, and they will replace national currencies by end of Feb; banks admit to last-minute anxieties even though they have long been preparing for changeover (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: U.S. Decision On New Drug Lifts Schering
abstract: Schering-Plough shares rise after Food and Drug

headline: World Briefing | Outer Space: Workout For Spacewalkers
abstract: Russian cosmonautsMikhail Tyurin and Vladimir Dezhurov, aboard International Space Station, take six-hour space walk setting up new equipment for Japanese Space Agency(S)

headline: Iran's Judiciary Sends Moderate Member of Parliament to Prison
abstract: Iran's hard-line judiciary sends Hossein Loqmanian, pro-reform member of Parliament, to prison for 13 months for insulting judiciary (S)

headline: Economists Make It Official: U.S. Is in Recession
abstract: National Bureau of Economic Research concludes that US economy entered recession March; economists disagree about timing and strength of rebound that will follow, but consensus anticipates its start in first half of 2002 (M)

headline: Vouchers and Charters Fuel U.S. Debate on School Choice : More Quality, Less Equality?
abstract: WASHINGTON—  The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to rule on the constitutionality of a publicly financed voucher program in Ohio that helps parents pay their children's tuition at religious schools. The high court's ruling, expected by next summer, will constitute a milestone in the heated debate in the United States over what has come to be known as "school choice."

headline: U.S. PLANES BOMB TALIBAN COMPOUND IN KANDAHAR AREA
abstract: American warplanes bomb compound southeast of Kandahar, Afghanistan, that Pentagon says was used by leaders of Taliban, Al Qaeda and Al Wafa, Islamic foundation accused of terrorist activities; Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says compound was damaged and that fatalities were likely; officials are unsure whether Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar or Osama bin Laden were present; say they focus search for leaders on Kandahar region and narrow band of cave-riddled mountainous terrain; Taliban aide Mullah Abdul Salam Zaeef reportedly says Omar is safe; says he and other Taliban leaders were not in compound; officials say Pentagon has identified 40 Afghan labs and industrial facilities, some in areas still controlled by Taliban and Al Qaeda, that might have potential to make biological or chemical weapons; Gen Tommy R Franks says tests continue to determine how sites were used, news conference; map; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Philippines: Defending The First Husband
abstract: Philippines Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo asks prosecutors to investigate corruption charges against her husband, Jose Miguel Arroyo (S)

headline: Sales Continue to Pick Up, Despite Start of Bombing
abstract: Americans tentatively return to malls and movies over three-day holiday weekend and consumer spending improves slightly even as attacks on Afghanistan begin; photo (M)

headline: Islamist Brings Out Followers Against U.S.
abstract: Mullah Ghaffor Hydari of Pakistan's most militant religious party objects to house arrest of Mullah Fazlur Rehman, pro-Taliban leader in Peshawar, Pakistan; move expands Hydari's influence; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Cocaine Ring Smashed
abstract: Colombian police report dismantling ring believed to have smuggled 75 tons of cocaine to United States in last two years; arrest seven suspected smugglers; US seeks extradition of men, indicted by Florida grand jury (S)

headline: Two Promoted By Times Co.
abstract: The New York Times Company has announced the promotion of two corporate executives.     R. Anthony Benten, assistant treasurer, has been named treasurer. James C. Lessersohn, who had been vice president and treasurer, is now vice president for finance and corporate development.

headline: LVMH Completes Donna Karan Deal
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessey Louis Vuitton completes its $243 million acquisition of Donna Karan International Inc (S)

headline: EL PASO ENERGY TO BUY GAS ASSETS FOR $283 MILLION
abstract: El Paso Energy Partners LP, owner of natural gas and oil pipelines in Gulf of Mexico, agrees to buy gas-processing plant and stake in offshore pipelines in two separate transactions valued at $283.5 million; publicly traded partnership, which was set up by El Paso Corp, acquires Chaco gas processing plant in New Mexico from consortium of banks for $198.5 million; El Paso Energy Partners also acquires 50 percent in Deepwater Holdings LLC it does not already own from El Paso Corp for $85 million (S)

headline: Brazil's Unlikely Rising Star in Politics: a Woman
abstract: Roseana Sarney, unofficial presidential candidate and Maranhao State governor, has emerged as unlikely rising star of Brazilian politics; has unnerved Brazil's macho political establishment and carved out growing base of support by mixing personal charm with appeals for fairness; she comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: Nobel Peace Prize Is Awarded to Annan and U.N.
abstract: Norwegian Nobel Committee awards Nobel Peace Prize to UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan and to UN itself; decision, made on Sept 28, after terrorist attacks against US, comes as Annan and UN take prominent role in forging international campaign against global terrorism and as key to building post-Taliban Afghanistan; chairman Gunnar Berge says Nobel committee wishes, in its centenary year, to proclaim UN as route to global peace; Annan welcomes 'great encouragement;' photos; his predecessor Dag Hammarskjold won posthumous Nobel in 1961; citation lauds Annan for bringing 'new life' to UN; Pres Bush telephones congratulations (M)

headline: Two French Radio Journalists and a German Are Killed in Taliban Ambush of a Rebel Force
abstract: Two French radio journalists and German magazine writer are killed when Taliban forces ambush Northern Alliance forces they are traveling with in northern Afghanistan; they are Johanne Sutton of Radio France International, Pierre Billaud of Radio Tele Luxembourg, and Volker Handloik, freelance writer for Stern magazine; fourth journalist, who survived attack, says group never imagined they were in any danger as they set out to inspect area thought to be free of Taliban; photo (M)

headline: Global Warming Impasse Is Broken
abstract: Final details of Kyoto Protocol emerge from talks in Morocco, after four years of negotiations to curb global warming (M)

headline: William Jovanovich, 81, Longtime Publishing Chief, Dies
abstract: William Jovanovich, 81, longtime publishin

headline: A Country on the Brink of Default? It May Not Hurt Much
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer article on robust performance of most emerging-markets debt this year despite threatened default by Argentina; graph (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Housing Construction: Nov.

headline: Ad-Libbing His Way Into Trouble
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill, who developed reputation for speaking his mind and straying beyond Bush administration's line on numerous issues, has found himself playing less central role in economic policy making than his recent predecessors; has had his leash shortened, and several other administration officials have also encroached on Treasury's turf; administration says that O'Neill is still integral part of administration's economic brain trust, but officials are also urging O'Neill to become more of team player, something that could prove difficult for voluble and occasionally irritable O'Neill; photo (M)

headline: the end user / a voice for the consumer: Apple Users Reply
abstract: PARIS—  A couple of weeks ago, I reported that the public relations staff at Apple Computer had declined my requests for a hands-on demonstration of why people should buy Macintosh computers rather than Windows-based machines. So I invited readers who use Macs to make their case.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Elec Sells Airline Business Unit
abstract: Elec Communications Corp sells its Airline Ventures subsidiary to management for $500,000; Airline Ventures operates Internet site that enables airline crew members to buy travel-related products (S)

headline: Norway Will Cut Oil Output; Last Holdout on OPEC Effort
abstract: Norway will cut oil output by 150,000 barrels a day; announcement moves OPEC and non-OPEC nations closer to an agreement, but one that still seems to fall short of cartel's demands (M)

headline: For Japan's Would-Be Reformer, Little Traction
abstract: Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi is trying to lead Japan out of political and economic mire, and pledges deep and true reform, but cannot seem to get his own party to do anything; is blunt about whom he holds responsible for past stagnation: hidebound bureaucrats, central bankers, ruling-party elders and other keepers of status quo; leads political party that is suspicious of him and of any change in system that has given it near-monopoly of power for decades (M)

headline: U.S. Campaign On 2nd Front: Public Opinion
abstract: Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld will leave this week for Russia and nations near Afghanistan as Bush administration strives to hold together coalition for military campaign against Osama bin Laden and Taliban; Gen Tommy Franks meets with Uzbek leaders, saying US military activity may change from day to day; Sen Carl Levin says in interview that US may have to add to special operations forces to intensify pressure; British Sec Geoff Hoon, in Washington, says allies should make clear that they are 'taking account of Ramadan' holy month to avoid further strains with Muslim countries; photos; Rumsfeld observes that Taliban and Al Qaeda are 'unlikely to take a holiday' from trying to kill Americans; Prime Min Tony Blair tells Britons not to forget horror of Sept 11 attacks (M)

headline: 2 Private Firms Taking Stake in Casualty Insurer
abstract: Warburg Pincus and Hellman & Friedman plan to invest $750 million in Arch Capital Group, casualty and property insurer based in Bermuda; Warburg is going to invest $500 million, while Hellman will invest $250 million (M)

headline: Rift Grows Among Anti-Taliban Leadership
abstract: Split appears within political leadership of Northern Alliance that has potential to sap alliance's ability to govern territory it has seized, retard its military operations and delay formation of post-Taliban government; younger, pro-Western, religious moderates are led by foreign minister, Dr Abdullah Abdullah, interior minister, Yunos Qanooni, and Anwari, leader of ethnic Hazara forces; older, religious conservatives, who are more skeptical of West, are led by alliance's president, Burhanuddin Rabbani, and one of its more senior Pashtun leaders, Abdul Rasul Sayyaf; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 10th Fed Rate Cut This Year Raises Hopes for a Recovery
abstract: Market Place column on Federal Reserve's decision to lower federal funds rate by half-point, to 2 percent, holds Fed's decision spurred rally in stocks and hopes of investors that economy will recover (M)

headline: Finding the Presence of Anthrax
abstract: Sources: Dr. Stuart Isaacs and Dr. Elizabeth Colston, both of the University of Pennsylvania

headline: Raises for Public Servants
abstract: Jerry Frankel letter comments on Tom Redburn's Oct 28 column questioning why public's recognition of value of everyday workers in wake of Sept 11 attacks has not resulted in change of public policy, including higher wages

headline: Oil Money Pulls Sudan Out of Its Isolation and Toward an Uncertain Future
abstract: Sudan, one-time shelter for terrorist leader Osama bin Laden, is being pulled out of its isolation as foreign nationals flock to Khartoum to pursue oil deals; hard-line government is now split between those favoring more openness and those clinging to uncompromising Islamic vision; photos; map; nation has been torn for 18 years by civil war between Arab Muslim northerners and non-Muslim blacks in south; Pres Omar Hassan Ahmad al-Bashir, who seized power is 1989, leads moderates who would rebuild ties with US and other countries; jailing of hard-line Islamic figures noted, as well as domestic forces pressing for moderation (M)

headline: Citigroup to Shed Part of Travelers Unit in Stock Sale
abstract: Citigroup chief exec Sanford I Weill, nearly four years after creating world's largest financial services company by bringing together huge insurance, banking and brokerage businesses, says that he is jettisoning most of Travelers Insurance; for Weill, who took control of Travelers in 1993 and made it his flagship company, planned split represents sharp reversal and rare admission that one of his many acquisitions have not worked out; Weill plans to sell 20 percent of commercial, auto and home insurance business, known as Travelers Property Casualty Corp, through stock offering early next year that analysts expect to raise $4 billion to $6 billion; Weill photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Sally Andrews was named to the new post of vice president and direct marketing director at Cole & Weber/Red Cell, Seattle, part of the Red Cell unit of the WPP Group.

headline: AMERICAN SOYBEAN EXPORTER BUYS UNIT IN ARGENTINA
abstract: Bunge, exporter of soybeans, acquires La Plata Cereal unit of Andre & Cie for about $70 million in cash and debt; acquisition will make Bunge largest soybean crusher and second-largest exporter in Argentina (S)

headline: New Bcom3 Units In Multicultural Hue
abstract: Bcom3 Group in Chicago forms two divisions specializing in multicultural advertising and media services that will handle assignments with billings estimated at $330 million; will take 20 percent stake in Double Platinum, New York agency specializing in campaigns aimed at gay and lesbian customers as part of initiative, making it first large mainstream agency company to announce such step in that market (Advertising column) (M)

headline: De Klerk's Ex-Wife Found Slain In Apartment Near Cape Town
abstract: Marike del

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle Chief Warns On Outlook
abstract: Oracle Corp lowers its financial projections for its fiscal second quarter; photo (S)

headline: Race Strains a Mexican Campaign
abstract: Lazaro Cardenas, Mexican senator running for governor of Michoacan State, raises charge of racism against campaign of his opponent, Alfredo Anaya of Institutional Revolutionary Party, which seems to have focused on Cardenas's Cuban-born wife, Mayra Coffigny, who is black; Anaya dismisses charge; photo; map (M)

headline: Stocks End Mixed, With Nasdaq Higher Once Again
abstract: Technology stocks rose for the third straight day today after Dell Computer issued a reassuring earnings outlook, but they closed well off their highs.

headline: Economic Scene; The stimulus package should fix the unemployment insurance program first.
abstract: Alan B Kruger 'Economic Scene' column suggests any economic stimulus package should upgrading unemployment insurance program first; backs legislation sponsored by Reprs Benjamin Cardin, Amo Houghton and six others that would do much more to strengthen safety net than would be Pres Bush's proposal to extend unemployment benefits by 13 weeks for eligible workers; photo (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co renews marketing agreement for five years with Universal Studios; will provide products like film and cameras exclusively to Universal theme parks in US (S)

headline: HAYES LEMMERZ TO CLOSE AUTO WHEEL PLANT IN KENTUCKY
abstract: Hayes Lemmerz International Inc, leading maker of automobile wheels, will close plant in Bowling Green, Ky, by mid-2002 and eliminate about 235 jobs to reduce costs as vehicle output falls (S)

headline: A Pakistani City Disapproves, but Mildly
abstract: Article discusses reaction in Peshawar, Pakistan, to US air strikes against Afghanistan; pro-Taliban students protest vociferously, but other objections are muted; photo (M)

headline: Coors Earnings Rise 13%
abstract: Adolph Coors Co says third-quarter profit increased 13 percent, to $38.9 million; sales fell 3.4 percent, to $634.7 million (S)

headline: Concealing the Names Of E-Mail Recipients
abstract: Q. I often need to send an e-mail message to a group of people but don't want each recipient to be able to see all other recipients' names and addresses. I can't find a Bcc line in the Outlook Express window, so how can I avoid revealing the addresses?    A. Some e-mail programs handle Bcc's, or blind carbon copies, differently from other programs. (Normally the Bcc line in the header of an e-mail message program allows you to hide the names and addresses of your mail recipients. Any addresses entered in the To or Cc -- carbon copy -- lines on the message will be visible to all recipients.)

headline: Thai Oil Stock Offering Is Much in Demand
abstract: Foreign demand is unexpectedly strong for initial public offering of Thailand's oil and gas company, PTT; government sells about one-third of PTT, raising about $725 million (M)

headline: U.S. Walks a Tightrope On Terrorism in Israel
abstract: White House declares that 'Israel has a right to defend herself,' but denies that Pres Bush had effectively encouraged Prime Min Ariel Sharon to order military strikes in Palestinian-controlled territory (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Soccer Team's Shares Fall
abstract: Shares of Italian soccer team Juventus fall 6 percent on first day of trading (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Television Concern Cuts Jobs
abstract: NTL, British cable television provider, will eliminate 2,000 jobs, bringing jobs cuts for year to 8,800 or nearly one-third of work force (S)

headline: Pay Dispute Turns Violent in France
abstract: Employees of Moulinex, bankrupt French appliance maker, set fire to one building at company's microwave oven plant in western France and threaten to blow up another unless they are granted extra severance pay when their jobs are eliminated later in month; about 4,400 jobs are to be eliminated as company is liquidated, following court order to dissolve company after 69 years in business; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Stockbroker Is Arrested
abstract: India arrests Harshad Mehta, stockbroker accused in $1.3 billion 1992 stock market scandal, and his two brothers, Ashwini and Sudhir; charges them with misappropriating millions of shares of 90 different companies (S)

headline: Computers Hit Around Globe By New Form Of Old Virus
abstract: New version of malicious computer program known as Nimda infects world's computer networks, including New York Times Internet service; program is spread primarily through e-mail messages (S)

headline: Top Companies Issuing Debt At a Fast Pace
abstract: Blue-chip corporations issue torrent of debt since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; investors, disenchanted with stocks, inhale bond offerings at pace 31.5 percent higher than same eleven-week period last year; low interest rates encourage corporate borrowing from public sources, and banks have pruned their lending to corporations by 30 percent since last year; analysts' expectations before terrorist attacks was of exact opposite of what has materialized (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Deal Lifts Parthus
abstract: American depository receipts of Parthus Technologies PLC rise 22.7 percent, to $5.90, after company, semiconductor designer in Ireland, forms partnership with Motorola Inc; two companies will work together on chips that extend battery power in wireless devices; Parthus says third-quarter loss widened to $3.25 million from $2.28 million year ago; graph (S)

headline: German Bank Is in Talks With Enron To Buy a Unit
abstract: German bank Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale is reportedly in talks to purchase Wessex Water from Enron Corp (S)

headline: Professional Women From Afghanistan Meet to Press for Full Rights in Their Country
abstract: Group of 40 prominent Afghan women gather in Brussels at European Parliament to claim crucial role in rebuilding their country after years of living in silence at home or frustration abroad; group demands full restoration of rights as citizens and participation in drafting new laws and constitution; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Lays Off 15% Of Staff
abstract: Napster, Internet music service, says it is laying off 16 employees, or 15 percent of its work force, to cut costs; also says it is redeploying some employees in anticipation of still-unscheduled start of for-pay service but declines to say how its remaining work force will be realigned (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Expects Profit
abstract: France's Credit Agricole expects to post profit of about $1.3 billion for 2001, up 9 percent from levels year ago, and expects 5 to 10 percent rise in 2002 profits from 2001 (S)

headline: Claims for Unemployment Benefits Reach a Nine-Year High
abstract: Number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits soared last week to nine-year high as economic damage spread from terrorist attacks; Labor Department reports initial jobless claims rose by 71,000, to 528,000, in week ended Sept 29; Commerce Department reports new orders placed at manufacturers were little changed in August as inventories declined for seventh consecutive month; factory orders were valued at $322.6 billion, after falling 0.1 percent in July; graphs (M)

headline: Bill Maher Still Secure In ABC Slot, At Least Now
abstract: ABC is uneasy about Bill Maher, host of irreverent late night talk show Politically Incorrect, who stirred uproar with stand that suicide hijackers were fearless; has considered ousting him from time to time for mediocre ratings, but is unlikely to do that now since it would be seen as buckling under; photo (M)

headline: Helping Software Companies Be as Open as They Want to Be
abstract: Open-source programming is gaining ground among software companies, and even Microsoft Corp, which intitially regarded open source as threat to intellectual property, now acknowledges its merits, including community-building and better approaches to fixing errors and handling feedback; CollabNet and VA Linux Systems now offer services and systems that they say can ease development of almost any kind of software with code that might be open, closed or a mix, meaning some elements could be freely inspected and modified, while others could be for insiders' eyes only; drawing (M)

headline: TV's, DVD's: All Yours, But First Do the Math
abstract: David Leonhardt Economic View column deplores television ads for Rent-a-Center, largest US retailer in category known as 'rent to own,' which feature John Madden, television football commentator; notes that monthly payments to Rent-a-Center for electronic entertainment goods total many times regular retail prices; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Is Taking a Back Seat In Latest Talks on Climate
abstract: More than 150 countries will begin 12 days of talks in Morocco on October 29 on global warming, with US in attendance but out of spotlight; will seek final agreement on Kyoto Protocol to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, believed to cause global warming (S)

headline: Before and After Bush and Putin's Banter, No Agreement on Missile Defense
abstract: President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia ended their three-day summit meeting today with warm jokes and a pledge to bring stability to Afghanistan, but no discernible progress on amending the treaty that constrains Washington's plans to test an antimissile system.    After 24 hours on Mr. Bush's ranch here, punctuated by hours of private discussions and a barbecue dinner on Tuesday night that included lessons in how to dance the Cotton-Eyed Joe, the two presidents emerged this morning to visit the local high school.

headline: Greenspan Sees Economic Slide As Temporary
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan says damage to economy from terrorist attacks should be temporary and that US will soon start benefiting again from advances in technology that helped fuel boom of late 1990's, address to Joint Economic Committee of Congress; describes short-term economic outlook as murky; reiterates his position that cutting capital gains tax will not have much immediate effect on economy; says he continues to view cutting capital gains, or eliminating them, as good long-term policy; says research at Fed suggests that best way of providing economy with short-term stimulus is to provide tax breaks for business investment in new equipment by allowing companies to write off much of cost of investment immediately; gives cautious endorsement to Bush administration's proposal to cap liability of insurance industry on claims from future terrorist attacks (M)

headline: New York City May Issue More Notes, Mayor Says
abstract: DIARY New York City May Issue More Notes, Mayor Says  The $1 billion in one-year notes that New York City sold last week to help finance recovery from the attack on the World Trade Center may be just the beginning.

headline: Corporate Conformity
abstract: To the Editor:    For years, corporations have equated diversity with gender, race and ethic background while also preserving conformity of thought, values and perhaps even morals. The conclusion that one may draw is that promotions are also based on like thinking. In other words, management promotes in its own image. This is why changes in management style, goals and personnel relationships will be glacial at best.    PAUL R. RESNICK  Cary, N.C., Nov. 18

headline: U.S. Trade Panel Backs Putting Hefty Duties on Imported Steel
abstract: Federal trade panel recommends hefty duties on imported steel, making it likely that Bush administration will enact most sweeping protections for US steel makers since 1980's; prices of vehicles, appliances and other steel products would likely rise; proposed import tariffs of from 5 percent to 40 percent would reward workers and businesses in West Virginia, Pennsylvania and other swing states seen as crucial to winning presidential elections; quotas are also proposed; photos (M)

headline: Where Smugglers Once Roamed, Toothpaste Hardly Squeezes Through
abstract: Barren lawless terrain between Hayatabad, Pakistan, and Afghan border, which Pashtun tribal leaders hold sway, now has Pakistani troops on patrol, hoping to cut off escape routes of Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda; photo; people in chaotic bazaar along Grand Trunk Road describe troops convoys as soldiers patrol rugged mountains where smugglers usually roam (M)

headline: Saudi Prisoner Called a Chief For Al Qaeda
abstract: US officials identify Saudi, Abdul Aziz, as highest ranking Al Qaeda figure captured in Afghanistan and taken into US custody; he is now aboard helicopter carrier Pelileu; US says that Wafa, Saudi-based Islamic charity Aziz heads, has funneled money to Al Qaeda terrorists (S)

headline: New Leaders in Kabul, Pledges of Support and the Cleanup Operation
abstract: Overview of day's events in war against terrorism (M)

headline: Announcement Of a U.S. Reward
abstract: Text of US announcement of $25 million reward for capture of Osama bin Laden and other leaders of Al Qaeda terrorist network (S)

headline: Private Sector; Perot's Résumé Addendum: Hedge Fund Manager
abstract: Perot Investments, H Ross Perot's private money management firm, will open two hedge funds to outside investors; photo (S)

headline: Cairo Journal; A Tree Drooping With Its Ancient Burden of Faith
abstract: Coptic Christians make pilgrimage to El Matariya, village on Cairo's northern outskirts, to touch Virgin Tree, under whose boughs Mary and Joseph and infant Jesus are believed to have rested during their travels in Egypt 2,000 years ago; photo; map (M)

headline: 2 Weak Forecasts in Technology Push Equities Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at 9,766.45, down 128.36 points; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 17.69 points, to 1,119.38; Nasdaq composite index falls 64.87 points, to 1,946.51; graph (S)

headline: U.S. Official Sees Russia in Oil Catbird Seat
abstract: Energy Sec Spencer Abraham visits Russia and says Russia has taken on crucial importance as world energy producer and its role will grow even larger when Russian government clears way for extensive foreign investment in its energy sector; visit comes as OPEC is pressing Russia and other major nonmember oil producers to fall in line with its plans to prop up prices by cutting production significantly; domestic investment in Russian energy sector is booming, but critical mass of foreign investment has been slow in coming because Russia has not made firm commitments on tax rates to be assessed; photo (M)

headline: A Year Only As a Best Seller At No. 1 Chain
abstract: Barnes & Noble begins to remove books from its best-seller list after 12-month limit; says goal is to give new books prominence; has contributed indirectly to soaring best seller sales by promoting and discounting titles to lure customers (M)

headline: Quarterly Net Drops 71% at Wackenhut
abstract: Wackenhut Corp, No. 2 provider of security guards, says profit fell 71 percent in third quarter even as revenue rose at all of its businesses; net income falls to $900,000, or 6 cents a share (S)

headline: Deal for COR Continues Merger Trend In Biotech
abstract: Millennium Pharmaceuticals to buy COR Therapeutics for about $2 billion in stock in one of largest mergers of biotechnology companies; COR stock soars, while Millennium stock plunges (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Long-Delayed Chip Ready To Ship
abstract: Sarnoff Corp says it is ready to begin selling commercial quantities of Acadia, high-speed graphics and video microchip that it had originally hoped to have ready for marketing year ago (S)

headline: Seeing a Hit In Subtitles
abstract: Half-dozen foreign films debut toward end of 2001, hoping to get Oscar nominations beyond Foreign Language Film award; some have aspirations for Best Film nomination; photos (M)

headline: Canada's Global City (Not Toronto)
abstract: canada's global city (not toront

headline: Moderate Re-elected in Ulster; Vote Advances Peace Accord
abstract: Moderate Protestant leader David Trimble overcomes blocking tactics of hard-line Protestant opponents and is re-elected first minister of Northern Ireland Assembly; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Auto Sales Remain Strong As Incentives Are Reduced  Auto sales remained strong for much of November but slowed after Thanksgiving, when automakers started to restrict their interest-free financing offers.    The pace of auto sales dropped to an annual selling rate of 18 million vehicles in November, down from 21.3 million in October, but up 9.5 percent from last November, according to Ward's AutoInfoBankData. Year-end projections are for 17 million vehicles, just behind last year's record. [Page C4.]

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: More Women's Remains Found
abstract: Skeletal remains of five women are found in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, near field where three bodies were found earlier; police will not say if deaths are linked to 57 young women raped and murdered in city during 1990's; human rights groups plan demonstrations (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Foreigners Remain Jailed
abstract: Greek judge orders 14 British and Dutch plane enthusiasts detained since Nov 8 on charges of taking photos and notes of military jets' movements during their plane-spotting trip to Greece be held until panel of judges is formed to review case (S)

headline: Wheeling, Dealing and Making Side Deals; Vow to Scrap Latin Textile Deals Wins Vote on Bush Trade Powers
abstract: Rep Jim DeMint wins agreement to bolster textile manufacturers in his South Carolina district in exchange for switching his vote in final seconds, giving Bush administration 215-214 victory on legislation strengthening presidential powers over trade agreements; prominent Republicans promise him cancellation of textile export preferences Congress granted Caribbean, Central American and Andean nations during Clinton administration; this would gut central provision of Caribbean Basin Trade Preference Act designed to help some of world's poorest nations sell more textile and apparel products to US; photos (M)

headline: Trade Group Predicts Turnaround in Chip Sales Next Year
abstract: Trade Group

headline: General Gives Uzbek Leader Warm Words And Spotlight
abstract: Gen Tommy Franks, commander of US mlitary campaign in Afghanistan, meet with Uzbek Pres Islam Karimov in Tashkent to cement cooperation; photo; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Exodus Says Its Stock May Be Worthless
abstract: Exodus Communications, which operates Web sites, says it is likely that its common stock will have no value even if it finds new investors or is acquired (S)

headline: An Economy Keeping Its Guard Up
abstract: Impact of heavier security on US business in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks and anthrax incidents seems modest because of slowing economy itself; steps like added hours of worktime add significant costs and reduce productivity in already slowing economy, but economists say phenomenon is likely to be less of drag than they first feared; photos (M)

headline: To Bless, to Listen, to Comfort
abstract: Msgr Donald Sakano writes My Job column on being pastor of Church of the Holy Innocents and Church of Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary in Manhattan; photo (M)

headline: Fiat Auto Chief Resigns in Midst of a Revamping
abstract: Roberto Testore resigns as chief executive of Fiat Auto as Fiat SpA announces restructuring plan that includes closing or overhauling 18 factories and laying off 6,000 workers; photo (M)

headline: Bin Laden Aide Reported Killed By U.S. Bombs
abstract: American bombing raid near Kabul said to kill one of Osama bin Laden's most trusted lieutenants, Muhammad Atef; American officials suspect him of being planner of terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon; say his death would deprive bin Laden of important strategist and be important success in global campaign that has curtailed Al Qaeda's ability to mount large-scale terrorist operations; say Taliban's recent loss of territory has cost Al Qaeda haven in which it has trained thousands of operatives over last decade, as well as ability to move freely out of Afghanistan and communicate with terrorist cells around world; warn that individual Al Qaeda operatives and their associates in decentralized group might still be able to launch smaller terrorist attacks; photo (M)

headline: Manila's Muslim Policy Left in Tatters by Revolt
abstract: MANILA—  Nur Misuari was once the shining example of the success of the Philippines in integrating its Muslim minority into a largely Christian nation.

headline: Technology Briefing | Research: Heart Drug Shows Promise
abstract: Alexion Pharmaceuticals says pexelizumab, drug it is developing, prevents serious heart attacks and cognitive impairment in patients who have had coronary bypass surgery (S)

headline: Qatar Oil Minister Is Predicting A Price of $20 to $22 a Barrel
abstract: Qatar Oil Min Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah says crude oil prices will probably average $20 to $22 per barrel in 2002, level that will help economies of energy-consuming nations; benchmark price of OPEC for oil has averaged $23.18 in 2001 as group sought to keep prices between $22 and $28 per barrel; OPEC agrees to cut production for fourth time since February to reduce oil production to arrest decline in prices; photo (M)

headline: Allies Building Force to Keep Order in a Vacuum
