abstract: Western nations rush to assemble international force to keep order in Afghan areas wrested from Taliban; 160 British marines and American Special Operations troops fly to airfield north of Kabul and begin preparing it for shipments of food; American forces seek to make contact with Northern Alliance officers who forward credible claims of capturing some Taliban commanders and at least one high-ranking Al Qaeda leader; prisoners could provide valuable intelligence about location of Osama bin Laden and Mullah Muhammad Omar, chief of Taliban; country appears deeply fractured, with rival warlords filling power vacuum left by departing Taliban and with Mullah Omar vowing to fight on and 'destroy America'; America's allies signal willingness to fill power vacuum; France, Canada, Turkey and Jordan offer to send troops to maintain security in Afghanistan; Bangladesh and Malaysia said to be preparing to contribute as well; sense of urgency stems from fact that Taliban's resistance in northern Afghanistan has collapsed more quickly than expected, raising fears that unstable situation might interfere with delivery of badly needed aid shipments; photo (L)

headline: Ringing Everywhere But the Cash Register
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin Market Insight column interviews Michael Ching communications equipment industry analyst at Merrill Lynch, on prospects for cellular telephone sector; photo (M)

headline: Looking for bin Laden, Staving Off Chaos, Domestic Disquiet
abstract: Overview of developments, November 13, in US war against terrorism (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; For Polaroid, the bad news seems to be the only news.
abstract: Market Place column on bleak outlook for Polaroid Corp; stock, which traded at $14.19 a year ago, closes at 49 cents a share (M)

headline: Stepping Out on My Own
abstract: The Boss column by David L Steward, chief executive of World Wide Technologies, describes achieving goal of owning and operating own business; photo (S)

headline: Microsoft Aims to Settle Suits by Equipping 12,500 Schools
abstract: Microsoft filed a proposal in federal court today that could remove another of its legal headaches -- more than 100 class-action antitrust suits alleging that it overcharged consumers.

headline: Climate Talks Come Down To Haggling Over Details
abstract: Negotiators from more than 160 countries meeting in Morocco rush to complete work on Kyoto Protocol, pioneering climate treaty that would require cuts in greenhouses gases (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Parts Maker Plans Cuts
abstract: NSK Ltd, auto parts maker, will close or sell four factories in Europe and one in Japan (S)

headline: The Taliban Retreats
abstract: A timeline chronicling the progress of the war thus far.

headline: Price Haggling Is Intense Among Insurers This Year
abstract: Insurers face limited availability and sharply higher prices for reinsurance, on which they depend to limit their own risks, in wake of terrorist attacks; are able to pass most of increases on to corporate customers, but regulators limit how much they can pass on to small businesses and consumers; photo (M)

headline: Canada Pushes Broad Antiterror Measure, Alarming Some Who Fear Erosion of Rights
abstract: Canadian government introduces most stringent antiterrorism legislation in country's history, allowing preventive arrests and broader electronic surveillance, and granting power to compel testimony during investigations, setting aside right to remain silent; Foreign Minister John Manley says legislation, combined with new regulations stepping up border operations and revamping immigration procedures since September 11 attacks in US, represents first step toward dealing with new sense of danger across North America; legal experts, civil rights advocates and others voice concern; fear erosion of rights; three Canadian warships head for Arabian Sea to join American-led coalition in military action against Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: Former French Finance Minister Is Acquitted in Forgery Trial
abstract: French court acquits former Finance Min Dominique Strauss-Kahn of forgery charges, finding before trial that he had done work he billed for; prosecutor admits he has no evidence of fraudulent motive; ruling is second serious setback for new breed of corruption-busting investigating magistrates in recent months and could dampen what some critics call excess of judiciary zeal (M)

headline: Rather Reports Another War, This Time in a Windbreaker
abstract: CBS News anchorman Dan Rather begins reporting from Kabul, Afghanistan (M)

headline: Plan Backed to End Diamond Trade That Fuels War
abstract: Government and industry representatives from dozens of nations agree, after over year of talks, on framework for system to certify legitimately traded diamonds and stamp out market for stones mined by rebels in war zones; leave few issues unresolved; human rights groups, while endorsing system, say enforcement mechanisms are inadequate; plan must now be approved by United Nations General Assembly; South African Min Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, who chairs talks, expects system to begin almost immediately in som nations and be function by end of 2002 in others taking part (M)

headline: Flat-Screen Monitors That Come With a Change of View
abstract: Planar offers two new flat-screen computer monitors that can be turned 90 degrees, providing choice of landscape or portrait viewing; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Strike At Volkswagen Off, for Now
abstract: Striking metal workers at Volkswagen's biggest Brazilian factory provisionally return to work after company offers to reverse 3,000 layoffs in exchange for 15 percent reduction in work week and voluntary buyouts for 700 employees (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Foot-And-Mouth Controls Lifted
abstract: Britain lifts livestock controls on large swaths of Northern England, leaving fewer than five percent of affected farms still under curbs imposed to combat foot-and-mouth disease (S)

headline: Rendezvous Of Suspects In Hickackings Is Investigated
abstract: Spain probes whether Mohamed Atta, suspected of leading Sept 11 suicide attacks, met with others involved in attacks on trips to Spain in Jan and July; top Spanish police official Juan Cotino comments, interview (M)

headline: Judge Vows Aid Workers' Trial Will Be Fair
abstract: Trial of eight Western aid workers charged with spreading Christianity resumes in Kabul, Afghanistan; Noor Muhammad Saqib, chief justice of country's Supreme Court assures them they will be treated fairly despite possibility of American air strikes in retaliation for September 11 terrorist attacks in US; workers, including Americans Heather Mercer and Danya Curry, were employed by Shelter Now International, German-run aid organization (S)

headline: AUTONATION FACES LIABILITY IN ANC BANKRUPTCY
abstract: AutoNation, automobile retailer based in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, says that it could face financial obligations of $50 million to $150 million under bankruptcy filing of ANC Rental Corp (S)

headline: In a Global Tide, Beware the Undertow
abstract: William J Holstein reviews Diane Coyle's book Paradoxes of Prosperity: Why the New Capitalism Benefits All, in which she argues that globalization has multiple benefits but acknowledges that it also generates resentment; she believes that economic progress in poor countries will discourage terrorism and extremism; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Late Surge in Holiday Sales May Have Lifted Retailers  A surge of last-minute shopping may have given the nation's retailers and the economy a small boost, according to several reports on holiday sales.    The late sales gains will not add much to retailers' profits because most of the increases came after deep price cuts. Still, analysts said the discounts that moved merchandise out of the stores should be good for the overall economy. [Page A1.]

headline: AMC, a Movie Chain, Will Sell Bonds
abstract: AMC Entertainment Inc, biggest publicly traded cinema chain in US, prepares to sell first bonds to be issued by theater chain since investors lost $1.7 billion in three-year wave of bankruptcies by other cinema companies (M)

headline: HEWLETT-PACKARD IS DEALT A BLOW ON COMPAQ DEAL
abstract: Family foundation that is Hewlett-Packard's largest shareholder says it will vote against company's proposed merger with Compaq Computer; move by David and Lucile Packard Foundation unites heirs of founders of company and family foundations against $24 billion deal; Walter Hewlett, one of heirs, is tring to persuade other large shareholders to oppose merger; 18 percent of Hewlett-Packard shares now united in opposition does not kill deal but it is setback for boards and management teams of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq; if deal fails it could bring downfall of Hewlett-Packard's chairwoman Carleton S Fiorina; chart (M)

headline: Palm's Shrinking Lead
abstract: The Palm operating system is still the market-leading software for hand-held computing devices. But among makers of hand-held hardware, Palm Inc.'s lead has slipped significantly in the last year. In August 2000, the company had a 70 percent share of the device market, based on unit sales, according to the research firm NPD Intelect. By last August, Palm's share was only 51 percent.      A big chunk of that market share was taken by Sony, which is No. 3 and rising fast. Like Handspring, currently No. 2, Sony uses the same operating system as Palm's hand-held devices.

headline: Drop in Housing Construction, At 1.3%, Is Below Expectations
abstract: Commerce Dept reports that starts of new housing fell less than expected in October; report suggests that home construction industry continues to buttress economy; dept reports that work began in October on 1.552 million home at annual race, down 1.3 percent from 1.572 million in September; graph (S)

headline: Congress Reviews EchoStar Plan to Buy DirecTV
abstract: EchoStar chief executive, Charles Ergen, and other witnesses at Congressional hearing are questioned about possible loss of competition in satellite television industry if EchoStar completes $32 billion purchase of DirecTV (M)

headline: Covanta Shares Fall Because of Cash Woes
abstract: Shares of Covanta Energy Corp fall 60 percent in one day after power producer says that it has limited available cash and is negotiating with its creditors for covenant waivers (S)

headline: NOMURA IN TALKS FOR STAKE IN U.S. INVESTMENT BANK
abstract: Nomura Holdings is in talks to buy stake in Thomas Weisel Partners, which invests in and provides underwriting and merger advice to computer-related companies (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Nauru: Taking More Asylum Seekers, And Money
abstract: Island of Nauru agrees to take in more asylum seekers turned away at sea by Australia, in echange for which Australia will increase its payment to Nauru to $15 million, total amounting to more than half tiny island's gross domestic product; number of people held in detention camp in Nauru is now 1,200 (S)

headline: British Defense Secretary Says Troops for Afghanistan Are Being Taken Off High Alert
abstract: Britain's Defense Sec Geoff Hoon says most of 6,400 British troops, placed on 48-hour alert for action in Afghanistan, will have readiness downgraded to week; says 400 troops from parachute regiment and air assault brigade will remain on two-day standby; reports four soldiers were wounded in fighting in Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Body Shop Talks
abstract: Body Shop International is in takeover talks with unspecified potential buyers; says first-half profit fell by about 60 pecent, to $2.8 million (S)

headline: MEDTRONIC DISMISSES 450 AFTER LOSING PATENT RULING
abstract: Medtronic, medical device maker, lays off 450 workers after court rules it cannot sell artery-clearing tool in US because of patent infringement; court ruled in September device infringed on patent licensed to Boston Scientific Corp (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Firmly Tilting, Tower Of Pisa Reopens
abstract: Leaning Tower of Pisa is set to reopen for first time since 1990 after major repairs to prop it up; photo (S)

headline: Taliban Chief Urges Troops: Defy 'Infidel'
abstract: Mullah Muhammad Omar, Taliban's supreme leader, breaks four days of silence with appeal to soldiers not to buckle under US military pressure; address over military radio network, probably Taliban's last remaining communications system, reiterates that fighters are waging jihad against US, and will defeat 'big infidel' as they did Soviet forces in 1980's (M)

headline: A Programmable Dog That Will Bite Back
abstract: Sony comes out with new four-legged Aibo robot; photo (S)

headline: Use of Pinpoint Air Power Comes of Age in New War
abstract: Guidance systems employed in US airstrikes in Afghanistan make them devastatingly accurate; satellites, electronic-eavesdropping planes and human ground spotters are working together more reliably than ever, enabling distant commanders to direct warplanes to targets with stunning speed and accuracy; Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners confirm that precise bombing from planes they often could not hear or see broke will of battle-hardened troops; relatively small number of civilian casualties made possible by pinpoint bombing helps US maintain support of friendly Islamic nations, and air campaign's deadly effectiveness helps embolden opposition commanders; photos; drawing (L)

headline: Afghan Warlords and Bandits Are Back in Business
abstract: Lawlessness that gave rise to Afghanistan's strict Islamic movement in mid-1990's has begun to spread, once again, as warlords carve out chunks of country following fall of Taliban; warlords have all pledged loyalty to interim government in Kabul, but Hamid Karzai, picked by United States to head government, is previously little-known figure nationally who controls no real army of his own and no territory; photos; map (M)

headline: Why Small-Cap Stocks Are So Hot in Cold Weather
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column notes that 'January effect,' tendency of small-capitalization stocks to outperform broader market in first month of each year, persists despite predictions of its demise; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Expects Down Quarters
abstract: Anadigics Inc says fourth-quarter sales will fall 33 percent, to $20.3 million; says sales in first quarter of 2002 will be as much as 44 percent below same period previous year; graph (S)

headline: Malls Are Tightening Security as the Holiday Rush Begins
abstract: Shopping malls are tightening security and making efforts more visible in wake of Sept 11 terrorism as holiday shopping season begins; are concerned that customers are still fearful of terrorism; photo (M)

headline: International Business; Argentina's Malaise, Ever Worsening, Could Infect Others
abstract: Argentina's economic malaise continues to worsen, causing concerns in Brazil, which depends on Argentina for 15 percent of its exports, and other Latin American countries; photo (M)

headline: Settsu Journal; All the Spin Came First, and Then the Agitation
abstract: Settsu, Japan, becomes battle ground between Sanyo Electric Co and detergent manufacturers after Sanyo unveils washing machine that relies on ultrasound waves to loosen dirt and electrolysis to clean water; detergent manufacturers, whose sales have dropped 10 percent in volume and about 20 percent in revenue during last decade, contend machine is designed to run without detergent only to clean light grime; map; photo (M)

headline: Opening a Gateway, Closing In on bin Laden and Setting the Priorities
abstract: Overview of day's events in war on terrorism in Afghanistan and United States (M)

headline: Capture of City Would Provide First Victory in U.S. Campaign
abstract: The capture of Mazar-i-Shaif would deliver the first tangible victory for the American-led military campaign against the Taliban after more than a month of war.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Uzbek Dissident Arrested
abstract: czech republic: uzbek

headline: Russia Delays Any Decision On Oil Cuts
abstract: Russia surprises world oil markets by rebuffing OPEC's demands to cut oil output for 2002, postponing decision until next month; in meantime, Russian oil execs offer to trim 50,000 barrels off their daily exports, up from previous pledge of 30,000 barrels, but far below 500,000-barrel reduction that OPEC is demanding of outside producers (M)

headline: Bush, in Reversal, Seeks Rules for Enforcing Biological Treaty
abstract: Bush administration says it will work with international community to devise enforcement plan for treaty to rid world of biological weapons (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Delays For Kursk
abstract: Technical problems delay hoisting of Russian submarine Kurskto floating dock (S)

headline: India, Upset by Kashmir, Rejects 2nd Pakistan Invitation
abstract: The urgency of the invitation reflected the extremely high tensions between the two countries and pressure from the United States to try to defuse the situation.

headline: Rebuilding a Day at a Time; Law Firm Pushes 2 Steps Forward for Every Step Back
abstract: Sidley Austin Brown & Wood, law firm that had 600 of its 800 employees at 1 World Trade Center on Sept 11, now struggles to rebuild practice; operates from makeshift offices and plans move to new location in Midtown Manhattan in 2002; lost only one employee in tower's collapse, but attacks left many traumatized; photos (M)

headline: Qaeda Survivors by the Hundreds Hide in Pakistan
abstract: Hundreds of Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters have slipped across the Afghan border and evaded the Pakistani Army to disappear into remote tribal areas of Pakistan.

headline: The Fifth 'Potter' Raises Questions
abstract: Hottest new book of 2002 is epected to be Harry Poï

headline: Mexico Lower on Bush's List Since Sept. 11
abstract: Mexico has fallen off Washington's foreign policy agenda since Sept 11, despite Pres Bush's previous emphasis on importance of relationship and Pres Vicente Fox's expression of support for US campaign against terrorism; photo; Fox says he understands focus on terrorism, but hopes two countries can reach agreement on sweeping immigration reforms by next summer; his dream of open border may be victim of Sept 11, although Mexican officials say terrorist strikes should make it easier to win political support for legalization that would pull illegal migrants out of shadows and into light of government oversight (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: EchoStar Deal for Hughes Draws Investor Skepticism  Investors are showing deep skepticism about EchoStar Communications' $26 billion deal for the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors, which owns the DirecTV satellite television service. The share prices of EchoStar and Hughes are both down sharply.    There is a widespread sentiment that antitrust regulators may reject the deal because DirecTV and EchoStar are the only big satellite television providers and the only pay-TV services available in rural areas that are not wired for cable. Market Place. [Page C5.]

headline: Sweet Memories
abstract: Deborah Beaulieu letter comments on Michelle Slatalla's Nov 29 column on buying candy online, which mentioned Fannie May candy

headline: Microsoft Launches Windows XP
abstract: Following is a compilation of articles from The Times about Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system.

headline: After Two Months, Some Receive Food, but Others Can Only Watch
abstract: Shipment of food is distributed in refugee camp in Bagh-i-Shirkat, Afghanistan, by International Organization for Migration, private organization, for first time since start of American bombing campaign more than two months ago; marks resumption of relief effort for thousands of families set adrift by war and drought; photos (M)

headline: Ownership of Funds Is Up
abstract: Investment Company Institute reports number of households that own mutual funds rose 5.9 percent in 2000, to 54.8 million, 52 percent of all households in the nation (S)

headline: 'No Isolation From Evil,' Bush Declares
abstract: Excerpts from Pres Bush's speech to United Nations General Assembly on global context of US war against terrorism

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Airline Loan Shift
abstract: European Commission says bankrupt Sabena airlines can pass unused $111.6 billion Belgian government bridge loan to its Delta Air Transport unit (S)

headline: CANTV Shareholders Approve Buyback of Stock
abstract: Shareholders of CA Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela approve share buyback and dividend in latest chapter of takeover battle involving American companies AES Corp and Verizon Communications; shareholders agree to management's plan to repurchase 15 percent of company's stock at $30 each; also agree to dividend of about $550 million; approval of moves increases pressure on AES, one of company's largest minority shareholders; dispute among AES and foreign concerns that are company's largest shareholders, Verizon and Telefonica of Spain, is one of Latin America's most publicized takeover battles (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dynegy Plans to Acquire Enron for $9 Billion in Stock  The Enron Corporation agreed to be acquired by rival Dynegy for about $9 billion in stock and the assumption of $13 billion in debt.    The deal is an extraordinary turnabout for Enron, a Houston-based company that had been a driving force behind electricity deregulation nationwide. Its chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, a major contributor to the Republican Party, provided political influence, while its former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, helped create financial markets for the trading of electricity and natural gas. But last winter, when California's effort to deregulate the electricity market led to soaring power prices and rolling blackouts, Enron was the subject of much criticism and political anger. [Page A1.]

headline: Can the I.M.F. Tame the Capital Beast?
abstract: Alan Cowell reviews The Chastening, Inside the Crisis That Rocked the Global Financial System and Humbled the IMF, by Paul Blustein; photo (M)

headline: Gillette Says Its Profit Fell, But Sales Rose Unexpectedly
abstract: Gillette Says Its Profit Fe

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Resigns
abstract: World Business Briefing:

headline: Danaher Agrees To Buy Viridor
abstract: Danaher Corp will pay $135 million to purchase Viridor Instrumentation, division of Pennon Group, to bolster its water-quality business (S)

headline: In Changed World, Qadaffi Is Changing, Too
abstract: Libyan leader Col Muammar el-Qadaffi notifies diplomats in Netherlands that he is ready to sign international treaty banning chemical weapons, after spending last two decades building one of largest stockpiles in Middle East; he is said to be accelerating his efforts to improve his standing in West in aftermath of Sept 11 terrorist attacks; he was among Arab leaders who denounced attacks as 'horrible,' and he publicly stated that United States has right to pursue perpetrators; with lifting of United Nations sanctions in 1999 and subsequent upsurge in European business, he seems eager to win removal of US trade and arms embargo that has been in place for more than two decades; now, in consultation with intermediaries, Qadaffi is said to be offering intelligence information on members of Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda terrorist organization, including number of Libyans who reportedly served on bin Laden's personal protection force (M)

headline: Those Online Bargains Aren't Always Bargains
abstract: Survey by BizRate.com concludes that many promotions by online retailers are structured so that not every purchaser will benefit (S)

headline: Muted Response to U.S. Law
abstract: WASHINGTON—  As President George Bush signed new legislation last Friday aimed at strengthening anti-money-laundering procedures, most private banks in the United States were not anticipating any major changes in the way they do business.

headline: INVESTING WITH/Peter J. Quinn; UAM Clipper Focus Portfolio
abstract: Carole Gould column describes contrarian investment strategy of Peter J Quinn, co-manager of UAM Clipper Focus Portfolio fund; photo; table of fund data (M)

headline: U.S. AIMING TO CUT SUPPLIES TO LIFT THE TALIBAN'S GRIP
abstract: US launches third day of air raids against Taliban troops on front lines in Afghanistan, and senior Pentagon officials say for first time that they hope to choke off fuel, food and other supplies that Taliban leaders need to maintain their grip on power; strikes along northern front are intended to bolster rebel forces that oppose Taliban, but main objective remains communications, headquarters and supplies around Kandahar in south, spiritual and political capital for Taliban movement; officials confirm that American soldiers aboard two helicopters came under fire from unknown gunmen near military base in Pakistan, underscoring security concerns that commanders have about relatively limited US military presence in Pakistan, where anti-American sentiment has flared since strikes in Afghanistan began; photo; map (M)

headline: Israelis Rebuff U.S. On Pullout Request
abstract: Israel turned down President Bush's request to withdraw its forces from Palestinian-controlled territory, putting new pressure on American-Israeli relations and the anti-terror coalition with Arab allies. Israel's foreign minister, Shimon Peres, said in Washington that Israel would not pull out until the Palestinians arrested the men who killed Israel's tourism minister.       Article, Page A8.

headline: Officials Fear Tuberculosis Epidemic in Camps
abstract: Even as aid workers struggle to provide enough food to countless Afghans displaced by war, drought and Taliban repression, health officials say they are increasingly concerned that both Afghanistan and Pakistan face another threat: a potential epidemic of tuberculosis.    Pakistan and Afghanistan already have high incidence of tuberculosis, with more than 350,000 people developing the disease each year. Now, the crowded refugee camps threaten to become a mass incubator of the disease, creating a health crisis that could last for years after the fighting stops, World Health Organization officials said last week.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Bush Signs Internet Tax Ban
abstract: Pres Bush renews ban on Internet taxes for two years (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Student Permitted To Wear Veil
abstract: Court in Cairo rules that graduate student wearing full facial veil has right to use library at American University in Cairo; though head scarves are common, school banned veils, citing security concerns; court calls veil a matter of 'personal and religious freedom'; full veils are banned at all state universities (S)

headline: Mideast Talks More Urgent Now, Arafat and Blair Say
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat meets with Britain's Prime Min Tony Blair in London; urges Israel to resume immediate negotiations for peace in Middle East; Blair says now is time to reinvigorate process; remarks appear aimed at easing Washington's path while putting pressure on Israel; both men insist September 11 attacks against US make settlement between Israel and Palestinians more urgent than ever; Arafat reiterates condemnation of attacks; says attacks and military campaign in Afghanistan should not delay resumption of talks; both agree viable Palestinian state should be part of any negotiated agreement, that should also guarantee peace and security for Israel; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Aide's Son Arrested
abstract: Bangladesh police arrest son of new minister for post and telegraph; he is charged with kidnapping brother of journalist in Western Kushtia District and threatening to kidnap journalist because he did not like his articles (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Bond Man's Eye View, From Behind the Camera
abstract: James A Lebenthal, 73-year-old retired head of Lebenthal & Co, is filming short video vignettes about life in New York and showing them on Web site; photo (S)

headline: ETHAN ALLEN FORMS PARTNERSHIP WITH MFI FURNITURE
abstract: Ethan Allen Interiors forms partnership with MFI Furniture Group to open stores in Britain; companies will open as many as five retail stores in first phase of partnership (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pension Drops Stocks
abstract: Boots, Britain's biggest pharmacy chain, has sold all of stock in its $3.3 billion pension fund and bought bonds (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: An American Report Finds the Taliban's Violation of Religious Rights 'Particularly Severe'
abstract: Bush administation designates Taliban leadership of Afghanistan as 'particularly severe violator' of religious freedom and says status of ethnic and religious minorities in country had deteriorated over last year; State Dept releases its annual report on religious freedom; report is also critical of some United States allies, including Pakistan and Saudi Arabia (S)

headline: 'Banner' Rings in Many American Ears
abstract: Synthesized version of national anthem has been favorite option downloaded by AT&T Wireless subscribers to replace standard cellphone ring tone since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; America the Beautiful is second favorite and God Bless America fourth (S)

headline: U.S. Is Voicing Confidence In a Kabul Administration
abstract: United States special representative for Afghanistan James F Dobbins expresses optimism that interim Afghan government will succeed; cites American involvement, support of Afghanistan's neighbors and large amount of promised foreign aid as indicators of success (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VERIZON WIRELESS, a partnership of Verizon Communications, New York, and Vodafone Group, Newbury, England, won a contract to carry phone traffic for Wingcast, a venture of Ford Motor and Qualcomm, that will provide voice, Internet and e-mail access in cars and trucks. Terms were not disclosed.    RADIOSHACK, Fort Worth, the consumer electronics chain, said it would increase the number of shares it plans to repurchase to 25 million from 10 million. The company has repurchased 7.8 million shares since last December.

headline: Slow Lane to Kmart's Recovery; Consumers Turn Frugal and Many Suppliers Discontent
abstract: Kmart Corp chief executive Charles C Conaway remains confident company's turnaround plan is on track, despite decline in Halloween sales below year-earlier period, predictions that fourth-quarter will likely be flat at best and decision by Moody's Investors Service to review credit rating for possible downgrade; even though some problems seem beyond management's control, such as stagnating economy and effects of September 11 terrorist attacks, analysts and manufacturers cite Kmart's persistent lack of strong image that might draw consumers; analysts note while other discount merchants have picked up newly frugal customers, Kmart has been largely left in cold; say Conway, despite efforts over past 18 months as chief executive, has not found formula he needs to distinguish company from competitors; company trails retail industry leaders by wide margin on several key measures of performance; charts; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Rebuke Seen For President In Argentina
abstract: Argentine Pres Fernando de la Rua's governing coalition, after months of worsening economic crisis, appears to lose several seats in legislative and local elections, possibly weakening its position in Congress; sharp voter rebuke to de la Rua was widely expected as 20 million Argentine's went to polls, and large proportion spoiled ballots or abstained altogether in protest (S)

headline: Bin Laden's Statement: 'The Sword Fell'
abstract: Text of statement by Osama bin Laden broadcast by Al Jazeera in Qatar (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Philips Sues Over Patents
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics sues four computer parts makers in US and four in Taiwan, accusing them of copying technique that allows discrete electronic components to work together in device; Philips asserts US defendants made computer circuits that illegally copied Philips technology and that Taiwan companies exported illegal products including circuit boards, motherboards and computers to US (S)

headline: Time Out of Joint in a Ruined Land
abstract: The story of Afghanistan is like Job's, except God has not yet appeared in the whirlwind to explain the suffering and set things right. This is a land where war has put time out of joint, where people live in ruins resembling archaeological sites, using the tools of centuries gone by. The tools — hand-hewn wooden furrows plowing the earth, hand-shaped clay ovens baking bread — create the beautiful necessities that make life bearable.

headline: I Think I Hear Voices
abstract: Jean Fitzgerald letter comments on Nov 22 article on bad cellphone manners

headline: Cantor Details Aid to Survivors
abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald, trading firm that lost 700 employees in World Trade Center attack, says victims' families will receive health insurance for 10 years and share of partnership's profits for five years; 25 percent of money that would have been distributed to partners will be given to families of employees killed in attacks over five years, or until they receive $100,000 each; each will get life insurance payment of double victim's salary up to maximum $100,000 (S)

headline: In Streets of Pakistani Cities, Cries of 'Death to America!'
abstract: Gangs of protesters numbering up to 15,000 riot in Quetta, Pakistan, destroying anything Western or American, burning theaters showing American movies; other cities have smaller demonstrations, all protesting American-led military attacks against Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: Business Diary
abstract: For Famous Pianos, A Steinway Encore.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility To Sell Bonds
abstract: Scottish Power, Britain's largest electric utility, no longer plans to sell Southern Water, its water utility, in southern England; it will try to raise $2.6 billion by selling Southern Water bonds to restructure Scottish Power's $8.5 billion debt; Scottish Power reports loss in six months ended Sept 30 of 126.7 million pounds ($185 million), compared with profit of 76.4 million pounds year earlier; graph (S)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Fims
abstract: Michael Cannon, executive creative director at Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was named a partner.

headline: Lucent Lowers Sales Forecast; Stocks Hit Hard
abstract: Stocks of Lucent Technologies and other telecommunications equipment makers dive as companies indicate that industry's long slump is continuing; Lucent warns that its revenue for current quarter will shrink by 35 percent; Qwest Communications will eliminate 7,000 jobs (M)

headline: AMERICAN CLASSIC VOYAGES FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: American Classic Voyages, cruise ship company controlled by Sam Zell, seeks bankruptcy protection; cruise bookings fell 50 percent after Sept 11 terrorist attacks; company will cease operating its Hawaii vessels and will shut down four of five Delta Queen vessels in next three days (S)

headline: Indicators Fell In September; Biggest Drop In Five Years
abstract: Conference Board reports index of leading economic indicators fell 0.5 percent, Sept, after falling revised 0.1 percent in Aug; Sept drop is biggest in over 5 years; graph; table of index components (M)

headline: EMI Group's Top Executive for Recorded Music Quits
abstract: EMI Group says Ken Berry, its well-known head of recorded music and its highest paid executive, has resigned; Alain Levy, best known for turning PolyGram into world's largest music company before it was sold in 1998 to Seagram, now part of Vivendi Universal, will succeed Berry as chief executive of recorded music; David Mumms, another former Polygram executive, will return to EMI in newly created post of vice chairman of division; photo (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Sees Long Battle; Says Bombs Aren't Enough
abstract: Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld warns nation to prepare for years of battle in war on terrorism, and says missiles alone cannot wipe out terrorists; for first time, NATO forces will cross Atlantic to defend US, which frees up Air Force Awacs for missions elsewhere; says new attacks in Afghanistan will focus on 'emerging targets,' or concentrations of Taliban forces and militants from Al Qaeda flushed out by earlier campaign; photos; illustration of Joint Direct Attack Munitions, or 'smart' bomb (M)

headline: Thousands Hear Call of Prayer and Politics at World's Mosques
abstract: In mosques yesterday, Muslims gathered for Friday Prayers, and in many instances the preaching was political and sharply anti-American.

headline: Bank One Set to Hire 600
abstract: Bank One Corp will hire 600 people to develop computer systems and improve its World Wide Web customer service (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: England: No Right To Die
abstract: British High Court panel turns down terminally ill woman's request to allow her husband to help her die without being prosecuted for assisted suicide, which carries a maximum 14-year jail term; Lord Justice Tuckey says Diane Pretty's human right is to 'live with dignity, not die with dignity' (S)

headline: Israel Denies Groups' Charge That It Is Torturing Detainees
abstract: Appearing before a United Nations committee, Israel defended itself today against accusations by Amnesty International and other groups that it uses methods amounting to torture during the interrogation of Palestinian detainees.    The London-based Amnesty International, in a written report to the Committee Against Torture, said that it had ''strong evidence'' that Israeli authorities continued to use methods of dealing with detainees that violated international standards even after the Israeli Supreme Court barred such practices.

headline: Upcoming Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: TV Station Raid in Georgia Leads to Protests and Cabinet's Ouster
abstract: Georgia, already racked by tensions with Russia and guerrilla war, descends further into political crisis today after police raid on popular television station sets off mass protests and dismissal of most of cabinet by Pres Eduard Shevardnadze (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Horse Betting Surges
abstract: Despite global economic uncertainty, bets flowed into gambling companies nationwide for the 2001 Melbourne Cup horse race, which is celebrated with a state holiday in Victoria and afternoons off by many Australians in the rest of the country. TAB Ltd. took in record bets worth 43 million Australian dollars, or $21.9 million, an increase of 4.6 percent from last year, according to a spokesman, Peter Fletcher.     Becky Gaylord (NYT)

headline: German Investigators Unravel Web of Hijackers' Relations
abstract: German investigators, aided by team of FBI agents in Hamburg, are focusing increasingly on relations of Mohamed Atta, who flew one of planes that rammed World Trade Center, and Marwan al-Shehhi, who crashed second hijacked plane into towers; problem is untangling relationships; some of suspects knew hijackers intimately; in case of others, ties are hard to find; office of federal prosecutor, Kay Nehm, has confirmed formal investigations of Mamoun Darkazanli, Syrian businessman in Hamburg, and Dr Adly el-Attar, Egyptian surgeon from Neu-Ulm, southern German city near Munich; attention was drawn to Darkazanli by his contacts in past with former aides of bin Laden; Darkazanli claimed last month that contacts were for business purposes and denied any terrorist involvement; grounds for investigating of Dr Attar lie in his past contacts with Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, former bin Laden top aide (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: No Bonuses For Cisco Executives
abstract: Top executives at Cisco Systems Inc will not receive bonuses for 2001 fiscal year because company fell short of its financial goals (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Death Sentence For High Official
abstract: Li Jizhou, former vice minister of public security in Xiamen, China, is sentenced to death for role in huge smuggling scandal in which he allegedly accepted more than $600,000 in bribes (S)

headline: Smoke Alarm Can Distinguish Between Emergency and Bacon
abstract: First Alert's new smoke alarm can distinguish between cooking smoke or steam and serious smoke, and its alarm can be turned off by pushing button on any TV or VCR remote control (S)

headline: Taliban Dig In And U.S. Uses Pakistan Bases To Join Hunt
abstract: United States is using two Pakistan bases to send several hundred Special Operations forces into Afghanistan to battle Taliban troops that are establishing strong pockets of resistance across wide swath of Afghanistan and hunt for Osama bin Laden; Taliban contingents, led by hard-line Arab fighters, reportedly are digging in at two points south of Kabul and have established bases at two sites near Jalalabad; anti-Taliban leader says some 1,200 Arab fighters are holed up inside base at Tora Bora, near Jalalabad, phone interview; rumors abound that bin Laden may be among those fighters; map (M)

headline: Bowing to Nation's Mood, Retailer Cancels Issue of Racy Catalog
abstract: Abercrombie & Fitch, apparel retailer known for advertising campaigns that celebrate pleasures of youth, will announce it has canceled holiday issue of its quarterly publication because of content and tone are deemed in appropriate after terrorist attacks in US; other companies, including Coca-Cola, Microsoft Corp, and World Wrestling Federation Entertainment, have also been forced to alter campaigns and promotions as they struggle to strike right balance for advertising in last five weeks (M)

headline: INSURANCE REGULATORS GIVE LLOYD'S A BREAK
abstract: American insurance regulators say that because of Lloyd's of London is facing liquidity problems in connection with claims from World Trade Center attacks, company will be granted exception to rules governing its operations in US; regulators says Lloyd's will have four and half months to set aside amount equal to its estimated billions of dollars of losses in attacks as guarantee that claims will be paid (S)

headline: Behind the Burka: Women Subtly Fought Taliban
abstract: Petty brutality endured by women for nearly half decade under Taliban ends in city of Herat and across much of Afghanistan as forces of opposition Northern Alliance take control; women of Herat express hope that they will be treated like human beings, free to leave homes and work, and that daughters will again be able to return to school; many show faces for first time, abandoning mandatory full-length burkhas; describe many brutalities of Taliban rule; Soheila Helal describes running illegal school for 120 girls clandestinely in her home after husband was killed by Taliban; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; In This Particular Tire Test, Failure Was Not an Option
abstract: Air France Concorde that took off from Charles de Gaulle airport, first flight since supersonic jets were grounded after July 25, 2000, when blown tire on takeoff caused fatal crash, was equipped with Michelin tires; Edouard Michelin comments; photo (S)

headline: ROADWAY TO SELL A WAREHOUSING UNIT FOR $105 MILLION
abstract: Roadway Corp, leading trucking company, plans to sell warehousing and ship-tracking unit, for $105 million; Roadway, which is buying Arnold Industries for $475 million, agrees to sell business to group that includes Arnold's chief executive Edward Arnold (S)

headline: Portugal Is Losing a History Told in Bank Notes
abstract: Design of Portuguse escudo, which is about to be replaced by euro, evokes glories of 500 years ago, when Portuguese navigators challenged oceans and explored distant realms of Africa, India and Americas; disappearance of escudo prompts some nostalgia, but it is seen as ticket to broader European identity that has already brought some Portuguese unparalleled prosperity; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   5.50   5.50   9.50       Discount rate   2.00   2.00   6.00       Federal funds   2.56   2.39   6.59       3-month T-bills   2.20   2.18   6.08       6-month T-bills   2.16   2.17   5.99       10-yr. T-infl.   3.12   3.14   3.91       10-yr. T-note   4.60   4.66   5.73       30-yr. T-bond   5.37   5.42   5.81       Telephone bd.   7.53   7.53   8.00       Municipal bds.   5.25   5.24   5.81          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: U.S. Couple Held in Philippines Describe Their Ordeal on Tape
abstract: American missionary couple held for six months by Muslim guerrillas in Philippines describe their ordeal in videotaped interview conducted by freelance Philippine journalist; tape, shown on local television, is first to show couple, Gracia and Martin Burnham, since their capture by Abu Sayyaf guerrillas, who have been linked to Osama bin Laden; Abu Sayyaf leader, Abu Sabaya, also appears on tape saying he would free couple if ransom is paid; Burnhams look frightened and gaunt and paint harrowing picture of their life with Abu Sayyaf; they and Philippine nurse are only hostages still held by Abu Sayyaf group, who beheaded several others (M)

headline: Goldman Unit to Buy Bad Japanese Loans
abstract: Asahi Bank hires Goldman Sachs Group to set up unit to buy Asahi's bad loans at market value; Asahi intends to write off up to 300 billion yen ($2.49 billion) of its shakiest lending in two years (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Guidelines To List Foreign Concerns
abstract: China issues broad guidelines allowing foreign companies to list shares in their Chinese operations on Chinese stock exchanges (S)

headline: Nasdaq 100 May Lose Some Technology Flavor
abstract: DIARY Nasdaq 100 May Lose Some Technology Flavor  For many investors, the Nasdaq 100 index is synonymous with technology stocks. But its definition is changing.

headline: Army Coffins, $2,500 Each, Anger Indians
abstract: India's military and political establishment is shaken by release of official audit finding that army paid $2,500 each for coffins to bring home soldiers killed by Pakistani Army infiltrators in Kashmir two years ago; opposition in Parliament seizes on audit as evidence of mismanagement; Defense Min George Fernandes says coffin expenditure never crossed his desk for approval because contract amount of $1.5 million was too small; although focus in Parliament is on coffins, auditor general's investigation is far more scathing about how $500 million was spent for India's small-scale war with Pakistan in 1999 (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ex-Penguin Putnam Chief Is Moving to Random House  The Random House division of Bertelsmann named Phyllis E. Grann, the departing chief executive of Penguin Putnam, to the new position of vice chairman, fueling speculation among editors and agents that she may seek to lure away some of Penguin Putnam's authors.    Others, however, wondered how Ms. Grann will fit in among the internally competitive chiefs of Random House's many publishing divisions. [Page C2.]

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: U.S. Presses for New Talks By Israelis and Palestinians
abstract: US urges Israel to withdraw forces from Palestinian-governed territory immediately; deplores Army's recent killing of civilians; also demands that Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat combat terrorism against Israel; Foreign Min Shimon Peres says Israel will seek to achieve cease-fire, revive confidence-building measures and restart talks with Palestinians; says Arafat must arrest handful of troublemakers instigating most of terror against Israel, have police force prevent incursions of suicide bombers, and outlaw other armed groups that do not obey his orders; photo (M)

headline: Cablevision Says Its Loss Grew Wider In 3rd Quarter
abstract: Cablevision Systems Corp says loss widened to $77.1 million in third quarter from $40.1 million year earlier; sales slipped 3.8 percent, to $1 billion (M)

headline: Uncertain Deal Is Key To Fate of Executive
abstract: Article on fuÈ

headline: U.S. Raid Kills Unknown Number in an Afghan Village
abstract: US bombs Karam, Afghanistan, village once training camp for Islamic guerrillas that has been closed for several years; whether camp was intended target of American bombers or whether there was somebody or something in village that American military planners wanted to hit, may never be known; Pakistani journalist, working temporarily for New York Times, says villagers told him that 53 people died, though only 22 bodies have yet been pulled from wreckage; they say radical Islamic Taliban government seems inclined to inflate toll; Pakistani newspapers report hamlet was obliterated and that more than 100 people are dead; Afghan Islamic Press quotes Taliban official who says body count reached 160 and is likely to exceed 200; photo (M)

headline: FINANCING ARM SELLS $6 BILLION WORTH OF DEBT
abstract: General Motors Acceptance Corp sells $6 billion worth of debt (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retail Sales Fall
abstract: Standard & Poor's reduces its rating of Japan's credit by a notch, to AA, penalizing government for failing to curtail its fiscal deficit or revive its faltering economy; many analysts expected two-notch downgrade, and investors bid up value of yen and government's 10-year bond (M)

headline: Patents; Some inventions for the season of gift giving, including how to pass along virtual fruitcake.
abstract: Separate patents for devices helpful for online gift giving are granted to RichFX and Arye Sachs (M)

headline: When a Tiny Taut Gesture Upstages Demons and Noise
abstract: Charles Herold reviews computer games Ico by Sony Computer Entertainment America and Portal Runner by 3DO; photos (M)

headline: When the Camera Itself Boasts a Signature Style
abstract: Logitech's ClickSmart 310 and 510 combine digital camera and Webcam and are designed for people who want to share their pictures via e-mail or by posting them on Web (S)

headline: A Holiday Buying Guide to Technology
abstract: This year's Circuits buying guide looks at over 80 gadgets, gizmos and digital doo-dads. From PC peripherals to children's toys to electronic aids, a complete resource to all that should be the electronic rage this holiday season.

headline: 2 Acquisitions Are Being Made
abstract: Eric Mower & Associates acquires Sage Macrom; US operations of Publicis Groupe is acquiring Fusion DM advertising agency from MarketFirst Software (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Return to Extravagance by Chrysler
abstract: Chrysler Corp, despite its economic woes, will throw extravagant party at Detroit Auto Show despite its financial woes; photo (S)

headline: Airline Cutbacks With an Agenda; Preserving Hub Networks Is the Carriers' Motivation
abstract: New York Times computer analysis reveals that schedule reductions by major airlines cut passenger capacity at major airports by as much as one third and increased largest carriers' dominance at those airports; their agenda is to preserve service in their major hub networks while lowering it elsewhere; outcome, when travel revives, will likely be raises in fares and continued shoddy service due to elimination of substantial competition; charts (M)

headline: Pakistan Asks India to Revive Talks Aimed at Bringing Peace to Kashmir
abstract: Pakistan's military ruler Gen Pervez Musharraf asks India's Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee to resume negotiations over disputed territory of Kashmir, started in July in Agra; says talks should focus only on Kashmir, but is rebuffed by Vajpayee, who says talks cannot be productive if Kashmir is sole issue (S)

headline: Trying to Attract Cell Users To Next Wireless Generation
abstract: NTT DoCoMo has begun selling world's first third-generation cellular phone service, distributing 4,000 handsets with rapid Internet links in Tokyo; is wary of luring subscribers to abandon i-mode phones immediately, before new system proves its reliability and has enough multimedia material to satisfy customers; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Food-Price Controls
abstract: Zimbabwe government reintroduces price controls on basic foodstuffs to appease disaffected consumers (S)

headline: Agfa-Gevaert Moves Ahead On Mitra Deal
abstract: Agfa-Gevaert, largest European manufacturer of X-ray products and film, signs definitive agreement to acquire Mitra, Canadian provider of imaging and information-management systems for health care industry (S)

headline: Merrill Lynch In an Overhaul
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co names Paul Roy and Arshad Zakaria to head its investment bank, putting four business units under managers appointed by president E Stanley O'Neal, last three weeks; Winthrop H Smith Jr says he will retire (S)

headline: Conference on Biological Weapons Breaks Down Over Divisions
abstract: Anthrax attacks in United States focus international attention on germ weapons, but countries meeting in Geneva to strengthen global pact banning those weapons are so divided on how to proceed that they suspend gathering for year rather than allow their effort to collapse; three-week review of Biological Weapons Convention of 1972, signed by 144 countries, is held every five years; cold-war-era biological weapons treaty has no system to catch cheaters (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Business Travel; The nation's airline security system continues to come up short in its basic responsibility.
abstract: Industry officials and security experts agree that most frequent fliers consider domestic air-travel security system to be grim joke, run by low-paid, badly educated and inadequately trained private guards (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Taliban Foes Move on Kandahar
abstract: Aided by American air power and ground troops, opposition forces in southern Afghanistan have encircled the city of Kandahar.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Army Reprimand For Boys' Deaths
abstract: Israeli army says several officers will be reprimanded for deaths of five Palestinian boys killed by booby trap in Gaza Strip (S)

headline: More Muted Talk About Help for Economy
abstract: Economists disagree on importance, propriety and potential effects of any economic stimulus legislation Congress might enact; some fear that it would prompt Federal Reserve to raise interest rates; others lower forecasts for economic growth because lawmakers have failed to pass any stimulus legislation thus far; other bills stuck in Congress could be of equal importance to business (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AFRICA SOUTH AFRICA: LAWMAKER RESIGNS POST The chief parliamentary whip for the president's African National Congress Party has quit his leadership post after being charged with fraud and corruption. By stepping down, the lawmaker, Tony Yengeni, spares his party the burden of deciding whether to suspend him as the police press ahead with their investigation of a multibillion- dollar arms deal. Mr. Yengeni, who was chairman of a key parliamentary defense committee, is accused of promising to help a defense contractor in exchange for a low price on a Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle.

headline: Restructuring Will Make I.N.S. Dual Focus Agency
abstract: Attorney General John D. Ashcroft said today that the Immigration and Naturalization Service was being restructured to better serve law-abiding immigrants and keep out terrorists and troublemakers.

headline: Trying to Keep Young Internet Users From a Life of Piracy
abstract: Experts on piracy, hacking and other forms of Internet mischief cite importance of preparing students to use Internet in safe and responsible manner well before college age; cite growing population of ever-younger computer pirates; piracy ranges from exchanges of programs and games in chat rooms to bigger players who operate quietly with vast storage and bandwidth, cracking copyright protection on array of products made available in limitless Internet discount stores; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Welfare Minister Quits
abstract: Argentina's Social Secuyrity Minister Patricia Bullrich resigns, citing lack of political will to eliminate overlapping welfare programs (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies column; dollar drops against Japanese yen; graph; chart; table (S)

headline: U.S. and Partners Quickly Set Sights on a Post-Taliban Kabul
abstract: United States and countries most closely affected by developments in Afghanistan call for 'broadbased, multiethnic, politically balanced, freely chosen Afghan administration' to take charge once Taliban is totally driven from Kabul; goal is issued in statement by so-called Six Plus Two group: US and Russia, plus China, Iran, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan; group meets with special United Nations envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, who has toured region and whose mission group formally endorses; Brahimi says he will seek to convene 'representative sample' of Afghan population and see about interim arrangements for Kabul; Secretary General Kofi Annan says political aspects must be brought in line with fast-moving military developments on the ground, and Secretary of State Colin Powell also stresses need for speed; photo (M)

headline: Now Arriving, On a Fast Track
abstract: Models trains enter digital era and give hobbyist closer feel of what it is like to run a real train, collisions and all; several trains can be run on single layout without cumbersome wiring or central control station that was previously necessary, and more people can run trains at same time, using hand-held throttles; photo (M)

headline: MARINES JOINING GROUND FIGHT; DETAINED TALIBAN STAGE REVOLT
abstract: Hundreds of marines land at makeshift airfield near southern Afghan city of Kandahar in first major infusion of American ground troops into Afghanistan; arrival begins what Pentagon officials say will be period of sustained assault against Taliban and Al Qaeda forces; marines will be front edge of powerful force of more than 1,000 combat troops who are likely to join hunt for Osama bin Laden and begin raids against Taliban forces concentrated in Kandahar and in mountain redoubts near border with Pakistan; their arrival unambiguously confirms shift in American strategy away from using air power and proxy Afghan armies to oust Taliban from power; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls
abstract: Japan's trade surplus fell 18.3 percent, Sept, from Sept 2000; exports fell 11.1 percent (S)

headline: Positive Reports Hint at Swift Recovery
abstract: Flurry of unexpectedly positive results hint that economy might make swift exit from recession; latest figures on home sales, consumer confidence, orders for durable goods and claims for unemployment benefits all come in better than anticipated; despite pleasant surprises, economists still warn that recovery next year will be feeble; graphs (L)

headline: Fallout From Enron Continues to Take Toll on Power Sector
abstract: Stocks and bonds of power companies tumble in fallout from Enron's collapse as investors worry about whether companies' financial statements can be trusted and whether their profits can grow if natural gas and electricity prices remain low; since end of October, shares of El Paso Corp have fallen 16 percent; Dynegy, 30 percent; Calpine, 36 percent; Mirant, 28 percent; analysts express concern that negative investor sentiment may spread to other industries containing companies with heavy debt burdens and opaque financial statements; graph (M)

headline: Business; Fake Goods Are Flowing Under the New Radar
abstract: Government detection and seizure of counterfeit merchandise drops sharply as law enforcement officials turn their attention to fighting terrorism; some experts in intellectual trademark enforcement insists that battles against counterfeiting and terrorism may not be as distinct as they seem, since sale of counterfeit goods can finance terrorists' activities; executives of Oakley, maker of high-priced sunglasses and leader at fighting counterfeiting, comment on their frustration; photos; graph (M)

headline: U.N. Study Says Nairobi Is Inundated With Crime
abstract: United Nations downgrades security status of Nairobi, Kenya, from B to C, even below Bogota and Beirut, after study finds city is inundated with crime; more than third of capital's residents were robbed with threat of force over last year; survey finds Nairobi's criminals are so brazen they no longer seem to fear police or prosecutors; finds machetes, axes and wooden clubs are their weapons of choice; says television sets are carted out of living rooms, often in full view of alarmed residents (M)

headline: MARINES ADVANCE TOWARD KANDAHAR TO PREPARE SIEGE
abstract: US marines advance from Afghan desert base to prepare siege of Kandahar; scout enemy movements and set up checkpoints to seal roads and prevent Taliban from reinforcing or escaping from largest stronghold; are joined by British and Australian Special Operations forces; Pentagon announces steady increase in American role in ground war; Defense Sec Donald Rumnsfeld says there are no plans for marines to join rapidly approaching final assault on Kandahar; says job of capturing city will be left to southern Pashtun tribal fighters, who are gradually encircling it; unconfirmed reports say Ayman al-Zawahiri, top deputy to Osama bin Laden, was wounded in air strike and that other Al Qaeda figures were killed; air campaign on Taliban cave and tunnel complexes in eastern Afghanistan, from Kabul to Khyber Pass, to flush out or kill Al Qaeda leaders discussed; photo; maps (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Three employees were promoted at Adient, Parsippany, N.J., a unit of CommonHealth.

headline: Plan for More G.I.'s on the Ground, Economic Slump, Anthrax Unease
abstract: Overview of situation in war against terrorism; more ground soldiers will be deployed in Afghanistan and using B-52 bombers allows airstrikes to hit targets with more precision; government figures confirm end of longest economic expansion in country's history, and Sept 11 attacks play part in decline; death of Kathy T Nguyen from inhalation anthrax compounds fears of public, as it is not known how she contracted it (M)

headline: Ugly Duckling Turns Out to Be Formidable In the Air
abstract: Unmanned drone known as Predator proves formidable weapon as war in Afghanistan enters its most complex phase, hunt for leadership of Al Qaeda and Taliban; Predator is ungainly, propeller-driven craft that flies as slowly as 80 mph and is operated by remote control; CIA recently used it to coordinate surgical strike in which one of Osama bin Laden's closest lieutenants, Muhammad Atef, was killed; military experts say ability to fly armed, unmanned drones is significant advance for search-and-destroy missions on battlefield; say Predator permits US to hit targets as soon as they are sighted, instead of waiting for fighter-bombers to respond; diagram (M)

headline: Filmmakers Send a Message With Lego as the Medium
abstract: Brick films, new niche in world of filmmaking, uses Lego plastic blocks in traditional technique of stop-motion animation; most works are from one to five minutes, enough time to satirize just about anything; efforts are viewable online; photo (M)

headline: United Nations and Kofi Annan Share Nobel Peace Prize
abstract: The United Nations and Secretary General Kofi Annan were jointly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday.

headline: CNBC Struggles To Stay Relevant; With Stocks No Longer the Big Story, News Viewers Are Looking Elsewhere
abstract: CNBC, business-news channel that became most-watched information source on cable television during heady 1990's, is in rough seas; its buzz has faded, its ratings are falling, and it is having to rethink its direction as ground shifts beneath it; with Sept 11 terrorist attacks, news has entirely moved away from investment arena, trend that was already under way as economy slowed and stocks slumped; executives say they are trying to broaden network's scope, without losing its identity; chart compares ratings of CNN, Fox News and CNBC before and after Sept 11; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Murdoch Expects Flat Year
abstract: News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch says immediate effects of Sept 11 terrorist attacks cost company at least $100 million in advertising bookings, address to annual meeting; predicts results in this fiscal year will be flat against prior year; adds promising signs have emerged; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil futures prices rise; crude oil for Feb delivery rises 34 cents to $19.52 a barrel; graph; table (S)5

headline: Pakistan Finds U.S. Charges Good Enough for Court
abstract: Pakistan says evidence compiled by United States of Osama bin Laden's involvement in terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon is enough to justify charges in court of law; urges Bush administration to go public with evidence to strengthen case for US retaliation and so that other Muslim nations might align themselves with Pakistan; photo (M)

headline: Panel Picks Candidate For U.A.W.
abstract: United Automobile Workers panel nominates Ron Gettelfinger to succeed Stephen Yokich as president, move that virtually assures he will take over as union's leader next year (S)

headline: XEROX HIRES PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS AS NEW AUDITOR
abstract: Xerox Corp, subject of accounting investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission, names PricewaterhouseCoopers to replace KPMG, independent auditor for more than 30 years (S)

headline: Enron Struggles to Find Financing to Remain in Business
abstract: Enron Corp struggles to line up financing that would allow it to enter bankruptcy as functioning company; its broken deal to merge with Dynegy continues to cloud its efforts to reorganize as two companies argue over who will control Northern Natural Gas, natural gas pipeline that is one of Enron's most prized assets; Dynegy plans to take control of pipeline on Dec 12; Federal prosecutors in Houston, Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York indicate interest in Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation into Enron; Arthur Andersen, Enron's outside auditor, confirms it has been issued subpoenas in SEC probe; company dismisses 1,100 workers in Britain, one day after PricewaterhouseCoopers takes over supervision of Enron's energy trading there; Japanese investors scramble to pull savings out of money market funds that held Enron bonds; Bank of Japan takes steps to assure there are enough reserves in banking system to avoid cash squeeze; Enron employees in US brace for layoffs (M)

headline: Millions of Afghan Children, and No Ideas About Their Future
abstract: Millions of Afghan children have virtually no idea about their future in aftermath of defeat of Taliban; UN estimates at least half of 23 million Afghans are younger than 18, and are largely illiterate and mostly unvaccinated; some are skilled in basics of waging war while others lack any moral reference point after being raised under Taliban's brand of law; photos (M)

headline: Israelis Storm Village in the West Bank
abstract: Israeli troops storm into another West Bank village, killing at least 5 Palestinians and arresting 11 more, including two men Israelis say helped kill cabinet minister last week; Palestinian leaders accuse Israeli government of inventing link to minister's killing to cover up what they call 'massacre' of at last 10 people; raid on Palestinian town, Beit Rima, brings to seven number of villages and cities in which Israeli troops have captured positions in operation begun after killing of tourism minister, Rehavam Zeevi; latest attack comes hours after Pres Bush appeals for Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian territory; photo (M)

headline: Fed Cuts Rate Again
abstract: The Federal Reserve cut its key short-term interest rate for the 10th time this year, pushing it down to a level not seen since the presidency of John F. Kennedy. The rate was cut by a half a percentage point.     Business Day, Page C1.

headline: Rabbi Eliezer Schach, 103; Leader of Orthodox in Israel
abstract: Rabbi Eliezer Menachem Schach, a leader of strictly orthodox Jews in Israel who wielded powerful influence over country's politics for more than two decades, dies at 103; photo (M)

headline: Defusing Catastrophes
abstract: Philip J Frankenfeld letter says terrorist attacks of Sept 11 show vulnerability of centralized systems in energy, banking and travel

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KPN Lenders Get More Facts
abstract: Royal KPN provides more details of restrictions related to 2.5 billion euro ($2.2 billion) credit facility it obtained last month, after shareholder activist group filed lawsuit demanding that company make same disclosures to all investors (S)

headline: French Reporter Tells of Days Held in Jail by the Taliban
abstract: French journalist Michel Peyrard describes his experience of being imprisoned by Taliban authorities in article in magazine Paris Match; photo (M)

headline: U.S. MOVES TO CUT 2 FINANCIAL LINKS FOR TERROR GROUP
abstract: Pres Bush announces international effort to destroy two financial networks long suspected of links to Qaeda terrorist organization; says networks, Al Barakaat and Al Taqwa, with presence in over 40 nations, finance movement of arms, provide secure communications and serve as network for Osama bin Laden to transmit intelligence and instructions to terrorist cells, as well as raise, manage, invest and distribute funds for Al Qaeda; law enforcement officials in United States and Europe carry out raids to disrupt networks; Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill describes complex mechanism he says Al Barakat uses to provide Al Qaeda secret financing; networks deny charges; photo (M)

headline: A Glimpse, Guard Down
abstract: Analysis: unparalleled glimpse into world of Osama bin Laden and like-minded Islamic extremists is offered in videotape released by White House; tape shows bin Laden had dual goals for Sept 11 attacks: to devastate US and to galvanize support for his brand of Islam; vision of bin Laden and his followers is laced with mysticism, reflecting firm conviction that God has taken their side in apocalyptic struggle against 'infidels,' epitomized by United States; bin Laden on tape is swaggering, boastful, humble and modest by turn; his guests appear to view him as perfect 'emir' of greatest Muslim victory since early days of Islam; bin Laden shows clear interest in how attacks were received in his native Saudi Arabia; tape is almost certain to put more pressure on Saudi Arabia to crack down on militant schools and Muslim preachers whom al-Saud ruling family has long tolerated (M)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: John Lieberman and Jim McKenna, technology professors from San Francisco, regard America Online's promotional CD-ROM's as junk mail and needless pollution and are attempting to amass one million of disks and deliver them to AOL's headquarters in Dulles, Va (S)

headline: On One Afghan Front Line, the Rebel Tide Surges, Then Flows Back
abstract: Article describes scene near Chagatai in northern Afghanistan, as front line of fighting teeters forward and back and soldiers advance and retreat in kind; photo (M)

headline: Telecommunications; Bandwidth Traders' Uncertain Future
abstract: Trading of telecommunications bandwidth as commodity will change markedly as result of Enron Corp's failure; market is glutted, with less than 10 percent of fiber optic cable buried under land and sea in use; other traders will fill vacuum left by Enron's absence (M)

headline: Ernst & Young Unit Settles With Fund Investors
abstract: Bermuda affiliate of Ernst & Young settles with investors who brought $400 million fraud suit against Manhattan Investment Fund Ltd, Michael Berger's bankrupt hedge fund (S)

headline: Katie Couric Signs NBC Contract Said to Be Largest in TV News
abstract: NBC and Katie Couric, anchor of its Today show, agree to what is believed to be largest financial deal ever signed in television news, reaching beyond $60 million for next four and half years; executives close to negotiations say that Couric would receive compensation of $15 million to $16 million a year, in deal structured to include both salary and stock in NBC's parent company, General Electric; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Plane Crews Fight Hunger From the Sky
abstract: Article describes humanitarian mission in which two American transport planes dropped more than 37,000 meals over area populated with starving Afghans; photo (M)

headline: Bin Laden, on Tape, Boasts of Trade Center Attacks
abstract: In a videotape released by the United States on Thursday, Osama bin Laden boasts that the Sept. 11 attacks were even more destructive than he had hoped they would be.

headline: Legal Maneuvers, Stalking Kandahar, Stalling and Speeding Up Aid
abstract: Overview of events in war on terrorism, including report that Ahmed Abdel Rahman, son of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, has been captured by Northern Alliance forces in Afghanistan, that alliance forces are closing in on Taliban stronghold in Kandahar, that fear of sheer lawlessness on many Afghan roads is preventing international relief groups from bringing food and other supplies to millions of hungry Afghans, and that New York Police Dept orders mandatory counseling for all members of force (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Arab Lawmaker Charged
abstract: Azmi Bishara, Israeli Arab member of Parliament, is formally charged with voicing support for guerrilla group Hezbollah; indictment charges him with encouraging violence and expressing support for terrorist organization; he faces separate charges for organizing visits by Israeli Arabs to Syria, with which Israel is technically at war (S)

headline: Changing of Guard at U.A.W.
abstract: Ron Gettelfinger, union executive who negotiated spinoff of Ford's auto supply business on exceedingly generous terms for its workers, is expected to be nominated as next president of United Automobile Workers; will run against Richard Shoemaker, vice president who oversees unions relations with General Motors; both are vying to succeed Stephen P Yokic, who has passed mandatory retirement age of 65 and will leave when term ends in 2002; photo (M)

headline: Group of 7 Set to Explore Ways to Recharge World Economy
abstract: Sec Paul O'Neill says he and Group of Seven counterparts will study ways to stimulate their economies; European and Japanese officials play down expectations from meeting in Washington (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Upgrade Bolsters Chip Maker
abstract: Shares of Atmel Corp, chip maker based in San Diego, rise 87 cents, to $7.49, after analyst for A G Edwards raises his rating to strong buy from buy (S)

headline: French Railway Worker Goes on Shooting Rampage, Killing 4
abstract: Jean-Pierre Roux-Durrafourt, railroad worker, goes on shooting rampage in central France, killing four people and wounding 10, including three police officers; authorities say he may be disgruntled with French national railroad, Societe Nationale des Chemins de Fer, which is his employer (S)

headline: CALIFORNIA ENERGY COMPANY LOWERS EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: Energy company Edison International says that it expects 2001 earnings of $1.27 to $1.30 a share (S)

headline: Technology & Media; New Cancer Drugs May Cut Side Effects
abstract: New cancer drugs, including Erbitux from ImClone Systems and others farther from availability, are more precisely aimed at cancer cells than traditional chemotherapy agents; greater specificity is expected to result in fewer side effects; Bristol-Myers Squibb paid $2 billion for rights to market Erbitux; growing investor confidence is expected to greet 30 to 40 initial public offerings of biotechnology stocks in 2002; photo (M)

headline: Rise in a Pay-Phone Rate
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Residents Flee Slum in Nairobi After 12 Are Killed in Clashes
abstract: Thousands of residenÿ

headline: Production At Factories Declined 1% Last Month
abstract: Federal Reserve reports industrial production fell 1 percent in September, 12th consecutive monthly decline; production dropped 0.7 percent in August; industry operated at 75.5 percent of capacity in September, down from 76.4 percent in August; manufacturing activity, which accounts for 90 percent of industrial production, fell 1.1 percent in September after 0.9 percent decline in August; graphs (M)

headline: Ford to Settle E.E.O.C. Suit
abstract: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, in discrimination lawsuit against Ford Motor Co, says company failed to punish white worker who discussed 'lynching' in front of black workers; Ford agrees to tentative settlement of suit, which seeks compensatory and punitive damages for about 20 black employees at site where prototype vehicles are made (S)

headline: 2 Copyright Cases Decided in Favor of Entertainment Industry
abstract: Federal appeals court rules in favor of Motion Picture Assocation of America in its lawsuit against Eric Corley and his hacking-oriented publication, 2600, over Corley's decision to publish program that could be used to unlock copyright protection for DVD's; Judge Garrett E Brown dismisses lawsuit brought by Prof Edward W Felten of Princeton against Recording Industry Association of America, which he accused of threatening him with lawsuits in order to keep him from presenting research into ways that digital copyright protection system can be broken (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Prisoners' Advocates Are Imprisoned
abstract: Police in Nairobi arrest 70 people who campaign on behalf of political prisoners for holding what authorities call illegal political meeting (S)

headline: AIDS and Death Hold No Sting for Fatalistic Men at African Bar
abstract: Article in series about HIV epidemic in South Africa describes sexual bravado born of poverty and ignorance about health; says men of Hlabisa, South Africa, often refuse to wear condoms, citing Zulu customs, their views about sex and cynicism about quality of foreign condoms; government's slipshod testing practices make South Africa dumping ground for substandard foreign condoms, and many tell stories of having one break; some men wear condoms, but if woman suggests it first, her suitor would accuse her of being promiscuous or infected; women are powerless to insist on condom use; photo (M)

headline: 'We're Losing the Giants Game. Divert All Power to Volume!'
abstract: news watch: gadget:

headline: Vote in Israel In Labor Party Seems to Keep Coalition Safe
abstract: Israeli Defense Min Binyamin Ben-Eliezer appears to have won election to lead stumbling Labor Party, extending life of broad coalition government (M)

headline: U.S. Insurers Are Concerned About Lloyd's
