abstract: United States insurance executives, at conference called by National Association of Insurance Commissioners, cite concern about Lloyd's of London's ability to pay its share of World Trade Center attack claims; react to decision to let Lloyd's cut from 100 percent to 60 percent funds it sets aside to guarantee claims payment; Lloyd's and its regulators say Lloyd's can meet obligations; Lloyd's puts its World Trade Center claims at $8 billion, all but $1.9 billion to be reimbursed by other insurers; analysts note much of reimbursement is to come from companies within Lloyd's, including some that were financially weak before attacks (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Conoco Plays Security Card In Promoting Its Merger
abstract: Market Place column on assertion by Archie W Dunham, chairman of Conoco, that proposed merger of his company with Phillips Petroleum would heighten nation's energy security by lessening dependence on Middle Eastern oil; says claim might be undermined by fact that Conoco has led effort to repeal Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, has been doing business in Libya for 47 years and is pursuing interest in natural gas projects in Saudi Arabia and Indonesia (M)

headline: British Secretly Used Babies' Bones in Tests
abstract: Britain's Atomic Energy Agency makes shocking disclosure that it took thousands of bones from dead babies without parental consent to help ascertain impact of atmospheric nuclear testing during 1950's and 1960's; spokesman says program was done for best of reasons and that testing of children's bones may have produced positive result by contributing to Britain's ban on atmospheric testing in 1963; disclosure follows recent revelation that dead children's organs were removed without parents' consent by Dutch pathologist in Liverpool; will likely add to chorus of calls by advocacy groups for far stricter laws to ensure disclosure by physicians of use of body parts, especially since Britain's medical profession is often depicted by patients as high-handed and unresponsive to inquiries (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Minister Resigns Under Fire
abstract: Ecuador Finance Min Jorge Gallardo resigns to fight criminal charges that he and eight other officials misued funds when he was president of government-run bank last year; Carlos Julio Emanuel takes finance post (S)

headline: Zimbabwe Opposition Party Says 3 Members Have Been Killed
abstract: Zimbabwe's leading opposition party says that three of its members have been killed in recent days by supporters of Pres Robert Mugabe, in what it charges were politically motivated attacks (M)

headline: GRAHAM PACKAGING SAYS IT WILL CLOSE A PLANT IN ONTARIO
abstract: Graham Packaging, maker of plastic containers, says that it would cut 140 jobs and close a manufacturing plant in Burlington, Ontario, because of slowing economy (S)

headline: Eye-Surgery Concern Posts a Wider Loss
abstract: TLC Laser Eye Centers Inc reports loss of $6.6 million in fiscal first quarter ended Aug 31 compared with loss of $5.2 million year earlier; revenue fell 27 percent, to $35 million from $48 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bid To Stop Mining Sale Is Rejected
abstract: Australian Takeovers Panel rejects challenge to proposed takeover bid by Newmont Mining aimed at Australia's Normandy Mining that rival suitor, AngloGold, had filed over aspects of Newmont's three-way merger proposal, which includes Franco-Nevada Mining (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese currency weakens against dollar, which buys 124.03 yen; table of conversion rates for other currencies; graph (S)

headline: Bargains Galore, if You Make the List
abstract: Fashion retailers offer rash of special invitation-only sales, which usually include only friends and relatives of store employees and sometimes its best customers; such sales are far more exclusive than private sales to which department stores have long invited all charge card holders; trend is sign of soft sales and jaded consumer response to regular markdowns; could put further pressure on profits; photos (M)

headline: Under Noisy Skies, Britons Assert a Right to Sleep
abstract: British government faces European Court of Human Rights ruling that could aid residents of Brentford, Eng, which is directly under Heathrow Airport's noisy flight paths, and have implications across Europe; court found Britian violates European Convention on Human Rights by failing to strike fair balance between nation's needs and people's right to good night's sleep; Britain, at least, must rethink process by which it decides how often night flights land at airport and may have to ground such flights; map; photos (M)

headline: TELLABS, PHONE GEAR MAKER, TO BUY OCULAR NETWORKS
abstract: Tellabs Inc, biggest maker of equipment that manages traffic on phone networks, agrees to buy closely held Ocular Networks Inc for $355 million in cash and options (S)

headline: Energy Traders Continue to Prowl The Floor That Enron Helped Build
abstract: Rival firms of Enron Corp and their thousands of young traders have made Houston into energy trading capital that in its own way rivals brokerage houses of Wall Street and futures pits in Chicago; scene at trading floor of Entergy-Koch, oint venture of Koch Industries and Entergy, detailed; photos (M)

headline: Paxson Communications Moves To Bar NBC Bid for Telemundo
abstract: Paxson Communications Corp will ask Federal Communications Commission to block NBC's planned $2.7 billion acquisition of Spanish-language television network Telemundo, which would prevent NBC from completing its acquisition of Paxson under existing FCC regulations, leaving Paxson's future in doubt; also accuses NBC of breach of fiduciary responsibility for trying to manipulate its board of directors by having three -- out of nine -- board members who are NBC executives vote for NBC's interests above interests of Paxson (M)

headline: $5 Million Settlement on Vacation Clubs
abstract: Federal Trade Commission says Med Resorts International and other providers of vacation accommodations will pay some $5 million to settle United States claims that they used deceptive practics to sell vacation travel club memberships; says they also agree to let travel club members cancel $22 million in contractual payment obligations (M)

headline: Shoe-Bomb Suspect Fell in With Extremists
abstract: Head of London mosque says airline shoe-bomb suspect Richard Reid, son of Jamaican father and British mother, is small-time criminal who converted to Islam in prison and was lured on by Muslim extremists; Abdul Haqq Bakr says Reid took name Abdel Rahim in 1995; photos; Brixton mosque, frequented by many ex-convicts, is also linked to Zacarias Moussaoui, suspected 20th hijacker now held in US; Al Qaeda prisoners have identified Reid photographs as possibly having been in Afghan training camp; Bakr says Reid was gullible 'tester' being used by terrorists (M)

headline: Investing; Those Who Did, Shopped Discount
abstract: Shoppers and investors alike have been turning toward discount stores and wholesale clubs since Sept 11; many analysts think customers increasingly want low prices, easy parking and broad assortment of goods that discounters such as Wal-Mart Stores and Target provide; photo; charts (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GUINNESS NORTH AMERICA INC., a unit of Diageo P.L.C., London, the world's largest maker of liquor, purchased a former Pabst Brewing Co., brewery in the Lehigh Valley in Pennsylvania, where it will produce its Smirnoff Ice malt beverage. Terms were not disclosed.    IGEN INTERNATIONAL INC., Gaithersburg, Md., a maker of medical test equipment, said that F. Hoffman-La Roche, a unit of Roche Holding A.G., Basel, Switzerland, a maker of pharmaceuticals, vitamins and fine chemicals, had agreed to pay $5.7 million in legal fees and dismiss its patent-infringement suit against Igen.

headline: Radio Free Europe Hopes To Expand in Afghanistan
abstract: Radio Free Europe will resume broadcasting in Afghanistan for first time in nearly decade, if Congress approves; Radio Free Europe already has 20 staff reporters in and around Afghanistan, reporting for its many services; in January, it hopes to open full-time bureau in Kabul (M)

headline: U.S. and Britain at Odds Over Use and Timing of Peacekeeping Troops
abstract: US and Britain are at odds over use of peacekeeping forces in Afghanistan; Pentagon has made it clear that British Prime Min Tony Blair's proposal for peacekeeping force will be put on hold as US pursues its military campaign; question is not whether US should contribute troops for peacekeeping in Afghanistan; Pentagon has signaled for weeks that this will not happen and that large numbers of American troops are not needed; British have been planning for peacekeeping in and around Kabul; question is whether any international peacekeepers are needed at all and, if they are, whether European nations and other allies should deploy peacekeeping troops before American military wraps up its campaign; issue has been matter of some debate in Bush administration, with some State Department officials somewhat receptive to European position and Pentagon deeply skeptical (M)

headline: QANTAS AIRWAYS TO CUT UP TO 2,000 JOBS BY END OF YEAR
abstract: Blaming the slump in the international aviation market, Qantas Airways said yesterday that it would cut up to 2,000 jobs by the end of the year. Qantas, Australia's largest airline, also plans to stop all flights to New York as of Nov. 25 and to reduce flights to some other cities abroad. The airline has taken control of almost 90 percent of the domestic market after its rival, Ansett Australia, collapsed in September. But last year, Qantas earned almost 80 percent of its profit from international operations. ''The events of Sept. 11 have affected services far beyond the United States,'' said the chief executive, Geoff Dixon. Since Sept. 11, business from Japan and Britain has dropped by one-quarter and overall traffic levels have declined 10 to 20 percent, he said.   Becky Gaylord (NYT)

headline: Terror Cells Slip Through Europe's Grasp
abstract: Second article in series Missed Signals, on Islamic terrorism; focuses on Muslim militancy in Europe in 1990's, its shifting focus and varied structure and failure of most European governments to understand its gravity, danger and depth before Sept 11 attacks; notes terrorist cells formed, carried out specialized tasks, dissolved and then re-formed elsewhere, careful to maintain isolation and disguise their identities; Jamal Beghal, Algerian-born Frenchman, arrested in Dubai in July enroute to France to orchestrate suicide bombing of American Embassy in Paris, typifies immigrant Muslims who fell under Al Qaeda's sway in 1990's; diagrams of links among Al Qaeda cells in Europe, including their links to Osama bin Laden; photo (M)

headline: No Claim Is Too Small In a Huge Bankruptcy
abstract: Collapse of Enron Corp left many companies with small unpaid bills, such as Evans Telephone Co, Luther's BBQ, Dynamic Graphics magazine, Mississippi Tax Commission, Houston Chronicle and W W Grainger (S)

headline: Report Calls Ulster Police Force Inept in Fatal-Bombing Inquiry
abstract: Scathing report is issued by British police force's independent ombudsman, Nuala O'Loan, that says police investigating 1998 terrorist bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, hampered inquiry by ineptitude, poor judgment, lack of communication and constant delays; report is particularly critical of Sir Ronnie Flanagan, who has been head of force in Northern Ireland since 1996; calls his judgment and leadership 'seriously flawed' and says result is that chances of detaining and convicting Omagh bombers is significantly reduced; Sir Ronnie says he may take legal action to quash report, deriding O'Loan's research methods and conclusions; Real IRA, dissident republican group opposed to peace agreement, claimed responsibility for attack, which killed 29 people and injured more than 200 (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   5.00   5.00   9.50        Discount rate   1.50   1.50   6.00        Federal funds   1.94   2.03   6.48        3-month T-bills   1.79   1.79   6.16        6-month T-bills   1.77   1.75   6.05        10-yr. T-infl.   2.97   2.92   3.88        10-yr. T-note   4.31   4.28   5.78        30-yr. T-bond   4.88   4.86   5.87        Telephone bd.   7.05   7.10   8.03        Municipal bds.   5.17   5.18   5.80          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: MP3.Com Settles Copyright Suit
abstract: Technology BriefinÔ

headline: 2 New York Agencies Merge as Blum Ellenson
abstract: Two agencies in New York, Blum Network and Ellenson Group, merge to form Blum Ellenson (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Soybeans gain on concern that heavy rain in next few days will delay harvest in Midwest; in Chicago, soybeans for November delivery rise 1.75 cents, or 0.4 percent, to $4.54 per bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: NESTLÉ TO BUY IONICS' BOTTLED WATER BUSINESS
abstract: Nestle will buy Aqua Cool Pure Bottled Water operation of Ionics Inc for $220 million (S)

headline: Argentina May Restructure Its Debt, Risking Default
abstract: Argentine bond and stock prices fall sharply after country's Economy Min Domingo Cavallo indicates that he wants to voluntarily restructure Argentina's billions of dollars in public-sector debt, including that owned by foreigners; such a move acknowledges how much more serious country's financial crisis is; economic slowdown around the world is just deepening recession in Argentina that already is more than three years old; there are fewer and fewer spending cuts country can make so that it can meet its interest and principal payments; some analysts argue that effort to restructure the debt could lead to a default; photo (M)

headline: Italy's Leader Raises Storm by Opposing European Warrant Plan
abstract: For the first time there is real consternation in Italy over a government policy that even some supporters of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi see as an effort to help him out of his continuing legal problems.    Italy is blocking the creation of a European arrest warrant that the other 14 European Union countries see as an important new tool for fighting terrorism -- a way of allowing prosecutors to make arrests in other countries without waiting for lengthy extradition proceedings.

headline: Consumer Group Has Plan For Managing Insurers' Loss
abstract: Consumer Federation of America, with skepticism in Congress deepening over proposals that government pay major share of insurance costs from future terrorist attacks, makes proposal that would help insurers manage their losses with long-term federal loans; many in Congress are beginning to wonder why insurers cannot cover costs of future attacks; they have estimated $300 billion in capital; Repr Richard Baker, chairman of House Subcommittee on Capital Markets, Insurance and Government, say many in Congress are convinced 'we should act' (M)

headline: Recruiting a New Afghan Ruler, Bush's 'No' and Tracking Anthrax
abstract: Overview of events in war on terrorism as second week of bombing Afghanistan gets under way (M)

headline: Americans Urge Japanese To Move Fast on Bad Loans
abstract: Treasury Under Sec Kenneth W Dam and R Glenn Hubbard, chairman of US Council of Economic Advisers, say Japan's main economic problem is growing moountain of bad loans in banking sector and Japan's new bad-loan agency should conduct 'rapid purchases and equally rapid sales' of bad loans to address problem, conference of 100 Japanese and American financial executives and academics in Gotemba, Japan; Dam says bad-loan problem could be four to six times as large as insolvency crisis that swept through American savings and loan industry in late 1980's; conference participants warn that new agency could prove to be slow, underfinanced and subject to political pressure (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Synagogue In Dresden
abstract: First new synagogue to be built in what was East Germany since Nazi era will be dedicated in Dresden on anniversary of Kristallnacht rampage in 1938; $9.5-million building was provided by city (S)

headline: 4 Factions Approve New Setup
abstract: Four Afghan factions meeting in Bonn, Germany, agree on protocol establishing responsibilities, shape and timetable of interim post-Taliban administration for Afghanistan and path toward more permanent government; have not yet begun to negotiate who will serve in administration or who will lead it (M)

headline: Gunmen Kill 16 Christians in Church in Pakistan
abstract: Gunmen open fire on group of Pakistani Protestants using Roman Catholic church for worship in Bahawalpur, Pakistan, killing 16; Christians say killers were acting to avenge American bombing of Afghanistan; cite fact that America, predominantly Christin country, is at war with Afghanistan, which is predominantly Muslim; blame Islamic militants; attack and scene of carnage described; photos (M)

headline: Relief Groups Seek a Peacekeeping Force for Afghanistan
abstract: Human rights groups call for international military force to go into Afghanistan to prevent chaos and bloodshed and ease way to post-Taliban government more fair to women; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Confidence Slides
abstract: Ifo Institute says German business confidence dropped close to eight-year low in September; overall index dropped 4.5 points, to 85 (S)

headline: United Is Expected To Ask Its Employees For Cuts in Wages
abstract: united is expected to ask its employees for cuts

headline: New Economy; During emergencies, officials need access to wireless communications systems. But regular people do, too.
abstract: ONCE again, the federal government has asked the telecommunications industry to find a way to provide public safety officials with priority access on wireless communications systems in times of crisis. And once again, those involved in the effort are discovering the difficulty of carrying out such a mission.     Since Sept. 11, no one has disputed the value of devising priority access methods for wireless systems. For several hours after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, cellular phone networks were flooded with calls, making it difficult for almost everyone, including emergency service officials, to use the systems. Networks were so strained in the hours after the attacks that sending and receiving rudimentary text messages on pagers was far easier than completing a call on a mobile phone.

headline: Nasdaq 100 May Lose Some Technology Flavor
abstract: Study by Lehman Brothers shows that when Nasdaq 100 is rebalanced in December, it is likely to become more diversified, less volatile and less accurate as technology barometer (S)

headline: ARAMARK BUYING SERVICES BUSINESS FROM SERVICEMASTER
abstract: Aramark Corp acquires ServiceMaster Co's facility-service business for $800 million (S)

headline: PHILIP MORRIS PROFIT RISES ON SALES OF PREMIUM BRANDS
abstract: Philip Morris Companies says net income in third quarter rose to $2.33 billion from $2.32 billion year earlier; sales climbed 12 percent, to $22.4 billion from $20.1 billion (S)

headline: Afghan Leader Says Mullah Omar Will Be Arrested if Found
abstract: Taliban forces abandoned Kandahar today, departing from an agreement they had made with Afghanistan's interim leader.

headline: Kremlin and Rebel Envoys Discuss Peace for Chechnya
abstract: Top envoys from Kremlin and Chechnya meet publicly in Moscow to discuss peace for first time since war erupted 27 months ago between Russia and Chechnya; both envoys say talks are productive (M)

headline: Lobbying Down to the Wire As Industry and Politicians Battle Over Aid to Carriers
abstract: Bush administration expects to release new rules giving four-man panel headed by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan broad powers to dole out $10 billion in federally backed loans to airline industry; other members are Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill, Transportation Sec Norman Mineta, and comptroller general David M Walker; draft of rules says that loans receive partial government backing and have repayment schedule of three to seven years, but executives press for complete government guarantees and ten-year option to repay (M)

headline: Cantor's eSpeed Will Take Over Trading
abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald's chief executive Howard W Lutnick, whose bond-trading firm was devastated in terrorist attacks, says his two-and-a-half-year-old eSpeed Inc electronic trading unit will account for most of his partnership's business (S

headline: 3 Marines Wounded by Land Mine at Kandahar Airport
abstract: Three marines are wounded by land mine, one seriously, while working to clear Kandahar, Afghanistan, airport of unexploded ordnance; are first marines seriously hurt since hundreds began arriving in area Nov 25; photos (M)

headline: NTT DoCoMo Introduces New Generation Cellphone Service
abstract: NTT DoCoMo will introduce world's first third-generation cellular phone network; new service, at first available only in Tokyo area, promises Internet connections up to 40 times faster than current phones so users can download audio and video files onto handsets; carriers in Europe and United States are delaying or scaling back plans to offer own versions of service (M)

headline: U.S. Bombs Taliban Troops as They Make a Speedy Retreat to the South
abstract: US military moves to capitalize on disarray of Taliban forces in Afghanistan, bombing them as they retreat and moving to expand American forces in region and open new airfields closer to rapidly shifting front; Pentagon officials say campaign, currently in 38th day, may shift into mountains outside Kabul or into Kandahar, Taliban stronghold in south where groups of American Special Operations Forces are on move; Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld and Gen Richard B Myers, chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, comment; photos (M)

headline: I'm on the Hunt for Lost Data
abstract: After the terrorist attacks, I helped set up mobile work areas at one of our North Jersey recovery centers. The stockbrokers from Fleet Securities started moving in even before we were finished.

headline: US Airways' Top Executive Is Leaving at a Critical Time
abstract: Rakesh Gangwal resigns as US Airways chief executive, citing desire to pursue private equity financing and venture capital investing; Stephen M Wolf, his longtime mentor and company's chairman, will become chief executive; is not trusted or appreciated by company's unions, and his succession stirs their concerns; photos (M)

headline: Several Agencies Are Cutting Jobs
abstract: Several Agencies Are Cutting Jobs.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: 'Bloody Sunday' Challenge
abstract: Former British solders who served in Londonderry in 1972 begin legal challenge against tribunal investigating incident in which soldiers shot and killed 14 unarmed civilians during Roman Catholic civil rights march (S)

headline: Agreements on 2 Mergers In Biotechnology Industry
abstract: Two merger agreements in biotechnology industry represent efforts to augment product pipelines and bolster profits; MedImmune Inc will acquire Aviron Inc for about $1.5 billion in stock, gambling that it can win approval of Aviron's ground-breaking flu vaccine, which is sprayed into the nose rather than injected; Cephalon Inc will take over Group Lafon for $450 million in cash, eliminating royalties it must currently pay on sales of its flagship pharmaceutical product, Provigil, drug for excessive sleepiness; will also gain other products that it estimates will increase its sales by $80 million next year (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro settles at 88.25 cents, up from 88.03 cents; dollar trades at 124 yen, down from 124.09 yen; graphs; list of exchange rates (S)

headline: Afghans' Unhappy Ending: Castaways in Indonesia
abstract: Tiny dim hostel in Jakarta is end of road for two dozen refugees who fled Afghanistan months ago after paying smugglers fortune to herd them along long clandestine route toward Australia, destination of choice for illegal migrants from places like Iraq, Iran and Pakistan; photo; map; they are now blocked from going either forward or backward; Australia is paying island nation of Nauru and Papua New Guinea millions of dollars to house thousands more, as other islands negotiate to take more (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Dissident Web Site Blocked
abstract: Cuban dissidents and human rights advocates who recently mounted country's first opposition-run Web site say government has blocked its citizens from seeing the site (S)

headline: THE BOSS; Vacations as Early Education
abstract: Charles Herington, president of AOL Latin America, writes The Boss column on his upbringing in Mexico; photo (M)

headline: Protecting the Macintosh, A Lesser-Known Victim
abstract: Q. Is it worth it to buy a firewall program for my Mac? I ran the firewall and Trojan-horse diagnostic from the Norton Web site, and it said that all my ports were safe and that buying a firewall program wouldn't add much protection.    A. While most attacks from hackers, worms, viruses and Trojan horses are aimed at Windows-based computers, Macintosh machines are not impervious to Internet-related security problems.

headline: Microsoft Launches Windows XP
abstract: Following is a compilation of articles from The Times about Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system.

headline: Third-Quarter Profit Drops 17% at Kellogg
abstract: Kellogg Co reports third-quarter profit fell to $150.3 million from $181.9 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Credit Suisse Is Taking Hits On Wall Street And at Home
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston, saddled with highest cost structure on Wall Street, says it will eliminate 2,000 jobs, or about 7 percent, of its workers worldwide; lost $120 million on operating basis in third quarter and says it expects reductions to help lower its costs $1 billion by end of 2002; Goldman Sachs Group reportedly plans to eliminate about 300 jobs in next few weeks; industry report published on Sept 11 by analysts at Sanford C Bernstein projected that nearly 34,000 workers, or 9 percent of securities industry, will lose their jobs next year, and picture has darkened since then; Securities Industry Association estimates net loss of about $200 million in third quarter; had expected domestic operting profits of all Wall Street firms to be $1 billion to $1.4 billion in quarter (M)

headline: Earnings Down 80% at Big Coke Bottler
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc says third-quarter profit fell 80 percent; net income fell to $26 million from $131 million year earlier; sales rose nearly 11 percent, to $4.3 billion from $3.9 billion (M)

headline: Joel Carlson, 75, Lawyer Who Fought Apartheid in 50's
abstract: Joel Carlson, white South African lawyer who used spectacular political trials to battle apartheid and expose its practices of secret detention and torture (S)

headline: GROUP IN PAKISTAN IS BLAMED BY INDIA FOR SUICIDE RAID
abstract: India blames militant Islamic group Lashkar-e-Taiba, which operates openly in Pakistan and Kashmir, for suicide attack on Indian Parliament that killed seven people; demands that Pakistan halt group's activities, arrest its leaders and cut off its financial assets; India faces possibility of having to decide whether to risk war with Pakistan for sake of going into Pakistani-controlled area of Kashmir to strike at Lashkar-e-Taiba; for its part, Pakistan must decide whether to crack down on group, which might further inflame Islamic fundamentalists; Bush administration officials appear to be studiously avoiding any public insistence on restraint by India; map; photo (M)

headline: Media Moguls Over Munich
abstract: News Corp's Rupert Murdoch and Liberty Media's John C Malone attempt to gain partial or complete control over Munich-based Kirch Group, which owns significant portion of all commercial German television programming and is in difficult financial position; photos (M)

headline: PAKISTANI LEADER SEEKS  'GESTURES' FOR  BACKING  U.S.
abstract: Pres Pervez Musharraf says he is visiting United States in search of major gestures from Bush administration to blunt criticism in Pakistan of his strong support for war on terrorism, interview; seeks release of 28 F-16 jets, whose delivery was blocked because of Pakistan's development of nuclear arms; says he is unsure how long bombing campaign can continue in Afghanistan without becoming threat to his government; sees intensity of demonstrations against stance waning; photo (M)

headline: Salvage Teams Begin to Raise Russian Sub
abstract: Salvage teams begin efforts to raise Russian nuclear submarine Kursk from floor of Barents Sea, nearly 14 months after vessel plummeted to seabed following unexplained explosions that took lives of all 118 crew members (S)

headline: Firm of Reagan Adviser Raises $1.4 Billion Fund
abstract: Heartland Industrial Partners, firm founded by David Stockman to make acquisitions in auto parts and other manufacturing industries, gets $150 million investment from Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board, bringing fund total to $1.4 billion (S)

headline: Quarterly Profit at Dean Dropped 9.4%
abstract: Quarterly profit at Dean Foods Co falls 9.4 percent, to $27 million; Suiza Foods Corp is acquiring Dean (S)

headline: Digital Printers Cut The PC From the Equation
abstract: Hewlett-Packard introduces printers that creates high-quality photos directly from digital camera's memory card without computer; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Cement Company Chief Resigns
abstract: Thomas Schmidheiny is stepping down after two decades as chief exec of cement maker Holcim Ltd (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Offers a Bargain Basement
abstract: Yahoo will open Yahoo Warehouse for used and discounted merchandise; service, which will begin in late October, is modeled after eBay's Half.com, which lets individuals and businesses sell goods at fixed prices rather than through auctions (S)

headline: Text of Federal Reserve's Statement
abstract: Text of statement released by Federal Reserve after Federal Open Market Committee moved to lower interest rates for 11th time in 2001 (M)

headline: Luxury's Old Guard, Battered by New Realities
abstract: New designer stores are taking sales from traditional luxury department store chains like Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue, which are being forced to offer uncharacteristic discounts to make up for lost business; designers like Hugo Boss, Armani, Louis Vuitton and Gucci, whose goods used to be sold only at luxury department stores, have all established their own retail outlets in recent years, some in very backyards of department stores; adding to department stores' woes are Sept 11 terrorist attack, which have hurt luxury retailers more than they have others, and competition from downmarket retailers as lifestyle and aspirations of more affluent Americans become more casual; photos; chart (M)

headline: Joblessness In Japan Rises To a Record
abstract: Japan's unemployment rate sets another postwar record in October, rising to 5.4 percent, as homebuilding contracts and prices continue two-year downward drift; photo (S)

headline: Anthrax Anxiety at Home, Signs of Progress Abroad
abstract: Overview of events in war on terrorism that is now being fought on two distinct fronts: at home, with threat of anthrax-laced mail, and in Afghanistan, with 10 days of bombing and missile attacks (M)

headline: U.S. Accuses The Japanese Of Inflexibility On Trade Talks
abstract: US trade representative, Robert B Zoellick, says Japan's pursuit of its own 'narrow-minded interests' threatens to obstruct efforts to forge agreement at long-planned world trade summit in Doha, Qatar; says that while US and European Union have worked together to draft agenda for global trade, Japan has remained on sidelines, hobbled by its own domestic paralysis; comments are part of American strategy to soften Japanese stance as trade ministers scramble to make progress on divisive issues before World Trade Organization talks formally commence; Zoellick is also expressing concern that negotiations could collapse, as in Seattle in 1999, where fights between rich and poor nations and violent street demonstrations sunk hopes of reducing trade barriers (M)

headline: Drug Maker Seems Uncertain In Response to Cipro Frenzy
abstract: Bayer AG's seeming detachment about need for its antibiotic, Cipro, in anthrax scare has proved costly to company; Canadian health ministry overrides company's patents and orders nearly one million tablets from manufacturer of generic drugs; in United States, Tommy G Thompson, secretary of health and human services, says he is negotiating with Bayer and other drug companies to buy Cipro and other antibiotics that could be used to treat anthrax; Bayer AG, hoping to reassure public, takes out newspaper advertisements pledging its commitment to American public to meet anthrax threat head on; public relations consultants say Bayer, German company, has bungled opportunity to establish itself as friend of US; Bayer has staunchly opposed Sen Charles Schumer's suggestion that it relax patent claims, and also refuses to spell out any plans for hiring backup manufacturer if it needs one (M)

headline: Security Tight for Start of United Nations Meeting in New York
abstract: Highest security alert is in place as world leaders convene at UN, in city still stunned by Sept 11 terrorist attack (S)

headline: Winfrey Rescinds Offer to Author for Guest Appearance
abstract: Jonathan Franzen earned the distinction as the first author to be formally uninvited to appear on the Oprah Winfrey show.

headline: Voters in Sri Lanka Reject The Nation's Ruling Coalition
abstract: Opting for opposition parties, which have promised to pursue peace talks with rebels, Sri Lanka's voters have rejected the governing coalition in election results announced today.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: A Hewlett Director Is Criticized
abstract: Top execs of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer, in letter to shareholders, criticize Hewlett board member, Walter Hewlett, whose opposition to planned merger has cast deal in doubt; they challenge him to offer better plan (S)

headline: Confidence Index Drops, but Housing Sales Rise
abstract: Conference Board reports unexpected slump in its index of consumer confidence in November, to 82.2 from 85.3 in October; this is lowest level seen in seven and a half years; but falling mortgage rates aided October home sales, which surged to surprising annual pace of 5.17 million units, up from 4.9 million rate in September; graph (M)

headline: CONTINENTAL PLANS SHARE SALE TO RAISE MONEY
abstract: Continental Airlines plans to raise about $151.7 million by selling common shares; company needs cash to contend with losses stemming from reduced air traffic following Sept 11 attacks on US (S)
